tgt_text.341: However, besides possessing gracefulness of person, and merit deserving of such an empire, Darius was related to the preceding kings ;
tgt_text.342: and, in the beginning of his reign, he took to wife the daughter of Cyrus, in order to strengthen his kingdom by a royal marriage, so that it might not so much seem transferred to a stranger, as to be restored to Cyrus's family.
tgt_text.343: Some time after, when the Assyrians had revolted and seized upon Babylon, and the capture of the city proved difficult, so that the king was in great anxiety about it, Zopyrus, one of the assassins of the Magi, caused himself to be mangled with stripes, in his own house, over his whole body, and his nose, ears, and lips to be cut off, and in this condition presented himself unexpectedly before the king;
tgt_text.344: when he privately informed Darius, who was astonished, and inquired the cause and author of so dire an outrage, with what object he had done it, and, having settled his plan of action for the future, set out for Babylon in the character of a deserter.
tgt_text.345: There he showed the people his lacerated body;
tgt_text.346: complained of the barbarity of the king, by whom, in the competition for the throne, he had been defeated, not by merit but by fortune, not by the judgment of men but by the neighing of a horse;
tgt_text.347: and bade them form an opinion, from his treatment of his friends, what was to be apprehended by his enemies;
tgt_text.348: exhorting them not to trust to their walls more than to their arms, and to allow him, whose resentment was fresher, to carry on the war in common with them.
tgt_text.349: The nobleness and bravery of the man was known to them all:
tgt_text.350: nor did they doubt of his sincerity, of which they had the wounds on his person, and the marks of his ill-usage, as proofs.
tgt_text.351: He was therefore chosen general by the suffrages of all;
tgt_text.352: and, having received a small body of men, and the Persians, once or twice, purposely retreating from the field, he fought some successful battles.
tgt_text.353: At last he betrayed the whole army, with which he had been entrusted, to Darius, and brought the city under his power.
tgt_text.354: Some time after, Darius made war upon the Scythians, as shall be related in the following book.
tgt_text.355: Account of the Scythians and their actions, L, II., In.
tgt_text.357: —The war of the Scythians with their slaves;
tgt_text.358: the expeditions of Darius against the Scythians and Ionians, V.— The Athenians, and Solon, VI., VII.
tgt_text.360: —Hippias, being exiled, brings the Persians against Greece;
tgt_text.364: Xerxes invades Greece, X.—Leonidas at Thermopylae, XI.
tgt_text.373: IN narrating the acts of the Scythians, which were very great and glorious, we must commence from their origin ;
tgt_text.374: for they had a rise not less illustrious than their empire ;
tgt_text.375: nor were they more famous for the government of their men than for the brave actions of their women.
tgt_text.376: As the men were founders of the Parthians and Bactrians, the women settled the kingdom of the Amazons;
tgt_text.377: so that to those who compare the deeds of their males and females, it is difficult to decide which of the sexes was more distinguished.
tgt_text.378: The nation of the Scythians was always regarded as very ancient;
tgt_text.379: though there was long a dispute between them and the Egyptians concerning the antiquity of their respective races;
tgt_text.380: the Egyptians alleging that, “ In the beginning oi things, when some countries were parched with the excessive heat of the sun, and others frozen with extremity of cold, so that, in their early condition, they were not only unable to produce human beings, but were incapable even of receiving and supporting such as came from other parts (before coverings for the body were found out against heat and cold, or the moon­ veniences of countries corrected by artificial remedies), Egypt was always so temperate, that neither the cold in winter nor the sun's heat in summer, incommoded its inhabitants;
tgt_text.381: and its soil so fertile, that no land was ever more productive of food for the use of man;
tgt_text.382: and that, consequently, men must reasonably be considered to have been first produced in that country,* where they could most easily be nourished.
tgt_text.383: "The Scythians, on the other hand, thought that the tem perateness of the air was no argument of antiquity;
tgt_text.384: " because Nature, when she first distributed to different countries degrees of heat and cold, immediately produced in them animals fitted to endure the several climates, and generated also numerous sorts of trees and herbs, happily varied according to the con­ dition of the places in which they grew;
tgt_text.385: and that, as the Scythians have a sharper air than the Egyptians, so are their bodies and constitutions in proportion more hardy.
tgt_text.386: But that if the world, which is now distinguished into parts of a different nature, was once uniform throughout;
tgt_text.387: whether a deluge of waters originally kept the earth buried under it;
tgt_text.388: or whether fire, which also produced the world,† had possession of all the parts of it, the Scythians, under either supposition as to tne primordial state of things, had the advantage as to origin.
tgt_text.389: For if fire was at first predominant over all things, and, being gradually extinguished, gave place to the earth, no part of it would be sooner separated from the fire, by the severity of winter cold, than the northern, since even now no part is more frozen with cold;
tgt_text.390: but Egypt and all the east must have been the latest to cool, as being now burnt up with the parching heat of the sun.
tgt_text.391: But if originally all the earth were sunk under water, assuredly the highest parts would be first uncovered when the waters decreased, and the water must have remained longest in the lowest grounds;
tgt_text.392: while the sooner any portion of the earth was dry, the sooner it must have begun to produce animals;
tgt_text.393: but Scythia was so much higher than all other countries, that all the rivers which rise in it run down into the Mæotis, and then into the Pontic and Egyptian seas;
tgt_text.394: whereas Egypt, (which, though it had been fenced by the care and expense of so many princes and gene­ rations, and furnished with such strong mounds against the violence of the encroaching waters, and though it had been intersected also by so many canals, the waters being kept out by the one, and retained by the other, was yet unin­ habitable unless the Nile were excluded,*) could not be thought to have been the most anciently peopled;
tgt_text.395: † being a land, which, whether from the accessions of soil col­ lected by its kings, or those from the Nile, bringing mud with it, must appear to have been the most recently formed of all lands."
tgt_text.396: The Egyptians being confounded with these argu­ meats, the Scythians were always accounted the more ancient.
tgt_text.398: Scythia, which stretches towards the east, is bounded on one side by the Pontus Euxinus;
tgt_text.399: on the other, by the Rhipæan Mountains;
tgt_text.400: at the back,‡ by Asiai and the river Phasis.
tgt_text.401: It extends to a vast distance, both in length and breadth.
tgt_text.402: The people have no landmarks, for they neither cultivate the soil, nor have they any house, dwelling, or settled place of abode, but are always engaged in feeding herds and flocks, and wandering through uncultivated deserts.
tgt_text.403: They carry their wives and children with them in waggons,|| which, as they are covered with hides against the rain and cold, they use instead of houses.
tgt_text.404: Justice is observed among them, more from the temper of the people, than from the influence of laws.
tgt_text.405: No crime in their opinion is more heinous than theft;
tgt_text.406: for, among people that keep their flocks and herds without fence or shelter in the woods, what would be safe, if stealing were permitted ?
tgt_text.407: Gold and silver they despise, as much as other men covet them.
tgt_text.408: They live on milk and honey.
tgt_text.409: The use of wool and clothes is unknown among them, although they are pinched by perpetual cold;
tgt_text.410: they wear, however, the skins of wild animals, great and small.¶
tgt_text.411: Such abstemiousness has caused justice to be observed among them, as they covet nothing belonging to their neighbours;
tgt_text.412: for it is only where riches are of use, that the desire of them prevails.
tgt_text.413: And would that other men had like temperance, and like freedom from desire for the goods of others!
tgt_text.414: There would then assuredly be fewer wars in all ages and countries, and the sword would not destroy more than the natural course of destiny.
tgt_text.415: And it appears extremely wonderful, that nature should grant that to them which the Greeks cannot attain by long instruc­ tion from their wise men and the precepts of their philo­ sophers ;
tgt_text.416: and that cultivated morals should have the disadvan­ tage in a comparison with those of unpolished barbarians.
tgt_text.417: So much better effect has the ignorance of vice in the one people than the knowledge of virtue in the other.
tgt_text.419: They thrice * aspired to the supreme command in Asia;
tgt_text.420: while they themselves remained always either unmolested or unconquered by any foreign power.
tgt_text.421: Darius, king of the Per­ sians, they forced to quit Scythia in disgraceful flight.
tgt_text.422: They slew Cyrus with his whole army.
tgt_text.423: They cut off in like manner Zopyrion, a general of Alexander the Great, with all his forces.
tgt_text.424: Of the arms of the Romans they have heard, but never felt them.
tgt_text.425: They founded the Parthian and Bactrian powers.
tgt_text.426: They are a nation hardy in toils and warfare :
tgt_text.427: their strength of body is extraordinary;
tgt_text.428: they take possession of nothing which they fear to lose, and covet, when they are conquerors, nothing but glory.
tgt_text.429: The first that proclaimed war against the Scythians was Sesostris, king of Egypt, previously sending messengers t to announce conditions on which they might become his subjects.
tgt_text.430: But the Scythians, who were already apprized by their neigh­ bours of the king's approach, made answer to the deputies, that the prince of so rich a people had been foolish in com­ mencing a war with a poor one (for war was more to be dreaded by himself at home), as the result of the contest was uncertain, prizes of victory there were none, and the ill con­ sequences of defeat were apparent;
tgt_text.431: and that the Scythians, therefore, would not wait till he came to them, since there was so much more to be desired in the hands of the enemy, but would proceed of their own accord to seek the spoil."
tgt_text.432: Nor were their deeds slower than their words;
tgt_text.433: and the king, hearing that they were advancing with such speed, took to flight,.
tgt_text.434: and leaving behind him his army and all his military stores, returned in consternation to his own kingdom.
tgt_text.435: The morasses prevented the Scythians from invading Egypt;
tgt_text.436: in their retreat from which they subdued Asia, and made it tributary, imposing, however, only a moderate tribute, rather as a token of their power over it, than as a recompence for their victory.
tgt_text.437: After spending fifteen years in the reduction of Asia, they were called home by the importunity of their wives, who sent them word that " unless their husbands returned, they would seek issue from their neighbours, and not suffer the race of the Scythians to fail of posterity through the fault of their women."
tgt_text.438: Asia was tributary to them for fifteen hundred years;
tgt_text.439: and it was Ninus, king of Assyria, that put a stop to the payment of the tribute.
tgt_text.441: Among the Scythians, in the meantime, two youths † of royal extraction, Ylinos and Scolopitus, being driven from their country by a faction of the nobility, took with them a numerous band of young men, and found a settlement on the coast of Cappadocia, near the river Thermodon, occupying the Themiscyrian plains that border on it.
tgt_text.442: Here, making it their practice for several years to rob their neighbours, they were at last, by a combination of the surrounding people, cut to pieces in an ambuscade.
tgt_text.443: Their wives, when they found that to exile was added the loss of their husbands, took arms themselves, and maintained their position, repelling the attacks of their enemies at first, and afterwards assailing them in return.
tgt_text.444: They relinquished all thoughts of marrying with their neigh­ bours, saying that it would be slavery, not matrimony.
tgt_text.445: Ven­ turing to set an example unimitated through all generations.
tgt_text.446: they established their government without the aid of men, and soon maintained their power in defiance of them.
tgt_text.447: And that none of their females might seem more fortunate than others, they put to death all the men who had remained at home.
tgt_text.448: They also took revenge for their husbands that were killed in wart by a great slaughter of their neighbours.
tgt_text.449: Having thus secured peace by means of their arms, they proceeded, in order that their race might not fail, to form con­ nexions with the men of the adjacent nations.
tgt_text.450: If any male children were born, they put them to death.
tgt_text.451: The girls they bred up to the same mode of life with themselves, not con­ signing them to idleness, or working in wool, but training them to arms, the management of horses, and hunting;
tgt_text.452: burning their right breasts in infancy, that their use of the bow might not be obstructed by them;
tgt_text.453: and hence they were called Amazons.*
tgt_text.454: They had two queens, Marpesia and Lani­ pedo, who, dividing their forces into two bodies (after they were grown famous for their power), conducted their wars, and defended their borders separately and by turns.
tgt_text.455: And that a reason for their success might not be wanting, they spread a report that they were the daughters of Mars.
tgt_text.456: After subduing the greater part of Europe, they possessed themselves also of some cities in Asia.t
tgt_text.457: Having then founded Ephesus and several other towns there, they sent a detach­ ment of their army home, laden with a vast quantity of spoil.
tgt_text.458: The rest, who remained to secure their power in Asia, were cut to pieces, together with their queen Marpesia, by a com­ bination of the barbarous tribes.
tgt_text.459: Orithya, the daughter of Marpesia, succeeded to the government in her room, and has attracted extraordinary admiration, not only for her eminent skill in war, but for having preserved her virginity to the end of her life.
tgt_text.460: So much was added by her valour and conduct to the fame and glory of the Amazons, that the king, for whom Hercules was bound to perform twelve labours, ordered him, as if it were a thing impossible, to bring him the arms of the queen of the Amazons.
tgt_text.461: Hercules, accordingly, having pro­ ceeded thither with nine ships of war, the principal young men of Greece accompanying him, attacked the Amazons unawares.
tgt_text.462: Two sisters at this time held the government, Antiope and Orithya;
tgt_text.463: but Orithya was engaged in a wax abroad.
tgt_text.464: When Hercules, therefore, landed on the coast of the Amazons, there was but a small number of them there with their queen Antiope, free from all apprehension of hos­ tilities.
tgt_text.465: Hence it happened that a few only, roused by the sudden alarm, took up arms, and these afforded an easy con­ quest to the enemy.
tgt_text.466: Many were slain, and many taken prisoners;
tgt_text.467: among the latter were two sisters of Antiope.
tgt_text.468: Menalippe being taken by Hercules, and Hippolyte by The­ seus.
tgt_text.469: Theseus, having received his prisoner as his share of the spoil, took her to wife, and had by her his son Hippolytus.
tgt_text.470: Hercules, after his victory, restored his captive Menalippe to her sister, receiving the arms of the queen as a recompence ;
tgt_text.471: and having thus executed what was imposed on him, he returned to the king.
tgt_text.472: But Orithya, when she found that war had been made upon her sister, and that the assailant was a chief of the Athenians, exhorted her followers to revenge the affront, saying that the “ coast of the Pontus, and Asia, had been conquered in vain, if they were still exposed, not merely to the wars, but to the marauding invasions, of the Greeks."
tgt_text.473: She then solicited aid from Sagillus, king of Scythia;
tgt_text.474: representing to him “ their Scythian descent, the loss of their husbands, their obligation to take arms, and their reasons for making war;
tgt_text.475: " adding, “ that they had proved by their valour, that the Scythians must be thought to have women not less spirited than their men."
tgt_text.476: Sagillus, alive to the glory of his nation, sent his son Panasa* goras, with a numerous body of cavalry, to their aid.
tgt_text.477: But some disagreement having occurred before the battle, they were deserted by their auxiliaries, and worsted in the conflict by the Athenians.
tgt_text.478: They had, however, the camp of their allies as a place of refuge, under whose protection they returned to their kingdom unmolested by other nations.
tgt_text.479: After Orithya, Penthesilea occupied the throne, of whose valour there were seen great proofs among the bravest heroes in the Trojan war, when she led an auxiliary force thither against the Greeks.
tgt_text.480: But Penthesilea being at last killed, and her army destroyed, a few only of the Amazons, who had remained at home in their own country, established a power that continued (defending itself with difficulty against its neighbours), to the time of Alexander the Great.
tgt_text.481: Their queen Minithya, or Thalestris, after obtaining from Alexander the enjoyment of his society for thirteen days, in order to have issue by him, returned into her kingdom, and soon after died, together with the whole name of the Amazons.
tgt_text.483: The Scythians, in their Asiatic expedition, having been absent from their wives and children eight years, were met on their return home by a war raised by their slaves.
tgt_text.484: For their wives, weary of waiting so long for their husbands, and think­ ing that they were not detained by war, but had perished in the field, married their slaves that had been left at home to take care of the cattle ;
tgt_text.485: who, taking up arms, repelled their masters, returning with victory, from the borders of their country, as if they had been strangers.
tgt_text.486: Success against them being uncertain, the Scythians were advised to change their method of attack, remembering that they were not to fight with soldiers, but with slaves, who were to be conquered, not by means of arms, but of magisterial authority;
tgt_text.487: that whips, not weapons, were to be used in the field ;
tgt_text.488: and that, swords being laid aside, rods and scourges, and other instru­ ments of terror to slaves, were to be provided.
tgt_text.489: This sugges­ tion being approved, and all being equipped as was prescribed, the Scythians, as soon as they drew near the enemy, held out scourges towards them unexpectedly, and struck them such terror, that they conquered with the dread of stripes those whom they could not conquer with the sword, and who took to flight, not as defeated enemies, but as fugitive slaves.
tgt_text.490: As many as could be taken, paid the penalty for their rebellion on the cross.
tgt_text.491: The women too, conscious of their ill conduct, put an end to their lives partly by the sword and partly by hanging.
tgt_text.492: After this occurrence, there was peace among the Scythians till the time of king Jancyrus, on whom Darius, king of Persia, as was said above, made war, because he could not obtain his daughter in marriage.
tgt_text.493: Darius, having entered Scythia with seven hundred thousand armed men, and the enemy allowing him no opportunity of fighting, dreading lest, if the bridge over the Ister were broken down, his retreat should be cut off, hurried back in alarm, with the loss of eighty thousand men;
tgt_text.494: which loss, however, out of so vast a number, was scarcely accounted a disaster.
tgt_text.495: Darius afterwards subdued Asia and Macedonia, and defeated the lonians in a fight at sea.
tgt_text.496: Then, learning that the Athenians had given aid to the lonians against him, he turned all his warlike fury upon them.
tgt_text.498: Since we have now come to the wars of the Athenians, which were carried on, not only beyond expectation as to what could be done, but even beyond belief as to what was done, the efforts of that people having been successful beyond their hopes, the origin of their city must be briefly set forth;
tgt_text.499: for they did not, like other nations, rise to eminence from a mean commencement, but are the only people that can boast, not only of their rise, but also of their birth.
tgt_text.500: It was not a concourse of foreigners, or a rabble of people collected from different parts, that raised their city, but men who were born on the same ground which they inhabit;
tgt_text.501: and the country which is their place of abode, was also their birth- place.
tgt_text.502: It was they who first taught.
tgt_text.503: the art of working in wool, and the use of oil and wine.
tgt_text.504: They also showed men, who had previously fed on acorns, how to plough and sow.
tgt_text.505: Literature and eloquence, it is certain, and the state of civil discipline which we enjoy, had Athens as their temple.
tgt_text.506: Before Deucalion's time, they had a king named Cecrops, whom, as all antiquity is full of fables, they represented tc have been of both sexes, because he was the first to join male and female in marriage.
tgt_text.507: To him succeeded Cranaus, whose daughter Atthis gave name to the country.
tgt_text.508: After him reigned Amphictyon, who first consecrated the city to Minerva, and gave it the name of Athens.
tgt_text.509: In his days, a deluge swept away the greater part of the inhabitants of Greece.
tgt_text.510: Those only escaped, whom a refuge on the mountains pro­ tected, or who went off in ships to Deucalion, king of Thessaly, by whom, from this circumstance, the human race is said to have been restored.
tgt_text.511: The crown then descended, in the course of succession, to Erectheus, in whose reign the sowing of corn was commenced by Triptolemus at Eleusis;
tgt_text.512: in commemoration of which benefit the nights sacred to the mysteries of Ceres were appointed.
tgt_text.513: Ægeus also, the father of Theseus, was king of Athens, from whom Medea divorcing herself, on account of the adult age of her step-son, returned to Colchis with her son Medus, whom she had had by Egeus.
tgt_text.515: and after Theseus his son Demophoon, who afforded aid to the Greeks against the Tro­ jans.
tgt_text.516: Between the Athenians and Dorians there had been animosities of long standing, which the Dorians, intending to revenge in war, consulted the oracle about the event of the contest.
tgt_text.517: The answer was, that the “ Dorians would have the advantage, if they did not kill the king of the Athenians."
tgt_text.518: When they came into the field, the Done soldiers were charged above all things to take care not to attack the king.
tgt_text.519: At that time the king of the Athenians was Codrus, who, learning the answer of the god and the direc­ tions of the enemy, laid aside his royal dress, and entered the camp of the enemy in rags, with a bundle of sticks on his back.
tgt_text.520: Here, among a crowd of people that stood in his way, he was killed by a soldier whom he had purposely wounded with a pruning knife.
tgt_text.521: His body being recognized as that of the king, the Dorians went off without coming to battle ;
tgt_text.522: and thus the Athenians, through the bravery of a prince who submitted to death for the safety of his country, were relieved from war.
tgt_text.524: After Codrus there was no king at Athens;
tgt_text.525: a cir umstance which is attributed to the respect paid to his memory.
tgt_text.526: The government of the state was placed in the hands of magistrates elected annually.
tgt_text.527: At this period the people had no laws, for the wills of their princes had always been received instead of laws.
tgt_text.528: Solon, a man of eminent integrity, was in consequence chosen to found the state, as it were afresh, by the establishment of laws.
tgt_text.529: This man acted with such judicious moderation between the commons and the senate (though whatever he proposed in favour of one class, seemed likely to displease the other), that he received equal thanks from both parties.
tgt_text.530: Among many illustrious acts of Solon, the following is eminently worthy of record.
tgt_text.531: A war had been carried on between the Athenians and Megarians, concerning their respective claims to the island of Salamis, almost to the utter destruction of both.
tgt_text.532: After many defeats, it was made a capital offence at Athens to propose a law for the recovery of the island.
tgt_text.533: Solon, anxious lest he should injure his country by keeping silence, or himself by expressing his opinion, pretended to be suddenly seized with madness, under cover of which he might not only say, but do, what was prohibited.
tgt_text.534: In a strange garb, like an insane person, he rushed forth into the public streets, where, having collected a crowd about him, he began, that he might the better conceal his design, to urge the people in verse (which he was unaccus. tomed to make), to do what was forbidden, and produced such an effect on the minds of all, that war was instantly decreed against the Megarians;
tgt_text.535: and the enemy being defeated, the island became subject to the Athenians.
tgt_text.537: After a time, the Megarians, cherishing the remem brance of the war made upon them by the Athenians, and fearing that they might be said to have taken up arms to no purpose, went on board a fleet with a design to seize the Athenian matrons as they were celebrating the Eleusinian mysteries during the night.
tgt_text.538: Their intention becoming known, Pisistratus, the Athenian general, placed a body of young men in ambush to receive them, directing the matrons, at the same time, to continue the celebration of the sacred rites with their usual cries and noise, even while the enemy were ap­ proaching, in order that they might not know that their coming was expected;
tgt_text.539: and thus attacking the Megarians unawares, just as they were leaving their ahips, he put them all to the sword.
tgt_text.540: Immediately after, having taken some women with his men on board the fleet which he had seized, to appear like captured matrons of the Athenians, he set sail for Megara.
tgt_text.541: The Megarians, seeing ships of their own build approaching, apparently with the desired prey on board, went out to the harbour to meet them.
tgt_text.542: Pisistratus cut them to pieces, and almost succeeded in taking their city.
tgt_text.543: Thus the Megarians, having their own stratagem turned against them, afforded their enemies a triumph.
tgt_text.544: But Pisistratus, as if he had conquered for himself and not for his country, possessed himself of the sovereign authority by a subtle contrivance.
tgt_text.545: Having undergone a voluntary scourging in his own house, he ran out, with his body lace­ rated, into the open street, and, having summoned an as­ sembly of the people, showed them his wounds, complaining of the cruelty of the great men of the city, from whom he pretended to have received this treatment.
tgt_text.546: Tears were joined to his words, and the credulous mob was easily inflamed be a calumnious speech, in which he affirmed that he had incurred the hatred of the senate by showing his love for the common people.
tgt_text.547: He thus obtained a guard for the protection of his person, by the aid of which he got the sovereign power into his hands, and reigned thirty-three years.
tgt_text.549: After his death Diocles,* one of his sons, having offered violence to a maiden, was slain by her brother.
tgt_text.550: His other son, whose name was Hippias, taking upon him the authority of his father, ordered the murderer of his brother to be apprehended;
tgt_text.551: who, being forced by torture to name those that were privy to the murder, named all the intimate friends of the tyrant.
tgt_text.552: These being put to death, and Hippias asking him “ whether any of the guilty still survived," he replied, that “there was no one surviving whom he should more rejoice to see die than the tyrant himself."
tgt_text.553: By which answer he proved himself superior to the tyrant, after having avenged, too, the violated honour of his sister.
tgt_text.554: The city being animated, through his spirited conduct, with a desire for liberty, Hippias was at last deprived of his power, and driven into exile.
tgt_text.555: Setting out for Persia, he offered him­ self as a leader to Darius against his own country;
tgt_text.556: Darius being then, as has been said before, ready to make war on the Athenians.
tgt_text.557: The Athenians, hearing of Darius's approach, requested assistance from the Lacedæmonians, who were then in alliance with them.
tgt_text.558: But finding that they delayed at home four days, in consequence of some religious scruple, they did not wait for their help, but, having mustered ten thousand of their own citizens, and a thousand auxiliaries from Platææ, went out to battle in the plain of Marathon, against six hundred thousand of the enemy.
tgt_text.559: Miltiades was both their general in the field, and the person who advised them not to wait for assistance, being possessed with such confidence of success, that he thought there was more trust to be placed in expedition than in their allies.
tgt_text.560: Great, therefore, was their spirit as they proceeded to battle;
tgt_text.561: so that, though there were a thousand paces between the two armies, they came full speed upon the enemy before their arrows were discharged.
tgt_text.562: Nor did the result fall short of their daring;
tgt_text.563: for such was the courage with which they fought, that you might have supposed there were men on one side and a herd of cattle on the other.
tgt_text.564: The Persians, utterly defeated, fled to their ships, of which many were sunk and many taken.
tgt_text.565: In this battle, the bravery of every individual was such, that it was difficult to determine to whom the highest praise was due.

tgt_text.739: XERXES, king of Persia, once the terror of the nations around him, became, after his unsuccessful conduct of the war against Greece, an object of contempt even to his own subjects.
tgt_text.740: Artabanus, his chief officer, conceiving hopes of usurping the throne, as the king's authority was every day declining, entered one evening into the palace (which from his intimacy with Xerxes was always open to him), accompanied by his seven stout sons, and, having put the king to death, proceeded to remove by stratagem such of the king's sons as opposed his wishes.
tgt_text.741: Entertaining little apprehension from Artaxerxes, who was but a boy, he pretended that the king had been slain by Darius, who was of full age, that he might have possession of the throne the sooner, and instigated Artaxerxes to revenge parricide by fratricide.

tgt_text.745: On this information, Artaxerxes, fearing the number of Arta­ banus's sons, gave orders for the troops to be ready under arms on the following day, as if he meant to ascertain their strength, and their respective efficiency for the field.

tgt_text.749: During these transactions in Persia, all Greece, under the leadership of the Lacedæmonians and Athenians, was split into two parties, and turned their arms from foreign wars as it were against their own bowels.

tgt_text.757: In the meantime, while the child was growing up, and he had the guardianship of him, he composed laws for the Spartans, who previously had had none.
tgt_text.758: Nor was he more celebrated for the making of these laws, than for his exemplary con­ formity to them;
tgt_text.759: for he imposed nothing by law upon others, of the observation of which he did not first give an example in his own conduct.
tgt_text.760: He trained the people to be obedient to those in authority, and those in authority to be just in the exercise of their government.
tgt_text.761: He enjoined frugality on all, thinking that the toils of war would be made more endurable by a constant observance of it.
tgt_text.762: He ordered all purchases to be made, not with money, but by exchange of commodities.
tgt_text.763: The use of gold and silver he prohibited, as being the origin of all evils.
tgt_text.765: He divided the administration of the government among the several orders;
tgt_text.766: to the kings he gave the power of making war, to the magistrates the seats of justice in yearly succession;
tgt_text.767: to the senate, the guardianship of the laws;
tgt_text.768: to the people, the power of choosing the senate, or of creating what magistrates they pleased.
tgt_text.769: The lands of the whole state he divided equally among all, that equality of possession might leave no one more powerful than another.
tgt_text.770: He ordered all to take their meals in public, that no man might secretly indulge in splendour or luxury.
tgt_text.771: He would not allow the young people to wear more than one dress in a year, nor any one to walk abroad in finer garments than another, or to fare more sumptuously, lest imitation of such practices should lead to general luxury.
tgt_text.772: He ordered boys to be carried, not into the forum, but into the field, that they might spend their early years, not in effeminate employments, but in hard labour and exertion;
tgt_text.773: not suffering them to put any thing under them to sleep upon, or to live on high seasoned food, and forbidding them to return into the city till they arrived at manhood.
tgt_text.774: He caused virgins to be married without portions, that wives, not money, might be sought;
tgt_text.775: and that husbands might govern their wives more strictly, being influenced by no regard to dowry.
tgt_text.776: He ordained that the highest respect should be paid, not to the rich and powerful, but to the old, according to thei degrees of seniority ;
tgt_text.777: nor had old age, indeed, a more honour­ able habitation anywhere than at Sparta.

tgt_text.779: And to secure perpetuity to his laws, he bound the city by an oath “to make no change in them till he should return," pretending that he was going to ask the oracle at Delphi whether any thing seemed necessary to be added to his institutions, or changed in them But he went in reality to Crete, and continued there it, voluntary exile;
tgt_text.780: and, when he was dying, ordered his bones to be thrown into the sea, lest, if they were taken back to Lacedæmon, the Spartans might think themselves absolved from their oath respecting alteration in his laws.
tgt_text.782: Under such a state of manners, the city acquired, in a short time,* such a degree of strength, that, on going to war with the Messenians for offering violence to some of their maidens at a solemn sacrifice of that people, they bound themselves under a severe oath not to return till they had taken Messene, promising themselves so much either from their strength or good fortune.
tgt_text.783: This occurrence was the commence­ ment of dissension in Greece, and the origin and cause of a civil war.
tgt_text.784: But being detained in the siege of this city, con­ trary to their expectation, for ten years, and called on to return by the complaints of their wives after so long a widowhood, and being afraid that by persevering in the war they might hurt themselves more than the Messenians (for, in Messene, whatever men were lost in the war, were replaced by the fruitfulness of their women, while they themselves suffered constant losses in battle, and could have no offspring from their wives in the absence of their husbands), they in conse­ quence selected, out of the soldiers that had come, after the military oath was first taken,!
tgt_text.785: as recruits to the army, a number of young men ;
tgt_text.786: whom they sent back to Sparta with permission to form promiscuous connexions with all the women of the city, thinking that conception would be more speedy if each of the females made the experiment with several men.
tgt_text.787: Those who sprung from these unions were called Partheniæ,* as a reflection on their mothers' violated chastity ;
tgt_text.788: and, when they came to thirty years of age, being alarmed with the fear of want (for not one of them had a father to whose estate he could hope to succeed,) they chose a captain named Phalantus, the son of Aratus, by whose advice the Spartans had sent home the young men to propagate, that, as they had formerly had the father for the author of their birth, they might now have the son as the establisher of their hopes and fortunes.
tgt_text.789: Without taking leave of their mothers, therefore, from whose adultery they thought that they derived dishonour, they set out to seek a place of settlement, and being tossed about a long time, and with various mischances, they at last arrived on the coast of Italy, where, after seizing the citadel of the Tarentines, and expelling the old inhabitants, they fixed their abode.
tgt_text.790: But several years after, their leader Phalantus, being driven into exile by a popular tumult, went to Brundusium, whither the former inhabitants of Tarentum had retreated after they were expelled from their city.
tgt_text.791: When he was at the point of death, he urged the exiles “to have his bones, and last relics, bruised to dust, and privately sprinkled in the forum of Tarentum ;
tgt_text.792: for that Apollo at Delphi had signified that by this means they might recover their city.”
tgt_text.793: They, thinking that he had revealed the destiny of his countrymen to avenge himself, complied with his directions;
tgt_text.794: but the intention of the oracle was exactly the reverse;
tgt_text.795: for it promised the Spartans, upon the performance of what he had said, not the loss, but the perpetual possession of the city.
tgt_text.796: Thus by the subtlety of their exiled captain, and the agency of their enemies, the possession of Tarentum was secured to the Partheniæ for ever.
tgt_text.798: Meantime the Messenians, who could not be conquered by valour, were reduced by stratagem.
tgt_text.799: For eighty years they bore the severe afflictions of slaves, as frequent stripes, and chains, and other evils of subjugation;
tgt_text.800: and then, after so long an endurance of suffering, they proceeded to resume hostilities.
tgt_text.801: The Lacedæmonians, at the same time, ran to arms with the greater ardour and unanimity, because they seemed to be called upon to fight against their own slaves.
tgt_text.802: While ill- treatment, therefore, on the one side, and indignation on the other, exasperated their feelings, the Lacedæmonians con sulted the oracle at Delphi concerning the event of the war, and were directed to ask the Athenians for a leader to con­ duct it The Athenians, learning the answer of the oracle, sent, to express their contempt of the Spartans a lame poet, named Tyrtæus;
tgt_text.803: who, being routed in three battles, reduced the Lacedæmonians to so desperate a condition, that, to re cruit their army, they liberated a portion of their slaves, promising that they should marry the widows of those who were slain, and thus fill up, not merely the number of the lost citizens, but their offices.
tgt_text.804: The kings of Sparta, however, lest, by contending against fortune, they should bring greater losses on their city, would have drawn off their army, had not Tyrtæus interposed, and recited to the soldiers, in a public assembly, some verses of his own composition, in which he had comprised exhortations to courage, consolations for their losses, and counsels concerning the war.
tgt_text.805: By this means he inspired the soldiers with such resolution, that, being no longer concerned for their lives, but merely for the rites of sepulture, they tied on their right arms tickets, inscribed with their names and those of their fathers, that if an unsuccessful battle should cut them off, and their features after a time be­ come indistinct, they might be consigned to burial according to the indication of the inscriptions.
tgt_text.806: When the kings saw the army thus animated, they took care that the state of it should be made known to the enemy;
tgt_text.807: the report, however, raised in the Messenians no alarm, but a correspondent ardour.
tgt_text.808: Both sides accordingly encountered with such fury, that there scarcely ever was a more bloody battle.
tgt_text.809: But at last victory fell to the Lacedæmonians.
tgt_text.811: Some time after, the Messenians renewed the war a third time, when the Lacedæmonians, among their other allies, called also upon the Athenians for assistance;
tgt_text.812: but afterwards, conceiving some mistrust of them, they prevented them from joining in the war, pretending that they had no need for their services.
tgt_text.813: The Athenians, not liking this pro- ceeding, removed the money, which had been contributed by the whole of Greece to defray the expense of the Persian war, from Delos to Athens, that, if the Lacedæmonians broke their faith as allies, it might not be an object of plunder to them.
tgt_text.814: The Lacedæmonians, on the other hand, did not rest, for though they were engaged in the war with the Messenians, they set the people of the Peloponnesus to make war on the Athenians.
tgt_text.815: The forces of the Athenians at home were at that time incon­ siderable, as their fleet had been despatched into Egypt, so that, engaging in battle by sea, they were quickly worsted.
tgt_text.816: Soon after, on the return of their fleet, being strengthened both by sea and land, they renewed the war;
tgt_text.817: when the Lacedæ­ monians, leaving the Messenians at rest, turned their full force against the Athenians.
tgt_text.818: Victory was long doubtful, and at last both parties gave over with equal loss.
tgt_text.819: The Lacedæ­ monians being then recalled to the war with the Messenians, but not wishing to leave the Athenians in the meantime un­ molested, bargained with the Thebans to restore them the supremacy of Bceotia, which they had lost in the time of the Persian war, if they would but take up arms against the Athe­ nians.
tgt_text.820: Such was the fury of the Spartans, that, though they were involved in two wars, they did not hesitate to occasion a third, if they might but raise up enemies against their ene­ mies.
tgt_text.821: The Athenians, therefore, to meet this storm of war, made choice of two eminent leaders, Pericles, a man of tried courage, and Sophocles, the writer of tragedies;
tgt_text.822: who, dividing their forces, laid waste the lands of the Spartans, and brought many cities of Achaia* under the power of the Athenians.
tgt_text.824: The Lacedæmonians, being humbled by these losses, agreed upon a peace for thirty years.
tgt_text.825: But their hostile feelings did not allow of so long a period of repose.
tgt_text.826: Hence, having broken the treaty before the fifteenth year was ended, they laid waste the territories of Attica in violation of their obligations towards the gods and towards men.
tgt_text.827: And lest they should seem to have desired to plunder rather than to fight, they challenged the enemy to the field.
tgt_text.828: But the Athenians, by the advice of their leader Pericles, deferred revenge for the spoliation of their lands to a fitter time of exacting it, thinking it needless to hazard a battle, when they could avenge themselves on the enemy without risk.
tgt_text.829: Some days afterwards, accordingly, they embarked in their fleet, and, while the Lacedæmonians expected nothing of the kind, laid waste all Sparta,* carrying off much more than they had lost;
tgt_text.830: so that, in a comparison of their respective sufferings, the retaliation was much greater than the injury at first received.
tgt_text.831: This expedition of Pericles was considered as greatly to his honour;
tgt_text.832: but his disregard of his private property was far more honourable.
tgt_text.833: The enemy, while they wasted the lands of others, had left his uninjured;
tgt_text.834: hoping, by this means, either to bring danger on him by rendering him unpopular, or dis.
tgt_text.835: honour by making him suspected of treachery.
tgt_text.836: But Pericles, foreseeing what would happen, had both foretold it to the people, and, to escape the effects of popular odium, had made over his lands to the state as a gift;
tgt_text.837: and thus obtained the greatest honour from that by which his ruin had been in­ tended.
tgt_text.838: Some days afterwards, an engagement took place by sea;
tgt_text.839: and the Lacedæmonians, being worsted, fled.
tgt_text.840: Neverthe­ less they did not cease from fierce attacks on one another, by sea or land, with various success.
tgt_text.841: At last, exhausted with disasters on both sides, they made peace for fifty years, which however they maintained only for six;
tgt_text.842: for they broke the treaty which they had concluded on their own account, under pretence of assisting their allies ;
tgt_text.843: as if they were less guilty of perjury by aiding their dependants, than by engaging in open hostilities themselves.
tgt_text.844: The war was in consequence transferred into Sicily;
tgt_text.845: but before I relate its progress, it is proper to give some ac­ count of the situation of that island.

tgt_text.852: -Utter defeat of the Athenians, V.I. IT is said that Sicily was formerly joined to Italy by a narrow pass,.
tgt_text.853: and was torn off, as it were, from the larger body, by the violence of the upper sea,t which impels itself in that direction with the whole force of its waters.
tgt_text.854: The soil itself, too, is light and frangible, and so perforated with caverns and passages, that it is almost everywhere open to blasts of wind ;
tgt_text.855: and the very matter of it is naturally adapted for generating and nourishing fire, as it is said to be impregnated with sulphur and bitumen, a circumstance which is the cause that when air contends with fire in the subterraneous parts, the earth frequently, and in several places, sends forth flame, or vapour, or smoke.
tgt_text.856: Hence it is that the fire of Mount Ætna has lasted through so many ages.
tgt_text.857: And when a strong wind passes in through the openings of the cavities, heaps of sand are cast up.
tgt_text.858: The promontory of Italy on the side nearest to Sicily, is called Rhegium,‡ beeause things broken off are designated by that term in Greek.
tgt_text.859: Nor is it strange that antiuity should have been full of fables concerning these parts, in which so many extraordinary things are found together.
tgt_text.860: The sea, in the first place, is nowhere so impetuous, pouring on with a current not only rapid but furious, not only frightful to those who feel its effects, but to those who view it from a distance.
tgt_text.861: So fierce is the conflict of the waves as they meet, that you may see some of them, put to flight as it were, sink down into the depths, and others, as if victorious, rising up to the skies.
tgt_text.862: Sometimes, in one part, you may hear the roaring of the sea as it boils up;
tgt_text.863: and again, in another part, the groaning of it as it sinks into a whirlpool.
tgt_text.864: Next are to be observed the adjacent and everlasting fires of Mount Ætna and the Æolian islands, which burn as if their heat were nourished by the sea itself;
tgt_text.865: nor indeed could such a quantity of fire have endured in such narrow bounds for so many ages unless it were supported by nourishment from the water..
tgt_text.866: Hence fables produced Scylla and Charybdis;
tgt_text.867: hence barkings were thought to have been heard ;
tgt_text.868: hence the appearances of monsters gained credit, as the sailors, frightened at the vast whirlpools of the subsiding waters, imagined that the waves, which the vortex of the absorbent gulf clashes together, actually barked.
tgt_text.869: The same cause makes the fires of Mount Ætna perpetual;
tgt_text.870: for the shock of the waters forces into the depths a portion of air hurried along with it, and then keeps it confined till, being diffused through the pores of the earth, it kindles the matter which nourishes the fire.
tgt_text.871: In addition, the proximity of Italy and Sicily is to be noticed, with the heights of their respective promontories, which are so similar, that, whatever wonder they raise in us in the present day, they excited proportionate terror in the ancients, who believed that whole ships were intercepted and destroyed by the promontories closing together and opening.
tgt_text.872: Nor was this invented by the ancients to gratify the hearer with a fabulous wonder, but occasioned by the terror and con­ sternation of those who passed by those parts;
tgt_text.873: for such is the appearance of the coasts to any one beholding them from a distance, that you would take the passage between them for a bay in the sea, and not a strait;
tgt_text.874: and, as you draw nearer, you would think that the promontories, which were before united, part asunder and separate.
tgt_text.876: At first Sicily had the name of Trinacria ;
tgt_text.877: f afterwards it was called Sicania.*
tgt_text.878: It was originally the abode of the Cyclops;
tgt_text.879: when they became extinct, Cocalus made himself ruler of the island.
tgt_text.880: After his time the cities fell severally under the dominion of tyrants, of whom no country was more productive.
tgt_text.881: One of them, Anaxilaus, strove to be as just as the others were cruel, and reaped no small advantage from his equity ;
tgt_text.882: for having left, at his death, some sons very young, and having committed the guardianship of them to Micythus, a slave of tried fidelity, so great was the respect paid to his memory among all his subjects, that they chose rather to submit to a slave than to abandon the king's children;
tgt_text.883: and the noblemen of the state, forgetful of their dignity, suffered the authority of government to be exercised by a bondman.
tgt_text.884: The Carthaginians, too, attempted to gain the sovereignty of Sicily, and fought against the tyrants for a long time with various success;
tgt_text.885: but at length, after losing their general Hamilcar and his army, they remained quiet for some time in consequence of that defeat.
tgt_text.887: In the meantime, the people of Rhegium being troubled with dissension, and the city being divided by disputes into two factions, a body of veteran soldiers from Himera, who were invited by one of the parties to their assist­ ance, having first expelled from the city those against whom they had been called, and then put to the sword those whom they had come to aid, took the government into their own hands, and made prisoners of the wives and children of their allies;
tgt_text.888: venturing upon an atrocity to which that of no tyrant can be compared ;
tgt_text.889: so that it would have been better for the Rhegians to have been conquered than to conquer ;
tgt_text.890: f for whether they had become slaves to their conquerors by the laws of war,‡ or, withdrawing from their country, had been necessitated to live in exile, yet they would not have been butchered amidst their altars and household gods, and have left their country, with their wives and children, a prey to the most cruel of tyrants.
tgt_text.891: The people of Catana, also, finding themselves oppressed by the Syracusans, and distrusting their own power to with­ stand them, requested assistance from the Athenians, who whether from desire of enlarging their dominions, so that they might master all Greece and Asia, or from apprehension of a fleet lately built by the Syracusans, and to prevent such a force from joining the Lacedæmonians, sent Lamponius, as general, with a naval armament into Sicily, that under pretence of assisting the people of Catana, they might endeavour to secure the sovereignty of the whole island.
tgt_text.892: Having succeeded in their first attempts, and made havoc among the enemy on several occasions, they despatched another expedition to Sicily, with a greater fleet and more numerous army, under the command of Laches and Chariades.
tgt_text.893: But the people of Catana, whether from fear of the Athenians, or from being weary of the war, made peace with the Syra­ cusans, and sent back the Athenian force that had come to assist them.
tgt_text.895: After a lapse of some time, however, as the articles of the peace were not observed by the Syracusans, they sent ambassa­ dors a second time to Athens, who, arriving in a mean dress, with long hair and beards, and every sign of distress adapted to move pity, presented themselves in that wretched plignt before the public assembly.
tgt_text.896: To their entreaties were added tears;
tgt_text.897: and the suppliants so moved the people to compassion, that the commanders who had withdrawn the auxiliary force from them received a sentence of condemnation.-
tgt_text.898: A powerful fleet was then appointed to aid them ;
tgt_text.899: Nicias, Alcibiades, and Lamachus were made captains;
tgt_text.900: and Sicily was revisited with such a force as was a terror even to those to whose aid it was sent.
tgt_text.901: In a short time, Alcibiades being recalled to answer certain charges made against him, Nicias and Lamachus fought two successful battles by land, and, drawing lines of circum­ vallation around Syracuse, cut off all supplies from the enemy by sea, keeping them closely blocked up in the city.
tgt_text.902: The Syracusans, being greatly reduced by these measures, sought assistance from the Lacedæmonians, by whom Gylippus alone was sent;
tgt_text.903: but he was a man equal to whole troops of aux­ iFaries.
tgt_text.904: He, having heard on his way of the declining state ot the war, and having collected some support partly from Greece and partly from Sicily, took possession of some posts suitable for carrying on the war.
tgt_text.905: He was then conquered in two battles, but engaging in a third, he killed Lamachus, put the enemy to flight, and rescued his allies from the siege.
tgt_text.906: But as the Athenians transferred their warlike efforts from the land to the sea, Gylippus sent for a fleet and army from Lacedæmon;
tgt_text.907: upon intelligence of which the Athenians themselves, too, sent out Demosthenes and Eurymedon, in the room of their late leader, with a reinforcement to their troops.
tgt_text.908: The Peloponnesians again, by a general resolution of their cities, sent powerful assistance to the Syracusans, and, as it the Greek war had been transported into Sicily, the contest was pursued on both sides with the utmost vigour.
tgt_text.910: In the first encounter at sea.
tgt_text.911: the Athenians were worsted, and lost their camp, with all their money, both what was public and what belonged to private individuals.
tgt_text.912: When, in addition to these disasters, they were also beaten in a battle on land, Demosthenes began to advise that “they should quit Sicily, while their condition, though bad, was not yet desperate;
tgt_text.913: and that they should not persist in a war so inauspiciously commenced, as there were more considerable, and perhaps more unhappy wars, to be dreaded at home, for which it was expedient that they should reserve the present force of their city."
tgt_text.914: But Nicias, whether from shame at his ill success, from fear of the resentment of his countrymen for the disappointment of their hopes, or from the impulse of destiny, contended for staying.
tgt_text.915: The war by sea was therefore renewed, and their thoughts turned from reflections on their previous ill-fortune to the hopes of a successful struggle, but, through the unskilfulness of their leaders, who attacked the Syracusans when advantageously posted in a strait, they were easily overcome.
tgt_text.916: Their general, Eurymedon, was the first to fall, fighting bravely in the front of the battle;
tgt_text.917: and thirty ships which he commanded were burnt.
tgt_text.918: Demosthenes and Nicias being also defeated, set their forces on shore, thinking that retreat would be safer by land.
tgt_text.919: Gylippus seized a hundred and thirty ships which they had left, and then, pursuing them as they fled, took some of them prisoners, and put others to death.
tgt_text.920: Demosthenes, after the loss of his troops saved himself from captivity by voluntarily falling on his sword.
tgt_text.921: But Nicias, not induced, even by the example of Demosthenes, to put himself out of the power of fortune, added to the loss of his army the disgrace of being made prisoner.
