tgt_text.1409: WHEN Philip had once come into Greece, allured by the plunder of a few cities, and had formed an opinion, from the spoil of such towns as were of less note, how great must be the riches of all its cities put together, he resolved to make war upon the whole of Greece.
tgt_text.1410: Thinking that it would greatly conduce to the promotion of his design, if he could get possession of Byzantium, a noble city and sea­ port, which would be a station for his forces by land and sea, he proceeded, as it shut its gates against him, to lay close siege to it.
tgt_text.1411: This city had been founded by Pausanias, king of Sparta, and held by him for seven years, but afterwards, as the fortune of war varied, it was regarded as at one time belonging to the Athenians, and at another to the Lacedæmonians;
tgt_text.1412: and this uncertainty of possession was the cause that, while neither party supported it as its own, it maintained its liberty with the greater determination.
tgt_text.1413: Philip, exhausted by the length of the siege, had recourse to piracy for a supply of money, and having captured a hundred and seventy ships, and sold off the cargoes, he was enabled for a while to relieve his craving wants.
tgt_text.1414: But that so great an army might not be wasted in the siege of a single city, he marched away with his best troops, and stormed some towns of the Chersonese.
tgt_text.1415: He also sent for his son Alexander, who was then eighteen years of age, to join him, and learn the rudiments of war in the camp of his father.
tgt_text.1416: He made an expedition, too, into Scythia, to get plunder, that, after the practice of traders, he might make up for the expenses of one war by the profits of another.
tgt_text.1418: The king of the Scythians at that time was Atheas, who, being distressed by a war with the Istrians, sought aid from Philip through the people of Apollonia, on the under standing that he would adopt him for his successor on the throne of Scythia.
tgt_text.1419: But in the mean time, the king of the Istrians died, and relieved the Scythians both from the fear of war and the want of assistance.
tgt_text.1420: Atheas, therefore, sending away the Macedonians, ordered a message to be sent to Philip, that " he had neither sought his aid, nor proposed his adoption;
tgt_text.1421: * for the Scythians needed no protection from the Macedonians, to whom they were superior in the field, nor did he himself want an heir, as he had a son living."
tgt_text.1422: When Philip heard this, he sent ambassadors to Atheas to ask him to defray at least a portion of the expense of the siege, t that he might not be forced to raise it for want of money;
tgt_text.1423: "a request," he said," with which he ought the more readily to comply, as, when he sent soldiers to his assistance, he had not even paid their expenses on the march, to say nothing of remuneration for their service."
tgt_text.1424: Atheas, alluding to the rigour of their climate and the barrenness of their soil, which, far from 1 enriching the Scythians with wealth, scarcely afforded them sustenance, replied, that "he had no treasury to satisfy so great a king, and that he thought it less honourable to do little than to refuse altogether;
tgt_text.1425: but that the Scythians were to be estimated by their valour and hardiness of body, not by their possessions."
tgt_text.1426: Philip, mocked by this message, broke up the siege of Byzantium, and entered upon a war with the Scythians, first sending ambassadors to lull them into security, by telling Atheas that " while he was besieging Byzantium, he had vowed a statue to Hercules, which he was going to erect at the mouth of the Ister, requesting an unobstructed passage to pay his vow to the god, since he was coming as a friend to the Scythians."
tgt_text.1427: Atheas desired him, " if his object was merely to fulfil his vow, to let the statue be sent to him," pro­ mising that " it should not only be erected, but should remain uninjured."
tgt_text.1428: but refusing " to allow an army to enter his ter ritories," and adding that, "if he should set up the statue in spite of the Scythians, he would take it down when he was gone, and turn the brass of it into heads for arrows."
tgt_text.1429: With feelings thus irritated on both sides, a battle was fought.
tgt_text.1430: Though the Scythians were superior in courage and numbers, they were defeated by the subtlety of Philip.
tgt_text.1431: Twenty thou­ sand young men and women were taken, and a vast number of cattle, but no gold or silver.
tgt_text.1432: This was the first proof which they had of the poverty of Scythia.
tgt_text.1433: Twenty thousand fine mares were sent into Macedonia to raise a breed.
tgt_text.1435: But as Philip was returning from Scythia, the Triballi met him, and refused to allow him a passage, unless they received a share of the spoil.
tgt_text.1436: Hence arose a dispute, and afterwards a battle, in which Philip received so severe a wound through the thigh, that his horse was killed by it;
tgt_text.1437: and while it was generally supposed that he was dead, the booty was lost.
tgt_text.1438: Thus the Scythian spoil, as if attended with a curse, had almost proved fatal to the Macedonians.
tgt_text.1439: But as soon as he recovered from his wound, he made war upon the Athenians, of which he had long dissembled his intention.
tgt_text.1440: The Thebans espoused their cause, fearing that if the Athenians were conquered, the war, like a fire in the neighbourhood, would spread to them.
tgt_text.1441: An alliance being accordingly made between the two cities, which were just before * at violent enmity with each other, they wearied Greece with embassies, stating that " they thought the common enemy should be repelled by their common strength, for that Philip would not rest, if his first attempts succeeded, until he had subjugated all Greece."
tgt_text.1442: Some of the cities were moved by these arguments, and joined themselves to the Athenians;
tgt_text.1443: but the dread of a war induced some to go over to Philip.
tgt_text.1444: A battle being brought on,t though the Athenians were far superior in number of soldiers, they were conquered by the valour of the Macedonians, which was invigorated by constant service in the field.
tgt_text.1445: They were not, however, in defeat, unmindful of their ancient valour;
tgt_text.1446: for, falling with wounds in front, they all covered the places which they had been charged by their leaders to defend, with their dead bodies.
tgt_text.1447: This day put an end to the glorious sovereignty and ancient liberty of all Greece.
tgt_text.1449: Philip's joy for this victory was artfully concealed.
tgt_text.1450: He abstained from offering the usual sacrifices ‡ on that day ;
tgt_text.1451: he did not smile at table, or mingle any diversions with the enter­ tainment;
tgt_text.1452: he had no chaplets or perfumes;
tgt_text.1453: and, as far as was in his power, he so managed his conquest that none might think of him as a conqueror.
tgt_text.1454: He desired that he should not be called king, but general of Greece;
tgt_text.1455: and conducted himself with such prudence, between his own secret joy on the one hand and the grief of the enemy on the other, that he neither appeared to his own subjects to rejoice, nor to the vanquished to insult them.
tgt_text.1456: To the Athenians, whom he had found to be his bitterest enemies, he both sent back their prisoners without ransom, and gave up the bodies of the slain for burial;
tgt_text.1457: exhorting them to convey the relics of their dead to the sepul­ chres of their ancestors.
tgt_text.1458: He also sent Alexander his son with his friend Antipater to Athens, to establish peace and friendship with them.
tgt_text.1459: The Thebans, however, he compelled to purchase their prisoners, as well as the liberty of burying their dead.
tgt_text.1460: Some of the chief men of their city, too, he put to death;
tgt_text.1461: others he banished, seizing upon the property of them all.
tgt_text.1462: Afterwards, he reinstated in their country those that had been unjustly banished, of whom he made three hun­ dred judges and governors of the city, before whom when the most eminent citizens were arraigned on this very charge, that of having banished them unjustly, they had such spirit that they all acknowledged their participation in the fact, and affirmed that it was better with the state when they were con­ demned than when they were restored.
tgt_text.1464: They passed sentence, as far as they could, on those who had the disposal of them for life or death, and set at nought the pardon which their enemies could give them ;
tgt_text.1465: and, as they could not avenge themselves * by deeds, they manifested their boldness of spirit by words.
tgt_text.1467: War being at an end in Greece, Philip directed depu­ ties from all the states to be summoned to Corinth, to settle the condition of affairs.
tgt_text.1468: Here he fixed terms of peace for the whole of Greece, according to the merits of each city;
tgt_text.1469: and chose from them all a council, to form a senate as it were foi the country.
tgt_text.1470: But the Lacedæmonians, standing alone, showed contempt alike for the terms and the king;
tgt_text.1471: regarding the state of things, which had not been agreed upon by the cities themselves, but forced upon them by a conqueror, as a state, not of peace, but of slavery.
tgt_text.1472: The number of troops to be furnished by each state was then determined, whether the king, in case of being attacked, was to be supported by their united force, or whether war was to be made on any other power under him as their general.
tgt_text.1473: In all these preparations for war it was not to be doubted that the kingdom of Persia was the object in view.
tgt_text.1474: The sum of the force was two hundred thousand infantry and fifteen thousand cavalry.
tgt_text.1475: Exclusive of this number there was also the army of Macedonia, and the adjacent barbarians of the conquered nations.
tgt_text.1476: In the beginning of the next spring, he sent forward three of his generals into that part of Asia which was under the power of the Persians, Parmenio, Amyntas, and Attalus, whose sister he had recently married, having divorced Olympias, the mother of Alexander, on suspicion of adultery.
tgt_text.1478: In the meantime, while the troops were assembling from Greece, he celebrated the marriage of his daughter Cleo­ patra with Alexander, whom he had made king of Epirus.
tgt_text.1479: The day was remarkable for the pomp displayed on it, suitable to the magnificence of the two princes, him that gave his daughter in marriage, and him that married her.
tgt_text.1480: Magnificent games were also celebrated, and as Philip was going to view them, unattended by his guards, walking between the two Alexanders, his son and son-in-law, Pausanias, a noble Mace­ donian youth, without being suspected by any one, posting himself in a narrow passage, killed him as he was going through it, and caused a day appointed for joy to be over­ clouded with mourning for a death.
tgt_text.1481: Pausanias, in the early part of his youth, had suffered gross violence at the hands of Attalus, to the indignity of which was added this further affront, that AttaIns had exposed him, after bringing him to a banquet and making him drunk, not only to insults from him­ self, but also to those of the company, as if he had been a common object for ill-treatment, and rendered him the laughing-stock of those of his own age.
tgt_text.1482: Being impatient under this ignominy, Pausanias had often made complaints to Philip, but being put off with various excuses, not unattended with ridicule, and seeing his adversary also honoured with a general's commission, he turned his rage against Philip him­ self, and inflicted on him, as an unjust judge, that revenge which he could not inflict on him as an adversary.
tgt_text.1484: It is even believed that he was instigated to the act by Olympias, Alexander's mother, and that Alexander himself was not ignorant that his father was to be killed;
tgt_text.1485: as Olympias had felt no less resentment at her divorce, and the preferment of Cleopatra to herself, than Pausanias had felt at the insults which he had received.
tgt_text.1486: As for Alexander, it is said that he feared his brother by his step-mother as a rival for the throne ;
tgt_text.1487: and hence it happened that he had previously quarrelled at a banquet, first with Attalus, and afterwards with his father him­ self, insomuch that Philip pursued him even with his drawn sword, and was hardly prevented from killing him by the entrea­ ties of his friends.
tgt_text.1488: Alexander had in consequence retired with his mother into Epirus, to take refuge with his uncle, and from thence to the king of the Illyrians, and was with difficulty reconciled to his father when he recalled him, and not easily induced by the prayers of his relations to return.
tgt_text.1489: Olympias, too, was instigating her brother, the king of Epirus, to go to war with Philip, and would have prevailed upon him to do so, had not Philip, by giving him his daughter in marriage, dis­ armed him as a son-in-law.
tgt_text.1490: With these provocations to resentment, both of them are thought to have encouraged Pausanias, when complaining of his insults being left unpun­ ished, to so atrocious a deed.
tgt_text.1491: Olympias, it is certain, had horses prepared for the escape of the assassin;
tgt_text.1492: and, when she heard that the king was dead, hastening to the funeral under the appearance of respect, she put a crown of gold, the same night that she arrived, on the head of Pausanias,t as he was hanging on a cross;
tgt_text.1493: an act which no one but she would have dared to do, as long as the son of Philip was alive.
tgt_text.1494: A few days after, she burnt the body of the assassin, when it had been taken down, upon the remains of her husband, and made him a tomb in the same place;
tgt_text.1495: she also provided that yearly sacrifices should be per­ formed to his manes, possessing the people with a superstitious notion for the purpose.
tgt_text.1496: Next she forced Cleopatra, for whose sake she had been divorced from Philip, to hang herself, hav­ ing first killed her daughter in her lap, and enjoyed the sight of her suffering this vengeance, to which she had hastened by procuring the death of her husband..
tgt_text.1497: Last of all she conse­ crated the sword, with which the king.
tgt_text.1498: had been killed, to Apollo, under the name of Myrtale,t which was Olympias's own name when a child.
tgt_text.1499: And all these things were done so publicly, that she seems to have been afraid lest it should not be evident enough that the deed was promoted by her.
tgt_text.1501: Philip died at the age of forty-seven, after having reigned twenty-five years.
tgt_text.1502: He had, by a dancing girl of Larissa, a son named Aridæus, who reigned after Alexander.
tgt_text.1503: He had also many others by several wives, ‡as is not unusual with princes, some of whom died a natural death, and others by the sword.
tgt_text.1504: As a king, he was more inclined to display in war, than in entertainments;
tgt_text.1505: and his greatest riches were means for military operations.
tgt_text.1506: He was better at getting wealth than keeping it, and, in consequence, was always poor amidst his daily spoliations.
tgt_text.1507: Clemency and perfidy were equally valued by him;
tgt_text.1508: and no road to victory was, in his opinion, dishonourable.
tgt_text.1509: He was equally pleasing and trea­ cherous in his address, promising more than he could perform.
tgt_text.1510: He was well qualified either for serious conversation or for jesting.
tgt_text.1511: He maintained friendships more with a view to interest than good faith.
tgt_text.1512: It was a common practice with him to pretend kindness where he hated, and to counterfeit dislike where he loved;
tgt_text.1513: to sow dissension among friends, and try to gain favour from both sides.
tgt_text.1514: With such a disposition, his eloquence was very great, his language full of point and studied effect;
tgt_text.1515: so that neither did his facility fall short of his art, nor his invention of his facility, nor his art of his invention.
tgt_text.1516: To Philip succeeded his son Alexander, a prince greatei than his father, both in his virtues and his vices.
tgt_text.1518: two had a different mode of conquering;
tgt_text.1519: the one prosecute­ his wars with open force, the other with subtlety;
tgt_text.1520: the one de­ lighted in deceiving his enemies, the other in boldly repulsing them.
tgt_text.1521: The one was more prudent in council, the other mor* noble in feeling.
tgt_text.1522: The father would dissemble his resentment.
tgt_text.1524: when the son was provoked, there was neither delay nor bounds to his vengeance.
tgt_text.1525: They were both too fond of wine, but the ill effects of their intoxication were totally different;
tgt_text.1526: the father would rush from a banquet to face the enemy, cope with him, and rashly expose himself to dan­ gers ;
tgt_text.1527: the son vented his rage, not upon his enemies, but his friends.
tgt_text.1528: A battle often sent away Philip wounded;
tgt_text.1529: Alexander often left a banquet* stained with the blood of his companions.
tgt_text.1530: The one wished to reign with his friends, the other to reign over them.
tgt_text.1531: The one preferred to be loved, the other to be feared.
tgt_text.1532: To literature both gave equal attention.
tgt_text.1533: The father had more cunning, the son more honour.
tgt_text.1534: Philip was more staid in his words, Alexander in his actions.
tgt_text.1535: The son felt readier and nobler impulses to spare the conquered;
tgt_text.1536: the father showed no mercy even to his allies.
tgt_text.1537: The father was more inclined to frugality, the son to luxury.
tgt_text.1538: By the same course by which the father laid the foundations of the empire of the world, the son consummated the glory of conquering the whole world.
tgt_text.1539: The sons of Artaxerxes conspire against him, and are put to death, I.— Causes of the conspiracy, II.
tgt_text.1542: end of the Persian monarchy, III.I. ARTAXERXES, t king of Persia, had a hundred and fifteen sons by his concubines, but only three begotten in lawful wed.
tgt_text.1544: Of these the father from paternal fondness, made Darius king during his own life­ time, contrary to the usage of the Persians, among whom the king is changed only by death ;
tgt_text.1545: for he thought nothing taken from himself that he conferred upon his son, and expected greater enjoyment from having progeny, if he saw the insignia of royalty adorning his son while he lived.
tgt_text.1546: But Darius, after such an extraordinary proof of his father's affection, conceived the design of killing him.
tgt_text.1547: He would have been bad enough, if he had meditated the parricide alone, but he became so much the worse, by enticing fifty of his brothers to a participa.
tgt_text.1548: tion in his crime, and making them parricides in intention as well as himself.
tgt_text.1549: It was certainly a kind of prodigy, that, among so great a number, the assassination should not only have been plotted, but concealed, and that of fifty children there should not have been found one, whom either respect for their father's dignity, or reverence for an old man, or gratitude for paternal kindness, could deter from so horrible a purpose.
tgt_text.1550: Was the name of father so contemptible among so many sons, that he who should have been secured even against enemies by their protection, should be beset by their treason, and find it easier to defend himself against his foes than his children ?
tgt_text.1552: The cause of the intended parricide was even more atrocious than the crime itself;
tgt_text.1553: for after Cyrus was killed in the war against his brother, of which mention has been pre­ viously* made, Artaxerxes had married Aspasia, † the concu­ bine of Cyrus;
tgt_text.1554: and Darius had required that his father should resign her to him as he had resigned the kingdom.
tgt_text.1555: Artax­ erxes, from fondness from his children, said at first that he would do so, but afterwards, from a change of mind, and in order plausibly to refuse what he had inconsiderately promised, made her a priestess of the sun, an office which obliged her to perpetual chastity.
tgt_text.1556: The young Darius, being incensed at this proceeding, broke out at first into reproaches against his father, and subsequently entered into this conspiracy with his brothers.
tgt_text.1557: But while he was meditating destruction for his father, he was discovered and apprehended with his associates, and paid the penalty of his guilt to tho gods who avenge paternal authority.
tgt_text.1558: The wives of them all, too, together with their children, were put to death, that no memorial of such execrable wickedness might be left.
tgt_text.1559: Soon after Artaxerxes died of a disease contracted by grief, having been happier as a king than as a father.
tgt_text.1561: Possession of the throne was given to Ochus, who, dreading a similar conspiracy, filled the palace with the blood and dead bodies of his kinsmen and the nobility, being touched with compassion neither for consanguinity, nor sex, nor age, lest, apparently, he should be thought less wicked than his brothers that had meditated parricide.
tgt_text.1562: Having thus, as it were, purified his kingdom, he made was upon the Cardusii;
tgt_text.1563: in the course of which one Codomannus.
tgt_text.1564: followed by applause from all the Persians, engaged with one of the enemy that offered himself for single combat, and, having killed his antagonist, regained the victory for his fellow soldiers, as well as the glory which they had almost lost.
tgt_text.1565: For this honourable service Codomannus was made governor of Armenia.
tgt_text.1566: Some time after, on the death of Ochus, he was chosen king by the people from regard to his former merits, and, that nothing might be wanting to his royal dignity, honoured with the name of Darius.
tgt_text.1567: He main­ tained a long war, with various success, but with great efforts, against Alexander the Great.
tgt_text.1568: But being at last overcome by Alexander, and slain t by his relations, he terminated his life and the kingdom of the Persians together.

tgt_text.1584: IN the army of Philip there were various nations, and after his death different feelings prevailed among them.
tgt_text.1585: Some, oppressed with an unjust yoke, were excited with hopes of recovering their liberty ;
tgt_text.1586: others, from dislike of going to war in a distant country, rejoiced that the expedition was broken off;
tgt_text.1587: others grieved that the torch, kindled at the daughters nuptials, should have been applied to the funeral pile of the father.
tgt_text.1588: It was no small fear, too, that possessed his friends on so sudden a change, contemplating at one time Asia that had been provoked, at another Europe.
tgt_text.1589: that was not yet paci* tied, at another the Illyrians, Thracians, Dardanians, and other barbarous nations, who were of wavering faith and per­ fidious dispositions, and whom, if they should all rebel at once, it would be utterly impossible to resist.
tgt_text.1590: To all these apprehensions the succession of Alexander was a relief, who, in a public assembly, so effectually soothed and encouraged the people, as to remove all uneasiness from those that were afraid, and to fill every one with favourable expectations.
tgt_text.1591: He was now twenty years old ;
tgt_text.1592: at which age he gave great promise of what he would be, but with such modesty, that it was evident he reserved the further proofs of his ability for the time of action.
tgt_text.1593: He granted the Macedonians relief from all burdens, except that of service in war;
tgt_text.1594: by which conduct he gained such popularity with his subjects, that they said they had changed only the person, not the virtues, of their king.
tgt_text.1596: His first care was about his fathers funeral, when he caused all who had been privy to his murder to be put to death at his burial-place.
tgt_text.1597: The only one that he spared was Alexander Lyncestest his brother, preserving in him the man who had first acknowledged his royal authority, for he had been the first to salute him king.
tgt_text.1598: His brother Caranus,t a rival for the throne, as being the son of his step-mother, he ordered to be slain.
tgt_text.1599: In the beginning of his reign he put down many tribes that were revolting, and quelled some seditions in their birth.
tgt_text.1600: Encouraged by his success, he marched with haste into Greece, where, after his father's example, having summoned the states to meet at Corinth, he was appointed general in his room.

tgt_text.2226: Arriving in Africa, they dislodged the inhabitants from a hill named Cyras, and took possession of it for themselves, on account both of the pleasantness of the situation and the abundance of springs in it.
tgt_text.2227: Here Battus, their leader, the strings of his tongue being loosed, began to speak;
tgt_text.2228: which circumstance, as one part of the god's promises was fulfilled, gave them encouragement to entertain the further hope of building a city.
tgt_text.2229: Pitching their camp, accordingly, they received information of an old tradition, that Cyrene, a maiden of extraordinary beauty, was carried off by Apollo from Pelion, a mountain in Thessaly, and brought to that very mountain on which they had seized a hill, where, becoming pregnant by the god, she brought forth four sons, Nomius, Aristæus, Authocus, and Argaeus;
tgt_text.2230: and that a party being sent by her father Hypsæus, king of Thessaly, to seek for the damsel, were so attracted by the charms of the place, that they settled there with her.
tgt_text.2231: Of her four sons, it was said that three, when they grew up, returned to Thessaly, and inherited their grandfather's kingdom;
tgt_text.2232: and that the fourth, Aristæus, reigned over a great part of Arcadia, and taught mankind the management of bees and honey, and the art of making cheese, and was the first that observed the solstitial risings of Sirius.*
tgt_text.2233: On hearing this account, Battus built the city in obedience to the oracle, calling it Cyrene,* from the name of the maiden.
tgt_text.2235: Ptolemy, having increased his strength from the forces of this city, made preparations for war against the coming of Perdiccas.
tgt_text.2236: But the hatred which Perdiccas had incurred by his arrogance did him more injury than the power of the enemy;
tgt_text.2237: for his allies, detesting his overbearingness, went over in troops to Antipater.
tgt_text.2238: Neoptolemus, too, who had been left to support Eumenes, intended not only to desert himself, but also to betray the force of his party;
tgt_text.2239: when Eumenes, understanding his design, thought it a matter of necessity to engage the traitor in the field.
tgt_text.2240: Neoptolemus, being worsted, fled to Antipater and Polysperchon, and per­ suaded them to surprise Eumenes, by marching without inter­ mission, while he was full of joy for his victory, and freed from apprehension by his own flight.
tgt_text.2241: But this project did not escape Eumenes;
tgt_text.2242: the plot was in consequence turned upon the contrivers of it;
tgt_text.2243: and they who expected to attack him unguarded, were attacked themselves when they were on their march, and wearied with watching through the previous night.
tgt_text.2244: In this battle, Polysperchon was killed.
tgt_text.2245: t Neoptolemus, too, engaging hand to hand with Eumenes, and maintaining a long struggle with him, in which both were wounded more than once, was at last overpowered and fell.
tgt_text.2246: Eumenes, therefore, being victorious in two successive battles, supported in some degree the spirits of his party, which had been cast down by the desertion of their allies.
tgt_text.2247: At last, however, Perdiccas being killed,‡ Eumenes was declared an enemy by the army together with Pitho, Illyrius, and Alcetas, the brother of Per­ diccas ;
tgt_text.2248: and the conduct of the war against them was com­ mitted to Antigonus.

WHEN Eumenes found that Perdiccas was slain, that he himself was declared an enemy by the Macedonians, and that the conduct of the war against him was committed to Anti­ gonus, he at once made known the state of affairs to his troops, lest report should either exaggerate matters, or alarm the minds of the men with the unexpected nature of the events;
tgt_text.2253: designing at the same time to learn how they, were affected towards him, and to take his measures according to.
tgt_text.2254: the feeling expressed by them as a body.
tgt_text.2255: He boldly gave notice, however, that “ if any one of them felt dismayed at the news, he had full liberty to depart.”
tgt_text.2256: By. this declaration he so strongly attached them to his side, that they all imme­ diately exhorted him to prosecute the war, and protested that “ they would annul the decrees of the Macedonians with their swords."
tgt_text.2257: Having then led his army into Ætolia,* he exacted contributions from the different cities, and plundered, like an enemy, such as refused to pay.
tgt_text.2258: Next he went to Sardis, to Cleopatra, the sister of Alexander the Great, that with her influence he might encourage his captains and chief officers, who would think that the royal authority was on that side on, which the sister of Alexander stood.
tgt_text.2259: Such veneration was there for the greatness of Alexander, that the influence of his.
tgt_text.2260: sacred name was sought even by means of women.
tgt_text.2261: When he returned to his camp, letters were found scattered:
tgt_text.2262: through it, in which great rewards were offered to any that should bring the head of Eumenes to Antigonus.
tgt_text.2263: This coming to his knowledge, Eumenes, assembling his men, first offered them his congratulations that " none had been found.
tgt_text.2264: among them who preferred the expectation of a reward stained with blood to the obligation of his military oath."
tgt_text.2265: He then craftily added that these letters had been forged by himself to sound their feelings;
tgt_text.2266: but that his life was in the hands of them all;
tgt_text.2267: and that neither Antigonus nor any other general would be willing to conquer by such means as would afford the worst of examples against himself."
tgt_text.2268: By acting thus, he both preserved for the present the attachment of such as were wavering, and made it likely that if anything similar should happen in future, the soldiers would think that they were not tampered with by the enemy, but sounded by their own general.
tgt_text.2269: All of them in consequence zealously offered him their services for the guard of his person.
tgt_text.2271: In the meantime Antigonus came up with his army, and having pitched his camp, offered battle on the following day.
tgt_text.2272: Nor did Eumenes delay to engage with him;
tgt_text.2273: but, being defeated, he fled to a fortress, where, when he saw that he must submit to the hazard of a siege, he dismissed the greater part of his army, lest he should either be delivered to the enemy by consent of the multitude, or the sufferings of the siege should be aggravated by too great a number.
tgt_text.2274: He then sent a deputation to Antipater, who was the only general that seemed a match for the power of Antigonus, to entreat his aid;
tgt_text.2275: and Antigonus, hearing that succour was despatched by him to Eumenes, gave up the siege.
tgt_text.2276: Eumenes was thus for a time, indeed, relieved from fear of death;
tgt_text.2277: but, as so great a portion of his army was sent away, he had no great hope of ultimate safety.
tgt_text.2278: After taking everything into consideration, therefore, he thought it best to apply to the Argyraspides of Alexander the Great, a body of men that had never yet been conquered, and radiant with the glory of so many victories.
tgt_text.2279: But the Argyras­ pides disdained all leaders in comparison with Alexander, and thought service under other generals dishonourable to the memory of so great a monarch.
tgt_text.2280: Eumenes had, therefore, to address them with flattery;
tgt_text.2281: he spoke to each of them in the language of a suppliant, calling them his " fellow-soldiers," his “ patrons," or his " companions in the dangers and exploits of the east;
tgt_text.2282: " sometimes styling them “ his refuge for pro­ tection, and his only security;
tgt_text.2283: " saying that “they were the only troops by whose valour the east had been subdued, the only troops that had gone beyond the achievements of Bacchus and the monuments of Hercules;
tgt_text.2284: that by them Alexander had become great, by them had attained divine honours and immortal glory;
tgt_text.2285: " and he begged them “ to receive him, not so much in the character of a general, as in that of a fellow-soldier, and to allow him to be one of their body."
tgt_text.2286: Being received on these terms, he gradually sue.
tgt_text.2287: ceeded, first by giving them hints individually, and afterwards by gently correcting whatever was done amiss, in gaining the sole command.
tgt_text.2288: Nothing could be done in the camp without him;
tgt_text.2289: nothing managed without the aid of his judgment.
tgt_text.2291: At length, when it was announced that Antigonus was approaching with his army, he obliged them to march into the field;
tgt_text.2292: where, slighting the orders of their general, they were defeated by the bravery of the enemy.
tgt_text.2293: In this battle they lost, with their wives and children, not only their glory from -so many wars, but also the booty obtained in their long service.
tgt_text.2294: But Eumenes, who was the cause of their disaster,.
tgt_text.2295: and had no other hope of safety remaining, encouraged them after their repulse, assuring them that" they had the superiority in courage, ,as five thousand of the enemy had been slain by them ;
tgt_text.2296: and that if they persevered in the war, their enemies would gladly sue for peace;
tgt_text.2297: " adding, that " the losses, by which they esti­ mated their defeat, were two thousand women, and a few chil- Aren and slaves, which they might better recover by conquering, than by yielding the victory."
tgt_text.2298: The Argyraspides, on the other hand, declared that “ they would neither attempt a retreat, after the loss of their property and wives, nor would they war .against their own children,”† and pursued him with reproaches “ for having involved them, when they were returning home after so many years of completed service, and with the fruits of so many enterprises, and when on the point of being disbanded, in fresh efforts and vast struggles in the field;
tgt_text.2299: for laving deluded them, when they were recalled, as it were, from their own hearths, and from the very threshold of their country, with vain promises;
tgt_text.2300: and for not allowing them, after having lost all the gains of their fortunate service, to support quietly under their defeat the burden of a poor and unhappy old age."
tgt_text.2301: Immediately after, without the knowledge of their leaders,* they sent deputies to Antigonus, requesting that “ he would order what was theirs t to be restored to them."
tgt_text.2302: Anti­ gonus promised that "he would restore what they asked, if they would deliver up Eumenes to him."
tgt_text.2303: Hearing of this reply, Eumenes, with a few others, attempted to flee, but being brought back, and finding his condition desperate, he requested, as a great crowd gathered around him, to be allowed to address the army for the last time.
tgt_text.2305: Being desired by them all to speak, and silence being made, and his chains loosed, he held out his hand, fettered as he was, and said, "Soldiers, ye behold the dress and equip­ ments of your general, which it is not any one of the enemy that has put upon me;
tgt_text.2306: for that would be even a consolation to me;
tgt_text.2307: but it is you that have made me of a conqueror con­ quered, and of a general a prisoner.
tgt_text.2308: Four times ‡ within the present year have you bound yourselves by oath to obey me ;
tgt_text.2309: but on that point I shall say nothing, for reproaches do not become the unfortunate.
tgt_text.2310: One favour only I entreat, that, if the performance of Antigonus's promises depends on my life, you would allow me to die among yourselves;
tgt_text.2311: for to him it signifies nothing how or where I fall, and I shall be delivered from an ignominious end.
tgt_text.2312: If I obtain this request, I release you from the oath by which you have so often devoted your­ selves to me.
tgt_text.2313: Or if you are ashamed to offer violence to me at my entreaty, give me a sword, and permit your general to do for you,§ without the obligation of an oath, that which you have taken an oath to do for your general."
tgt_text.2314: Not being able, however, to obtain his request, he changed his tone of entreaty to that of anger, and exclaimed, “ May the gods, then, the avengers of perjury, look down in judgment upon you, ye accursed wretches, and bring upon you such deaths as you have brought upon your leaders.
tgt_text.2315: It was you, the same who now stand before me, that were lately sprinkled with the blood of Perdiccas, and that planned a similar end for Antipater.
tgt_text.2316: You would even have killed Alexander himself, if it had been pos­ sible for him to fall by a mortal hand :
tgt_text.2317: * what was next to it,‡ you harassed him with your mutinies.
tgt_text.2318: I, the last victim of your perfidy, now pronounce on you these curses and impreca­ tions :
tgt_text.2319: may you live your whole lives in poverty, far from your country, in this camp where you are exiled;
tgt_text.2320: and may your own arms, by which you have killed more generals of your own than of your enemies, sink you in utter destruction."
tgt_text.2321: Then, full of indignation, he began to walk before his guards towards the camp of Antigonus.
tgt_text.2322: The army followed, surrendering their general, and being themselves made prisoners;
tgt_text.2323: and, leading up a triumph over themselves to the camp of their conqueror, resigned to him, together with their own persons, all their honour gained under king Alexander,‡ and the palms and laurels of so long a warfare;
tgt_text.2324: and, that nothing might be wanting to the procession, the elephants and auxiliaries of the east§ brought up the rear.
tgt_text.2325: This single victory was so far more glorious to Antigonus than so many other victories had been to Alexander, that whereas Alexander subdued the east, Anti­ gonus defeated those by whom the east had been subdued.
tgt_text.2326: These conquerors of the world, then, Antigonus distributed among his army, restoring to them what he had taken in the victory;
tgt_text.2327: and directed that Eumenes, whom, from regard to their former friendship, he did not allow to come into his pre­ sence, should be committed to the care of a guard.
tgt_text.2329: In the meantime Eurydice, the wife of king Aridæus, when she learned that Polysperchon was returning from Greece into Macedonia, and that Olympias was sent for by him, being prompted by a womanish emulation, and taking advantage of her husband s weakness, whose duties she took upon herself, wrote in the king's name to Polysperchon, desiring him “to deliver up the army to Cassander, on whom the king had con ferred the government of the kingdom."
tgt_text.2330: She made a similar communication to Antigonus, in a letter which she wrote to him in Asia.
tgt_text.2331: Cassander, attached to her by such a favour, managed everything according to the will of that ambitious woman.
tgt_text.2332: Marching into Greece, he made war upon several cities;
tgt_text.2333: by the calamities of which, as by a fire in the neighbourhood, the Spartans were alarmed, and, distrusting their power in arms.
tgt_text.2334: enclosed their city (which they had always defended, not with walls, but with their swords) with works of defence, in disre­ gard both of the predictions of the oracles, and of the ancient glory of their forefathers.
tgt_text.2335: Strange, that they should have so far degenerated from their ancestors, that, when the valour of the citizens had been for many ages a wall to the city, the citizens could not now think themselves secure unless they had walls to shelter them.
tgt_text.2336: But during the course of these pro­ ceedings, the disturbed state of Macedonia obliged Cassander to return home from Greece;
tgt_text.2337: for Olympias, the mother of Alexander the Great, coming from Epirus to Macedonia, with Æacides, king of the Molossians, attending her, and being forbidden to enter the country by Eurydice and king Aridæus, the Macedonians being moved, either by respect for the memory of her husband, or the greatness of her son, or by the indignity with which she was treated, went over to Olympias, by whose order both Eurydice and the king were put to death, he having held the kingdom six years since the decease of Alexander.
tgt_text.2339: But neither did Olympias reign long;
tgt_text.2340: for having com­ mitted great slaughter among the nobility throughout the country, like a furious woman rather than a queen, she turned the favour with which she was regarded into hatred.
tgt_text.2341: Hearing, therefore, of the approach of Cassander, and distrusting the Mace­ donians, she retired, with her daughter in-law Roxane, and her grandson Hercules, to the city of Pydna.
tgt_text.2342: Deidamia, the daugh­ ter of king Æacides, and Thessalonice, her step-daughter, ren­ dered illustrious by the name of Philip, who was her father, and many others, wives of the leading men, a retinue showy rather than serviceable, attended her on her journey.
tgt_text.2343: When the news of her retreat was brought to Cassander, he marched immediately, with the utmost expedition, to Pydna, and laid siege to the city.
tgt_text.2344: Olympias, distressed with famine and the sword, and the wearisomeness of a long siege, surrendered herself to the conqueror, stipulating only for life.
tgt_text.2345: But Cas- sander, on summoning the people to an assembly, to inquire “ what they would wish to be done with Olympias," induced the parents of those whom she had killed to put on mourn­ ing apparel, and expose her cruelties;
tgt_text.2346: when the Mace­ donians, exasperated by their statements, decreed, without regard to her former majesty, that she should be put to death;
tgt_text.2347: utterly unmindful that, by the labours of her son and her hus­ band, they had not only lived in security among their neigh­ bours, but had attained to vast power, and even to the conquest of the world.
tgt_text.2348: Olympias, seeing armed men advancing towards her, bent upon her destruction, went voluntarily to meet them, dressed in her regal apparel, and leaning on two of her maids.
tgt_text.2349: The executioners, on beholding her, struck with the recollection of her former royal dignity,.
tgt_text.2350: and with the names of so many of their kings, that occurred to their memory in connexion with her, stood still, until others were sent by Cassander to despatch her;
tgt_text.2351: she, at the same time, not shrinking from the sword or the blow, or crying out like a woman, but submitting to death like the bravest of men, and suitably to the glory of her ancient race, so that you might have perceived the soul of Alexander in his dying mother.
tgt_text.2352: As she was expiring, too, she is said to have settled her hair,t and to have covered her feet with her robe, that nothing unseemly might appear about her.
tgt_text.2353: After these events, Cassander married Thessalonice, the daughter of king Aridæus, and sent the son of Alexander.
tgt_text.2354: ‡ with his mother to the citadel of Amphipolis, to be kept under guard.

tgt_text.2360: death of Antigonus, IV.I. PERDICCAS and his brother, with Eumenes and Polysperchon, and other leaders of the opposite party, being killed, the contention among the successors of Alexander seemed to be at an end;
tgt_text.2361: when, on a sudden, a dispute arose among the conquerors themselves;
tgt_text.2362: for Ptolemy, Cassander, and Lysimachus, demanding that “ the money taken amongst the spoil, and the provinces, should be divided," Antigonus said that “ he would admit no partners in the advantages of a war of which he alone had undergone the perils."
tgt_text.2363: And that he might seem to engage in an honourable contest with his confederates, he gave out that “ his object was to avenge the death of Olympia.,;
tgt_text.2364: , who had been murdered by Cassander, and to release the son of Alexander, his king, with his mother, from their confinement at Amphipolis."
tgt_text.2365: On hearing this news, Ptolemy and Cassander, forming an alliance with Lysimachus and Seleucus, made vigorous preparations for war by land and sea.
tgt_text.2366: Ptolemy had possession of Egypt, with the greater part of Africa, Cyprus, and Phœnicia.
tgt_text.2367: Macedonia and Greece were subject to Cassander.
tgt_text.2368: Antigonus had taken possession of Asia and the eastern countries.
tgt_text.2369: Demetrius, the son of Antigonus, was defeated in the first 3ngagement by Ptolemy, at Gamala.*
tgt_text.2370: In this action, the renown gained by Ptolemy for his moderation was greater than that which he obtained from the victory itself;
tgt_text.2371: for he let the friends of Demetrius depart, not only with their baggage, but with presents in addition;
tgt_text.2372: and he restored Demetrius himself all his private property, together with his family, making, at the same time, this honourable declaration, that "he had not engaged in the war for plunder, but for the maintenance of his own character, being indignant that when the leaders of the opposite faction were conquered, Antigonus claimed the fruits of their common victory for himself."
tgt_text.2374: During these transactions, Cassander, returning from Apollonia, fell in with the Antariatæ,* who, having abandoned their country on account of the vast number of frogs and mice that infested it, were seeking a settlement.
tgt_text.2375: Fearing that they might possess themselves of Macedonia, he made a compact with them, received them as allies, and assigned them lands at the extremity of the country.
tgt_text.2376: Afterwards, lest Hercules, the son of Alexander, who had nearly completed his fourteenth year, should be called to the throne Of Macedonia through the influence of his father's name, he sent secret orders that he should be put to death, together with his mother Barsine, and that their bodies should be privately buried in the earth lest the murder should be betrayed by a regular funeral.t
tgt_text.2377: As if, too, he had previously incurred but small guilt, first in the case of the king himself,‡ and afterwards in that of his mother Olympias and her son, he cut off his other son, and his mother Roxane, with similar treachery;
tgt_text.2378: as though he could not obtain the throne of Macedonia, to which he aspired, otherwise than by crime.
tgt_text.2379: Ptolemy meanwhile engaged a second time with Demetrius at sea;
tgt_text.2380: § and, having lost his fleet, and left the victory to the enemy, fled back to Egypt, whither Demetrius sent Leontiscus, the son of Ptolemy, his brother Menelaus, and his friends, with all their baggage, being induced to this act by like kindness previously shown || to himself;
tgt_text.2381: and that it might appear that they were stimulated, not by hatred, but by desire of glory and honour, they vied with one another, even amidst war itself, in kindnesses and services.
tgt_text.2382: So much more honourably were wars then conducted than private friend­ ships are now maintained !
tgt_text.2383: *Antigonus, being elated with this victory, gave orders that he himself, as well as his son Demetrius, should be styled king by the people.
tgt_text.2384: Ptolemy also, that he might not appear of less authority among his subjects, was called king by his army.
tgt_text.2385: Cassander and Lysimachus, too, when they heard of these proceedings, assumed regal dignity themselves.
tgt_text.2386: They all abstained, however, from taking the insignia of royalty, as long as any sons of their king survived.
tgt_text.2387: Such forbearance was there in them, that, though they had the power, they yet contentedly remained without the distinction of kings, while Alexander had a proper heir.
tgt_text.2388: But Ptolemy and Cassander, and the other leaders of the opposite faction, perceiving that they were individually weakened by Antigonus, while each regarded the war, not as the common concern of all, but as merely affecting himself, and all were unwilling to give assistance to one another, as if victory would be only for one, and not for all of them, appointed, after encouraging each other by letters, a time and place for an interview, and prepared for the contest with united strength.
tgt_text.2389: Cassander, being unable to join in it, because of a war near home, despatched Lysimachus to the support of his allies with a large force.
tgt_text.2391: Lysimachus was of a noble family in Macedonia, but was exalted far above any nobility of birth by the proofs which he had given of personal merit, which was so great, that he excelled all those by whom the east was conquered, in great­ ness of mind, in philosophy, and in reputation for prowess.
tgt_text.2392: For when Alexander the Great, in his anger, had pretended that Callisthenes the philosopher, for his opposition to the Persian mode of doing obeisance, was concerned in a plot that had been formed against him, and, by cruelly mangling all his limbs, and cutting off his ears, nose, and lips, had rendered him a shocking and miserable spectacle, and had had him car­ ried about, also, shut up in a cage with a dog, for a terror to others, Lysimachus, who was accustomed to listen to Callis­ thenes, and to receive precepts of virtue from him, took pity an so great a man, undergoing punishment, not for any crime, but for freedom of speech,.
tgt_text.2393: and furnished him with poison to relieve him from his misery.
tgt_text.2394: At this act Alexander was so displeased, that he ordered Lysimachus to be exposed to a fierce lion;
tgt_text.2395: but when the beast, furious at the sight of him, had made a spring towards him, Lysimachus plunged his hand, wrapped in his cloak, into the lion's mouth, and, seizing fast hold of his tongue, killed him.
tgt_text.2396: This exploit being related to the king, his wonder at it ended in pleasure, and he regarded Lysimachus with more affection than before, on account of his extraordinary bravery.
tgt_text.2397: Lysimachus, likewise, endured the in-treatment of the king with magnanimity, as that of a parent.
tgt_text.2398: At last, when all recollection of this affair was effaced from the king's mind, Lysimachus was his only attendant in an excursion through vast heaps of sand, when he was in pursuit of some flying enemies, and had left his guards behind him in consequence of the swiftness of his horse.
tgt_text.2399: His brother Philip,† having previously attempted to do him the same service, had expired in the king's arms.
tgt_text.2400: Alexander, however, as he alighted from his horse, happened to wound Lysimachus in the forehead with the point of his spear, so severely that the blood could not by any means be stopped, till the king, taking off his diadem, placed it on his head by way of closing the wound;
tgt_text.2401: an act which was the first omen of royal dignity to Lysimachus.
tgt_text.2402: And after the death of Alexander, when the provinces were divided among his suc­ cessors, the most warlike nations were assigned to Lysimachus as the bravest of them all;
tgt_text.2403: so far, by general consent, had he the pre-eminence over the rest in military merit.
tgt_text.2405: Before the war with Antigonus was commenced by Ptolemy and his allies, Seleucus, on a sudden, leaving the Greater Asia,‡ came forward as a fresh enemy to Antigonus.
tgt_text.2406: The merit of Seleucus was well known, and his birth had been attended with extraordinary circumstances.
tgt_text.2407: His mother Laodice, being married to Antiochus, a man of eminence among Philip's generals, seemed to herself, in a dream, to nave conceived from a union with Apollo, and, after becoming pregnant, to:
tgt_text.2409: a- reward for her com­ pliance, a. ring, on the stone of which was engraved an anchor, and which she was desired to give to the child that she should bring forth.
tgt_text.2410: A ring similarly engraved, which was found the next day in the bed, and the figure of an anchor, which was visible on the thigh of Seleucus when he was born, made this dream extremely remarkable.
tgt_text.2411: This ring Laodice gave to Seleucus, when he was going with Alexander to the Persian war, informing him, at the same time, of his paternity.
tgt_text.2412: After the death of Alexander, having secured dominion in the east, he built a city, where he established a memorial of- his two­ fold origin;
tgt_text.2413: for he called the city Antioch from the name of his father Antiochus, and consecrated the plains near the city to Apollo.
tgt_text.2414: This mark of his paternity continued also among his descendants;
tgt_text.2415: for his sons and grandsons had an anchor on their thigh;
tgt_text.2416: as a natural proof of their extraction.
tgt_text.2417: After the division of the Macedonian empire among the followers of Alexander, he carried on several wars in the east.
tgt_text.2418: He first took Babylon, and then, his strength being increased by this success, subdued the Bactrians.
tgt_text.2419: He next made an expedition into India;
tgt_text.2420: which, after the death of Alexander, had shaken, as it were, the yoke of servitude from its neck, and put his governors to death.
tgt_text.2421: The author of this liberation was Sandrocottus, who afterwards, however, turned their semblance of liberty into slavery;

tgt_text.2423: This man was of mean origin, but was stimulated to aspire to regal power by supernatural encourage­ ment;
tgt_text.2424: for, having offended Alexander by his boldness of speech, and orders being given to kill him, he saved himseli by swiftness of foot;
tgt_text.2425: and while he was lying asleep, after his fatigue, a lion of great size having come up to him, licked oft with his tongue the sweat that was running from him, and after gently waking him, left him.
tgt_text.2426: Being first prompted by this prodigy to conceive hopes of royal dignity, he drew together a band of robbers, and solicited the Indians to sup­ port his new sovereignty.
tgt_text.2427: Some time after, as he was going to war with the generals of Alexander, a wild elephant -of great bulk presented itself before him of its own accord, and, as if tamed down to gentleness,* took him on its back, and became his guide in the war, and conspicuous in fields of battle.
tgt_text.2428: Sandrocottus, having thus acquired a throne, was in possession of India, when Seleucus was laying the foundations of his future greatness;

tgt_text.2444: The cause of this matricide was that, in the division of the kingdom between the brothers, she seemed to have favoured Alexander.
tgt_text.2445: This deed appeared the more atrocious to every one, as there was no proof of injustice on the part of the mother;
tgt_text.2446: although, indeed, in a case of matricide, no reason can be alleged sufficient to justify the crime.
tgt_text.2447: Alexander, in consequence, resolving to go to war with his brother, to avenge his mothers death, solicited aid from Demetrius;
tgt_text.2448: and Demetrius, in hopes of seizing the throne of Macedonia, made no delay in complying with his request.
tgt_text.2449: Lysimachus, alarmed at his approach, persuaded Antipater, his son-in-law, rather to be reconciled to his brother than to allow his father's enemy to enter Macedonia.
tgt_text.2450: Demetrius, therefore, finding that a reconciliation was commenced between the brothers, removed Alexander by treachery, and, having seized on the throne of Macedonia, called an assembly of the army, to defend himself before them for the murder.
tgt_text.2451: He alleged that " his life had been first attempted by Alexander, and that he had not contrived treachery, but prevented it;
tgt_text.2452: and that he himself was the more rightful king of Macedonia, both from experience attendant on greater age, and from other con siderations;
tgt_text.2453: for that his father * had been a follower of king Philip, and of Alexander the Great, in the whole of their wars, and afterwards an attendant on the children of Alexander, and a leader in the punishment of the revellers.
tgt_text.2454: That Anti pater, on the other hand, the grandfather of these young men, had always been more cruel as the governor of the kingdom than the kings themselves;
tgt_text.2455: and that Cassander, their father, had been the extirpator of the king's family, sparing neither women nor children, and not resting till he bad cut off the whole of the royal house.
tgt_text.2456: That vengeance for these crimes, as he could not exact it from Cassander himself, had been inflicted on his children;
tgt_text.2457: and that accordingly Philip and Alexander, if the dead have any knowledge of human affairs, would not wish the murderers of them and their issue, but their avengers, to fill the throne of Macedonia."
tgt_text.2458: The people being pacified by these arguments, he was saluted king of Macedonia.
tgt_text.2459: Lysimachus, too, being pressed with a war with Doricetes, king of Thrace, and not wishing to have to fight with Demetrius at the same time, made peace with him, resigning into his hands the other half of Macedonia, which had fallen to the share of his son-in-law Antipater.
tgt_text.2461: When Demetrius, therefore, supported by the whole strength of Macedonia, was preparing to invade Asia, Ptolemy, Seleucus, and Lysimachus, having experienced in the former contest how great the power of unanimity was, formed an alliance a second time, and having joined their forces, carried the war against Demetrius, it to Europe.
tgt_text.2462: With these leaders Pyrrhus, king of Epirus, united himself, as a friend and sharer in the war, hoping that Demetrius might lose Mace donia not less easily than he had obtained it.
tgt_text.2464: for he himself, having corrupted Deme trius's army, and put him to flight, seized on the throne of Macedonia.
tgt_text.2465: During the course of these transactions, Lysimachus put to death his son-in-law Antipater, who complained that he had been deprived of the throne of Macedonia by the treachery of his father-in-law, and put his daughter Eurydice, who had joined with him in his complaints, into prison ;
tgt_text.2466: and thus the whole house of Cassander made atonement to Alexander the Great, whether for killing himself or destroying his offspring, partly by violent deaths, partly by other sufferings, and partly by shedding the blood of one another.
tgt_text.2467: Demetrius, surrounded by so many armies, preferred, when he might have fallen honourably, to make an ignominious surrender to Seleucus.
tgt_text.2468: At the termination of the war died Ptolemy, after having attained great glory by his military exploits.
tgt_text.2469: Contrary to the custom among nations, he had resigned his kingdom, before his illness, to the youngest of .his sons, and had stated his reasons for that proceeding to the people, who showed themselves no less indulgent in accepting the son for their king than the father had proved himself in delivering the kingdom to him.
tgt_text.2470: Among other instances of mutual affection between the father and the son, the following had procured the young man favour from the people, that the father, having publicly resigned the throne to him, had done duty as a private soldier among his guards, thinking it more honour to be the father of a king than to possess any kingdom whatsoever.
tgt_text.2472: But the evil of discord, constantly arising among equals, had produced a war between Lysimachus and King Pyrrhus, who had just before been allies against Demetrius.
tgt_text.2473: Lysimachus, gaining the advantage, had expelled Pyrrhus, and made himself master of Macedonia.
tgt_text.2474: He then made war on Thrace, and afterwards on Heraclea, a city of which the origin and the subsequent fortunes were objects of wonder;
tgt_text.2475: for when the Bœotians were suffering from a pestilence, the oracle at Delphi had told them, that " they must plant a colony in the country of Pontus, dedicated to Hercules But as, through dread of a long and dangerous voyage, and all the people preferring death in their own country, the matter was neglected, the Phocians made war upon them;
tgt_text.2476: and after suffering from unsuccessful struggles with that people, they had recourse to the oracle a second time.
tgt_text.2477: The answer which they received was, that " what was a remedy for the pestilence would also be a remedy for the war."
tgt_text.2478: Raising therefore a body of colonists, and sailing to Pontus, they built the city Heraclea ;
tgt_text.2479: and as they had been led to that settlement by the guidance of fate, they soon acquired great power.
tgt_text.2480: In process of time the city had many wars with its neighbours, and many dissensions among its own people.
tgt_text.2481: Among other noble acts that they performed, the following is one of the most remarkable.
tgt_text.2482: When the Athenians were at the height of power, and, after the overthrow of the Persians, had imposed a tax on Greece and Asia for the support of a fleet, and when all were promptly contributing to the main­ tenance of their safety, the Heracleans alone, from friendship for the kings of Persia, refused to pay.
tgt_text.2483: Lamachus was accordingly despatched by the Athenians with an army to exact from them what was withheld ;
tgt_text.2484: but leaving his ships on the coast, and going to ravage the lands of the Heracleans, he lost his fleet, with the greater part of his army, by shipwreck, in a tempest that came on suddenly.
tgt_text.2486: therefore, to return by sea, from having lost his ships, and did not dare, with so small a body of men, to return by land through so many warlike nations, the Heracleans, thinking this a more honourable opportunity for kindness than for revenge, sent the invaders away with a supply of provisions and troops to protect them ;
tgt_text.2487: deeming the devastation of their lands no loss, if they could but make those their friends who had formerly been their enemies.
tgt_text.2489: Among many other evils they endured also that of tyranny;
tgt_text.2490: for when, on the populace violently clamouring for an abolition of debts, and a division of the lands of the rich, the subject was long discussed in the senate, and no settle­ ment of it was devised, they at last sought assistance against the commons, who were grown riotous by too long idleness, from Timotheus general of the Athenians, and afterwards from EDaminondas general of the Thebans.
tgt_text.2491: As both, however, refused their request, they had recourse tc Clearchus, whom they themselves had exiled ;
tgt_text.2492: such being tho urgency of their distresses, that they recalled to the guardian ship of his country him whom they had forbidden to enter his country.
tgt_text.2493: But Clearchus, being rendered more desperate by his banishment, and regarding the dissension among the people as a means of securing to himself the government, first sought a secret interview with Mithridates,* the enemy of his countrymen, and made a league with him on the understanding that when he was re-established in his country, he should, on betraying the city into his hands, be made lieutenant-governor of it.
tgt_text.2494: But the treachery which he had conceived against his countrymen, he afterwards turned against Mithridates himself;
tgt_text.2495: for on returning from banishment, to be as it were the arbiter of the disputes in the city, he, at the time appointed for delivering the town to Mithridates, made Mithridates himself prisoner, with a party of his friends, and released him from captivity only on the receipt of a large sum of money.
tgt_text.2496: And as, in this case, he suddenly changed himself from a friend into an enemy, so, in regard to his countrymen, he soon, from a supporter of the senate's cause, became a patron of the common people, and not only inflamed the populace against those who had conferred his power upon him, and by whom he had been recalled into his country and established in the citadel, but even exercised upon his benefactors the most atrocious inflictions of tyrannic cruelty.
tgt_text.2497: Summoning the people to an assembly, he declared that " he would no longer support the senate in their proceedings against the populace, but would even interpose his authority, if they persisted in their former severities;
tgt_text.2498: and that, if the people thought themselves able to check the tyranny of the senate, he would retire with his soldiers, and take no further part in their dissensions ;
tgt_text.2499: but that, if they distrusted their ability to make resistance, he would not be wanting to aid them in taking revenge.
tgt_text.2500: They might therefore," he added, " deter­ mine among themselves;
tgt_text.2501: they might bid him withdraw, if they pleased, or might request him to stay as a sharer in the popular cause."
tgt_text.2502: The people, induced by these fair speeches, conferred on him the supreme authority, and, while they were incensed at the power of the senate, surrendered them selves, with their wives and children, as slaves to the power of a single tyrant.
tgt_text.2503: Clearchus then apprehended sixty senators (the rest had taken flight), and threw them into prison.
tgt_text.2504: The people rejoiced that the senate was overthrown, and especially that it had fallen by means of a leader among the senators, and that, by a reverse of fortune, their support was turned to their destruction.
tgt_text.2505: Clearchus, by threatening all his prisoners with death, made the price offered for their ransom the higher;
tgt_text.2506: and, after receiving from them large sums of money, as if he would secretly withdraw them from the violence threatened by the people, despoiled those of their lives whom he had previously despoiled of their fortunes.
tgt_text.2508: Learning, soon after, that war was prepared against him by those who had made their escape (several cities being moved by pity to espouse their cause), he gave freedom to their slaves;
tgt_text.2509: and that no affliction might be wanting to distress the most honourable families, he obliged their wives and daughters to marry their slaves, threatening death to such as refused, that he might thus render the slaves more attached to himself, and less reconcileable to their masters.
tgt_text.2510: But such marriages were more intolerable to the women than immediate death;
tgt_text.2511: and many, in consequence, killed themselves before the nuptial rites were celebrated, and many in the midst of them, first killing their new husbands, and delivering themselves from dishonourable sufferings by a spirit of noble virtue.
tgt_text.2512: A battle was then fought, in which the tyrant, being victorious, dragged such of the senators as he took prisoners before the faces of their countrymen in triumph.
tgt_text.2513: Returning into the city, he threw some into prison, stretched others on the rack, and put others to death;
tgt_text.2514: and not a place in the city was unvisited by the tyrants cruelty.
tgt_text.2515: Arrogance was added to severity, insolence to inhumanity.
tgt_text.2516: From a course of continued good fortune, he sometimes forgot that he was a man, sometimes called himself the son of Jupiter.
tgt_text.2517: When he appeared in public, a golden eagle, as a token of his parentage, was carried before him;
tgt_text.2518: he wore a purple robe, buskins like kings in tragedies, and a crown of gold.
tgt_text.2519: His son he named Ceraunos,* to mock the gods, not only with false statements, but with impious names.
tgt_text.2520: Two noble youths, Chion and Leonides, incensed that he should dare to commit such outrages, and desiring to deliver their country, formed a conspiracy to put him to death
tgt_text.2521: They were disciples of Plato the philosopher, and being desirous to exhibit to their country the virtue in which they were daily instructed by the precepts of their master, placed fifty of their relations, as if they were their attendants, in am.
tgt_text.2523: while they themselves, in the character of men who had a dispute to be settled, went into the citadel to the tyrant..
tgt_text.2524: Gaining admission, as being well known, the tyrant, while he was listening attentively to the one that spoke first, was killed by the other.
tgt_text.2525: But as their accomplices were too late in coming to their support, they were overpowered by the guards;
tgt_text.2526: and hence it happened that though the tyrant was killed, their country was not liberated.
tgt_text.2527: Satyrus, the brother of Clearchus, made himself tyrant in a similar way;
tgt_text.2528: and for many years, with various successive changes, the Heracleans continued under the yoke of tyrants.

tgt_text.2535: ABOUT the same time there was an earthquake in the regions round the Hellespont and the Chersonese;
tgt_text.2536: t but the chief effect of it was, that the city of Lysimachia, founded two and twenty years before by king Lysimachus, was sunk in ruins;
tgt_text.2537: a prodigy which portended disasters to Lysimachus and his family, destruction to his kingdom, and calamity to the disturbed provinces.
tgt_text.2538: Nor was fulfilment wanting to these omens ;
tgt_text.2539: for, in a short time after, conceiving towards his son Agathocles (whom he had appointed to succeed him on the throne, and through whose exertions he had managed several wars with success), a hatred unnatural in him not only as a father but as a man, he took him off by poison, using as his agent in this affair his step-mother Arsinoë.
tgt_text.2540: This was the first commence­ ment of his calamities, the prelude to approaching ruin;
tgt_text.2541: for executions of several great men were added to the murder of his son, who were put to death for expressing concern at the young prince's fate;
tgt_text.2542: and, in consequence, both those about the court who escaped this cruelty, and those who were in command of the troops, began at once to desert to Seleucus, and incite him to make war upon Lysimachus;
tgt_text.2543: an enterprise to which he was already inclined from a desire to emulate his glory.
tgt_text.2544: This was the last contest between the fellow soldiers of Alexander;
tgt_text.2545: and the two combatants were reserved, as it were, for an example of the influence of fortune.
tgt_text.2548: But at this age they both had the fire of youth, and an insatiable desire of power;
tgt_text.2549: for though they alone possessed the whole world,* they yet thought themselves confined within narrow limits, and measured their course of life, not by their length of years, but by the extent to which they carried their dominion.
tgt_text.2551: In this war, Lysimachus (who had previously lost, by various chances of fortune, fifteen children) died, with no small bravery, and crowned the ruin of his family.
tgt_text.2552: Seleucus, overjoyed at such a triumph, and what he thought greater than the triumph, that he alone survived of all Alexander's staff,† the conqueror of conquerors, boasted that " this was not the work of man, but a favour from the gods," little think­ ing that he himself was shortly after to be an instance of human instability;
tgt_text.2553: for in the course of about seven months, he was treacherously surprised by Ptolemy,‡ whose sister Lysimachus had married, and put to death, losing the king dom of Macedonia, which he had taken from Lysimachus.
tgt_text.2555: Ptolemy, being ambitious to please his subjects, both for the honour of the memory of the great Ptolemy his father, and for the sake of palliating the revenge which he had taken on behalf of Lysimachus, resolved, in the first place, to con ciliate the sons of Lysimachus, and sought a marriage with their mother Arsinoë, his sister,.
tgt_text.2556: promising to adopt the young men, so that, when he should succeed to the throne of their father, they might not venture, through respect for their mother, or the influence of the name of father, to attempt anything against him.
tgt_text.2557: He solicited, too, by letter, the friendship of his brother the king of Egypt, professing that " he laid aside all feelings of resentment at being deprived of his fathers kingdom, and that he would no longer ask that from a brother which he had more honourably obtained from his father's enemy."†
tgt_text.2558: He also in every way flattered Nicomedes,‡ that as he was about to have a war with Antigonus, the son of De­ metrius, and Antiochus the son of Seleucus, he might not come upon him as a third enemy.
tgt_text.2559: Nor was Pyrrhus of Epirus, neglected by him, a king who would be of great assistance to whichsoever side he attached himself, and who, while he desired to spoil them one by one, sought the favour of all.
tgt_text.2560: On going to assist the Tarentines, therefore, against the Romans, he desired of Antigonus the loan of vessels to trans­ port his army into Italy;
tgt_text.2561: of Antiochus, who was better provided with wealth than with men, a sum of money ;
tgt_text.2562: and of Ptolemy, some troops of Macedonian soldiers.
tgt_text.2563: Ptolemy, who had no excuse for holding back for want of forces, supplied him with five thousand infantry, four thousand cavalry, and fifty ele­ phants, but for not more than two years' service.
tgt_text.2564: In return for this favour, Pyrrhus, after marrying the daughter of Ptolemy, appointed him guardian of his kingdom in his absence;
tgt_text.2565: lest, on carrying the flower of his army into Italy, he should leave his dominions a prey to his enemies.
tgt_text.2567: But since I have come to speak of Epirus,§ a few particulars should be premised concerning the rise of that kingdom.
tgt_text.2568: The first regal power in this country was that of the Molossi.
tgt_text.2569: Afterwards Pyrrhus, the son of Achilles, having been deprived of his father's dominions - during his absence in the Trojan war, settled in these parts;
tgt_text.2570: the inhabitants of which were first called Pyrrhidæ, and afterwards Epirots.
tgt_text.2571: This Pyrrhus, going to the temple of Jupiter at Dodona to consult the oracle, seized there by force Lanassa, the grand­ daughter of Hercules, and by a marriage with her had eight children.
tgt_text.2572: Of his daughters he gave some in marriage to the neighbouring princes, and by means of these alliances acquired great power.
tgt_text.2573: He gave to Helenus,t the son of King Priam, for his eminent services, the kingdom of the Chaonians, and Andromache the widow of Hector in marriage, after she had been his own wife, he having received her at the division of the Trojan spoil.
tgt_text.2574: Shortly after he was slain at Delphi, at the very altar of Apollo, by the treachery of Orestes the son of Agamemnon.
tgt_text.2575: His successor was his son Pielus.
tgt_text.2576: The throne afterwards passed in regular descent to Arrybas, over whom, as he was an orphan, and the only survivor of a noble family, guardians were publicly appointed, the concern of all being so much the greater to preserve and educate him.
tgt_text.2577: He was also sent to Athens for the sake of instruction;
tgt_text.2578: and, as he was more learned than his predecessors, so he became more popular with his subjects.
tgt_text.2579: He was the first, accordingly, that established laws, a senate, annual magistrates, and a regular form of government;
tgt_text.2580: and as a settlement was found for the people by Pyrrhus, so a more civilized way of life was introduced by Arrybas.
tgt_text.2581: A son of this king was Neoptolemus, the father of Olympias (mother of Alexander the great), and of Alexander, who occupied the throne of Epirus after him, and died in Italy in a war with the Bruttii.
tgt_text.2582: On the death of Alexander his brother Æacides became king, who, by wearying his people with constant wars against the Macedonians, incurred their dislike, and was in consequence driven into exile, leaving his little son Pyrrhus, about two years old.
tgt_text.2584: The child, too, being sought for by the populace to be put to death, through their hatred to the father, was concealed and carried off into lllyricum, and delivered to Beroë, who was the wife of king Glaucias, and of the family of the AEacidae, to be brought up.
tgt_text.2585: This king, moved either by pity for the boys misfortunes, or by his infantine caresses, protected him for a long time against Cassander, king of Macedonia, (who demanded him with menaces of war,) having the kindness also to adopt him for his better security.
tgt_text.2586: The Epirots, being moved by these acts, and turning their hatred into pity, brought him back, when he was eleven years old, into the kingdom, appointing him guardians to keep the throne for him till he became of age.
tgt_text.2587: When he grew up he engaged in many wars, and, by a train of success, attained such eminence as a leader, that he was the only man who was thought capable of defending the Tarentines against the RomansWar of Pyrrhus with the Romans, I.—The Romans refuse aid from Carthage;
