tgt_text.3053: History and character of Hiero, IV.I. AGATHOCLES, sovereign of Sicily, having concluded a peace with the Carthaginians, reduced, by force of arms, a part of the cities which, presuming upon their strength, had thrown off their allegiance to him.
tgt_text.3054: Then, as if he were confined within too narrow limits in an island (a part of the dominion of which, even when he first began to rise, he could scarcely have hoped to obtain), he proceeded, after the example of Dionysius,* who had subdued many cities of Italy, to cross over into that country.
tgt_text.3055: His first enemies there were the Bruttii, who, at that period, seem to have been the bravest and most powerful people of the country, and to have been extremely ready to attack their neighbours;
tgt_text.3056: for they had driven the inhabitants of many of the Greek cities from Italy, and had conquered in war the Lucanians their founders, and made peace with them on equal terms;
tgt_text.3057: such being the fierce­ ness of their nature, that they had no respect even for those to whom they owed their origin.
tgt_text.3058: The Lucanians were accustomed to breed up their children with the same kind of education as the Spartans;
tgt_text.3059: for, from their earliest boyhood, they were kept in the wilds among the shepherds, without any slaves to attend them, and even with­ out clothes t to wear or to sleep upon, that, from their first years, they might be accustomed to hardiness and spare diet, having no intercourse with the city.
tgt_text.3060: Their food was what they took in hunting, and their drink milk or water.
tgt_text.3061: Thus were they prepared for the toils of war.
tgt_text.3062: Fifty of these people, who, at first, used to plunder the lands of their neighbours, but who, as numbers flocked to join them, increased in strength, and were tempted by hopes of greater booty, disturbed the whole of the neighbouring coun­ try ;
tgt_text.3063: and Dionysius, the tyrant of Sicily, being wearied with complaints from his allies, had sent six hundred Africans to put a stop to their ravages.
tgt_text.3064: But the marauders, having seized a fort which the Africans had built, and which was betrayed into their hands by a woman named Bruttia, proceeded to build a city there for the shepherds, who, at the report of a new settlement, came in numbers to join them ;
tgt_text.3065: and, from the name of the woman, they called themselves Bruttii.
tgt_text.3066: Their first war was with the Lucanians, from whom tney sprung.
tgt_text.3067: Encouraged by a victory over them, and making peace on equal terms, they subdued the rest of their neigh­ bours by force of arms, and acquired, in a short time, such extraordinary strength, that they were thought formidable even by princes.
tgt_text.3068: After some time, Alexander, king of Epi­ rus,* coming into Italy with a great army to the aid of the Greek cities, was cut off by them with all his force;
tgt_text.3069: and their natural fierceness, increased by this success, was for a long time terrible to all around them.
tgt_text.3070: At last Agathocles, being importuned to come over, set sail, with the hope of enlarging his dominions, from Sicily to Italy.
tgt_text.3072: At the first news of his arrival, the Bruttii, alarmed at his name, sent ambassadors to solicit alliance and friendship with him.
tgt_text.3073: Agathocles, inviting them to an entertainment, that they might not see his army shipped over, and ap­ pointing the next day for giving them audience, went off immediately after the banquet in a vessel, and left them in the lurch.
tgt_text.3074: But what followed this deceit was unhappy for him;
tgt_text.3075: for the violence of a disease t which he contracted obliged him a few days after to return to Sicily.
tgt_text.3076: Being affected by the distemper through his whole body, and a pestilential humour spreading through all his nerves and joints, he was tormented, as it were, by an intestine war among all his members.
tgt_text.3077: As his life was despaired of, a contention arose between his son and grandson, each claiming the right of succession to his power as if he were already dead;
tgt_text.3078: and the grandson, after killing the son, got possession of the supreme dignity.
tgt_text.3079: Aga­ thocles, therefore, when the pain of his disease and his anxiety of mind were grown intolerable, the one being increased by the severity of the other, resolved on embarking his wife Texena, and two infant sons.
tgt_text.3080: that he had by her, with all his treasure, and servants, and regal furniture (in which no king at that time was richer), and sending her back to Egypt, from whence he had received her, fearing that they would find the usurper of his power their enemy.
tgt_text.3081: His wife, however, long entreated that she might not be separated from her sick husband, that the affliction of her departure might not be added to the atrocities of his grandson, and that she might not be made to appear as cruel in forsaking her husband as he in attacking his grandfather;
tgt_text.3082: saying that, " by marrying him, she not only engaged to share his good fortune, but all his fortune;
tgt_text.3083: nor would she unwillingly purchase, with the hazard of her own life, the privilege of receiving her husband's last breath, and of performing, with all the care of conjugal duty and affection, the last offices at his funeral, which, when she was gone, no one would take upon himself to discharge."
tgt_text.3084: The little children, at parting, embraced and clung to their father with doleful lamentations ;
tgt_text.3085: while the wife, who was to see her husband no more, could not desist from kissing him.
tgt_text.3086: Nor were the tears of the old man less moving ;
tgt_text.3087: the children wept for their dying father, the father for his banished children.
tgt_text.3088: They bewailed the forlorn condition of their parent, a sick old man ;
tgt_text.3089: he lamented that his offspring, born to the prospect of a throne, should be left in want.
tgt_text.3090: At the same time the whole palace resounded with the cries of those who were witnesses to so cruel a separation.
tgt_text.3091: The necessity for departure, however, at length put a stop to their weeping, and the death of the prince followed the leave-taking of his children.
tgt_text.3092: During these occurrences, the Carthaginians, learning the state of affairs in Sicily, and thinking that an opportunity was afforded them of securing the whole island, crossed over to it with a great force, and reduced several cities.
tgt_text.3094: At this time, too, Pyrrhus was engaged in a war with the Romans, and, being entreated by the Sicilians, as has been said, to come to their assistance,.
tgt_text.3095: and crossing, in consequence, over to Syracuse, and taking several cities, received the title of king of Sicily as well as of Epirus.
tgt_text.3096: Elated by this success, he destined for his son Helenus the kingdom of Sicily, as an inheritance from his grandfather (for he was the son of Agathocles's daughter), and to Alexander that of Italy.
tgt_text.3097: He then fought many successful battles with the Carthaginians;
tgt_text.3098: but, after a time, ambassadors came to him from his Italian allies, announcing that “ they could no longer withstand the Romans, and that, unless he gave them assistance, they must submit."
tgt_text.3099: Alarmed at this danger from another quarter, and uncertain what to do, or whither first to direct his efforts, he took time, while he was in suspense between the two, for consideration.
tgt_text.3100: As the Carthaginians threatened him on one side, and the Romans on the other, it seemed hazardous not to transport a force into Italy, and more hazardous to withdraw troops from Sicily, lest the one should be lost by not receiving assistance, or the other by being deserted.
tgt_text.3101: In this conflict of perils, the safer determination seemed to be, to bring the struggle to an end, by exerting his utmost strength in Sicily, and then, after having subdued the Carthaginians, to carry his victorious army into Italy.
tgt_text.3103: but, though he had the advantage, yet, as he quitted Sicily, he seemed to flee as one defeated;
tgt_text.3104: and his allies, in consequence, revolted from him, and he lost his dominion in Sicily as speedily and easily as he had obtained it.
tgt_text.3105: Experiencing no better success in Italy, he returned to Epirus.
tgt_text.3106: His fortune, indeed, good and bad, was wonderful for the examples which it gave of both.
tgt_text.3107: For as, at first, his good fortune, when his attempts succeeded even beyond his wishes, had procured him empire in Italy and Sicily, and so many victories over the Romans;
tgt_text.3108: so now his adverse fortune, overthrowing all that he had raised, as if to afford an illustra­ tion of human instability, added to his failure in Sicily the destruction of his fleet at sea, loss of honour in a battle with the Romans, and an ignominious retreat out of Italy.
tgt_text.3110: When Pyrrhus had withdrawn from Sicily, Hiero was made governor of it;
tgt_text.3111: and such was the prudence he displayed in his office, that, by the unanimous consent of all the cities, he was first made general against the Carthaginians, and soon after king.
tgt_text.3112: The fortune of Hiero, in his infancy, had been as it were a presage of his future dignity.
tgt_text.3113: He was the son of Hierocles, a man of high rank, whose descent was traced from Gelo an ancient prince of Sicily.
tgt_text.3114: His extraction on the mothers side, however, was so mean as to be even dishonour­ able ;
tgt_text.3115: for he was the child of a female slave, and was in consequence exposed by his father as a disgrace to his family.
tgt_text.3116: But, when he was thus left destitute of human aid, bees for several days fed him with honey, which was heaped round him as he lay.
tgt_text.3117: Hence his father, admonished by a com­ munication from the soothsayers, who signified that sovereign power was foreboded to the infant, took him home again, and brought him up most carefully with the hope that he would attain the promised honour.
tgt_text.3118: As he was learning his lesson at school, too, among his equals in age, a wolf, that suddenly appeared in the midst of the boys, snatched from him his book.
tgt_text.3119: And when he was grown up, and commencing his first campaign, an eagle settled on his shield, and an owl upon his spear;
tgt_text.3120: a prodigy which indicated that he would be prudent in counsel, active in the field, and a king.
tgt_text.3121: He fought frequently, moreover, with persons that challenged him, and always gained the victory;
tgt_text.3122: and he was presented by king Pyrrhus with many military gifts.
tgt_text.3123: The handsomeness of his person was remarkable, and his bodily strength wonderful.
tgt_text.3124: He was affable in his address, just in his dealings, moderate in command ;
tgt_text.3125: so that nothing kingly seemed wanting to him but a kingdom.

tgt_text.3136: DURING the course of these proceedings in Sicily, the kings, Ptolemy Ceraunus* and Antigonus, quarrelling and going to war with one another in Greece, almost all the cities of that country, under the Spartans as leaders, encouraged as it were by the opportunity thus offered to entertain hopes of recovering their liberty, and sending to each other ambassadors by whom leagues might be formed to unite them, broke out into hostilities;
tgt_text.3137: and, that they might not seem to commence war with Antigonus, under whose dominion they were, they attacked his allies the Ætolians, making it a pretext for war with them, that they had taken possession of the Cirrhæan plain, which by the unanimous consent of Greece had been dedicated to Apollo.
tgt_text.3138: For their general in this war they selected Areus, who, drawing together an army, laid waste the towns and corn-fields lying in the plain, and burnt whatever he was unable to carry off.
tgt_text.3139: When the shepherds of the Ætolians beheld this destruction from their mountains, about five hundred of them assembling together, attacked the enemy as they were dispersed, and knew not what was the number of their assailants (for the sudden alarm, and the smoke of the fires, prevented them from ascertaining), and having killed about nine thousand t of the depredators, put the rest to flight.
tgt_text.3140: And when the Spartans afterwards renewed the war, many of the states refused them their support, thinking that they sought dominion for themselves, and not liberty for Greece.
tgt_text.3141: In the meantime the war between the princes that contended for the throne of Macedonia was concluded, for Ptolemy, having routed Antigonus and made himself master of the whole country, arranged a peace with Antiochus, and contracted an affinity with Pyrrhus by giving him his daughter in marriage.
tgt_text.3143: Having thus freed himself from the fear of foreign enemies, he turned his impious and unprincipled mind to the perpetration of wickedness at home, and contrived a plot against his sister Arsinoë,* to deprive her sons of life, and herself of the possession of the city of Cassandrea.
tgt_text.3144: His first stratagem was to pretend love to his sister, and to seek her hand in marriage, for he was unable to come at his sister's sons, whose throne he had usurped, otherwise than by counterfeiting affection for their mother.
tgt_text.3145: But the criminal intentions of Ptolemy were understood by his sister.
tgt_text.3146: As she expressed distrust of him, therefore, he assured her that “ he wished to share the kingdom with her children, against whom he had not taken arms because he wished to wrest the kingdom from them, but that he might have it in his power to present them with a portion of it.
tgt_text.3147: She might therefore send a person to receive an oath from him, in whose presence he would bind himself, before the gods of their country, by whatever execrations she pleased."
tgt_text.3148: Arsinoë, not knowing what to do, was afraid that if she sent any one, she would be deceived by a false oath, and that, if she did not send, she would provoke her brother's fury and cruelty.
tgt_text.3149: Fearing, therefore, less for herself than her children, whom she thought she might protect by the marriage, she sent Dion, one of her friends, to him.
tgt_text.3150: Ptolemy, after conducting him into the most sacred temple of Jupiter, held in high veneration from of old among the Mace­ donians, took hold of the altar, and, touching the images and couches of the gods, vowed, with unheard-of and most solemn imprecations, that “ he sought a marriage with his sister in true sincerity, and that he would give her the title of Queen, nor would, to her dishonour, have any other wife, or any other children than her sons."
tgt_text.3151: Arsinoë, being thus filled with hope, and relieved from apprehensions, held a conference with her brother in person, and as his looks and flattering glances promised no less sincerity than his oath, she agreed to marry him, though her son Lysimachus* exclaimed that " there was treachery at the bottom."
tgt_text.3153: The nuptials were celebrated with great magnificence and general rejoicings.
tgt_text.3154: Ptolemy, before the assembled army, placed a diadem on his sister's head, and saluted her with the title of Queen.
tgt_text.3155: Arsinoë, overjoyed at the name, as having regained what she had lost by the death of Lysimachus her former husband, invited Ptolemy to her city Cassandrea;
tgt_text.3156: to get possession of which city the plot was laid.
tgt_text.3157: Going thither before her husband, she appointed a festival in the city against his arrival, ordering the houses, temples, and all other places, to be magnificently decorated, altars and victims to be every­ where kept in readiness, and her sons, Lysimachus who was sixteen years old, and Philip three years younger, both remark­ able for their comeliness, to go to meet him with crowns on their heads.
tgt_text.3158: Ptolemy, to conceal his treachery, caressing them with eagerness, and beyond the warmth of real affection, persisted for a long time in kissing them.
tgt_text.3159: But as soon as he arrived at the gate, he ordered the citadel to be seized, and the boys to be slain.
tgt_text.3160: They, fleeing to their mother, were slain upon her lap, as she was embracing them;
tgt_text.3161: while Arsinoë ex­ claimed, “ What monstrous crime had she committed, † either in marrying or since her marriage?”
tgt_text.3162: She several times offered herself to the assassins in the room of her children, and, em­ bracing them, covered their bodies with her own, endeavouring to receive the wounds intended for them.
tgt_text.3163: At last, deprived even of the dead bodies of her sons, she was dragged out of the city, with her garments torn and her hair dishevelled, and with only two attendants, and went to live in exile in Samothracia ;
tgt_text.3164: sorrowing the more, that she was not allowed to die with her children.
tgt_text.3165: But the crimes of Ptolemy were not unpunished;
tgt_text.3166: for soon after (the immortal gods inflicting vengeance on him for so many perjuries, and such cruel murders), he was driven from his throne and taken prisoner by the Gauls, and lost his life, as he had merited, by the sword.
tgt_text.3168: The Gauls, when the land that had produced them was unable, from their excessive increase of population, to contain them, sent out three hundred thousand men, as a sacred spring, ‡ to seek new settlements.
tgt_text.3169: Of these adventurers part settled in Italy, and took and burnt the city of Rome;
tgt_text.3170: and part penetrated into the remotest parts of Illyricum under the direction of a flight of birds (for the Gauls are skilled in augury beyond other nations), making their way amidst great slaughter of the barbarous tribes, and fixed their abode in Pannonia.
tgt_text.3171: They were a savage, bold, and warlike nation, and were the first after Hercules (to whom that undertaking procured great admiration for his valour, and a belief in his immortality), to pass the unconquered heights of the Alps, and places uninhabitable from excess of cold.
tgt_text.3172: After having subdued the Pannonians, they carried on various wars with their neighbours for many years.
tgt_text.3173: Success encouraging them, they betook themselves, in separate bands, some to Greece, and some to Macedonia, laying waste all before them with the sword.
tgt_text.3174: Such indeed was the terror of the Gallic name, that even kings, before they were attacked, purchased peace from them with large sums of money.
tgt_text.3175: Ptolemy alone, the king of Macedonia, heard of the approach of the Gauls without alarm, and, hurried on by the madness that distracted him for his unnatural crimes, went out to meet them with a few undisciplined troops, as if wars could be despatched with as little difficulty as murders.
tgt_text.3176: An embassy from the Dar­ danians, offering him twenty thousand armed men for his assistance, he spurned, adding insulting language, and saying that "the Macedonians were in a sad condition, if, after having subdued the whole east without assistance, they now required aid from the Dardanians to defend their country ;
tgt_text.3177: and that he had for soldiers the sons of those who had served under Alexander the Great, and had been victorious throughout the world."
tgt_text.3178: This answer being related to the Dardanian prince, he observed that “ the famous kingdem of Macedonia would soon fall a sacrifice to the rashneso of a raw youth."*V. The Gauls, under the command of Belgius, sent depu. ties to Ptolemy to sound the disposition of the Macedonians, offering him peace if he liked to purchase it;
tgt_text.3179: but Ptolemy boasted to his courtiers that the Gauls sued for peace from fear of war.
tgt_text.3180: Nor was his manner less vaunting before the ambassadors than before his own adherents, saying that “ he would grant peace only on condition that they would give their chiefs as hostages, and deliver up their arms;
tgt_text.3181: for he would put no trust in them until they were disarmed.
tgt_text.3182: It The do puties bringing back this answer, the Gauls laughed, and exclaimed throughout their camp, that " he would soon see whether they had offered peace from regard for themselves or for him."
tgt_text.3183: Some days after a battle was fought, and the Macedonians were defeated and cut to pieces.
tgt_text.3184: Ptolemy, after receiving several wounds, was taken, and his head, cut off and stuck on a lance, was carried round the whole army to strike terror into the enemy.
tgt_text.3185: Flight saved a few of the Macedo­ nians ;
tgt_text.3186: the rest were either taken or slain.
tgt_text.3187: When the news of this event was spread through all Mace­ donia, the gates of the city were shut, and all places filled with mourning.
tgt_text.3188: Sometimes they lamented their bereavement, from the loss of their children ;
tgt_text.3189: sometimes they were seized with dread, lest their cities should be destroyed;
tgt_text.3190: and at other times they called on the names of their kings, Alexander and Philip, as deities, to protect them;
tgt_text.3191: saying that “ under them they were not only secure, but conquerors of the world ;
tgt_text.3192: " and begging that " they would guard their country, whose fame they had raised to heaven by the glory of their exploits, and give assistance to the afflicted, whom the insanity and rashness of Ptolemy had ruined."
tgt_text.3193: While all were thus in despair, Sosthenes, one of the Macedonian chiefs, thinking that nothing would be effected by prayers, assembled such as were of age for war, repulsed the Gauls in the midst of their exultation at their victory, and saved Macedonia from devastation.
tgt_text.3194: For these great services, he, though of humble extraction, was chosen before many nobles that aspired to the throne of Macedonia.
tgt_text.3195: But though he was saluted as king by the army, he made the soldiers take an oath to him, not as king, but as general.
tgt_text.3197: In the meantime Brennus, under whose command a part of the Gauls had made an irruption into Greece, having heard of the success of their countrymen, who, under the leadership of Belgius, had defeated the Macedonians, and being indignant that so rich a booty, consisting of the spoils of the east, had been so lightly abandoned, assembled an army of a hundred and fifty thousand foot and fifteen thousand horse, and suddenly invaded Macedonia.
tgt_text.3198: As he was laying waste the fields and villages, Sosthenes met him with his army of Macedonians in full array, but being few in number, and in some consternation, they were easily overcome by the more numerous and powerful Gauls;
tgt_text.3199: and the defeated Macedonians retiring within the walls of their cities, the victorius Brennus, meeting with no opposition, ravaged the lands throughout the whole of Macedonia.
tgt_text.3200: Soon after, as if the spoils of mortals were too mean for him, he turned his thoughts to the temples of the immortal gods, saying, with a profane jest, that “ the gods, being rich, ought to be liberal to men."
tgt_text.3201: He suddenly, therefore, directed his march towards Delphi, regarding plunder more than religion, and caring for gold more than for the wrath of the deities, “ who," he said, “stood in no need of riches, as being accustomed rather to bestow them on mortals.
tgt_text.3202: "The temple of Apollo at Delphi is situate- on Mount Par­ nassus, on a rock steep on all sides.
tgt_text.3203: A concourse of people, who, collecting from the parts around, through venerationt for the majesty of the god, settled on the rock, formed a city there.
tgt_text.3204: Thus, not walls, but precipices, not defences formed by the hand, but by nature, protect the temple and the city;
tgt_text.3205: so that it is utterly uncertain whether the strength of the place, or the influence of the deity residing in it.
tgt_text.3207: The central part of the rock falls back in the shape of an amphitheatre;
tgt_text.3208: and, in consequence, if ever shouts are raised, or if the noise of trumpets is mingled with them, the sound, from the rocks echoing and re-echoing to one another, is heard many times repeated, and louder than it was made at first.
tgt_text.3209: This effect, on those who are ignorant of its cause, and are struck with wonder at it, produces a greater awe of the power of the god.
tgt_text.3210: In the winding of the rock, about half way up the hill, there is a small plain, and in it a deep fissure in the ground, which is open for giving oracles;
tgt_text.3211: for a cold exhalation, driven upwards by some force, as it were by a wind, produces in the minds of the priestesses a certain madness, and compels them, filled with the influence of the god, to give answers to such as consult them.
tgt_text.3212: Hence many rich presents of kings and nations are to be seen there, which, by their magnificence, testify the grateful feelings of those that have paid their vows, and their belief in the oracles given by the deity.
tgt_text.3214: Brennus, when he came within sight of the temple, deliberated for some time, whether he should at once make an attempt upon it, or should allow his soldiers, wearied with their march, a night to refresh themselves.
tgt_text.3215: Two of the captains, Emanus and Thessalorus, who had joined him for a share in the booty, advised that " no delay should be made," while the enemy were unprovided for defence, and the alarm at their coming still fresh;
tgt_text.3216: that in the interval of a night, the courage of the enemy would perhaps revive, and assistance come to them;
tgt_text.3217: and that the approaches, which were now open, might be blocked up."
tgt_text.3218: But the common soldiers, when, after a long endurance of scarcity, they found a country abounding with wine and other provisions, had dispersed themselves over the fields, rejoicing as much at the plenty as if they had gained a victory, and leaving their standards deserted, wandered about to seize on everything like conquerors.
tgt_text.3219: This conduct gave some respite to the Delphians.
tgt_text.3220: At the first report that the Gauls were approaching, the country people are said to have been prohibited by the oracle from carrying away their corn and wine from their houses.
tgt_text.3221: The salutariness of this prohibi­ tion was not understood, until, through this abundance of wine and other provisions being thrown in the way of the Gauls, as a stop to their progress, reinforcements from their neighbours had time to collect.
tgt_text.3222: The Delphians, accordingly, supported by the strength of their allies, secured their city before the Gauls, who clung to the wine-skins, on which they had seized, could be recalled to their standards.
tgt_text.3223: Brennus had sixty-five thousand infantry, selected from his whole army ;
tgt_text.3224: of the Del­ phians there were not more than four thousand ;
tgt_text.3225: in utter con tempt of whom, Brennus, to rouse the courage of his men, pointed to the vast quantity of spoil before them, declaring that the statues, and four-horse chariots, of which a great number were visible at a distance, were made of solid gold, and would prove greater prizes when they came to be weighed than they were in appearance.
tgt_text.3227: The Gauls, animated by these assertions, and dis­ ordered, at the same time, with the wine which they had drunk the day before, rushed to battle without any fear of danger.
tgt_text.3228: The Delphians, on the other hand, placing more confidence in the god than in their own strength, resisted the enemy with contempt, and, from the top of the hill, repelled the Gauls as they climbed up, partly with pieces of rock, and partly with their weapons.
tgt_text.3229: Amidst this contest between the two, the priests of all the temples,* as well as the priestesses themselves, with their hair loose, and with their decorations and fillets, rushed, trembling and frantic, into the front ranks of the combatants, exclaiming that " the god was come;
tgt_text.3230: that they had seen him leap down into his temple through the opening roof;
tgt_text.3231: that, while they were all humbly imploring aid of the deity, a youth of extraordinary beauty, far above.
tgt_text.3232: that of mortals, and two armed virgins, coming from the neighbouring temples of Diana and Minerva, met them;
tgt_text.3233: that they had not only perceived them with their eyes, but had heard also the sound of a bow and the rattling of arms and they therefore conjured them with the strongest entreaties, " not to delay, when the gods were leading them on, to spread slaughter among the enemy, and to share the victory with the powers of heaven."
tgt_text.3234: Incited by these exhortations, they all rushed eagerly to the field of battle, where they themselves also soon perceived the presence of the divinity;
tgt_text.3235: for a part of the mountain, broken off by an earthquake, overwhelmed a host of the Gauls, and some of the densest bodies of the enemy were scattered abroad, not without wounds, and fell to the earth.
tgt_text.3236: A tempest then followed, which destroyed, with bail and cold, those that were suffering from bodily injuries.
tgt_text.3237: The general Brennus himself, unable to endure the pain of his wounds, ended his life with his dagger.
tgt_text.3238: The other gene­ ral,* after punishing the advisers of the war,t made off from Greece with all expedition, accompanied with ten thousand wounded men.
tgt_text.3239: But neither was fortune more favourable to those who fled;
tgt_text.3240: for in their terror, they passed no night under shelter, and no day without hardship and danger;
tgt_text.3241: and con­ tinual rains, snow congealed by the frost, famine, fatigue, and, what was the greatest evil, the constant want of sleep, con­ sumed the wretched remains of the unfortunate army.
tgt_text.3242: The nations and people too, through whom they marched, pursued their stragglers, as if to spoil them.
tgt_text.3243: Hence it happened that, of so great an army, which a little before, presuming on its strength, contended even against the gods, not a man was left ‡ to be a memorial of its destruction.
tgt_text.3244: The Gauls, who had been left behind by Brennus, proceed to attack Antigonus Gonnatas, I. — Massacre of the Gauls;
tgt_text.3247: — Pyrrhus. king of Epirus, expels Antigonus from Macedonia, III.
tgt_text.3249: Pyrrhus goes to war with the Spartans, IV.
tgt_text.3251: his character, V.I. AFTER peace was made between the two kings, Antigonus and Antiochus, a new enemy suddenly started up against Antigonus as he was returning to Macedonia.
tgt_text.3252: The Gauls, who had been left behind by their general Brennus, when he marched into Greece, to defend the borders of their country, armed fifteen thousand foot and three thousand horse (that they alone might not seem idle), and having routed the forces of the Getæ and Triballi, and preparing to invade Macedonia, sent ambassadors to Antigonus to offer him peace if he would pay for it, and to play the part of spies, at the same time, in his camp.
tgt_text.3253: Antigonus, with royal munificence, invited them to a banquet, and entertained them with a sumptuous display of luxuries.
tgt_text.3254: But the Gauls were so struck with the vast quantity of gold and silver set before them, and so tempted with the richness of such a spoil, that they re­ turned more inclined to war than they had come.
tgt_text.3255: The king had also ordered his elephants to be shown them, as monsters unknown to those barbarians, and his ships laden with stores to be displayed ;
tgt_text.3256: little thinking that he was thus exciting the cupidity of those to seize his treasures, whom he sought to strike with terror by the ostentation of his strength.
tgt_text.3257: The ambassadors, returning to their countrymen, and exaggerating every thing excessively, set forth at once the wealth and un­ suspiciousness of the king;
tgt_text.3258: saying that “ his camp was filled with gold and silver, but secured neither by rampart nor trench, and that the Macedonians, as if they had sufficient protec­ tion in their wealth, neglected all military duties, apparently thinking that, as they had plenty of gold, they had no use for steel.”
tgt_text.3260: By this statement, the desires of a covetous people were sufficiently stimulated to take possession of such spoil.
tgt_text.3261: The example of Belgius, too, had its influence with them, who, a little before, had cut to pieces the army of the Macedonians and their king.
tgt_text.3262: Being all of one mind, therefore, they attacked the kings camp by night;
tgt_text.3263: but he, foreseeing the storm that threatened him, had given notice to his soldiers to remove all their baggage, and to conceal themselves noiselessly in a neigh­ bouring wood;
tgt_text.3264: and the camp was only saved because it was deserted.
tgt_text.3265: The Gauls, when they found it destitute not only of de­ fenders, but of sentinels, suspecting that there was not a flight, but some stratagem on the part of the enemy, were for some time afraid to enter the gates.
tgt_text.3266: At last, leaving the defences entire and untouched, and more like men come to explore than to plunder, they took possession of the camp ;
tgt_text.3267: and then, carry­ ing off what they found, they directed their course towards the coast.
tgt_text.3268: Here, as they were incautiously plundering the vessels, and fearing no attack, they were cut down by the sailors, and a part of the army that had fled thither with their wives and children;
tgt_text.3269: and such was the slaughter among them that the report of this victory procured Antigonus peace, not only from the Gauls, but from his other barbarous neigh- hours.
tgt_text.3270: The nation of the Gauls, however, was at that time so prolific, that they filled all Asia as with one swarm.
tgt_text.3271: Th kings of the east then carried on no wars without a mercenary army of Gauls;
tgt_text.3272: nor, if they were driven from their thrones, did they seek protection with any other people than the Gauls.
tgt_text.3273: Such indeed was the terror of the Gallic name, and the unvaried good fortune of their arms, that princes thought they could neither maintain their power in security, nor recover it if lost, without the assistance of Gallic valour.
tgt_text.3274: Hence, being called by the king of Bithynia to his aid, and having gained him the victory over his enemies, they shared his kingdom with him.
tgt_text.3275: and called their part of it Gallogræcia.
tgt_text.3277: During these transactions in Asia, Pyrrhus, having been defeated by the Carthaginians in a sea-6ght on the coast of Sicily, sent ambassadors to Antigonus king of Macedonia, to ask for a supply of troops, saying that, "unless he sent him some, he should be obliged to return to his kingdom, and to seek that enlargement of his dominions from him,* which he had wished to gain from the Romans."
tgt_text.3278: The ambassadors bringing word that his request was refused, he pretended to be suddenly obliged to depart, but concealed his reasons for doing so.
tgt_text.3279: Meanwhile he directed his allies to prepare for war, and committed the citadel of Tarentum to the guardianship of his son Helenus and his friend Milo.
tgt_text.3280: Returning to Epirus, he immediately invaded Macedonia ;
tgt_text.3281: Antigonus met him with an army, but was defeated in battle, and put to flight.
tgt_text.3282: Pyrrhus then allowed the Macedonians to surrender on terms ;
tgt_text.3283: and as if, by the acquisition of Macedonia, he had made up for his loss of Sicily and Italy, he sent for his son and his friend, whom he had left at Tarentum.
tgt_text.3284: Antigonus, divesting himself at once of all the marks of royalty, repaired with a few horse­ men, thit attended him in his flight, to Thessalonica, there to watch what would follow on the loss of his throne, and to renew the war with a hired army of Gauls.
tgt_text.3285: But being utterly de­ feated, a second time, by Ptolemy the son of Pyrrhus, he fled with only seven followers, and no longer indulged hopes ot recovering his kingdom, but sought only hiding places for safety and solitary ways for flight.
tgt_text.3287: Pyrrhus, being raised to such a height of royal power.
tgt_text.3288: and not content with what had once been the object of his wishes, began to contemplate the subjugation of Greece and Asia.
tgt_text.3289: He had no greater delight in ruling than in warfare;
tgt_text.3290: nor was any power able to withstand him, wheresoever he directed his attack.
tgt_text.3291: But irresistible as he was deemed in conquering kingdoms, he also easily lost those which he subdued and ac­ quired, so much better did he manage to gain dominion than to keep it.
tgt_text.3292: Having led his army into the Peloponnesus,* he was met by embassies from the Athenians, Achæans, and Messenians;
tgt_text.3293: and all Greece, indeed, struck with admiration at his name, and at the glory of his achievements against the Romans and Carthaginians, was eagerly looking for his arrival.
tgt_text.3294: His first contest was with the Spartans, in which, being resisted with greater spirit by the women than by the men, he lost his son Ptolemy and the flower of his army ;
tgt_text.3295: for, when he proceeded to attack the city, such a number of women assembled to de­ fend their birth-place, that he retreated, overcome not more by bravery on their part than by shame on his own.
tgt_text.3296: As for his son Ptolemy, he is said to have been so brave and enterprising that he took the city of Corcyrat with only sixty men.
tgt_text.3297: In a naval engagement, too, he is reported to have leaped from a boat, with seven men, into a fifty-oared galley, and to have taken and kept possession of it.
tgt_text.3298: At the attack on Sparta he rode into the very middle of the city, and was there slain in a crowd that gathered around him.
tgt_text.3299: When his body was carried to his father, he exclaimed, it is said, “ that he had not been killed so soon as he had feared, or his own rashness deserved.
tgt_text.3300: "V. Pyrrhus, on being repulsed by the Spartans, marched to Argos, where, while he was endeavouring to capture Antigonus who was snut up in the city, and was fighting furiously among the thickest of the assailants, he was struck with a stone from the walls, and killed.
tgt_text.3301: His head was carried to Antigonus, who, using his victory with moderation, sent back his son Helenus, who surrendered to him with several Epirots, into his own country, and gave him the bones of his father, not having yet received the rites of burial, to carry home with him.
tgt_text.3302: It is pretty generally stated by authors, that no king, either of that or the former age, was to be compared to Pyrrhus;
tgt_text.3303: and that there has seldom been seen, either among princes, or other illustrious men, a man of more upright life or of stricter justice;
tgt_text.3304: and that he had such knowledge of the military art, that though he fought against such great princes as Lysi­ machus, Demetrius, and Antigonus, he was never conquered.
tgt_text.3305: In his wars too with the Illyrians, Sicilians, Romans, and Carthaginians, he never came off inferior, but generally vic­ torious ;
tgt_text.3306: and he rendered his country, which was before but mean and obscure, renowned throughout the world by the fame of his exploits and the glory of his name.
tgt_text.3307: The Peloponnesus given up to Antigonus;
tgt_text.3308: Aristotimus, tyrant of Elis, killed by Hellanicus, I.—Antigonus defeats the Gauls;
tgt_text.3309: Alexander, king of Epirus, drives him from Macedonia;
tgt_text.3310: Demetrius, the son of Antigonus, recovers it, and expels Alexander from Epirus, If. — Alexander re-established on his throne;
tgt_text.3311: death of Magas, king of Cyrene;
tgt_text.3313: AFTER the death of Pyrrhus, there were great warlike commotions, not only in Macedonia, but in Asia and Greece;
tgt_text.3314: for the Peloponnesians were betrayed into the power of Anti­ gonus;
tgt_text.3315: and while partly concern, partly exultation, prevailed variously among the inhabitants, as any city had either ex­ pected aid from Pyrrhus or conceived apprehensions of him, they either entered into alliance with Antigonus, or, impelled by mutual animosity, plunged into hostilities with one another Amidst these tumults in the disturbed provinces, the sove­ reignty over the city of the Epeans* was usurped by an emi­ nent man named Aristotimus;
tgt_text.3316: and when many of the leafing persons had been slain by him, and more driven into banish­ ment, and the Ætolians sent ambassadors to ask him “to give up the wives and children of the exiles," he at first refused, but afterwards, as if relenting, he gave all the married women leave to go to their husbands, and fixed a day for their departure.
tgt_text.3317: They, as being about to spend their lives in banishment with their husbands, were going to carry all their most valuable property with them;
tgt_text.3318: but, when they assembled at one of the gates of the city, intending to go forth in a body, they were despoiled of all that they had, and confined in the public prison, the infants having been first killed in the arms of their mothers, and the young women carried off for vio­ lation.
tgt_text.3319: The people being all amazed at such cruel tyranny, Hellanicus, the chief of them, an old man and without chil­ dren, and consequently having no fear either for life or offspring, assembled the most faithful of his friends in his house, and encouraged them to attempt the delivery of their country.
tgt_text.3320: But as they hesitated to remove a public evil at their own private risk, and demanded time for deliberation, Hellanicus, calling for his attendants, ordered the doors to be locked, and a message to be carried to the tyrant, requesting him " to send officers to seize a band of conspirators in Hel­ lanicus's house;
tgt_text.3321: " and he told all of them, with reproaches, that “ since he could not be the deliverer of his country, he would at least take revenge for the abandonment of its cause.”
tgt_text.3322: Being thus placed between two perils, they chose the more honourable course, and conspired to kill the tyrant;
tgt_text.3323: and thus Aristotimus was cut off in the fifth month after he had usurped the government.
tgt_text.3325: In the meantime Antigonus, being harassed with wars, of varied aspect, from the Spartans and King Ptolemy, and per­ ceiving that a new enemy, an army from Gallogræcia, was coming upon him, left a few troops as a semblance of a camp, to amuse his other assailants, and proceeded with all the rest of his force against the Gauls;
tgt_text.3326: who, becoming aware of his approach, as they were preparing for battle, sacrificed victims to take presages for the event;
tgt_text.3327: and as, from the entrails, great slaughter and destruction of them all was portended, they were moved, not to fear, but to fury, and thinking that the anger of the gods might be appeased by the slaughter of their kindred, butchered their wives and children, commencing hostilities with the murder of their own people ;
tgt_text.3328: for such rage had possessed their savage breasts, that they did not spare even that tender age which an enemy would have spared, but made deadly war on their own children and their children's mothers, in defence of whom wars are wont to be undertaken.
tgt_text.3329: As if, therefore, they had purchased life and victory by their barbarity, they rushed, stained as they were with the fresh blood of their relatives, into the field of battle, but with success no better than their auspices :
tgt_text.3330: for, as they were fighting, the furies, the avengers of murder, overwhelmed them sooner than the enemy, and the ghosts of the slain rising up before their eyes, they were all cut off with utter destruction.
tgt_text.3331: Such was the havoc among them, that the gods seemed to have conspired with men to annihilate an army of murderers.
tgt_text.3332: In consequence of the result of this battle,Ptolemy and the Spartans, avoiding the victorious army of the enemy, retreated to safer ground;
tgt_text.3333: and Antigonus, when he heard of their departure, turned his arms against the Athenians, while the ardour of his men was yet fresh from their recent victory.
tgt_text.3334: But during the time that he was thus engaged, Alexander, king of Epirus, longing to avenge the death of his father Pyrrhus, laid waste the frontiers of Macedonia.
tgt_text.3335: Antigonus returned from Greece to give him battle, but being deserted by his men, who went over to the enemy, he lost both the throne of Macedonia and his army.
tgt_text.3336: His son Demetrius, however, though but a boy, collecting an army in the absence of his father, not only recovered Macedonia, which had been lost, but drove Alexander from the throne of Epirus.
tgt_text.3337: Such was the fickleness of the soldiers, or the mutability of fortune, that kings were seen one day in the character of sovereign,.;
tgt_text.3338: , and the next in that of exiles.
tgt_text.3340: Alexander, after fleeing, on his expulsion, to the Acarnanians, was restored to his throne, with not less eager­ ness on the part of the Epirots than exertion on the part of his allies.
tgt_text.3341: About the same time died Magas,* king of Cyrene, who, before he fell sick, bad betrothed his only daughter Berenice to his brother Ptolemy's son, in order to end all disputes with him.
tgt_text.3342: But after the death of the king, Arsinoë, the mother of the girl, resolving to break off a marriage which had been contracted against her will, sent for Demetrius, the brother of King Antigonus, from Macedonia, to marry the damsel, and occupy the throne of Cyrene.
tgt_text.3343: Nor did Demetrius delay to comply with her wishes.
tgt_text.3344: But having speedily arrived, by the aid of a favourable wind, at Cyrene, he began, from the very first, through presuming on his handsome person (with which he had already made too much impression on his mother-in-law*), to conduct himself haughtily and overbearingly both to the royal family and the army.
tgt_text.3345: He also transferred his desire to please from the daughter to the mother;
tgt_text.3346: a fact which was first suspected by the damsel, and at last drew odium upon him from the people and the army.
tgt_text.3347: The affec­ tions of all, therefore, being set on the son of Ptolemy, a conspiracy was formed against Demetrius, and assassins were sent to kill him, when he was gone to bed with his mother- in-law.
tgt_text.3348: Arsinoë, hearing the voice of her daughter, standing at the door, and desiring them " to spare her mother," covered her paramour a while with her own person.
tgt_text.3349: He was however slain, and Berenice, by his death, both took revenge for the licentiousness of her mother, without violation of her duty to her, and, in choosing a husband, followed the judgment of her father.
tgt_text.3350: Seleucus II., king of Syria, puts to death Berenice, his mother-in law;
tgt_text.3351: Ptolemy Euergetes invades Syria, but is recalled home, 1.— Seleucus recovers himself, and makes war on Ptolemy unsuccess­ fully ;
tgt_text.3352: he calls to his aid his brother Antiochus, surnamed Hierax, II.
tgt_text.3353: —Antiochus, defeated by Fumenes and Seleucus, takes to flight;
tgt_text.3354: deaths of Antiochus and Seleucus, III.I.
tgt_text.3355: ON the death of Antiochus, king of Syria, his son Seleucus, succeeding in his stead, commenced his reign with murder in his own family, his mother Laodice.
tgt_text.3356: who ought to have re­ strained him, encouraging him to it.
tgt_text.3357: He put to death his step-mother Berenice, the sister of Ptolemy, king of Egypt, together with his little brother, her son.
tgt_text.3358: By perpetrating this cruelty, he both incurred the stain of infamy, and involved himself in a war with Ptolemy.
tgt_text.3359: As for Berenice, when she heard that assassins were sent to despatch her, she shut her­ self up in Daphne ;
tgt_text.3360: and it being reported throughout the cities of Asia, that she and her little son were besieged there, they all, commiserating her undeserved misfortunes from their recollection of the high character of her father and her ancestors, sent her assistance.
tgt_text.3361: Her brother Ptolemy, too, alarmed at the danger of his sister, left his kingdom, and hastened to her support with all his forces.
tgt_text.3362: But Berenice, before succour could arrive, was surprised by treachery, as she could not be taken by force, and killed.
tgt_text.3363: The deed was re­ garded by every one as an atrocity;
tgt_text.3364: and all the cities, in consequence, which had revolted (after having equipped a vast fleet), being suddenly alarmed at this instance of cruelty, and wishing to take revenge for her whom they had meant to defend, gave themselves up to Ptolemy, who, if he had not been recalled to Egypt by disturbances at home, would have made himself master of all Seleucus's dominions.
tgt_text.3365: Such hatred did an unnatural crime bring upon Seleucus;
tgt_text.3366: or so much good feeling did the death of a sister, dishonourably killed, excite in behalf of Ptolemy!
tgt_text.3368: After the departure of Ptolemy, Seleucus, having pre­ pared a great fleet against the cities that had revolted, lost it in a storm that suddenly arose, as if the gods themselves had taken vengeance on him for his murder;
tgt_text.3369: nor did fortune leave him anything, of all his mighty armament, except his body and life, and a few companions amid the wreck.
tgt_text.3370: It was indeed a lamentable occurrence, and yet such as Seleucus might have desired;
tgt_text.3371: for the cities, which from hatred to him had gone over to Ptolemy, being moved, by a sudden change in their feelings, to compassionate his loss at sea (as if, in the judgment of the gods, satisfaction had been made them), put themselves again under his government.
tgt_text.3372: Rejoiced at his misfortune, therefore, and enriched by his loss, he made war upon Ptolemy, as being now a match for him in strength;
tgt_text.3373: but as though he had been born only for a sport to fortune, and had received the power of a king only to lose it, he was defeated in a battle, and fled in trepidation to Antioch, not much better attended than after his shipwreck.
tgt_text.3374: From this place he despatched a letter to his brother Antiochus, in which he implored his aid, and offered him that part of Asia within Mount Taurus, as a recompense for his services.
tgt_text.3375: But Antiochus, though he was but fourteen years old, yet, being greedy of dominion beyond his years, caught at the oppor­ tunity, not with the kindly feeling with which it was offered, but, like a robber, desiring to take the whole kingdom from his brother, assumed, boy as he was, a manly and unprin­ cipled audacity.
tgt_text.3376: Hence he was called Hierax,* because, in taking away the possessions of others, he conducted himself, not like a man, but like a bird of preyPtolemy Euergetes, in the meantime, learning that An­ tiochus was coming to the aid of Seleucus, and not wishing to have to contend with two enemies at once, made peace with Seleucus for ten years.
tgt_text.3377: But the peace that was granted Seleucus by his enemy, was broken by his own brother, who, having hired an army of Gauls, brought hostilities instead of succour, and showed himself, though he had been implored for aid, an enemy instead of a brother.
tgt_text.3378: In the battle that followed Antiochus was victor, indeed, through the prowess of the Gauls ;
tgt_text.3379: but they, thinking that Seleucus had fallen on the field, began to turn their arms against Antiochus himself, in the hope of ravaging Asia with greater freedom, if they destroyed the whole royal family.
tgt_text.3380: Antiochus, seeing their design, pur­ chased peace from them, as from robbers, with a sum of money, and formed an alliance with his own mercenaries.
tgt_text.3382: Meanwhile Eumenes, king of Bithynia, when the brothers were divided and exhausted by civil war, attacked both the victorious Antiochus and the Gauls, as if he intended to take possession of Asia while it was left without a master.
tgt_text.3383: Nor did he find any difficulty in overthrowing them, as they were weakened by their previous conflicts, and he himself was fresh and vigorous.
tgt_text.3384: At that period, indeed, every war was intended for the reduction of Asia;
tgt_text.3385: whoever was stronger than his neighbours was ready to seize on Asia for his prey.
tgt_text.3386: The brothers, Seleucus and Antiochus, went to war for the sove­ reignty of Asia;
tgt_text.3387: Ptolemy, king of Egypt, under pretext of avenging his sister, was eager to secure Asia.
tgt_text.3388: On the one side Eumenes of Bithynia, on the other the Gauls (an army of mercenaries always ready to support the weaker), laid waste Asia, while no one, among so many robbers, was found to be its protector.
tgt_text.3389: When Antiochus was overthrown, and Eumenes had pos­ sessed himself of the greater part of the country, the two brothers, though the prize for which they had fought was lost, could not even then come to an agreement, but, leaving their foreign enemies unmolested, continued the war for the destruc­ tion of each other.
tgt_text.3390: Antiochus, being again defeated, and exhausted with a flight of many days' continuance, arrived at last at the palace of Artamenes, his father-in-law, king of Cappadocia.
tgt_text.3391: Being kindly received by him at first, but learning, after some days, that treacherous designs were form­ ing against him, he sought safety by again taking to flight.
tgt_text.3392: When he was thus a fugitive, and found nowhere a place of security, he betook himself to his enemy Ptolemy, whose faith he thought more to be trusted than that of his brother, whether he reflected on what he would have done to his brother, or what he had deserved from him.
tgt_text.3393: But Ptolemy, not more friendly to him when he came to surrender, that when he had been an open foe, ordered that he should be kept in the closest confinement.
tgt_text.3394: From hence however he escaped, eluding his keepers by the aid of a courtesan, with whom he had been familiar, and was slain in his flight by some robbers.
tgt_text.3395: Seleucus too, about the same time, lost his kingdom, and was killed by a fall from his horse.
tgt_text.3396: Thus these two brothers, as if brothers also in fate, both became exiles;
tgt_text.3397: and both, after losing their dominions, died a death merited by their crimes.

tgt_text.3404: death of Anti­ gonus, IV.I. WHEN Olympias, daughter of Pyrrhus king of Epiras, had lost her husband Alexander, who was also her brother,.
tgt_text.3405: she took upon herself the guardianship of her sons Pyrrhus and Ptolemy, whom she had by him, and the administration of the kingdom;
tgt_text.3406: and finding that the Ætolians wanted to take from her a part of Acarnania, which the father of the boys had received as a recompense for assisting them in war,t she ad­ dressed herself to Demetrius king of Macedonia, and gave him her daughter Phthia in marriage (though he was already united to a sister of Antiocbus king of Syria), that she might secure by right of relationship the assistance which she could not obtain from his compassion.
tgt_text.3407: A marriage was accordingly solemnized, by which Demetrius gained the love of a new wife, and the hatred of his former one;
tgt_text.3408: who, as if divorced, went off to her brother Antiochus, and excited him to make war upon her husband.
tgt_text.3409: The Acarnanians also, fearing to trust for support to the Epirots, requested of the Romans assistance against the Ætolians, and prevailed on the senate to send ambassadors to order the Ætolians “to withdraw their garrisons from the cities of carnania, and allow those to be free, who alone, of all the people of Greece, had not contributed aid to the Greeks against the Trojans, the authors of the Roman race."
tgt_text.3411: But the Ætolians listened to the embassy of the Ro­ mans with haughtiness, upbraiding them with their fortune against the Carthaginians and Gauls, by whom they had been fearfully slaughtered in so many wars, and saying that “ their gates, which the terror of the Punic war had closed, ‡ should be opened to meet the Carthaginians, before their arms were brought into Greece."
tgt_text.3412: They then desired them to remember “ who they were that threatened, and whom they threatened.
tgt_text.3413: That the Romans had not been able to defend their city against the Gauls;
tgt_text.3414: and, when it was taken, had recovered it,* not by the sword, but with gold;
tgt_text.3415: but that when that people entered Greece, in considerably greater numbers, they them­ selves had utterly destroyed them, not only without the assist­ ance of any foreign power, but without even calling into action the whole of their own force, and had made that a place for their graves which they had intended for the seat of their cities and empire;
tgt_text.3416: while Italy, on the other hand, when the Romans were still trembling at the recent burning of their city, was almost entirely occupied by the Gauls.
tgt_text.3417: That they should therefore have expelled the Gauls from Italy before they threatened the Ætolians, and have defended their own pos­ sessions before they sought those of others.
tgt_text.3418: And what sort of men were the Romans ?
tgt_text.3419: mere shepherds, who occupied a ter­ ritory wrested from its lawful owners by robbery;
tgt_text.3420: who, when they were unable to procure wives, from the baseness of their origin, seized them by open force;
tgt_text.3421: who, moreover, had founded their very city in fratricide, and sprinkled the foun­ dation of their walls with the blood of their king's brothel But that the Ætolians had always been the chief people of Greece, and, as they surpassed others in dignity, excelled them also in bravery;
tgt_text.3422: that they were the only nation who had always despised the Macedonians, even when flourishing in possession of the empire of the world;
tgt_text.3423: who had felt no dread of king Philip, and who had spurned the edicts of Alexander the Great, after he had conquered the Persians and Indians, and when all trembled at his name.
tgt_text.3424: That they therefore ad­ vised the Romans to be content with their present fortune, and not provoke the arms by which they knew that the Gauls had been cut to pieces, and the Macedonians set at nought."
tgt_text.3425: They thus dismissed the Roman embassy, and, that they might not seem to speak more boldly than they acted, laid waste the borders of Epirus and Acamania.
tgt_text.3427: Olympias* had now given up her dominions to her sons, and Ptolemy had succeeded in the room of his deceased brother Pyrrhus.
tgt_text.3428: Ptolemy, as he was marching to meet the enemy with his army in array, was seized with a fit of sickness, and died on his route.
tgt_text.3429: Olympias too, afflicted with her double bereavement in the death of her sons, and dragging on a suffering existence, did not long survive her offspring.
tgt_text.3430: The young princess Nereis, and her sister Laodamia, being then the only survivors of the royal family, Nereis married Gelo, the son of the king of Sicily ;

tgt_text.3434: and Milo, the assassin of Laodamia, becoming mad, and lacerating his flesh, § sometimes with the sword, some­ times with stones, and at last with his teeth, died the twelfth day afterwards.
tgt_text.3435: While these things were occurring in Epirus, king Deme trius in Macedonia died, leaving a son named Philip, quite a child;

tgt_text.3437: But some time after, being besieged in the palace by an alarming insurrection of the Macedonians, he walked forth publicly unattended by his guards, and throwing his diadem and purple robe among the mob, bade them “ give those to somebody else, who either knew not how to rule them, ¶ or whom they knew how to obey;
tgt_text.3438: for that he had found regal authority enviable,* not for its pleasures, but for its toils and dangers."

tgt_text.3440: " how he had punished the defection of their allies;

tgt_text.3444: and they themselves might look out for a prince whom they could govern.”
tgt_text.3445: The people, overcome with shame, bade him resume the regal authority;
tgt_text.3446: but he refused to do so till the leaders of the insurrection were delivered up to punishment.
tgt_text.3448: After this occurrence he made war upon the Spartans, who were the only people that, during the wars of Philip and Alexander, had set at nought the power of the Macedonians, and those arms which were dreaded by every other nation.
tgt_text.3449: Between these two most remarkable peoples war was prose­ cuted with the greatest vigour on both sides, the one fighting to support the old glory of the Macedonians, and the other, not only to secure their hitherto unviolated liberty, but even their lives.
tgt_text.3450: The Lacedæmonians being worsted, not only the men, but their wives and children, endured their adverse fortune with magnanimity.
tgt_text.3451: As no man had shrunk from exposing his life in the field, so no woman wept for her lost husband ;
tgt_text.3452: the old men extolled the honourable deaths of their sons, and the sons rejoiced over their fathers that were slain in battle;
tgt_text.3453: and all who survived lamented their lot, in not having died for the liberty of their country.
tgt_text.3454: All received the wounded with open doors, dressed their wounds, and recruited them in their exhaustion.
tgt_text.3455: In this condition of affairs, there was no noise or hurry in the city, and every one lamented the public suffering more than his own private troubles.
tgt_text.3456: In the course of these proceedings, king Cleomenes returned, with his whole body wet, after the great slaughter that he had made among the enemy, with his own blood and that of his adversaries, and, entering the city, did not rest himself on the ground, or call for meat or drink, or even relieve himself from the weight of his armour, but leaning against a wall, and finding that only four thousand men survived the battle, exhorted them “to reserve themselves for the better times that would come to their country."
tgt_text.3457: He then set out with his wife and children to Egypt to Ptolemy, by whom he was honourably received, and lived a long time in the highest esteem with that monarch.
tgt_text.3458: After the decease of Ptolemy, he was put to death, with all his family, by Ptolemy's sonAntigonus, when the Spartans were thus reduced, pitying the distress of so famous a city, prohibited his soldiers from plundering it, and granted pardon to all who survived, observ­ ing that “he had engaged in war, not with the Spartans, but with Cleomenes, with whose flight all his resentment was terminated ;
tgt_text.3459: nor would it be less glory to him, if Sparta should be recorded to have been saved by him by whom alone it had been taken;
tgt_text.3460: and that he accordingly spared the ground and buildings of the city, scarcely any inhabitants being left for him to spare."

tgt_text.3484: Emilius Paulus, the Roman consul, applied to him with earnest entreaties for aid, and complaints of the injustice of the Romans, " who," he said, " not content within the limits of Italy, but grasping, with presumptuous hopes, at the empire of the whole world, made war upon all kings.
tgt_text.3485: Thus, aspiring to the dominion of Sicily, Sardinia, and Spain, and finally to that of all Africa, they had engaged in a war with the Cartha­ ginians and Hannibal;
tgt_text.3486: and that hostilities had been directed against himself too, for no other reason than that he appeared to lie near Italy, as if it were unlawful for any king to be on the borders of their empire.
tgt_text.3487: And that Philip also himself must take warning by his case, since the nearer t and more valuable his kingdom, the more determined enemies would he find the Romans to be."
tgt_text.3488: In addition, he said, that " he would give up his kingdom, which the Romans had seized, to Philip himself as he should be better pleased to see his ally, rather than his enemies, in possession of his dominions "
tgt_text.3489: With such repre­ sentations as these, he prevailed upon Philip to lay aside his designs on the Ætolians, and to make war upon the Romans ;
tgt_text.3490: Philip supposing that there would be the less difficulty in the undertaking, as he had heard that they had already been beaten by Hannibal at the lake Trasimenus.
tgt_text.3491: Not to be dis­ traded, therefore, with more than one war at the same time, lie concluded a peace with the Ætolians, not as if intending to carry war elsewhere, but as if he wished to promote the tran­ quillity of Greece, “which," he asserted, “had never been in greater danger, as the new empires of the Carthaginians and Romans were rising in the west, who forbore from attacking Greece and Asia only till they should decide their dispute for the sovereignty by the sword, when the superior power of the two would immediately invade the east.
tgt_text.3493: He contemplated therefore," he said, " that cloud of cruel and sanguinary war which was rising in Italy;
tgt_text.3494: he contemplated the storm roaring and thundering from the west, which, to whatever parts of the world the tempest of victory might carry it, would pollute everything with a vast shower of blood.
tgt_text.3495: That Greece had frequently felt great disturbances at one time from the wars of the Persians, at another from those of the Gauls, at another from those of the Macedonians, but that they would think all those to have been but trifling, if the force, which was now collecting in Italy, should once pour itself forth from that country.
tgt_text.3496: He saw what cruel and bloody conflicts those two powers were maintaining with each other, with all the strength of their forces, and all the abilities of their generals;
tgt_text.3497: and that such fury could not end with the destruction of one party only, without ruin to the neighbouring people.
tgt_text.3498: That the cruel resolutions of the conquerors, it was true, were less to be dreaded by Macedonia than by Greece;
tgt_text.3499: for Macedonia was both more remote, and better able to defend itself;
tgt_text.3500: but he knew that those who contended with such spirit would not be content with Greece as a limit to their conquests, and that he himself should have to fear a conflict with the party that should get the advantage."
tgt_text.3501: Concluding, on this pretext, the war with the Ætolians, and thinking of nothing else but the contest of the Carthaginians and Romans, he carefully weighed the strength of each.
tgt_text.3502: But neither did the Romans, with the Carthaginians* and Hannibal on their necks, appear free from apprehension of Macedonia;
tgt_text.3503: indeed, both the ancient valour of the Macedonians, their glory in having conquered the east, and the character of Philip, who was fired with the ambition of rivalling Alexander, and whom they knew to be active and eager for the field, gave them sufficient cause for alarm.
tgt_text.3505: Philip, as soon as he heard that the Romans had been defeated by the Carthaginians in a second battle, openly de­ clared himself their enemy, and began to build ships for transporting an army into Italy.
tgt_text.3506: He then sent a deputy to Hannibal with a letter, with the view of forming an alliance with him.
tgt_text.3507: This deputy was taken prisoner, and brought before the senate, but released unharmed ;
tgt_text.3508: not from respect to the king, but that one who appeared still undetermined might not be rendered a decided enemy.
tgt_text.3509: But afterwards, when news was brought to the Romans that Philip was preparing to transport troops into Italy, they despatched the prætor Lævinus, with a well appointed fleet, to hinder him from crossing.
tgt_text.3510: Lævinus, sailing over to Greece, prevailed on the Ætolians, by making them numerous promises, to take up arms against Philip, who, on his side, solicited the Achæans to go to war with the Romans.
tgt_text.3511: Meanwhile the Dardanians began to ra. vage the country of Macedonia, and, carrying off twenty thou.
tgt_text.3512: sand prisoners, recalled Philip from his war with the Romans to defend his own territories.
tgt_text.3513: At the same time the prætor Lævinus, having made an alliance with king Attalus, proceeded to lay waste Greece;
tgt_text.3514: of which the several states, dismayed at such calamities, importuned Philip with embassies for succour ;
tgt_text.3515: while the princes of the Illyrians, sticking close to his side, demanded, with constant solicitations, the performance of his promises to them.
tgt_text.3516: In addition, the plundered Macedonians called on him for vengeance.
tgt_text.3517: Beset by such and so many d iffi­ calties, he was in doubt to what he should first turn his attend )n;
tgt_text.3518: but he promised them all to send them assistance shortly ;
tgt_text.3519: not that he was able to do what he promised, but in order to k eep them, by feeding them with hopes, in the bond of alliance with him.
tgt_text.3520: His first expedition, however, was against the Dardanians, who, watching for his absence, were ready to fall on Macedonia with a still heavier force.
tgt_text.3521: He made peace, too, with the Romans, who were well content to put on war with Macedonia for a time.
tgt_text.3522: He laid a plot, moreover, for the life of Philopœmen, strategus of the Achæaus, who, he understood, was soliciting some of his allies to join the Romans ;
tgt_text.3523: but Philopœmen, having discovered and escaped the plot, induced the Achæans, by the influence which he had with them, to abandon Philip's cause.

tgt_text.3532: I. WHILE Philip was intent on great exploits in Macedonia, the conduct of Ptolemy in Egypt was of an opposite character;
tgt_text.3533: for having got the throne by parricide, and added the murder of his brother to that of both his parents, he resigned himself, as if all had gone happily with him, to the attractions of luxury;
tgt_text.3534: and the whole court bad followed the manners of their king.
tgt_text.3535: Not only his personal friends, and chief officers, but the whole of the army had laid aside militarY exercises, and grown corrupt and enervated in idleness.
tgt_text.3536: Antiochus, king of Syria, when he heard of this state of things, and while the old animosity between the two kingdoms incited him, captured many cities belonging to Ptolemy by a sudden attack, and carried his arms into Egypt itself.
tgt_text.3537: Pto­ lemy was accordingly in consternation, and endeavoured to retard Antiochus, by sending embassies, until he could get troops in readiness.
tgt_text.3538: Having then hired a large army in Greece, he fought a battle with good success, and would have driven Antiochus from his throne, if he had supported his for­ tune with suitable spirit.
tgt_text.3539: But, content with recovering the cities that he had lost, and making peace, he eagerly seized the opportunity of sinking again into sloth, and, returr ing to his former licentious habits, he put to death his wife Eurydice, who was also his sister, and gave himself up to the caresses of a mistress named Agathoclia;
tgt_text.3540: and thus, forgetful of all the greatness of his name and dignity, he passed his nights in wantonness, and his days in the pleasures of the table.
tgt_text.3541: As ministrations to his luxury, timbrels and tabors- were intro­ duced ;
tgt_text.3542: and the king, no longer a mere spectator, but a leader of the revels, produced music from stringed instruments him­ self.
tgt_text.3543: Such were at first the secret and latent pests of a tottering court.
tgt_text.3545: Licentiousness subsequently increasing, the audacity of his mistress could no longer be confined within the walls of the palace :
tgt_text.3546: for the daily debaucheries of the king, which he shared with her brother Agathocles, a corrupt youth of cap­ tivating beauty, rendered her still more shameless.
tgt_text.3547: To all this was added, too, the influence of their mother CEnanthe, who, by the charms of her two children, kept the monarch quite enthralled.
tgt_text.3548: Not content with enslaving the king, they made themselves rulers of the kingdom;
tgt_text.3549: they showed them­ selves in public places, received salutations, and were followed by a train of attendants.
tgt_text.3550: Agathocles, attaching himself closely to the king's side, assumed the administration of the state;
tgt_text.3551: women disposed of offices, governments, and commissions;
tgt_text.3552: nor had any one less power in the kingdom than the king himself.
tgt_text.3553: In the midst of this state of things the king died, leaving a son, five years old, by his sister Eurydice;
tgt_text.3554: but his death, while the women were seizing on the royal treasures, and endeavouring, by forming a confederacy with some des­ perate characters, to get the government into their own hands, was for a long time kept secret.
tgt_text.3555: But the truth becoming known, Agathocles was killed by a rising of the people, and the women nailed on crosses to avenge the death of Eurydice.
tgt_text.3556: After the king's decease, and when the infamy of the king­ dom was expiated, as it were, by the punishment of the cour­ tezans, the people of Alexandria sent ambassadors to the Romans, requesting them “to take on themselves the guard­ ianship of the orphan, and to defend the kingdom of Egypt, which, they said, Philip and Antiochus had already portioned out between them by a treaty made for the purpose."
tgt_text.3558: This embassy was acceptable to the Romans, who were seeking a pretence for making war upon Philip, for having formed designs against them in the time of the Punic war.
tgt_text.3559: To this feeling was added the circumstance, that, since the Carthaginians and Hannibal were conquered, there was no one of whose arms they had a greater dread, considering what a commotion Pyrrhus, with but a small force, had excited in Italy, and what exploits the Macedonians had achieved in the east.
tgt_text.3560: Ambassadors were accordingly despatched to warn Philip and Antiochus " to- make no attempt upon Egypt."
tgt_text.3561: Marcus Lepidus was also sent into Egypt, to govern the orphan's kingdom in the character of guardian.
tgt_text.3562: During the course of these proceedings, embassies from king AttaIns, and from the Rhodians, arrived at Rome, to complain of injuries that they had suffered from Philip.
tgt_text.3563: These representations removed from the minds of the senate all hesitation about going to war with Macedonia;
tgt_text.3564: and forthwith, under pretence of taking the part of their allies, war was declared against Philip, and some legions, with one of the consuls, were sent off to Macedonia.
tgt_text.3565: Not long after, too, the whole of Greece, stimulated by confidence in the Romans, and the hope of recovering their ancient liberty, to rise against Philip, made war upon him ;
tgt_text.3566: and thus, being assailed on every side, he was compelled to beg for peace.
tgt_text.3567: But when the terms of it were set forth by the Romans, both Attalus and the Rhodians, as well as the Achæans and Ætolians, began to demand that the places belonging to them should be restored.
tgt_text.3568: Philip, on the other hand, allowed that 11 he might be induced to submit to the Romans, but that it was intolerable that the Greeks, who had been subdued by his ancestors Philip and Alexander, and brought under the yoke of the Macedonian empire, should die fate articles of peace to him, as if they were conquerors;
tgt_text.3569: and that they ought to give an account of their conduct in their state of slavery, before they sought to recover their liberty."
tgt_text.3570: At last, on his request, a truce was allowed for two months, that the peace, on which they could not come to terms in Macedonia, might be obtained from the senate at Rome.

tgt_text.3578: Having then led out his army into the field, he began to encourage his men, while the enemy stood in array on the opposite side, by saying that “the Persians, Bactrians, and Indians, and all Asia to the utmost boundaries of the east, had been subdued by the Macedonians;
tgt_text.3579: and that this war was more bravely to be maintained than those which had preceded it, in proportion as liberty was more precious than empire."
tgt_text.3580: Flamininus, too, the Roman consul, animated his men to battle by representing what had lately been achieved by the Romans, observing that “Carthage and Sicily on one side, and Italy and Spain on the other, had been thoroughly reduced by Roman valour;
tgt_text.3581: and that Hannibal, by whose expulsion from Italy they had become masters of Africa, a third part of the world, was not to be thought inferior to Alexander the Great.
tgt_text.3582: Nor were the Macedonians to be estimated by their ancient reputation, but by their present power;
tgt_text.3583: for that the Romans were not waging war with Alexander the Great, whom they had heard called invincible, or with his army, which had conquered all the east, but with Philip, a youth of immature years,* who could scarcely defend the frontiers of his dominions against his neighbours, and with those Macedonians who were not long ago a prey to the Dar­ danians.
tgt_text.3584: That they might recount the achievements of their forefathers, but that he could relate those of his own soldiers;
tgt_text.3585: since Hannibal and the Carthaginians, and almost all the west, had not been conquered by any other army, but by those very troops which he had with him in the field."
tgt_text.3586: The soldiers on both sides, roused by these exhortations, rushed to the encounter, the one army exulting in their conquest of the east, the other in that of the west;
tgt_text.3587: the one carrying to the battle the ancient and fading glory of their ancestors, the other the flower of valour fresh from recent exertions.
tgt_text.3588: But the fortune of Rome. was superior to that of the Mace­ donians;
tgt_text.3589: and Philip, exhausted by his efforts in war, and suing for peace from Flamininus, the consul, was allowed to retain indeed the name of king;
tgt_text.3590: but, being deprived of all the cities of Greece, as being parts of his dominion beyond the bounds of its ancient territory, he preserved only Mace­ donia.
tgt_text.3591: The Ætolians, however, were displeased, because Macedonia was not taken from the king at their suggestion, and given to themselves as a reward for their service in the war, and sent ambassadors to Antiochus, to induce him, by flattering his greatness, to engage in a war with the Romans, in the hope of securing the alliance of all Greece.

tgt_text.3596: Hannibal s advice to Antiochus, III.
tgt_text.3597: - Antiochus incites the Carthaginians to go to war with the Romans ;
tgt_text.3598: the Romans make Antiochus suspicious of Hannibal, IV.
