tgt_text.4138: The people, terrified at these proceedings, fled to other countries, and became exiles from their native soil through fear of death.
tgt_text.4139: Ptolemy, in consequence, being left alone with his soldiers in so large a city, and finding himself a king, not of men, but of empty houses, invited, by a proclamation, foreigners to become residents in it.
tgt_text.4140: While people were flocking thither, he went out to meet some Roman commissioners, Scipio Africanus, Spurius Mummius, and Lucius Metellus, who had come to inspect the dominions of their allies.
tgt_text.4141: But he appeared as ridiculous to the Romans as lie was cruel to his own sheets ;
tgt_text.4142: for he was disagreeable in countenance, short in stature, and, from his obesity, more like a beast than a man.
tgt_text.4143: This deformity the extraordinary thin­ ness of his apparel, which was even transparent, made more remarkable, just as if that was affectedly obtruded on the sight which by a modest man would have been most carefully con­ cealed.
tgt_text.4144: After the departure of the commissioners, (of whom African us, as he surveyed the city, was an object of interest to the Alexandrians), finding that he had become hateful even to the foreigners whom he had invited, he withdrew secretly, for fear of plots against his life, into voluntary exile, accom­ panied by a son that he had by his sister, and by his wife, her mother's rival, and, having collected an army of mercenaries.
tgt_text.4145: made war at once upon his sister and his country.
tgt_text.4146: He next sent for his eldest son from Cyrene, and put him to death, when the people began to pull down his statues and images, and he, imagining that this was done to please his sister, killed the son that he had by her, and contrived to have the body, divided into portions and arranged in a chest, presented to the mother at a feast on his birth-day.
tgt_text.4147: This deed occasioned grief and sorrow, not only to the queen, but also to the whole city, and threw such a gloom over a banquet intended to be most joyous, that the whole palace was suddenly filled with mourning.
tgt_text.4148: The attention of the nobility, in consequence, being turned from feasting to a funeral, they exhibited the mangled limbs to the people, and let them see, by the murder of his son, what they were to expect from their king.
tgt_text.4150: Cleopatra, when the mourning for the loss of her son was over, finding herself pressed by war on the part of her brother, sent ambassadors to request aid from Demetrius king of Syria, a prince whose changes of fortune had been numerous and remarkable.
tgt_text.4151: After making war, as has been said above,.
tgt_text.4152: upon the Parthians, and gaining the victory in several battles, he was suddenly surprised by an ambuscade, and, having lost his army, was taken prisoner.
tgt_text.4153: Arsacides,t king of the Parthians, having sent him into Hyrcania, not only paid him, with royal magnanimity, the respect due to a prince, but gave him his daughter also in marriage, and promised to recover for him the throne of Syria, which Trypho had usurped in his absence.
tgt_text.4154: After the death of this king, Demetrius, despairing of being allowed to return, being unable to endure captivity, and weary of a private, though splendid, life, secretly planned a mode of escaping to his own country.
tgt_text.4155: His counsellor and companion in the scheme was his friend Callimander, who, after Demetrius was taken prisoner, had come in a Parthian dress from Syria, with some guides that he had hired, through the deserts of Arabia to Babylon.
tgt_text.4156: But Phraates, who had succeeded Arsacides, brought him back, for he was over­ taken in his flight by the speed of a party of horse sent after him by a shorter road.
tgt_text.4157: When be was brought to the king, not only pardon, but a testimony of esteem for his fidelity, was given to Callimander, but as for Demetrius, he sent him back, after having severely reproached him, into Hyrcania to his wife, and directed that he should be kept in stricter con­ finement than before.
tgt_text.4158: Some time after, when children that were born to him had caused him to be more trusted,.
tgt_text.4159: he again attempted flight, with the same friend as his attendant, but was overtaken, with equal in-fortune, near the borders of his dominions, and being again brought to the king, was ordered out of his sight, as a person whom he could not endure to see.
tgt_text.4160: But being then also spared, for the sake of his wife and children, he was remanded into Hyrcania, the country of his punishment, and presented with golden dice, as a reproach for his childish levity.
tgt_text.4161: But it was not com­ passion, or respect for ties of blood, that was the cause of this extraordinary clemency t of the Parthians toward Demetrius ;
tgt_text.4162: the reason was, that they had some designs on the kingdom of Syria, and intended to make use of Demetrius against his brother Antiochus, as circumstances, the course of time, or the fortune of war, might require.
tgt_text.4164: Antiochus, having heard of their designs, and thinking it proper to be first in the field, led forth an army, which he had inured to service by many wars t with his neighbours, against the Parthians.
tgt_text.4165: But his preparations for luxury were not less than those for war, for three hundred thousand!
tgt_text.4166: camp followers, cf whom the greater number were cooks, bakers, and stage-players, attended on eighty thousand armed men.
tgt_text.4167: Of silver and gold, it is certain, there was such an abundance that the common soldiers fastened their buskins with gold, and trod upon the metal for the love of which nations contend with the sword.
tgt_text.4168: Their cooking instruments, too, were 01 silver, as if they were going to a banquet, not to a field of battle.
tgt_text.4169: Many kings of the east met Antiochus on his march, offering him themselves and their kingdoms, and expressing the greatest detestation of Parthian pride.
tgt_text.4170: Nor was there any delay in coming to an engagement.
tgt_text.4171: Antiochus, being victorious in three battles, and having got possession of Babylon, began to be thought a great man.

tgt_text.4174: It was then that Phraates sent Demetrius into Syria, with a body of Parthians, to seize the throne, so that Antiochus might be recalled fron Parthia to secure his own dominions.
tgt_text.4175: In the meantime, since be could not overthrow Antiochus by open force, he made attempts upon him everywhere by stratagem.
tgt_text.4176: On account of the number of his forces, Antiochus had distributed his army, in winter quarters, through several cities;
tgt_text.4177: and this dispersion was the cause of his ruin;
tgt_text.4178: for the cities, finding themselves harassed by having to furnish supplies, and by the depredations of the soldiers, revolted to the Parthians, and, on an appointed day, conspired to fall upon the army divided among them, so that the several divisions might not be able to assist each other.
tgt_text.4179: News of the attack being brought to Antiochus, he hastened with that body of troops which he had in winter- quarters with him, to succour the others that lay nearest.
tgt_text.4180: On his way he was met by the king of the Parthians, with whom he himself fought more bravely than his troops ;
tgt_text.4181: but at last, as the enemy had the superiority in valour, he was deserted, through fear on the part of his men, and killed.
tgt_text.4182: Phraates had funeral rites performed for him as a king, and married the daughter of Demetrius, whom Antiochus had brought with him, and of whom he had become enamoured.
tgt_text.4183: He then began to regret having sent away Demetrius, and hastily despatched some troops of horse to fetch him back ;
tgt_text.4184: but they found that prince, who had been in fear of pursuit, already seated on his throne, and, after doing all they could to no purpose, returned to their king.

AFTER Antiochus and his army were cut off in Persia, his brother Demetrius, being delivered from confinement* among the Parthians, and restored to his throne, resolved, while all S yria was mourning for the loss of the army, to make war upon Egypt, (just as if his and his brothers wars with the Partisans, in which one was taken prisoner and the other killed, had had a fortunate termination), Cleopatra his mother-in-law promis­ ing him the kingdom of Egypt, as a recompence for the assistance that he should afford her against her brother.
tgt_text.4196: But, as is often the case, while he was grasping at what belonged to others, he lost his own by a rebellion in Syria;
tgt_text.4197: for the people of Antioch, in the first place, under the leadership of Trypho, and from detestation of the pride of their king (which, from his intercourse with the unfeeling Parthians, had become in­ tolerable), and afterwards the ApameniansϮ and other people following their example, revolted from Demetrius in his absence Ptolemy, king of Egypt, too, who was threatened with a war by him, having learned that his sister Cleopatra had put much of the wealth of Egypt on ship-board, and fled into Syria to her daughter and son-in-law Demetrius, sent an Egyptian youth,‡ the son of a merchant named Protarchus, to claim the throne of Syria by force of arms, having forged a story, that he had been admitted into the family of King Antiochus by adoption, and the Syrians, at the same time, refusing no man for their king, if they might but be freed from the insolence of Demetrius.
tgt_text.4198: The name of Alexander was given to the youth, and great succours were sent him from Egypt.
tgt_text.4199: Meanwhile the body of Antiochus, who had been killed by the king of the Parthians, arrived in Syria, being sent back in a silver coffin for burial, and was received with great respect by the different cities, as well as by the new king, Alexander, in order to see cure credit to the fiction.
tgt_text.4200: This show of affection procured him extraordinary regard from the people, every one supposing his tears not counterfeit but real.
tgt_text.4201: Demetrius, being defeated by Alexander, and overwhelmed by misfortunes surrounding hint on every side, was at last forsaken even by his wife and child­ ren.
tgt_text.4202: Being left, accordingly, with only a few slaves, and setting sail for Tyre, to shelter himself in the sanctuary of a temple there, he was killed, as he was leaving the ship, by order of the governor of the city.
tgt_text.4203: One of his sons, Seleucus, for having assumed the diadem without his mother's consent, was put to death by her;
tgt_text.4204: the other, who, from the size of his nose was named Grypus,* was made king by his mother, so far at least that the regal name should belong to him, while all the power of sovereignty was to remain with herself.
tgt_text.4206: But Alexander, having secured the throne of Syria, and being puffed up with success, began, with insolent haughti­ ness, to show disrespect even to Ptolemy himself, by whom he had been artfully advanced to royal dignity.
tgt_text.4207: Ptolemy, in consequence, effecting a reconciliation with his sister, pre­ pared, with his utmost efforts, to overthrow that power, which, from hatred to Demetrius, he had procured for Alexander by supplying him with troops.
tgt_text.4208: He therefore sent a large force to the aid of Grypus, and his daughter Tryphæna to many him, that he might induce the people to support his nephew, not only by sharing in the war with him, but by contracting with him this affinity.
tgt_text.4209: Nor were his endeavours without effect;
tgt_text.4210: for when the people saw Grypus upheld by the strength of Egypt, they began by degrees to fall away from Alexander.
tgt_text.4211: A battle then took place between the kings, in which Alexander was defeated, and fled to Antioch.
tgt_text.4212: Here, being without money, and pay being wanted for his soldiers, he ordered a statue of Victory of solid gold, which was in the temple of Jupiter, to be removed, palliating the sacrilege with jests, and saying that "Victory was lent him by Jupiter."
tgt_text.4213: Some days after, having ordered a golden statue of Jupiter himself, of great weight, to be taken away secretly, and being caught in the sacrilegious ct, he was forced to flee by a rising of the people, and being overtaken by a violent storm, and deserted by his men, he fell into the hands of robbers, and being brought before Grypus, was put to death.
tgt_text.4214: Grypus, having thus recovered his father's throne, and being freed from foreign perils, found his life endangered by a plot of his own mother;
tgt_text.4215: who, after betraying, from desire of power, her husband Demetrius, and putting to death her other son, was discontented at her dignity being eclipsed by the victory of Grypus, and presented him with a cup of poison as he was returning home from taking exercise.
tgt_text.4216: But Grypus, having received notice of her treacherous intention, desired her (as if to show as much respect for his mother as she showed for him) to drink herself first, and, when she refused, pressed her earnestly, and at last, producing his informant, charged her with the fact, telling her, " that the only way left to clear herself from guilt, was, that she should drink what she had offered to her son."
tgt_text.4217: The queen, being thus disconcerted, and her wickedness turned upon herself, was killed with the poison which she had prepared for another.
tgt_text.4218: Grypus, accordingly, having securely established his throne, had peace himself, and secured it for his people, for eight years.
tgt_text.4219: At the end of that time a rival for the throne arose, named Cyzicenus, a brother of his own by the same mother, and son of his uncle Antiochus.
tgt_text.4220: Grypus having tried to take him off by poison, provoked him the sooner to contend for the throne with him by force of armsIII.
tgt_text.4221: During these unnatural contentions in the kingdom of Syria, Ptolemy,* king of Egypt, died, leaving the kingdom of Egypt to his wife, and one of her two sons, whichsoever she herself should choose ;
tgt_text.4222: as if the condition of Egypt would be more quiet than that of Syria had been, when the mother, by electing one of her sons, would make the other her enemy.
tgt_text.4223: Though she was more inclined to fix on the younger of lief sons, the people obliged her to nominate the elder, from whom, however, before she gave him the throne, she took away his wife, compelling him to divorce his sister Cleopatra, whom he very much loved, and requiring him to marry his younger sister Selene;
tgt_text.4224: a determination as to her daughters not at all becoming a mother, as she took a husband from one, and gave him to the other.
tgt_text.4225: But Cleopatra being not so much divorced by her husband, as torn from her husband by her mother, married Cyzicenus in Syria, and that she might not bring him the mere name of a wife, carried over to him, as a dowry, the army of Grypus, which she had induced to desert.
tgt_text.4226: Cyzicenus, thinking himself thus a match for the power of his brother, gave him battle, but was defeated and put to flight, and sought refuge in Antioch.
tgt_text.4227: Grypus then proceeded to be­ siege Antioch, in which Cleopatra, the wife of Cyzicenus, was;
tgt_text.4228: and, when he had taken it, Trypheena, the wife of Grypus, desired that nothing should be searched for before his sister Cleopatra, not that she might relieve her in her captivity, but that she might not escape the sufferings of captivity ;
tgt_text.4229: since she had invaded the kingdom chiefly from envy towards her, and by marrying the enemy of her sister had made her­ self her enemy..
tgt_text.4230: She also charged her with bringing a foreign army to decide the disputes between the brothers, and with having married out of Egypt, when she was divorced from her brother, contrary to the will of her mother.
tgt_text.4231: Grypus, on the other hand, besought her, that "he might not be driven to commit so heinous a crime;
tgt_text.4232: " saying, that " by none of his forefathers, in the course of so many civil and foreign wars, had cruelties after victory been inflicted upon women, whom their sex itself protected from the perils of war and from ill- treatment on the part of the conquerors ;
tgt_text.4233: and that in her case, besides the common practice of people at war, there was added the closest tie of blood, for she was the full sister of her who would treat her so cruelly, his own cousin, and aunt to their children."
tgt_text.4234: In addition to these obligations of relationship, he mentioned also the superstitious regard paid to the temple in which she had taken refuge, observing that " the gods were so much the more religiously to be revered by him, as he had been the better enabled to conquer by their favour and protection ;
tgt_text.4235: and that neither by killing her would he diminish the strength of Cyzicenus, nor increase it by re­ storing her to him."
tgt_text.4236: But the more Grypus held back, the more was Tryphæna excited with a womanish pertinacity, fancying that her husband's observations proceeded not from pity but from love.
tgt_text.4237: Summoning some soldiers herself, there­ fore, she despatched a party to kill her sister.
tgt_text.4238: They, going into the temple, and not being able to drag her away, cut off her hands while she was embracing the statue of the goddess.
tgt_text.4239: Soon after Cleopatra expired, uttering imprecations on her unnatural murderers, and commending the avenging of her fate to the outraged deities.
tgt_text.4240: And not long after, another battle being fought, Cyzicenus, being victorious, took Try­ phæna, the wife of Grypus, who had just before killed her sister, prisoner, and by putting her to death made atonement to the manes of his wife.
tgt_text.4242: In Egypt, Cleopatra, being dissatisfied at having her son Ptolemy to share her throne, excited the people against him, and taking from him his wife Selene (the more ignomini ously, as he had now two children by her), obliged him to go into exile, sending, at the same time, for her younger son Alexander, and making him king in his brother's room.
tgt_text.4243: Nor was she content with driving her son from the throne, but pursued him with her arms while he was living in exile in Cyprus.
tgt_text.4244: After forcing him from thence, she put to death the general of her troops, because he had let him escape from his hands alive ;
tgt_text.4245: though Ptolemy, indeed, had left the island from being ashamed to maintain a war against his mother, and not as being inferior to her in forces.
tgt_text.4246: Alexander, alarmed at such cruelty on the part of his mother, deserted her also himself, preferring a life of quiet and security to royal dignity surrounded with danger;
tgt_text.4247: while Cleopatra, fearing lest her elder son P.tolemy should be assisted by Cyzicenus to re-establish himself in Egypt, sent powerful succours to Grypus, and with them Selene, Ptolemy's wife, to marry the enemy of her former husband.
tgt_text.4248: To her son Alexander she sent messengers to recall him to his country ;
tgt_text.4249: but while, by secret treachery, she was plotting his destruction, she was anticipated by him and put to death, perishing, not by the course of nature, but by the hand of her son, and having, indeed, well deserved so infamous an end, since she had driven her mother.
tgt_text.4250: from the bed of her father, had made her two daughters† widows by alternate marriages with their brothers, had made war upon one of her sons after sending him into exile,‡ and plotted against the life of the other § after depriving him of his throne.
tgt_text.4252: Neither did so unnatural a murder, on the part of Alexander, go unpunished ;
tgt_text.4253: for as soon as it was known that the mother had been killed by the wickedness of her son, he was driven by an insurrection of the people, into banishment, and the crown was restored to Ptolemy, who was recalled, because he had refused to make war against his mother, and to take from his brother by force of arms what he himself had previously possessed.
tgt_text.4254: During the course of these proceedings, his natural brother,∥ to whom his father had left the kingdom of Cyrenæ by will, died, appointing the Roman people his heir;
tgt_text.4255: for the fortune of Rome, not content with the limits of Italy, bad now begun to extend itself to the kingdoms of the east.
tgt_text.4256: Thus that part of Africa became a province of the Roman empire ;
tgt_text.4257: and soon afterwards Crete and Cilicia, being subdued in the war against the pirates, were likewise made provinces.
tgt_text.4258: In consequence, the kingdoms of Syria and Egypt, which had been accustomed to aggrandize themselves by wars with their neighbours, being now confined by the vicinity of the Romans, and deprived of all opportunity of extending their frontiers, employed their strength to the injury of one another, so that, being exhausted by continual battles, they fell into contempt with their neighbours, and became a prey to the people of Arabia, a nation previously regarded as unwarlike.
tgt_text.4259: Their king Erotimus, relying on his seven hundred sons, whom he had had by his concubines, and dividing his forces, infested at one time Egypt, and another Syria, and procured a great name for the Arabians, by exhausting the strength of their neighbours.

tgt_text.4262: AFTER the kings and kingdom of Syria had been exhaust ed by unintermitting wars, occasioned by the mutual animosi ties of brothers, and by sons succeeding to the quarrels of their fathers, the people began to look for relief from foreign parts, and to think of choosing a king from among the sovereigns of other nations.
tgt_text.4263: Some therefore advised that they should take Mithridates of Pontus, others Ptolemy of Egypt, but it being considered that Mithridates was engaged in war with the Romans, and that Ptolemy had always been an enemy to Syria, the thoughts of all were directed to Tigranes king of Armenia, who, in addition to the strength of his own kingdom, was supported by an alliance with Parthia, and by a matrimonial connection with Mithridates.
tgt_text.4264: Tigranes, accordingly, being invited to the throne of Syria, enjoyed a most tranquil reign over it for eighteen years, without having occasion to go to war either to attack others or to defend himself.
tgt_text.4266: But Syria, though unmolested by enemies, was laid waste by an earthquake, in which a hundred and seventy thou­ sand people, and several cities, were destroyed;
tgt_text.4267: a portent which the soothsayers declared " to presage a change in things.
tgt_text.4268: "After Tigranes was conquered by Lucullus, Antiochus, the son of Cyzicenus, was made king of Syria by his authority.
tgt_text.4269: But what Lucullus gave, Pompey soon after took away;
tgt_text.4270: telling him, when he made application for the crown, that "he wouldnot give Syria, even if willing to accept him, and much less if unwilling, a king, who for eighteen years, during which Tigra­ nes had governed Syria, had lain hid in a corner of Cilicia, and now, when Tigranes was conquered by the Romans, asked for the reward of other men's labours.
tgt_text.4271: Accordingly, as he had not taken the throne from Tigranes while he held it, so he would not give Antiochus what he himself had yielded to Tigranes, and what he would not know how to defend, lest he should again expose Syria to the depredations of the Jews and Arabians."
tgt_text.4272: He in consequence reduced Syria to the con­ dition of a province, and the whole east, through the dissensions of kings of the same blood, fell by degrees under the power of the Romans.

tgt_text.4279: THE Parthians, in whose hands the empire of the east now is, having divided the world, as it were, with the Romans, were originally exiles from Scythia.
tgt_text.4280: This is apparent from their very name ;
tgt_text.4281: for in the Scythian language exiles are called Parthi.
tgt_text.4282: During the time of the Assyrians and Medes, they were the most obscure of all the people of the east.
tgt_text.4283: Subsequently, too, when the empire of the east was transferred from the Medes to the Persians, they were but as a herd without a name, and fell under the power of the stronger.
tgt_text.4284: At last they became subject to the Macedonians, when they conquered the east;
tgt_text.4285: so that it must seem wonderful to every one, that they should have reached such a height of good fortune as to rule over those nations under whose sway they had been merely slaves.
tgt_text.4286: Being assailed by the Romans, also, in three wars, under the conduct of the greatest generals, and at the most flourishing period of the republic, they alone, of all nations, were not only a match for them, but came oft victorious ;
tgt_text.4287: though it may have been a greater glory to them, indeed, to have been able to rise amidst the Assyrian, Median, and Persian empires, so celebrated of old, and the most powerful dominion of Bactria, peopled with a thousand cities, than to have been victorious in war against a people that came from a distance ;
tgt_text.4288: especially when they were continually harassed by severe wars with the Scythians and other neigh­ bouring nations, and pressed with various other formidable contests.
tgt_text.4289: The Parthians, being forced to quit Scythia by discord at nome, gradually settled in the deserts betwixt Hyrcania, the Dahæ, the Arei, the Sparni * and Marsiani.
tgt_text.4290: They then advanced their borders, though their neighbours, who at first made no opposition, at length endeavoured to prevent them, to such an extent, that they not only got possession of the vast level plains, but also of steep hills, and heights of the mountains;
tgt_text.4291: and hence it is that an excess of heat or cold prevails in most parts of the Parthian territories;
tgt_text.4292: since the snow is troublesome on the higher grounds, and the heat in the plains.
tgt_text.4294: The government of the nation, after their revolt from the Macedonian power, was in the hands of kings.
tgt_text.4295: Next to the royal authority is the order of the people,.
tgt_text.4296: from which they take generals in war and magistrates in peace.
tgt_text.4297: Their language is something between those of the Scythians and Medes, being a compound of both.
tgt_text.4298: Their dress was formerly of a fashion peculiar to themselves;
tgt_text.4299: afterwards, when their power had increased, it was like that of the Medes, light and full flowing.
tgt_text.4300: The fashion of their arms is that of their own country and of Scythia.
tgt_text.4302: They have an army, not like other nations, of free men, but chiefly consisting of slaves, the numbers of whom daily increase, the power of manumission being allowed to none, and all their offspring, in consequence, being horn slaves.
tgt_text.4303: These bondmen they bring up as carefully as their own children, and teach them, with great pains, the arts of riding and shooting with the bow.
tgt_text.4304: As any one is eminent in wealth, so he furnishes the king with a propor­ tionate number of horsemen for war.
tgt_text.4305: Indeed when fifty thousand cavalry encountered Antony, as he was making war upon Parthia, only four hundred of them were free men.
tgt_text.4306: Of engaging with the enemy in close fight, and of taking cities by siege, they know nothing.
tgt_text.4307: They fight on horseback, cither galloping forward or turning their backs.
tgt_text.4308: Often, too, they counterfeit flight, that they may throw their pursuers off their guard against being wounded by their arrows.
tgt_text.4309: The signal for battle among them is given, not by trumpet, but by drum.
tgt_text.4310: Nor are they able to fight long :
tgt_text.4311: but they would be irresistible, if their vigour and perseverance were equal to the fury of their onset.
tgt_text.4312: In general they retire before the enemy in the very heat of the engagement, and, soon after their retreat, return to the battle afresh;
tgt_text.4313: so that, when you feel most certain that you have conquered them, you have still to meet the greatest danger from them.
tgt_text.4314: Their armour, and that of their horses, is formed of plates, lapping over one another like the feathers of a bird, and covers both man and horse entirely*
tgt_text.4315: Of gold and silver, except for adorning their arms, they make no use.
tgt_text.4317: Each man has several wives, for the sake of gratifying desire with different objects.
tgt_text.4318: They punish no crime more severely than adultery, and accordingly they not only exclude their women from entertainments, but forbid them the very sight of men.
tgt_text.4319: They eat no flesh but that which they take in hunting.
tgt_text.4320: They ride on horseback on all occasions ;
tgt_text.4321: on horses they go to war, and to feasts;
tgt_text.4322: on horses they discharge public and private duties;
tgt_text.4323: on horses they go abroad, meet together, traffic, and converse.
tgt_text.4324: Indeed the difference between slaves and freemen is, that slaves go on foot, but freemen only on horseback.
tgt_text.4325: Their general mode of sepulture is dilaniation by birds or dogs;
tgt_text.4326: the bare bones they at last bury in the ground
tgt_text.4327: In their superstitions and worship of the gods, the principal veneration is paid to rivers.
tgt_text.4328: The disposition of the people is proud, quarrelsome, faithless, and insolent;
tgt_text.4329: for a certain roughness of behaviour they think becoming to men, and gentleness only to women.
tgt_text.4330: They are always restless, and ready for any commotion, at home or abroad;
tgt_text.4332: more ready to act than speak, and consequently shrouding both their successes and miscarriages in silence.
tgt_text.4333: They obey their princes, not from humility, but from fear.
tgt_text.4334: They are libidinous, but frugal in diet.
tgt_text.4335: To their word or promise they have no regard, except as far as suits their interest.
tgt_text.4337: After the death of Alexander the Great, when the kingdoms of the east were divided among his successors, the government of Parthia was committed to Stasanor, a foreign ally, because none of the Macedonians would deign to accept it.
tgt_text.4338: Subsequently, when the Macedonians were divided into parties by civil discord, the Parthians, with the other people of Upper Asia, followed Eumenes, and, when he was defeated, went over to Antigonus.
tgt_text.4339: After his death they were under the rule of Seleucus Nicator, and then under Antiochus and his successors, from whose great-grandson Seleucus they first revolted, in the first Punic war, when Lucius Manlius Vulso and Marcus Attilius Regulus were consuls.
tgt_text.4340: For their revolt, the dispute between the two brothers, Seleucus and Antiochus, procured them impunity ;
tgt_text.4341: for while they sought to wrest the throne from one another, they neglected to pursue the revolters.
tgt_text.4342: At the same period, also, Theodotus, governor of the thou­ sand cities of Bactria, revolted, and assumed the title of king;
tgt_text.4343: and all the other people of the east, influenced by bis example, fell away from the Macedonians.
tgt_text.4344: One Arsaces, a man of uncertain origin, but of undisputed bravery, happened to arise at this time;
tgt_text.4345: and he, who was accustomed to live by plunder and depredations, hearing a report that Seleucus was overcome by the Gauls in Asia, and being consequently freed from dread of that prince, invaded Parthia with a band of marauders, overthrew Andragoras his lieutenant, and, after putting him to death, took upon himself the government of the country.
tgt_text.4346: Not long alter, too, he made himself master of Hyrcania, and thus, invested with authority over two nations, raised a largo army, through fear of Seleucus and Theodotus, king of the Bactrians.
tgt_text.4347: But being soon relieved of his fears by the death of Theodotus, he made peace and an alliance with his son, who was also named Theodotus;
tgt_text.4348: and not long aftei, engaging with king Seleucus, who came to take vengeance on the re­ volters, he obtained a victory;
tgt_text.4349: and the Parthians observe the day on which it was gained with great solemnity, as the date of the commencement of their liberty.
tgt_text.4351: Seleucus being then recalled into Asia by new disturb­ ances, and respite being thus given to Arsaces, he settled the Parthian government, levied soldiers, built fortresses, and strengthened his towns.
tgt_text.4352: He founded a city also, called Darn, in Mount Zapaortenon, of which the situation is such, that no place can be more secure or more pleasant;
tgt_text.4353: for it is so encircled with steep rocks, that the strength of its position needs no defenders;
tgt_text.4354: and such is the fertility of the adjacent soil, that it is stored with its own produce.
tgt_text.4355: Such too is the plenty of springs and wood, that it is amply supplied with streams of water, and abounds with all the pleasures of the chace.
tgt_text.4356: Thus Arsaces, having at once acquired and established a kingdom, and having become no less memorable among the Parthians than Cyrus among the Persians, Alexander among the Macedonians, or Romulus among the Romans, died at a mature old age:
tgt_text.4357: and the Parthians paid this honour to his memory, that they called all their kings thenceforward by the name of Arsaces.
tgt_text.4358: His son and successor on the throne, whose name was also Arsaces, fought with the greatest bravery against Antiochus, the son of Seleucus, who was at the head of a hundred thousand foot and twenty thousand horse, and was at last taken into alliance with him.
tgt_text.4359: The third king of the Parthians was Priapatius;
tgt_text.4360: but he was also called Arsaces, for, as has just been observed, they distinguished all their kings by that name, as the Romans use the titles of Cæsar and Au­ gustus.
tgt_text.4361: He, after reigning fifteen years, died, leaving two sons, Mithridates and Phraates, of whom the elder, Phraates, being, according to the custom of the nation, heir to the crown, subdued the Mardi, a strong people, by force of arms, and died not long after, leaving several sons, whom he set aside, and left the throne, in preference, to his brother Mithridates, a man of extraordinary ability, thinking that more was due to the name of king than to that of father, and that he ought to con­ sult the interests of his country rather than those of his children.
tgt_text.4363: Almost at the same time that Mithridates ascended the throne among the Parthians, Eucratides began to reign among the Bactrians;
tgt_text.4364: both of them being great men.
tgt_text.4365: But the for­ tune of the Parthians, being the more successful, raised them, under this prince, to the highest degree of power;
tgt_text.4366: while the Bactrians, harassed with various wars, lost not only their dominions, but their liberty;
tgt_text.4367: for having suffered from conten­ tions with the Sogdians, the Drangians, and the Indians, they were at last overcome, as if exhausted, by the weaker* Par­ thians.
tgt_text.4368: Eucratides, however, carried on several wars with great spirit and though much reduced by his losses in them.
tgt_text.4369: yet, when he was besieged by Demetrius king of the Indians, with a garrison of only three hundred soldiers, he repulsed, by continual sallies, a force of sixty thousand enemies.-
tgt_text.4370: Having accordingly escaped, after a five months’ siege, he reduced India under his power.
tgt_text.4371: But as he was returning from the country, he was killed on his march by his son, with whom he had shared his throne, and who was so far from concealing the murder, that, as if he had killed an enemy, and not his father, he drove his chariot through his blood, and ordered his body to be cast out unburiedDuring the course of these proceedings among the Bac­ trians, a war arose between the Parthians and Modes, and after fortune on each side had been some time fluctuating, victory at length fell to the Parthians;
tgt_text.4372: when Mithridates, enforced with this addition to his power, appointed Bacasis over Media, while he himself marched into Hyrcania.
tgt_text.4373: On his return from thence, he went to war with the king of the Elymæns, and having conquered him, added this nation also to his dominions, and extended the Parthian empire, by reducing many other tribes under his yoke, from Mount Caucasus to the river Euphrates.
tgt_text.4374: Being then taken ill, he died in an honourable old age, and not inferior in merit to hit great-grandfather Arsaces.
tgt_text.4375: Phraates, king of the Parthians, is killed by the Greeks in his army, I.—The Parthians make war on Armenia;

tgt_text.4382: relics of the armies of Crassus and Antony given up to Augustus, V.I. AFTER the death of Mithridates, king of the Parthians, Phraates his son was made king, who, having proceeded to make war upon Syria, in revenge for the attempts of Antiochus on the Parthian dominions, was recalled, by hostilities on the part of the Scythians, to defend his own country.
tgt_text.4383: For the Scythians, having been induced, by the offer of pay, to assist the Parthians against,Antiochus king of Svria, and not having arrived till the war was ended, were disappointed of the ex­ peeled remuneration, and reproached with having brought their aid too late;
tgt_text.4384: and when, in discontent at having made so long a march in vain, they demanded that "either some recompence for their trouble, or another enemy to attack, should be assigned them," being offended at the haughty reply which they received, they began to ravage the country of the Parthians.
tgt_text.4385: Phraates, in consequence, marching against them, left a certain Himerus, who had gained his favours in the bloom of youth, to take care of his kingdom.
tgt_text.4386: But Himerus, unmindful both of his past life, and of the duty with which he was entrusted, miserably harassed the people of Babylon, and many other cities, with tyrannical cruelties.
tgt_text.4387: Phraates himself, meanwhile, took with him to the war a body of Greeks, who had been made prison­ ers in the war against Antiochus, and whom he had treated with great pride and severity, not reflecting that captivity had not lessened their hostile feelings, and that the indignity of the outrages which they had suffered must have exasperated them.
tgt_text.4388: As soon therefore as they saw the Persians giving ground, they went over to the enemy, and executed that revenge for their captivity, which they had long desired, by a sanguinary destruc­ tion of the Parthian army and of king Phraates himself.
tgt_text.4390: In his stead Artabanus, his uncle, was made king.
tgt_text.4391: The Scythians, content with their victory, and with having laid waste Parthia, returned home.
tgt_text.4392: Artabanus, making war upon the Thogarii, received a wound in the arm, of which he imme­ diately died.
tgt_text.4393: He was succeeded by his son Mithridates, to whom his achievements procured the surname of Great;
tgt_text.4394: for, being fired with a desire to emulate the merit of his ancestors, he was enabled by the vast powers of his mind to surpass their renown.
tgt_text.4395: He carried on many wars, with great bravery, against his neighbours, and added many provinces to the Parthian kingdom.
tgt_text.4396: He fought successfully, too, several times, against the Scythians, and avenged the injuries received from them by his forefathers.
tgt_text.4397: At last he turned his arms against Ortoadistes,* king of Armenia.
tgt_text.4398: But since we here make a transition to Armenia, we must look a little farther back into its origin;
tgt_text.4399: for it is not right that so great a kingdom should be passed in silence, since its territory, next to that of Parthia, is of greater extent than any other kingdom.
tgt_text.4400: Armenia, from Cappadocia to the Caspian Sea, stretches over a space of eleven hundred miles, and is seven hundred miles in breadth.
tgt_text.4401: It was founded by Armenius, the companion of Jason of Thessaly, whom King Pelias, wishing to procure his death from dread of his extraordinary ability, which was dangerous to his throne, despatched on a prescribed expedition to Colchis, to bring home the fleece of the ram so celebrated throughout the world;
tgt_text.4402: hoping that the man would lose his life, either in the perils of so long a voyage, or in war with barbarians so remote.
tgt_text.4403: But Jason, having spread abroad the report of so glorious an enterprise, at which the chief of the youth from almost all the world * came flocking to him, collected a band of heroes, who were called Argonauts.
tgt_text.4404: Having brought his troop back safe, and being again driven from Thessaly by the sons of Pelias, he set out on a second voyage for Colchis, accompanied by a numerous train of followers (who, at the fame of his valour, came daily from all parts to join him), by his wife Medea, whom, having previously divorced her, he had now received again from compassion for her exile, and by his step-son Medus, whom she had by Ægeus king of the Athenians ;
tgt_text.4405: and he re-established his father-in-law Æetes† who had been driven from his throne.
tgt_text.4407: He then carried on great wars with the neighbouring nations;
tgt_text.4408: and of the cities which he took, he added part to the kingdom of his father-in-law, to make amends for the injury that he had done him in his former expedition, in which he had carried off his daughter Medea and put to death his son Ægia­ leus,‡ and part he assigned to the people that he had brought with him ;
tgt_text.4409: and he is said to have been the first of mankind, after Hercules and Bacchus (whom tradition declares to have been kings of the east), that subdued that quarter of the world.
tgt_text.4410: Over some of these nations he appointed Recas and Amphi­ stratus, the charioteers of Castor and Pollux, to be their rulers.
tgt_text.4411: With the Albanians he formed an alliance, a people who are said to have followed Hercules out of Italy, from the Alban mount, when, after having killed Geryon, he was driving his herds through Italy, and who, remembering their Italian descent, saluted the soldiers of Pompey in the Mithridatic war as their brothers.
tgt_text.4412: Hence almost the whole east appointed divine honours, and erected temples, to Jason, as their founder;
tgt_text.4413: temples which Parmenio, one of the generals of Alexander the Great, caused many years after to be pulled down, that no name might be more venerated in the east than that of Alexander After the death of Jason, Medus, emulous of his virtues, built a city named Medea in honour of his mother, and established the kingdom of the Medes after his own name, under whose do­ minion the empire of the east afterwards fell.
tgt_text.4414: On the Albanians border the Amazons, whose queen Thalestris, as many authors relate, sought the couch of Alexander.
tgt_text.4415: Armenius, too, who was himself a Thessalian, and one of the captains of Jason, having re-assembled a body of men, who, after the death of Jason were wandering about, founded Armenia, from the mountains of which the river Tigris issues, at first with a very small stream, out after running some distance, is lost in the earth, and then, flowing five and twenty miles underground,* rises up a great river in the province of Sophene;
tgt_text.4416: and thus it is received into the marshes of the Euphrates.
tgt_text.4418: Mithridates king of the Parthians, after his war with Armenia, was banished from his kingdom for his cruelty by the Parthian senate.
tgt_text.4419: His brother Orodes, who took possession of the vacant throne, besieged Babylon, whither Mithridates had fled, for some time, and reduced the people, under the in­ fluence of famine, to surrender.
tgt_text.4420: Mithridates, from confidence in his relationship to Orodes, voluntarily put himself into his hands;
tgt_text.4421: but Orodes, contemplating him rather as an enemy than a brother, ordered him to be put to death before his face.
tgt_text.4422: After this, he carried on a war with the Romans, and overthrew their general Crassus, together with his son and all the Roman army.
tgt_text.4423: His son Pacorus, who was sent to pursue what re­ mained of the Roman forces, after achieving great actions in Syria, incurred some jealousy on the part of his father, and was recalled into Parthia;
tgt_text.4424: and during his absence the Parthian army left in Syria was cut off, with all its commanders, by Cassius the quæstor of Crassus.
tgt_text.4425: Not long after these occurrences the civil war among the Romans, between Cæsar and Pompey, broke out, in which the Parthians took the side of Pompey, both from the friendship that they had formed with him in the Mithri­ datic war, and because of the death of Crassus, whose son they understood to be of Cæsar’s party, and supposed that, if Cæsar were victorious, he would avenge his father's fate.
tgt_text.4426: When Pom­ pey’s party was worsted, they sent assistance to Cassius and Bru­ tus against Augustus and Antony;
tgt_text.4427: and, after the war was ended, they made an alliance with Labienus, and, under the leadership of Pacorus, again laid waste Syria and Asia, and assailed, with a vast force, the camp of Ventidius, who, like Cassius before him, had routed the Parthian army in the absence of Pacorus.
tgt_text.4428: Venti­ dius, pretending to be afraid, kept himself a long time in his camp, and suffered the Parthians to insult him.
tgt_text.4429: At last, however, when they were full of security and exultation, he sent out part of his legions upon them, and the Parthians, put to flight by their onset, went off in several directions;
tgt_text.4430: when Pacorus, supposing that his fugitive troops had drawn off all the Roman forces in pursuit of them, attacked Ventidius's camp, as if it had been left without defenders.
tgt_text.4431: Upon this, Ventidius, pouring forth the rest of his troops, put the whole force of the Par. thians, with their king Pacorus, to the sword;
tgt_text.4432: nor did the Parthians, in any war, ever suffer a greater slaughter.
tgt_text.4433: When the news of this discomfiture reached Parthia, Orodes, the father of Pacorus, who had just before heard that Syria had been ravaged, and Asia occupied by his Parthians, and was boasting of his son Pacorus as the conqueror of the Romans, was affected, on hearing of the death of his son and the de­ struction of his army, at first with grief, and afterwards with disorder of the intellect.
tgt_text.4434: For several days he neither spoke to any one, nor took food, nor uttered a sound, so that he seemed to have become dumb.
tgt_text.4435: Some time after, when his sorrow found vent in words, he did nothing but call upon Pacorus ;
tgt_text.4436: Pacorus seemed to be seen and heard by him;
tgt_text.4437: Pacorus appeared to talk with him, and stand by him;
tgt_text.4438: though at other times he mourned and wept for him as lost.
tgt_text.4439: After long indulgence in grief, another cause of concern troubled the unhappy old man, as he had to de­ termine which of his thirty sons he should choose for his succes­ sor in the room of Pacorus.
tgt_text.4440: His numerous concubines, from whom so large a progeny had sprung, were pepetually working on the old man's feelings, each anxious for her own offspring
tgt_text.4441: But the fate of Parthia, in which it is now.
tgt_text.4443: tomary that the princes should be assassins of their kindred, ordained that the most cruel of them all, Phraates by name should be fixed upon for their king.
tgt_text.4445: Phraates immediately proceeded to kill his father, as if he would not die, and put to death, also, all his thirty- brothers.
tgt_text.4446: But his murders did not end with his father's sons;
tgt_text.4447: for finding that the nobility began to detest him for his con­ stant barbarities, he caused his own son, who was grown up, to be killed, that there might be no one to be nominated king.
tgt_text.4448: On this prince Antony made war, with sixteen effective legions, for having sent troops against him and Caesar;
tgt_text.4449: but being severely, harassed in several engagements, he was forced to retreat from Parthia.
tgt_text.4450: Phraates, upon this success, becom­ ing still more insolent, and being guilty of many fresh acts of cruelty, was driven into exile by his subjects.
tgt_text.4451: Having then, for a long time, wearied the neighbouring people, and at last the Scythians, with entreaties for aid, he was at last restored to his throne by a powerful Scythian force.
tgt_text.4452: During his absence, the Parthians had made one Tiridates king, who, when he heard of the approach of the Scythians, fled with a great body of his partisans to Cæsar,† who was then carrying on war in Spain, ‡ taking with him, as a hostage for Cæsar, the youngest son of Phraates, whom, being but negligently guarded, he had secretly carried off.
tgt_text.4453: Phraates, on hearing of his flight, immediately sent ambassadors to Caesar, requesting that " his slave Tiridates, and his son, should be restored to him."
tgt_text.4454: Cæsar, after listening to the embassy of Phraates, and de­ liberating on the application of Tiridates (for he also had asked to be restored to his throne, saying that " Parthia would be wholly in the power of the Romans, if he should hold the kingdom as a gift from them"), replied, that “ he would neither give up Tiridates to the Parthians, nor give assistance to Tiridates against the Parthians."
tgt_text.4455: That it might not appear, however, that nothing had been obtained from Cæsar by all their applications, he sent back to Phraates his son without ransom, and ordered a handsome maintenance to be furnished to Tiridates, as long as he chose to continue among the Romans.
tgt_text.4456: Some time after, when Cæsar had finished the Spanish war, and had proceeded to Syria to settle the affairs of the east, he caused some alarm to Phraates, who was afraid that he might contemplate an invasion of Parthia.
tgt_text.4457: Whatever prisoners, accordingly, remained of the army of Crassus or Antony throughout, Parthia, were collected together, and sent, with the military standards that had been taken, to Augustus.
tgt_text.4458: In addition to this, the sons and grandsons of Phraates were delivered to Augustus as hostages;
tgt_text.4459: and thus Caesar effected more by the power of his name, than any other general could have done by his armsEarly age of Italy, I.—Birth and youth of Romulus and Remus, IT.- Foundation of Rome;

tgt_text.4464: family of Trogus Pompeius, V.I. HAVING narrated the history of the Parthians and other eastern nations, and of almost the whole world, Trogus re­ turns home, as if after a long journey in foreign parts, to relate the rise of the city of Rome, thinking it would be the mark of an ungrateful citizen, if, after he had set forth the acts of other nations, he should be silent concerning his native country alone.
tgt_text.4465: He therefore briefly touches on the origin of the Roman empire, so as neither to exceed the bounds of the work that he had proposed, nor to pass unnoticed the origin of a city which is now the mistress of the world.
tgt_text.4466: The first inhabitants of Italy were the Aborigines, whoso king, Saturn, is said to have been a man of such extraordinary justice, that no one was a slave in his reign, or had any private property, but all things were common to all, and undivided, as one estate for the use of every one ;
tgt_text.4467: in memory of which way of life, it has been ordered that at the Saturnalia slaves should everywhere sit down with their masters at the entertainments, the rank of all being made equal.
tgt_text.4468: Italy was accordingly called, from the name of that king, Saturnia;
tgt_text.4469: and the hill on which he dwelt Saturnius, on which now stands the Capitol, as if Saturn had been dislodged from his seat by Jupiter.
tgt_text.4470: After him, third in descent, they say that Faunus was king, in whose time Evander came into Italy from Pallanteum, a city of Arcadia, accompanied with a small band of his countrymen, to whom Faunus kindly gave land, and the mountain which he afterwards called Palatium.
tgt_text.4471: At the foot of this mountain he built a temple to the Lycæan god, whom the Greeks call Pan, and the Romans Lupercus,* the naked statue of the deity being covered with a goat-skin, in which dress the priests now run up and down during the Lupercalia at Rome.
tgt_text.4472: This Faunus had a wife named Fatua, who, being constantly filled with a spirit of divination, gave notice, in fits of frenzy as it were, of things to come ;
tgt_text.4473: and hence, to this day, those who are accustomed to be thus inspired, are said fatuari.
tgt_text.4475: Of an illicit connection between a daughter of Faunus and Hercules, (who, having killed Geryon about that time, was driving his herds, the prize of his victory, through Italy), was born Latinus, in whose reign AEneas came from Ilium ‡ into Italy, after the destruction of Troy by the Greeks, and being immediately received with hostile demonstrations, led out his troops into the field, but being first invited to a conference, raised such admiration of himself in Latinus, that he was both admitted to a sham of his throne, and became his son-in-law by a marriage with his daughter Lavinia.
tgt_text.4476: After this event, they had to carry on war in concert against Tumus, king of the Rutulians, because he had been disappointed of marrying Lavinia;
tgt_text.4477: and in the war both Turnus and Latinus were killed.
tgt_text.4478: AEneas, in consequence, becoming by right of victory master of both nations, built a city which he called Lavinium, from the name of his wife.
tgt_text.4479: Some time afterwards, he went to war with Mezentius, king of the Etrurians, and being killed in it, Ascanius his son succeeded him, who, removing from Lavi.
tgt_text.4480: Ilium, built Alba Longa, which for three hundred years was the metropolis of his kingdom.
tgt_text.4482: At length, after many kings had reigned in this city, Numitor and Amulius became joint sovereigns.
tgt_text.4483: But Amulius, having deprived Numitor, who was the elder, of his share of the throne, condemned his daughter Rhea to perpetual vir­ ginity, that no male offspring of Numitor's family might arise to claim the crown, palliating the injury by an appearance of honour, so that she might not seem to have been compelled, but to have been chosen one of the vestal virgins.
tgt_text.4484: Being shut up, accordingly, in a grove sacred to Mars, she gave birth to two boys, whether the offspring of an illicit connexion with a mortal, or of the god Mars, is uncertain.
tgt_text.4485: This affair becoming known, Amulius, whose fears were increased by the birth of twins, ordered the children to be exposed, and threw his niece into prison, of which ill-treatment she died.
tgt_text.4486: Fortune, however, having a care for the raising of Rome, threw the children in the way of a she-wolf to be suckled, which, having lost her cubs, and longing to empty her overcharged teats, offered herself as a nurse to the infants.
tgt_text.4487: As she made frequent returns to the children, as if they had been her own offspring, Faustulus, a shepherd, observed her proceedings, and, withdrawing them from the beast, brought them up in a rude way of life among his cattle.
tgt_text.4488: That they were the sons of Mars, was believed, as on plain proof, either because they were born in the grove of Mars, or because they were nursed by a wolf, which is under the protection of Mars.
tgt_text.4489: The names of the boys were Remus and Romulus.
tgt_text.4490: As they grew up among the shepherds, daily contests in strength increased their vigour and agility.
tgt_text.4491: While they were frequently engaged, with great activity, in preventing robbers from seizing the cattle, it happened that Remus, having been taken by the robbers, was brought before the king,- as if he had himself been guilty of that which he was endeavouring to prevent in others, and had been accustomed to make depredations on Numitor's flocks.
tgt_text.4492: He was consequently given up to Numitor for punishment.
tgt_text.4493: But Numitor,t who was touched with compas­ sion for the stripling's youth, was led to suspect that he might be one of his exposed grandchildren, and while the resemblance of his features to those of his daughter, and his age corre­ sponding with the time of the exposure, kept him in suspense, Faustulus unexpectedly came in with Romulus, and the origin of the youths being ascertained from him, a conspiracy was formed, the young men taking up arms to revenge the death of their mother, and Numitor to recover the throne of which he had been deprived.
tgt_text.4495: Amulius being killed, the tnrone was restored to Numitor, and the city of Rome was founded by the two young men.
tgt_text.4496: A senate was next appointed, consisting of a hundred old men who were called Fathers.
tgt_text.4497: Soon after, as the neighbouring people disdained to intermarry with shepherds, the Sabine virgins were seized by force;
tgt_text.4498: and the surrounding tribes being brought under their sway, the sovereignty of Italy, and afterwards that of the world, was acquired.
tgt_text.4499: In those times kings, instead of diadems, had spears, which the Greeks called sceptres;
tgt_text.4500: for the ancients, from the earliest period, worshipped spears as gods,.
tgt_text.4501: and in memory of this superstition spears are still given to the statues of the gods.
tgt_text.4502: In the time of King Tarquin, a company of Phocæans from Asia, sailing up the Tiber, formed an alliance with the Romans, and proceeding from thence to the inmost part of the gulf of Gaul,t built the city of Marseilles amidst the Ligurians and the savage Gallic tribes, and performed great exploits there, both in defending themselves against the fierce Gauls, and in attacking, of themselves, those by whom they had previously been molested.
tgt_text.4503: The Phocæans, compelled by the smallness and infertility of their territory, had applied themselves more to the sea than to the culture of the ground, supporting themselves by fishing, merchandise, and above all by piracy, which in those days was thought an honourable occupation.-
tgt_text.4504: Venturing accordingly to visit the remotest shores of the ocean, they came into the gulf of Gaul and to the mouth of the river Rhone;
tgt_text.4505: and, charmed with the pleasantness of the country, and relating, on their return home, what they had seen, they tempted others to go to the same parts.
tgt_text.4506: Of the fleet Simos and Protis were the captains, who applied to the king of the Segobrigii, named Nannus, in whose territory they were anxious to build a city, desiring his friendship.
tgt_text.4507: On that day, as it happened, the king was engaged in preparing for the nuptials of his daughter Gyptis, whom, after the custom of that people, he intended to give in marriage to a son-in-law to be chosen at the feast.
tgt_text.4508: The suitors having been all invited to the wedding, the Grecian strangers were also requested to join the festival.
tgt_text.4509: The maiden was then introduced, and being desired by her father to give water to him whom she chose for her husband, she overlooked all the rest, and turning to the Greeks, held out water to Prods, who, from the king's guest becoming his son-in-law, was presented by his father-in-law with the ground for building a city.
tgt_text.4510: Marseilles was accordingly built near the mouth of the river Rhone, in a retired bay, and as it were in a corner of the sea.
tgt_text.4511: The Ligurians, jealous of the growing greatness of the city, harassed the Greeks with continual war;
tgt_text.4512: but they, repelling their attacks, rose to such a degree of strength, that they conquered their enemies and planted several colonies in the lands which they captured.
tgt_text.4514: From the people of Marseilles, therefore, the Gauls learned a more civilized way of life, their former barbarity being laid aside or softened;
tgt_text.4515: and by them they were taught to cultivate their lands and to enclose their towns with walls
tgt_text.4516: Then too, they grew accustomed to live according to laws, and not by violence ;
tgt_text.4517: then they learned to prune the vine and plant the olive;
tgt_text.4518: and such a radiance was shed over both men and things, that it was not Greece which seemed to have immi­ grated into Gaul, but Gaul that seemed to have been trans­ planted into Greece.
tgt_text.4519: After Nannus, king of the Segobrigii, from whom the ground for building the city had been received, was dead, and his son Comanus had succeeded to the throne.
tgt_text.4520: a certain Lagurian told him that " Marseilles would one day be the ruin of the neighbouring people, and that he ought to suppress it in its rise, lest, when it grew stronger, it should overpower him.”
tgt_text.4521: To this prediction he added the following fable:
tgt_text.4522: "A bitch once asked a shepherd, when she was big with young, for a place to bring forth her puppies ;
tgt_text.4523: having obtained it, she re­ quested again that she might be allowed to bring them up in the same place ;
tgt_text.4524: and at last, when her young were grown up, and she could depend upon their support, she claimed posses­ sion of the place as her own.
tgt_text.4525: In like manner," he continued, “ the people of Marseilles, who are now regarded as your tenants, will one day become masters of your territory."
tgt_text.4526: Moved by these persuasions, the king formed a plan to overthrow Marseilles ;
tgt_text.4527: in pursuance of which, on the day appointed for the feast of Flora, he sent into the city several stout and able men, who were admitted as friends ;
tgt_text.4528: an additional number he ordered to be conveyed concealed in wagons, covered over with baskets and boughs of trees ;
tgt_text.4529: while he himself lay hid among the neighbouring hills, that after the gates had been opened in the night by the men before mentioned, he might come up in time to execute the plot, and might fall upon the city overcome with sleep and the fumes of wine.
tgt_text.4530: But a certain woman, a relative of the king, who had an intrigue with a Greek youth, revealed the plot to him, through compas­ sion for his youth and beauty, during their intercourse, and bade him escape from the danger.
tgt_text.4531: He however reported the matter to the magistrates, and the treachery being thus made public, all the Ligurians were seized, those concealed being dragged from among their baskets;
tgt_text.4532: and when they were all put to death, a plot was formed to surprise the plotter, and seven thousand of the enemy, with the king himself, were slain.
tgt_text.4533: Since that time the Massilians, on festal days, have been accustomed to shut their gates, to keep watch, to place sentinels on the walls, to examine strangers, to take all kinds of precaution, and to guard the city as carefully in time of peace as if they were at war.
tgt_text.4534: Thus what was wisely instituted, is still observed, not from the necessity of circumstances, but from the habit of acting prudently.
tgt_text.4536: Subsequently they had great wars with the Ligurians and Gauls, which increased the fame of their city, and ren derel the valour cf the Greeks, by their manifold victories renowned among their neighbours.
tgt_text.4537: The forces of the Carthagi­ nians,* too, in a war which rose between them about the capture of some fishing boats, they often routed, and granted them peace under defeat;
tgt_text.4538: with the Spaniards they made an alliance ;
tgt_text.4539: with the Romans they faithfully observed the league concluded al­ most at the foundation of the city, and effectively supported their allies, in all their wars, with auxiliary troops.
tgt_text.4540: Such con duct both increased their confidence in their own strength, and secured them peace from their enemies.
tgt_text.4541: But after a time, when Marseilles was at the height of distinction, as well for the fame of its exploits as for the abundance of its wealth and its reputation for strength, the neighbouring people, on a sudden, conspired to destroy the very name of Marseilles, as they would have united to put out a fire that threatened them all.
tgt_text.4542: Catu­ mandus, one of their petty princes, was unanimously chosen general, who, when he was besieging the enemy's city with a vast army of select troops, was frightened in his sleep by the vision of a stern-looking woman, who told him that she was a goddess, and of his own accord made peace with the Massilians.
tgt_text.4543: Having then asked permission to enter their city and pay adoration to their gods, and having gone into the temple of Minerva, and observed in the portico the statue of the goddess whom he had seen in his sleep, he suddenly exclaimed that it was she who had frightened him in the night;
tgt_text.4544: that it was she who had ordered him to raise the siege ;
tgt_text.4545: ” then, congratu­ lating the Massilians that they were under the care, as he perceived, of the immortal gods, and offering a neck-lace of gold to the goddess, he made a league with them for ever.
tgt_text.4546: After peace was thus obtained, and security established, some deputies from Marseilles, as they were returning from Delphi, whither they had been sent to carry presents to Apollo, heard that the city of Rome had been taken and burned by the Gauls.
tgt_text.4547: This calamity, when the news of it was brought home to them, the Massilians lamented with a public mourning, and contributed gold and silver, both public and private, to make up the sum to be given to the Gauls, from whom they knew that peace was bought.
tgt_text.4548: For this service an exemption from taxes was decreed them, a place in the theatre assigned them among the senators, and a league made with them upon equal terms.

tgt_text.4559: This country the ancients first called Iberia, from the river Iberus, and afterwards Hispania, from some person named Hispanus.
tgt_text.4560: It lies be­ tween Africa and Gaul, and is bounded by the Ocean Strait ‡ and the Pyrenees.
tgt_text.4561: It is less than either of these countries, but more fruitful than either;
tgt_text.4562: for it is neither scorched, like Africa, by a burning sun, nor disturbed, like Gaul,§ by incessant winds, but, being situate betwixt both, it is rendered, by moderate heat on the one hand, and genial and seasonable showers on the other, fertile in all kinds of fruits of the earth, 50 that it supplies abundance of everything, not only for its own inhabitants, but for Italy and the city of Rome.
tgt_text.4563: From hence, indeed, comes not only great plenty of corn, but of wine, honey, and oil.
tgt_text.4564: Its iron is excellent, and its breed of horses swift.
tgt_text.4565: Not only is the produce of the surface to be admired, but the abundant riches of the metals hidden beneath it.
tgt_text.4566: There is great plenty, too, of flax and hemp, and certainly no country is more productive of vermilion.
tgt_text.4567: The courses of the rivers fire not violent and rapid, so as to be hurtful, but gentle, watering the vineyards and the plains;
tgt_text.4568: they are also well stocked with fish from the estuaries of the sea, and most of them are rich in gold, which they carry down with their waters..
tgt_text.4569: It is joined to Gaul by one unbroken ridge of the Pyrenees;
tgt_text.4570: on every other side it is surrounded by sea.
tgt_text.4571: The shape of the country is almost square, except that it grows narrower towards the Pyrenees, the shores contracting in that quarter.
tgt_text.4572: The length of the Pyrenees is six hundred miles.
tgt_text.4573: The salubrity of the air is the same through the whole of Spain, for its atmosphere is infected with no unwholesome mists from fens.
tgt_text.4574: Besides, there are constant breezes from the sea on every side, by which, as they penetrate the whole country, the exhalations from the earth are dispersed, and the greatest health is secured to the inhabitants.
tgt_text.4576: The bodies of the inhabitants are well adapted to endure privation and fatigue;
tgt_text.4577: their minds are inured to contempt of death.
tgt_text.4578: A strict and parsimonious abstinence prevails among them all.

tgt_text.4582: Many have died under torture, to conceal what has been entrusted to them;
tgt_text.4583: so much stronger is their love of honour than of life.
tgt_text.4584: The patience of a slave, too, is greatly praised, who, having avenged his master in the war with the Carthaginians, exulted with smiles in the midst of tortures, and defied, with serenity and cheer­ fulness, the utmost cruelty of his tormentors.
tgt_text.4585: The activity of the people is extraordinary;
tgt_text.4587: To many, their war-horses and arms are dearer than their blood.
tgt_text.4588: There is no sumptuous preparation among them for festival days;
tgt_text.4589: nor was it till after the second Punic war that they learned from the Romans to use warm baths.
tgt_text.4590: During so long a course of years they have had no great general besides Viriatus,* who maintained a struggle against the Romans for ten years with various success;
tgt_text.4591: so much more similar are their dispositions to those of wild beasts than of men;
tgt_text.4592: and this very leader they followed, not as having been chosen by the judgment of the people, but as being well qualified to take precautions against the enemy, and artful in avoiding danger.
tgt_text.4593: His temperance and moderation were such, that though he often defeated armies commanded by consuls, yet, after such achievements, he made no change in the fashion of his dress or arms, or in his diet, but adhered to the same way of life with which he commenced his military career;
tgt_text.4594: so that any one of the common soldiers seemed better off than the general himself.
tgt_text.4596: In Lusitania, near the river Tagus, many authors have said that the mares conceive from the effect of the wind;
tgt_text.4597: but such stories have had their origin in the fecundity of the mares, and the vast number of herds of horses, which are so numerous, and of such swiftness, in Gallæcia and Lusitania, that they may be thought, not without reason, to have been the offspring of the wind.
tgt_text.4598: As for the Gallæcians, they claim for themselves a Greek origin;
tgt_text.4599: for they say that Teucer, after the end of the Trojan war, having incurred the hatred of his father on account of the death of his brother Ajax, and not being admitted into his kingdom, retired to Cyprus, where he built a city called Salamis, from the name of his native land;
tgt_text.4600: that, some time after, on hearing a report of his father's death, he returned again to his country, but, being hindered from landing by Eurysaces the son of Ajax, he sailed to the coast of Spain, and took possession of those parts where New Carthage now stands, and, passing from thence to Gallæcia, and fixing his abode there, gave name to the nation.

tgt_text.4604: It is also very rich in gold, so that they sometimes turn up clods of gold † with the plough.
tgt_text.4605: In the territory of this people there is a sacred mountain, which it is thought impious to open with any tool of iron, but whenever the earth is rent with lightning, an occurrence common in these parts, it is allowable to pick up the gold that may be laid open, as a gift from the deity of the place.
tgt_text.4606: The women manage household affairs, and the culture of the ground;
tgt_text.4607: the men attend only to arms, and the pursuit of spoil.
tgt_text.4608: Their iron is of an extra­ ordinary quality, but their water is more powerful than the iron itself;

tgt_text.4641: After the rule of kings was at an end, the Carthaginians were the first that made themselves masters of the country;
tgt_text.4642: for when the Gaditani, according to directions which they re­ ceived in a dream, had removed the sacred things of Hercules from Tyre, whence also the Carthaginians had their origin, into Spain, and had built a city there, the neighbouring people of the country, being jealous of the rise of this new city, and in consequence attacking the Gaditani in war, the Cartha­ ginians sent them succour as being their kindred.
tgt_text.4643: The expe­ dition being successful, they both secured the Gaditani from injury, and added the greatest part of the province to their own dominions.
tgt_text.4644: Subsequently, too, the success of their first attempt encouraging them, they sent their general Hamilcar, with a large army, to take possession of the whole country, who, having performed great exploits, but pursuing his fortune too rashly, was drawn into an ambush and killed.
tgt_text.4645: In his stead was sent his son-in-law Hasdrubal, who was also killed by the slave of a certain Spaniard, to avenge the unjust death of his master.

tgt_text.4775: I. THEMISTOCLES was the son of Neocles, an Athenian.
tgt_text.4776: The vices of his early youth were compensated by great vir­ tues, so that no one is thought superior, and few are considered equal to him.
tgt_text.4777: But we must begin from the beginning.
tgt_text.4778: His father Neocles was of a good family, and married a native of Acharnæ,∗ of whom Themistocles was the son.
tgt_text.4779: Falling under the displeasure of his parents, because he lived too freely, and took no care of his property, he was disinherited by his father.
tgt_text.4780: This disgrace, however, did not dishearten him, but incited him to exertion, for being aware that it could not be ob­ literated without the utmost efforts on his part, he devoted himself wholly to affairs of state, studying diligently to benefit his friends as well as his own reputation.
tgt_text.4781: He was much engaged in private causes, and appeared often before the assembly of the people;
tgt_text.4782: no matter of importance was managed without him;
tgt_text.4783: he quickly discovered what was necessary to be done, and readily explained it in his speeches.
tgt_text.4784: Nor was he less ready in managing business than in devising plans for it, for, as Thucydides says, he formed a most accurate judgment of present affairs, and the shrewdest conjectures as to the future.
tgt_text.4785: Hence it happened that he soon became distinguished.
tgt_text.4787: His first step in the management of public affairs was in the Corcyræan war.*
tgt_text.4788: Being chosen commander by the people to conduct it, he increased the confidence of the citizens, not only as to the struggle in which they were en­ gaged, but for time to come.
tgt_text.4789: As the public money, which came in from the mines, was annually wasted by the pro­ fusion† of the magistrates, he prevailed on the people that a fleet of a hundred ships should be built with that money.
tgt_text.4790: This being soon constructed, he first reduced the Corcyræans, and then, by vigorously pursuing the pirates, rendered the sea secure.
tgt_text.4791: In acting thus, he both supplied the Athenians with wealth, and made them extremely skilful in naval war­ fare.
tgt_text.4792: How much this contributed to the safety of Greece in general, was discovered in the Persian war, when Xerxes assailed the whole of Europe by sea and land, with such a force as no man ever had, before or since;

tgt_text.4794: When the news of his approach was spread through Greece, and the Athenians, on account of the battle of Marathon, were said to be the chief objects of his attack, they sent to Delphi to ask what they should do in their present circumstances.

tgt_text.4796: As no one understood to what this answer tended, Themistocles suggested that it was Apollo's recommendation that they should put themselves and their property on board their ships, for that such were the wooden walls intended by the god.

tgt_text.4826: He also rebuilt the walls of Athens at his own individual risk , for the Lacedæmonians, having found a fair pretext, in consequence of the inroads of the barbarians, for saying that no walled town should be kept up without the Peloponnesus, in order that there might be no fortified places of which the enemy might take possession, attempted to prevent the Athenians from building them.
