tgt_text.4899: Above all, it was through his integrity, when he was joined in command of the common fleet of Greece with Pausanias, under whose leadership Mardonius had been put to flight, that the supreme authority at sea was transferred from the Lacedæmonians to the Athenians;
tgt_text.4900: for before that time the Lacedaemonians had the command both by sea and land.
tgt_text.4901: But at this period it happened, through the indiscreet conduct of Pausanias, and the equity of Aristides, that all the states of Greece attached themselves as allies to the Athenians, and chose them as their leaders against the barbarians.
tgt_text.4903: -In order that they might repel the barbarians more easily, if perchance they should try to renew the war, Aristides was chosen to settle what sum of money each state should con­ tribute for building fleets and equipping troops.
tgt_text.4904: By his ap­ pointment four hundred and sixty talents were deposited annually at Delos, which they fixed upon to be the common treasury;
tgt_text.4905: but all this money was afterwards removed to Athens.
tgt_text.4906: How great was his integrity, there is no more certain proof, than that, though he had been at the head of such important affairs, he died in such poverty that he scarcely left money to defray the charges of his funeral.
tgt_text.4907: Hence it was that his daughters were brought up at the expense of the country, and were married with dowries given them from the public treasury.
tgt_text.4908: He died about four years after Themistooles was banished from Athens.
tgt_text.4909: Pausanias at Platææ, L—He takes Byzantium, and makes advances to Xerxes, II.
tgt_text.4913: His death at the temple of Minerva, V.I. PAUSANIAS the Lacedæmonian was a great man;
tgt_text.4914: but of varied character in all the relations of life;
tgt_text.4915: for as he was ennobled by virtues, he was also obscured by vices.
tgt_text.4916: His most famous battle was that at Platææ, for, under his command Mardonius, a royal satrap, by birth a Mede, and son-in-law tc the king (a man, among the chief of all the Persians, brave in action and full of sagacity), at the head of two hundred thousand infantry, whom he had chosen man by man, and twenty thousand cavalry, was routed by no very large army of Greeks;
tgt_text.4917: and the general himself was slain in the struggle.
tgt_text.4918: Elated by this victory, he began to indulge in irregular proceedings,* and to covet greater power.
tgt_text.4919: But he first in­ curred blame on this account, that he offered at Delphi, out of the spoil, a golden tripod with an inscription written upon it, in which was this statement, that " the barbarians had been cut off at Platææ by his management, and that, on account of that victory, he had presented this offering to Apollo."
tgt_text.4920: These lines the Lacedæmonians erased, and wrote nothing but the names of the states by whose aid the Persians had been conquered.
tgt_text.4922: After this battle they sent Pausanias with the confede­ rate fleet to Cyprus and the Hellespont, to expel the garrisons of the barbarians from those parts.
tgt_text.4923: Experiencing equal good fortune in this enterprise, he began to conduct himself still more haughtily, and to aim at still higher matters ;
tgt_text.4924: for having, at the taking of Byzantium, captured several Persian noble­ men, and among them some relations of the king, he sent them secretly back to Xerxes, and pretended that they had escaped out of prison.
tgt_text.4925: He sent with them, also, Gongylus of Eretria, to carry a letter to the king, in which Thucydides t has recorded that the following words were written :
tgt_text.4927: Pausa­ nias, the general of Sparta, having discovered that those whom he took at Byzantium are your relations, has sent them back as a gift, and desires to be joined in affinity with you.
tgt_text.4928: If there­ fore it seem good to you, give him your daughter in marriage.
tgt_text.4929: Should you do so, he engages, with your aid, to bring both Sparta and the rest of Greece under your sway.
tgt_text.4930: If you wish anything to be done with regard to these proposals, be careful to send a trustworthy person to him, with whom he may confer.
tgt_text.4931: "The king, extremely delighted at the restoration of so many persons so nearly related to him, immediately despatched Artabazus with a letter to Pausanias, in which he commended him, and begged that he would spare no pains to accomplish what he promised;
tgt_text.4932: if he effected it, he should never meet with a refusal of anything from him.
tgt_text.4933: Pausanias, learning what the king's pleasure was, and growing more eager for the accomplishment of his designs, fell under the suspicion of the Lacedæmonians.
tgt_text.4934: In the midst of his proceedings, accord­ ingly, he was recalled home, and being brought to trial on a capital charge, was acquitted on it, but sentenced to pay a fine;
tgt_text.4935: for which reason he was not sent back to the fleet.
tgt_text.4937: Not long after, however, he returned to the army of his own accord, and there, not in a sensible, but in an insane manner, let his views become known;
tgt_text.4938: for he laid aside, not only the manners of his country, but its fashions and dress.
tgt_text.4939: He adopted regal splendour and Median attire;
tgt_text.4940: Median and Egyptian guards attended him;
tgt_text.4941: he had his table served, after the Persian manner, more luxuriously than those who were with him could endure;
tgt_text.4942: he refused permission to approach him to those who sought it;
tgt_text.4943: he gave haughty replies and severe commands.
tgt_text.4944: To Sparta he would not return, but with­ drew to Colonæ, a place in the country of Troas, where he formed designs pernicious both to his country and himself.
tgt_text.4945: When the Lacedæmonians knew of his proceedings, they sent deputies to him with a scytala.
tgt_text.4946: on which it was written, after their fashion,!
tgt_text.4947: that " if he did not return home, they would condemn him to death."
tgt_text.4948: Being alarmed at this communication, but hoping that he should be able, by his money and his influence, to ward off the danger that threatened him, he returned home.
tgt_text.4949: As soon as he arrived there, he was thrown into the public prison by the Ephori, for it is allowable, by their laws.
tgt_text.4950: for any one of the Ephori to do this to a king..
tgt_text.4951: He however got himself freed from confinement, but was not cleared from suspicion, for the belief still prevailed, that he bad made a compact with the king of Persia.
tgt_text.4952: There is a certain class of men called Helots, of whom a great number till the lands of the Lacedæmonians, and per­ form the duties of slaves.
tgt_text.4953: These men he was thought to have solicited, by holding out to them hopes of liberty, to join him.
tgt_text.4954: But as there was no visible ground for a charge against him on these points, on which he might be convicted, they did not think that they ought to pronounce, concerning so eminent and famous a man, on suspicion only, but that they must wait till the affair should disclose itself.
tgt_text.4956: In the meantime a certain Argilian, † a young man whom, in his boyhood, Pausanias had loved with an ardent affection.‡ having received a letter from him for Artabazus, and conceiving a suspicion that there was something written in it about himself, because no one of those who had been sent to the same place on such an errand, had returned, loosed the string of the letter, § and taking off the seal, discovered that if he delivered it he would lose his life.
tgt_text.4957: In the letter were also some particulars respecting matters that had been arranged between the king and Pausanias.
tgt_text.4958: This letter he delivered to the Ephori.
tgt_text.4959: The cautious prudence of the Lacedæmonians, on this occasion, is not to be passed without notice;
tgt_text.4960: for they were not induced, even by this man's information, to seize Pausanias, nor did they think that violent measures should be adopted, until he gave proof of his own guilt.
tgt_text.4961: They accordingly directed the informer what they wished to have done.
tgt_text.4962: At Tænarus there is a temple of Neptune, which the Greeks account it a heinous crime to profane.
tgt_text.4963: To this temple the informer fled, and sat down on the steps of the altar.
tgt_text.4964: Close to the building, they made a recess under ground, from which, if any one held communication with the Argilian, he might be overheard;
tgt_text.4965: and into this place some the Ephori went down.
tgt_text.4966: Pausanias, when he heard that the Argilian had fled to the altar, came thither in great trepida­ tion, and seeing him sitting as a suppliant at the altar of the divinity, he inquired of him what was the cause of so sudden a proceeding.
tgt_text.4967: The Argilian then informed him what he had learned from the letter, and Pausanias, being so much the more agitated, began to entreat him " not to make any discovery, or to betray him who deserved great good at his hands;
tgt_text.4968: " adding that, "if he would but grant him this favour, and assist him when involved in such perplexities, it should be of great advantage to himV.
tgt_text.4969: The Ephori, hearing these particulars, thought it better that he should be apprehended in the city.
tgt_text.4970: After they had set out thither, and Pausanias, having, as he thought, pacified the Argilian, was also returning to Lacedæmon, he understood (just as he was on the point of being made prisoner) by a look from one of the Ephori who wished to warn him, that some secret mischief was intended against him.
tgt_text.4971: He accord­ ingly fled for refuge, a few steps before those who pursued him, into the temple of Minerva, which is called Chalcicecos.*
tgt_text.4972: That he might not escape from thence, the Ephori immediately blocked up the folding-doors of the temple, and pulled off the roof, that he might more readily die in the open air.
tgt_text.4973: It is said that the mother of Pausanias was then living, and that, though very aged, she was among the first to bring a stone, when she heard of her son's guilt, to the door of the temple, in order to shut him in.
tgt_text.4974: Thus Pausanias tarnished his great glory in war by a dishonourable death.
tgt_text.4975: As soon as he was carried, half-dead, out of the temple, lie gave up the ghost.
tgt_text.4976: When some said that his body ought to be carried to the place where those given up to capital punish­ ment were buried, the proposal was displeasing to the ma­ jority, and they interred him at some distance from the spot in which he died.
tgt_text.4977: He was afterwards removed from thence, in consequence of an admonition from the Delphic god, and buried in the same place where he had ended his life.
tgt_text.4978: Cimon is compelled to go to prison on the death of his father;
tgt_text.4979: is liberated by his wife, I.—His character and actions;
tgt_text.4980: he defeats the Persians by land and sea on the same day, II.
tgt_text.4981: —Is ostracised and recalled, and makes peace with the Lacedæmonians;
tgt_text.4983: —His praises, IV.I. CIMON, the son of Miltiades, an Athenian, experienced a very unhappy entrance on manhood;
tgt_text.4984: for as his father had been unable to pay to the people the fine imposed upon him, and had consequently died in the public gaol, Cimon was kept in prison, nor could he, by the Athenian laws,* be set at liberty, unless he paid the sum of money that his father had been fined.
tgt_text.4985: He had married, however, his sister by the father's side,f named Elpinice, induced not more by love than by custom ;
tgt_text.4986: for the Athenians are allowed to marry their sisters by the same father ;
tgt_text.4987: and a certain Callias, a man whose birth was not equal to his wealth, and who had made a great fortune from the mines, being desirous of having her for a wife, tried to prevail on Cimon to resign her to him, saying that if he obtained his desire, he would pay the fine for him.
tgt_text.4988: Though Cimon received such a proposal with scorn, Elpinice said that she would not allow a son of Miltiades to die in the public prison, when she could prevent it;
tgt_text.4989: and that she would marry Callias if he would perform what he promised.
tgt_text.4991: Cimon, being thus set free from confinement, soon attained great eminence;
tgt_text.4992: for he had considerable eloquence, the utmost generosity, and great skill, not only in civil Jaw, but in military affairs, as he had been employed from his boy­ hood with his father in the army.
tgt_text.4993: He in consequence held the people of the city under his control, and had great influ­ ence over the troops.
tgt_text.4994: In his first term of service, on the river Strymon, he put to flight great forces of the Thracians, founded the city of Amphipolis, and sent thither ten thousand Athenian citizens as a colony.
tgt_text.4995: He also, in a second expe­ dition.
tgt_text.4996: conquered and took at Mycale a fleet of two hundred ships belonging to the Cyprians and Phoenicians, and ex­ perienced like good fortune by land on the same day;
tgt_text.4997: for after capturing the enemy's vessels, he immediately led out his troops from the fleet, and overthrew at the first onset a vast force of the barbarians.
tgt_text.4998: By this victory he obtained a great quantity of spoil;
tgt_text.4999: and, as some of the islands, through the rigour of the Athenian government, had revolted from them, he secured the attachment, in the course of his return home, of such as were well disposed, and obliged the disaffected to return to their allegiance.
tgt_text.5000: Scyros, which the Dolopes at that time inhabited, he depopulated, because it had behaved itself insolently, ejecting the old settlers from the city and island, and dividing the lands among his own countrymen.
tgt_text.5001: The Thasians, who relied upon their wealth, he reduced as soon as he attacked them.
tgt_text.5002: With these spoils the citadel of Athens was adorned on the side which looks to the south.
tgt_text.5004: When, by these acts, he had attained greater honour in the state than any other man, he fell under the same public odium as his father, and others eminent among the Athenians ;
tgt_text.5005: for by the votes of the shells, which they call the ostracism, he was condemned to ten years' exile.
tgt_text.5006: Of this proceeding the Athenians repented sooner than himself;
tgt_text.5007: for after he had sub­ mitted, with great fortitude, to the ill-feeling of his ungrateful countrymen, and the Lacedæmonians had declared war against the Athenians, a desire for his well-known bravery im­ mediately ensued.
tgt_text.5008: In consequence, he was summoned back to his country five years after he had been banished from it.
tgt_text.5009: But as he enjoyed the guest-friendship* of the Lacedæmonians, he thought it better to hasten to Sparta, and accordingly pro­ ceeded thither of his own accord, and settled a peace between those two most powerful states.
tgt_text.5010: Being sent as commander, not long after, to Cyprus, with a fleet of two hundred ships, he fell sick, after he had conquered the greater part of the island, and died in the town of Citium.
tgt_text.5012: The Athenians long felt regret for him, not only in war, but in time of peace;
tgt_text.5013: for he was a man of such liberality, that though he had farms and gardens in several parts, he never set a guard over them for the sake of preserving the fruit, so that none might be hindered from enjoying his property as he pleased.
tgt_text.5014: Attendants always followed him with money, that, if any one asked his assistance, he might have something to give him immediately, lest, by putting him off, he should appear to refuse.
tgt_text.5015: Frequently, when he saw a man thrown in his way by chance* in a shabby dress, he gave him his own cloak.
tgt_text.5016: A dinner was dressed for him daily in such abundance, that he could invite all whom he saw in the forum uninvited ;
tgt_text.5017: a ceremony which he did not fail to observe every day.
tgt_text.5018: His protection, his assistance, his pecuniary means, were withheld from none.
tgt_text.5020: and he buried at his own cost many poor persons, who at their death had not left sufficient for their interment.
tgt_text.5021: In consequence of such conduct, it is not at all surprising that his life was free from trouble, and his death severely felt.
tgt_text.5022: Lysander conquers the Athenians, and establishes a decemvirate in the several states of Greece, I.—His cruelty to the Thracians, II.
tgt_text.5023: —He endeavours to dethrone the kings of Sparta, and corrupt the various oracles;
tgt_text.5024: is brought to trial and acquitted;
tgt_text.5025: is killed by the Thebans, III.
tgt_text.5026: —Was his own accuser, IV.I. LYSANDER, the Lacedæmonian, left a high character of himself, which was gained, however, more by good fortune than by merit.
tgt_text.5027: That he subdued the Athenians, when thej were at war with the Lacedæmonians, in the twenty-sixth year of the contest, is certain;
tgt_text.5028: but how he obtained that con­ quest is but little known;
tgt_text.5029: for it was not effected by the valour of his own troops, but by the want of discipline among the enemy, who, from not being obedient to the commands of their leaders, but straggling about in the fields, and abandoning their vessels, fell into the power of their adversaries ;
tgt_text.5030: in conse­ quence of which disaster the Athenians submitted to the Lacedæmonians.
tgt_text.5031: Lysander, elated with this victory, and having always before been a factious and bold man, allowed himself such liberty, that the Lacedæmonians, through his conduct, incurred the greatest unpopularity throughout Greece;
tgt_text.5032: for they having said that their object in going to war was to humble the overbear­ ing tyranny of the Athenians, Lysander, after he had captured the enemy's fleet at Ægospotamos, endeavoured after nothing so much as to keep all the states of Greece under his autho­ rity, while he pretended that he acted thus for the sake of the Lacedæmonians.
tgt_text.5033: Having every where ejected those who favoured the party of the Athenians, he made choice of ten men in each city, on whom he conferred supreme authority, and the control of all proceedings.
tgt_text.5034: Into the number of these no one was admitted who was not attached to him by friendship, or who had not assured him, by pledging his faith, that he would be entirely at his disposal.
tgt_text.5036: The decem viral government being thus established in every city, everything was done according to his pleasure.
tgt_text.5037: Of his cruelty and perfidy it is sufficient to give one instance, by way of example, that we may not weary our readers by enu­ merating many acts of the same individual.
tgt_text.5038: As he was returning in triumph from Asia, and bad turned aside towards Thasos, he endeavoured, as the people had been eminent for fidelity to the Athenians, to corrupt them,* as if those were wont to be the firmest friends who had been steady enemies.
tgt_text.5039: But he saw that unless he concealed his intention in the affair,, the Thasians would elude him, and take measures for their own interests.
tgt_text.5041: The decem viral government, which had been ap­ pointed by him, his countrymen abolished.
tgt_text.5042: Incensed at this affront, he entered upon measures to remove the kings of the Lacedæmonians;
tgt_text.5043: but he found that he could not effect his object without support from the gods, because the Lace dæmonians were accustomed to refer everything to the oracles.
tgt_text.5044: In the first place, therefore, he endeavoured to corrupt Delphi, and, when he could not succeed in doing so, he made an attempt upon Dodona.
tgt_text.5045: Being disappointed there also, he gave out that he had made vows which he must pay to Jupiter Ammon, thinking that he would bribe the Africans with greater ease.
tgt_text.5046: When he had gone, accordingly, with this expectation into Africa, the priests of Jupiter greatly disappointed him, for they not only would not be bribed, but even sent deputies to Lacedæmon to accuse Lysander of " having endeavoured to corrupt the ministers of the temple."
tgt_text.5047: After being brought to trial on this charge, and being acquitted by the votes of his judges, he was sent with some auxiliary troops to the Orcho­ menians, and killed by the Thebans at Haliartus.
tgt_text.5048: How just was the decision regarding him,t the speech was a proof, which was found in his house after his death, and in which he recommended to the Lacedæmonians, that, after they had abolished the regal government, a leader should be chosen from among the whole people to conduct the war ;
tgt_text.5049: but it was written in such a manner, that it might seem to be in accord­ ance with the advice of the gods, which he, relying on his money, did not doubt that he should procure.
tgt_text.5050: This speech Cleon of Halicarnassus is said to have written for himIV.
tgt_text.5051: In this place a transaction of Pharnabazus, the king's satrap, must not be omitted.
tgt_text.5052: When Lysander, as commander of the fleet, had done many cruel and avaricious acts in the course of the war, and suspected that reports of these proceed­ ings had been made to his countrymen, he asked Pharnabazus to give him a testimonial to present to the Ephori, showing with what conscientiousnes he had carried on the war and treated the allies, begging him to write fully concerning the matter, as his authority on that head would be great.
tgt_text.5053: Phar. nabazus promised him fairly, and wrote a long and full letter,* in which he extolled him with the greatest praises.
tgt_text.5054: But when Lysander had read and approved of it, Pharnabazus substi­ tuted, while it was being sealed, another of the same size in its place, so like it that it could not be distinguished from it, in which he had most circumstantially accused him of avarice and perfidy.
tgt_text.5055: Lysander, accordingly, when he had returned home, and had said what he wished before the chief magistrates, handed them, as a testimonial, the letter which he had received from Pharnabazus.
tgt_text.5056: The Ephori, after having perused it when Lysander was withdrawn, gave it to him to read.
tgt_text.5057: Thus he became unawares his own accuser.
tgt_text.5058: Alcibiades eminent both in his virtues and vices, I.—His education, II.
tgt_text.5059: —He commands in the expedition against Syracuse;
tgt_text.5060: is suspected of profaning the mysteries, and of conspiring against the govern­ ment, III.
tgt_text.5061: —Is recalled home, but flees, and attaches himself to the Lacedæmonians, IV.—
tgt_text.5062: Falling under suspicion among them, he flees to the Persians, and is afterwards reconciled to his countrymen, V.— His enthusiastic reception at Athens, VI.—
tgt_text.5065: He tries to promote the good of his country, VIII.
tgt_text.5067: —Is killed in Phrygia, X.—His character, XLI.
tgt_text.5068: ALCIBIADES, t son of Clinias, was a native of Athens.
tgt_text.5069: In him nature seems to have tried what she could do;
tgt_text.5070: for it is agreed among all who have written concerning him, that no one was ever more remarkable than he, either for vices or vir­ tues.
tgt_text.5071: Born in a most distinguished city, of a very high family, and by far the most handsome of all the men of his age, he was qualified for any occupation, and abounded in practical intelligence.
tgt_text.5072: He was eminent as a commander by sea and lai d;
tgt_text.5073: he was eloquent, so as to produce the greatest effect by his speeches;
tgt_text.5074: for such indeed was the persuasiveness of his looks and language, that in oratory no one was a match for him.
tgt_text.5076: and, when occasion required, labo­ rious, patient, liberal, and splendid, no less in his public than in his private life;
tgt_text.5077: t he was also affable and courteous, conform­ ing dexterously to circumstances;
tgt_text.5078: but, when he had unbent himself, and no reason offered why he should endure the labour of thought, was seen to be luxurious, dissolute, volup­ tuous, and self-indulgent, so that all wondered there should be such dissimilitude, and so contradictory a nature, in the same man.
tgt_text.5080: He was brought up in the house of Pericles (for he is said to have been his step-son),‡ and was taught by Socrates.
tgt_text.5081: For his father-in-law he had Hipponicus, the richest man of all that spoke the Greek language;
tgt_text.5082: so that, even if he had contrived for himself, he could neither have thought of more advantages, nor have secured greater, than those which fortune or nature had bestowed upon him.
tgt_text.5083: At his entrance on man­ hood he was beloved by many, after the manner of the Greeks, and among them by Socrates, whom Plato mentions in his Symposium;
tgt_text.5084: for he introduces Alcibiades, saying that " he had passed the night with Socrates, and had not risen up from him otherwise than a son should rise from a father."
tgt_text.5085: When he was of maturer age, he had himself no fewer objects of affection, his intercourse with whom, as far as was possible, he did many acts of an objectionable character, in a delicate and agreeable manner;
tgt_text.5086: which acts we would relate, had we not other things to tell of a higher and better nature.
tgt_text.5088: In the Peloponnesian war, the Athenians, by his ad­ vice and persuasion, declared war against the Syracusans, to conduct which he himself was chosen general.
tgt_text.5089: Two colleagues were besides assigned him, Nicias and Lamachus.
tgt_text.5090: While the expedition was in preparation, and before the fleet sailed, it happened one night that all the statues of Mercury* that were in the city of Athens were thrown down, except one, which was before the gate of Andocides, and which, in consequence, was afterwards generally called the Mercury of Andocides.†
tgt_text.5091: As it appeared that this could not have been done without a strong confederacy of many persons, since it had respect not to a private but to a public matter,‡ great dread was excited among the multitude, lest some sudden tumult should arise in the city to destroy the people's liberty.
tgt_text.5092: The suspicion of this seemed chiefly to attach to Alcibiades, because he was con­ sidered both more influential, and of higher standing, than any private person;
tgt_text.5093: for he had secured many adherents by his generosity, and had made still more his friends by assisting them in legal proceedings.
tgt_text.5094: Hence it happened, that as often as he appeared in public, he drew the eyes of all people upon him;
tgt_text.5095: nor was any man in the whole city thought equal to him.
tgt_text.5096: They accordingly bad not only the greatest hope of him, but also the greatest fear, because he was able to do much harm as well as much good.
tgt_text.5097: He was sullied also by ill report, for it was said that he celebrated the mysteries § in his own house, a practice which, according to public opinion among the Athenians, was regarded as impious;
tgt_text.5098: and this matter was thought to have reference, not to religion, but to a conspiracy.
tgt_text.5100: Of this crime he was accused by his enemies in a public assembly of the people.
tgt_text.5101: But the time for him to set out to the war was drawing near;
tgt_text.5102: and he considering this, and being aware of the habit t of his countrymen, requested that, if they wished anything to be done concerning him, an examination should rather be held upon him while he was pre sent, than that he should be accused in his absence of a crime against which there was a strong public feeling. ‡
tgt_text.5103: But his enemies resolved to continue quiet for the present, because they were aware that no hurt could then be done him, and to wait for the time when he should have gone abroad, that they might thus attack him while he was absent.
tgt_text.5105: for after they supposed that he had reached Sicily, they impeached him, during his absence, of having profaned the sacred rites.
tgt_text.5106: In consequence of this affair, a messenger, to desire him to return home to plead his cause, being de­ spatched into Sicily to him by the government, at a time when he had great hopes of managing his province success­ fully, he yet did not refuse to obey, but went on board a trireme which had been sent to convey him.
tgt_text.5107: Arriving in this vessel at Thurii in Italy, and reflecting much with himself on the ungovernable license § of his countrymen, and their violent feelings towards the aristocracy, and deeming it most advan­ tageous to avoid the impending storm, he secretly withdrew from his guards, and went from thence first to Elis, and after­ wards to Thebes.
tgt_text.5108: But when he heard that he was condemned to death, his property having been confiscated, and as had been usual, that the priests called Eumolpidæ had been obliged by the people to curse him, and that a copy of the curse, engraven on a stone pillar, had been set up in a public place, in order that the memory of it might be better attested, he removed to Lacedæmon.
tgt_text.5109: There, as he was accustomed to declare, he carried on a war, not against his country, but against his enemies, because the same persons were enemies to their own city;
tgt_text.5110: for though they knew that he could be of the greatest service to the republic, they had expelled him from it, and consulted their own animosity more than the common advantage.
tgt_text.5111: By his advice, in consequence, the Lace dæmonians made an alliance with the king of Peisia, and afterwards fortified Deceleia in Attica, and having placed a constant garrison there, kept Athens in a state of blockade.
tgt_text.5112: By his means, also, they detached Ionia from its alliance with the Athenians, and after this was done, they began to have greatly the advantage in the contest.
tgt_text.5114: Yet by these proceedings they were not so much ren­ dered friends to Alcibiades, as alienated from him by fear;
tgt_text.5115: for when they saw the singular intelligence of this most active- minded man in every way, they were afraid that, being moved by love for his country, he might at some time revolt from them, and return into favour with his countrymen.
tgt_text.5116: They therefore determined to seek an opportunity for killing him.
tgt_text.5117: But this determination could not long be concealed from Alcibiades;
tgt_text.5118: for he was a man of such sagacity that he could not be deceived, especially when he turned his attention to putting himself on his guard.
tgt_text.5119: He in consequence betook him­ self to Tissaphernes, a satrap of King Darius;
tgt_text.5120: and having gained a way to an intimate friendship with him, and seeing that the power of the Athenians, from the ill success of their attempts in Sicily, was on the decline, while that of the Lace­ daemonians, on the other hand, was increasing, he first of all conferred, through messengers, with Pisander the Athenian commander, who had a force at Samos, and made some men tion concerning his return;
tgt_text.5121: for Pisander, with the same feelings as Alcibiades, was no friend to the power of the people, but a favourer of the aristocracy.
tgt_text.5122: Though deserted by him,* he was received at first, through the agency of Thrasybulus the son of Lycus, by the army, and made com­ mander at Samos;
tgt_text.5123: and afterwards, from Theramenes making -nterest for him, he was recalled by a decree of the people, and, while still absent, was appointed to equal command with Thrasybulus and Theramenes.
tgt_text.5124: Under the influence of these leaders, so great a change in affairs took place, that the Lace­ dæmonians, who had just before flourished as conquerors, were struck with fear and sued for peace;
tgt_text.5125: for they had been de­ feated in five battles by land, and three by sea, in which they had lost two hundred triremes, that had been captured and had fallen into the possession of their enemies.
tgt_text.5126: Alcibiades, with his colleagues, had recovered Ionia, the Hellespont, and many Greek cities besides, situated on the coast of Asia, of which they had taken several by storm, and among them Byzantium.
tgt_text.5127: Nor had they attached fewer to their interest by policy, as they had exercised clemency towards those who were taken prisoners;
tgt_text.5128: and then, laden with spoil, and having enriched the troops and achieved very great exploits, they returned to Athens.
tgt_text.5130: The whole city having gone down to the Piræeus to meet them, there was such a longing among them all to see Alcibiades, that the multitude flocked to his galley as if he had come alone;
tgt_text.5131: for the people were fully persuaded of this, that both their former in success, and their present good fortune, had happened through his means.
tgt_text.5132: They therefore attributed the loss of Sicily, and the victories of the Lace­ dæmonians, to their own fault, in having banished such a man from the country.
tgt_text.5133: Nor did they seem to entertain this opinion without reason;
tgt_text.5134: for after Alcibiades had begun to command the army, the enemies could withstand them neither by land nor by sea.
tgt_text.5135: As soon as he came out of his ship, though Theramenes and Thrasybulus had commanded in the same enterprises, and came into the Piræeus at the same time with him, yet the people all followed him alone, and (what had never happened before, except in the case of conquerors at Olympia) he was publicly presented with golden and brazen crowns.
tgt_text.5136: Such kindness from his countrymen be received with tears, remembering their severity in past times.
tgt_text.5137: When he arrived at the city, and an assembly of the people had been called, he addressed them in such a manner, that no one was so unfeeling as not to lament his ill-treatment, and declare himself an enemy to those by whose agency he had been driven from his country, just as if some other people, and not the same people that was then weeping, had sentenced him to suffer for sacrilege.
tgt_text.5138: His property was in consequence made good to him at the public cost, and the same priests, the Eumolpidæ, who had cursed him, were obliged to recal their curses;
tgt_text.5139: and the pillars, on which the curse had been written, were thrown into the sea.
tgt_text.5141: This happiness of Alcibiades proved by no means lasting;
tgt_text.5142: for after all manner of honours had been decreed him, and the whole management of the state, both at home and in the field, had been committed to him, to be regulated at his sole pleasure, and he had requested that two colleagues, Thrasybulus and Adimantus, should be assigned him (a re­ quest which was not refused), proceeding with the fleet to Asia, he fell again under the displeasure of his countrymen, because he did not manage affairs at Cyme * to their wish;
tgt_text.5143: for they thought that he could do every thing.
tgt_text.5144: Hence it happened that they imputed whatever was done unsuccessfully to his misconduct, saying that he acted either carelessly or treacherously, as it fell out on this occasion, for they alleged that he would not take Cyme, because he had been bribed by the king.
tgt_text.5145: We consider, therefore, that their extravagant opinion of his abilities and valour was his chief misfortune;
tgt_text.5146: since he was dreaded no less than he was loved, lest, elated by good fortune and great power, he should conceive a desire to become a tyrant.
tgt_text.5147: From these feelings it resulted, that they took his commission from him in his absence, and put another commander in his place.
tgt_text.5148: When he heard of this proceeding, he would not return home, but betook himself to Pactye,t and there established three fortresses, Bomi, Bisanthe, and Neontichos, and having collected a body of troops, was the first man of any Grecian state t that penetrated into Thrace, thinking it more glorious to enrich himself with spoils from barbarians than from Greeks.
tgt_text.5149: In consequence his fame in­ creased with his power, and he secured to himself a strong alliance with some of the kings of Thrace.
tgt_text.5151: Yet he could not give up his affection for his country;
tgt_text.5152: for when Philocles, the commander of the Athenians, had stationed his fleet at Ægospotamos, and Lysander, the captain of the Lacedæmonians (who was intent upon protracting the war as long as possible, because money was supplied to the Lacedæmonians by the king, while to the exhausted Athenians, on the other hand, nothing was left but their arms and their ships) was not far distant, Alcibiades came to the army of the Athenians, and there, in the presence of the common soldiers began to assert,* that "if they pleased, he would force Lysander either to fight or beg peace;
tgt_text.5153: that the Lacedæmo­ nians were unwilling to engage by sea, because they were stronger in land-forces than in ships;
tgt_text.5154: but that it would be easy for him to bring down Seuthes, king of the Thracians, to drive them from the land, and that, when this was done, they would of necessity either come to an engagement with their fleet, or put an end to the war."
tgt_text.5155: Philocles, though he saw that this statement was true, would not yet do what was desired, for he knew that he himself, if Alcibiades were restored to the com­ mand, would be of no account with the army;
tgt_text.5156: and that, if any success resulted, his share in the matter would amount to nothing, while, on the other hand, if any ill-fortune occurred, he alone would be called to account for the miscarriage.
tgt_text.5157: Alcibiades, on taking leave of him, said, " As you hinder your country's success, I advise you to keep your sailors' camp near the enemy ;
tgt_text.5158: for there is danger that, through the insub­ ordination of our men, an opportunity may be afforded to Lysander of cutting off our army."
tgt_text.5159: Nor did his apprehension deceive him;
tgt_text.5160: for Lysander, having learned from his scouts that the body of the Athenian force was gone on shore to seek for plunder, and that the ships were left almost empty, did not neglect the opportunity of making an attack, and by that single effort put an end to the whole war.
tgt_text.5162: Alcibiades, after the Athenians were defeated, not thinking those parts sufficiently safe for him, concealed himself in the inland parts of Thrace above the Propontis, trusting that his wealth would most easily escape notice there, But he was disappointed ;
tgt_text.5163: for the Thracians, when they learned that he had come with a great sum of money, formed a plot against him, and robbed him of what he had brought, but were unable to secure his person.
tgt_text.5164: Perceiving that no place was safe for him in Greece, on account of the power of the Lacedæmonians, he went over into Asia to Phar­ nabazus, whom be so charmed, indeed, by his courtesy, that no man had a higher place in his favour;
tgt_text.5165: for he gave him Grunium, a strong-hold in Phrygia, from which he annually received fifty talents' revenue.
tgt_text.5166: But with this good fortune Alcibiades was not content, not could endure that Athens, conquered as she was, should con. tinue subject to the Lacedæmonians.
tgt_text.5167: He was accordingly bent, with his whole force of thought, on delivering his country, but saw that that object could not be effected without the aid of the king of Persia, and therefore desired that he should be attached to him as a friend;
tgt_text.5168: nor did he doubt that he should easily accomplish his wish, if he had but an opportunity for an interview with him;
tgt_text.5169: for he knew that his brother Cyrus was secretly preparing war against him, with the aid of the Lace­ dæmonians, and foresaw that, if he gave him information of this design, he would find great favour at his hands.
tgt_text.5171: While he was trying to effect this object, and entreating Pharnabazus that he might be sent to the king, Critias, and the other tyrants of the Athenians, despatched at the same time persons in their confidence into Asia to Lysander, to acquaint him, that, " unless he cut off Alcibiades, none of those arrangements which he had made at Athens would stand;
tgt_text.5172: and therefore, if he wished his acts to remain unaltered, he must pursue him to death."
tgt_text.5173: The Lacedæmonian, roused by this message, concluded that he must act in a more decided manner with Pharnabazus.
tgt_text.5174: He therefore announced to him, that " the relations which the king had formed with the Lacedæmonians would be of no effect, unless he delivered up Alcibiades alive or dead."
tgt_text.5175: The satrap could not withstand this menace, and chose rather to violate the claims of humanity than that the king's interest should suffer.
tgt_text.5176: He accordingly sent Sysamithres and Bagæus to kill Alcibiades, while he was still in Phrygia, and preparing for his journey to the king.
tgt_text.5177: The persons sent gave secret orders to the neighbourhood, in which Alcibiades then was, to put him to death.
tgt_text.5178: They, not daring to attack him with the sword, collected wood during the night round the cottage in which he was sleeping, and set light to it, that they might despatch by fire him whom they despaired of conquering hand to hand.*
tgt_text.5179: Alcibiades, having been awakened by the crackling of the flames, snatched up (as his word had been secretly taken away from him) the side­ weapon of a friend of his;
tgt_text.5180: for there was with him a certain associate from Arcadia, who would never leave him.
tgt_text.5181: This man he desired to follow him, and caught up whatever gar­ ments he had at hand, and throwing them out upon the fire, passed through the violence of the flames.
tgt_text.5182: When the barba­ rians saw that he had escaped the conflagration, they killed him by discharging darts at him from a distance,† and carried his head to Phamabazus.
tgt_text.5183: A woman, who had been accustomed to live with him, burned his dead body, covered with her own female garments, in the fire of the house which had been prepared to burn him alive.
tgt_text.5184: Thus Alcibiades, at the age of about forty, came to his end.
tgt_text.5186: This man, defamed by most writers, three historians of very high authority have extolled with the greatest praises;
tgt_text.5187: Thucydides, who was of the same age with him ;
tgt_text.5188: Theopompus, who was born some time after;
tgt_text.5190: the two latter, though much addicted to censure, have, I know not how, con­ curred in praising him only;
tgt_text.5191: for they have related of him what we have stated above, and this besides, that though he was born in Athens, the most splendid of cities, he surpassed all the Athenians in grandeur and magnificence of living;
tgt_text.5192: that when, on being banished from thence, he went to Thebes, he so devoted himself to the pursuits of the Thebans, that no man could match him in laborious exercises and vigour of body, for all the Bœotians cultivate corporeal strength more than mental power;
tgt_text.5193: that when he was among the Lacedæmo­ nians, in whose estimation the highest virtue is placed in endurance, he so resigned himself to a hardy way of life, that he surpassed all the Lacedæmonians in the frugality of his diet and living;
tgt_text.5194: that when he was among the Thracians, who are hard drinkers and given to lewdness, he surpassed them also in these practices ;
tgt_text.5195: that when he came among the Persians, with whom it was the chief praise to hunt hard and live high, he so imitated their mode of life, that they themselves greatly admired him in these respects;
tgt_text.5196: and that by such conduct, he occasioned that, with whatever people he was, he was regarded as a leading man, and held in the utmost esteem.
tgt_text.5197: But we have said enough of him;
tgt_text.5198: let us proceed to speak of others.
tgt_text.5200: he proceeds to deliver his country from the Thirty Tyrants, I.-His success and conduct in the enterprise, II.
tgt_text.5202: -He is honoured with an olive crown;
tgt_text.5203: is killed on the coast of Sicily, IV.I. THRASYBULUS, the son of Lycus, was a native of Athens.
tgt_text.5204: If merit is to be valued by itself, without regard to fortune, I doubt whether I ought not to place him first of all the Greek commanders.
tgt_text.5205: This I can say without hesitation, that I set no man above him in integrity, firmness, greatness of mind, and love for his country;
tgt_text.5206: for while many have wished, and few have been able, to deliver their country from one tyrant, it was his lot to restore his country, oppressed by thirty tyrants, from slavery to freedom.
tgt_text.5207: But though no man excelled him in these virtues, many, I know not how, surpassed him in fame.
tgt_text.5208: First of all, in the Peloponnesian war, he accomplished many undertakings without Alcibiades, while Alcibiades did nothing without him ;
tgt_text.5209: of all which successes Alcibiades, from certain natural advantages, got the credit.
tgt_text.5210: All such actions, however, are common to commanders with their soldiers and with fortune;
tgt_text.5211: for, in the shock of battle, the issue is trans­ ferred from generalship to the strength and fury of the combatants.
tgt_text.5212: The soldier, therefore, of his own right, takes something from the general, and fortune a great deal, and may truly say that she has had more influence on the event than the skill of the commander.
tgt_text.5213: This most noble action, then, is entirely Thrasybulus's ;
tgt_text.5214: for when the Thirty Tyrants, ap pointed by the Lacedæmonians, kept Athens oppressed in a state of slavery, and had partly banished from their country, and partly put to death, a great number of the citizens whom fortune had spared in the war, and had divided their confis cated property among themselves, he was not only the first, but the only man at the commencement, to declare war against them.
tgt_text.5216: When he fled to Phyle, which is a very strong fortress in Attica, he had not more than thirty of his countrymen with him;
tgt_text.5217: such was the origin of the deliverance of the Athenians, such the dependence of the liberty of that most famous city.
tgt_text.5218: He was at first, indeed, despised by the tyrants, as well as the small number of his followers;
tgt_text.5219: which circumstance proved both the ruin of those that despised him, and the security of him that was despised, for it rendered the one party slow to attack, and the other stronger by giving them time for prepa­ ration.
tgt_text.5220: The maxim, therefore, that " nothing should be despised in war," ought the more deeply to be fixed in the minds of all;
tgt_text.5221: and we should remember that it is not said without reason, that " the mother of a cautious person.
tgt_text.5223: The force of Thrasybulus, however, was not increased in proportion to his expectations;
tgt_text.5224: for even in those times good men spoke for liberty with more spirit than they fought for it.
tgt_text.5225: Hence he went to the Piræeus, and fortified the Munychia,t which the tyrants twice attempted to storm, but being dis­ gracefully repulsed, and having lost their arms and baggage, they immediately fled back to the city.
tgt_text.5226: Thrasybulus, on this occasion, exercised not less prudence than valour;
tgt_text.5227: for he for­ bade those that fled to be injured, thinking it just that " countrymen should spare countrymen;
tgt_text.5228: " nor was any one wounded except such as would attack him first.
tgt_text.5229: He spoiled no one, as he lay, of his clothes;
tgt_text.5230: he laid hands on nothing but arms, of which he was in want, and provisions.‡
tgt_text.5231: In the second battle Critias, the leader of the tyrants, was killed, after having, indeed, fought with great bravery against Thra­ sybulus.
tgt_text.5233: Critias being overthrown, Pausanias, king of the Lace­ dæmonians, came to the support of the Athenians.
tgt_text.5234: He made peace between Thrasybulus and those who held the town, on these conditions :
tgt_text.5236: That none should be banished except the Thirty Tyrants, and the Ten, who, having been afterwards made governors, had followed the example of their predecessors in cruelty;
tgt_text.5238: that no property should be confiscated;
tgt_text.5239: and that the government of the republic should be restored to the hands of the people.
tgt_text.5240: It was an honourable act of Thrasy bulus, that, when peace was settled, and he had become the most powerful person in the state, he made a law, " that no one should be brought to trial, or punished, for things dcne previously;
tgt_text.5241: " and this they called " the act of oblivion."
tgt_text.5242: Nor did he only cause this law to be passed, but also took care that it should be of effect;
tgt_text.5243: for when some of them who had been with him in exile, wished to put to death those with whom they nad returned to a good understanding, he openly prevented it.
tgt_text.5244: and adhered to what he had promised.
tgt_text.5246: For such merits a crown of honour was presented him by the people, made of two sprigs of olive, which, as the love of his countrymen, and not force, had procured it him, excited no envy, but was a great glory to him.
tgt_text.5247: The celebrated Pittacus, therefore who was reckoned in the number of the seven wise men, said well, when the Mitylenæans offered to give him several thousand aerest of land, " Do not, I be­ seech you, give me what many may envy and more may covet;
tgt_text.5248: for which reason I had rather take, out of that num­ ber, not more than a hundred acres, which will prove both the moderation of my desires and your good will."
tgt_text.5250: but valuable presents are not wont to be permanent.
tgt_text.5252: Thrasybulus, accordingly, being content with that crown, neither sought for anything more, nor considered that any one had surpassed him in honour.
tgt_text.5253: Some time after, when, being in command, he had brought up his fleet on the coast of Cilicia, and the watch in his camp was not kept with sufficient care, he was killed in his tent by the barbarians, in a sally made from the town* during the night.
tgt_text.5254: onon's services in the Peloponnesian war, L-In his exile he supports Pharnabazus against the Spartans, II.
tgt_text.5255: —He goes to Artaxerxes to accuse Tissaphernes, and treats with him by letter, III.
tgt_text.5257: Greece is set free, and the walls of Athens rebuilt, IV.
tgt_text.5258: -Conon made prisoner by Tiribazus, V.I. CONON the Athenian entered upon public life in the Peloponnesian war, and his service in it was of great value;
tgt_text.5259: for he was both general of the forces by land, and, as com­ mander of the fleet, performed great exploits by sea ;
tgt_text.5260: for these reasons particular honour was conferred upon him, for he had the sole authority over all the islands;
tgt_text.5261: in which office he took Pheræ, a colony of the Lacedæmonians.
tgt_text.5262: He was also com­ mander towards the end of the Peloponnesian war, when the forces of the Athenians were defeated by Lysander at Ægos­ potamos;
tgt_text.5264: and hence the affair was worse managed;
tgt_text.5265: for he was both skilled in military matters, and a careful general.
tgt_text.5266: It was doubted by nobody, therefore, in those days, that the Athenians, if he had been present, would not have met with that disaster.
tgt_text.5268: But when the affairs of the Athenians were in a ca­ lamitous condition, and he heard that his native city was besieged, he did not seek a place where he might himself live in security, but one from which he might render assistance to his countrymen.
tgt_text.5269: He in consequence betook himself to Phar­ nabazus, the satrap of Ionia and Lydia, and also a son-in-law and relative of the king, with whom, by much exertion and at great hazard, he contrived to procure himself strong personal influence;
tgt_text.5270: * for when the Lacedæmonians, after the Athenians were subdued, did not adhere to the alliance which they had made with Artaxerxes, but sent Agesilaus into Asia to make war (being chiefly induced to that course by Tissaphernes, f who, from being one of the king's confidants, had renounced his attachment to him, and entered into an alliance with the Lacedæmonians), Pharnabazus was regarded as general against Agesilaus, but Conon in reality led the army, and everything was done according to his direction.
tgt_text.5271: He greatly obstructed that eminent commander Agesilaus, and often thwarted hia plans.
tgt_text.5272: It was indeed apparent, that, if Conon had not been there, Agesilaus would have taken all Asia, as far as Mount Taurus, from the king.
tgt_text.5273: And after Agesilaus was recalled home by his countrymen, in consequence of the Boeotians and Athenians Having declared war against the Lacedæmonians, Conon nevertheless remained with the king's officers, and was of the greatest service to all of them.
tgt_text.5275: Tissaphernes had revolted from the king;
tgt_text.5276: yet his defection was not so evident to Artaxerxes as to others;
tgt_text.5277: for he had great influence with the king, by reason of his nume­ rous and important services, even when he did not strictly adhere to his duty;
tgt_text.5278: nor is it to be wondered at, if he was not easily induced to credit it, remembering that by his means he had overcome his brother Cyrus.
tgt_text.5279: Conon, being sent by Phar­ nabazus to the king to assure him of his guilt, went in the first place, on his arrival (after the manner of the Persians).
tgt_text.5280: to Tithraustes, the captain of the guard, t who held the second place in the empire, and signified that he wished to speak to the king j for no one is admitted without this ceremony.*
tgt_text.5281: Tithraustes answered him, " There is no objection on my part, but consider, for yourself, whether you had rather speak with him, or treat by letter, as to the objects which you have in view.
tgt_text.5282: For, if you come into the royal presence, it will be necessary for you to pay adoration to the king" (which the Greeks call πςοϭϰυνει̃ν):
tgt_text.5283: " if this is disagreeable to you, you may nevertheless effect what you desire by stating your com­ mission through me."
tgt_text.5285: To myself indeed, it is not disagreeable to pay any honour you please to the king, but I am afraid lest it should be derogatory to my country, if, coming from a city which has been accustomed to rule over other nations, I should observe the usages of foreigners rather than its own."
tgt_text.5286: He therefore delivered to him in writing what he wished to communicate.
tgt_text.5288: The king, having read his statement, was so much influenced by his authority, that he declared Tissaphernes an enemy, desired CODon to harass the Lacedæmonians with war, and gave him leave to choose whom be pleased to disburse the money for his army.
tgt_text.5289: Conon said that such a choice was not a matter for his consideration, but for the king's own, who ought to know his own subjects best;
tgt_text.5290: but that he recommended him to give that commission to Phamabazus.
tgt_text.5291: He was then de spatched, after being honoured with valuable presents, to the sea, to require the Cyprians, Phœnicians, and other maritime people, to furnish ships of war, and to prepare a fleet to secure the sea in the following summer, Pharnabazus, as he had requested, being appointed his colleague.
tgt_text.5292: When this arrange­ ment was made known to the Lacedæmonians, they took their measures with great care, for they thought that a greater war threatened them than if they had to contend with the Persians only.
tgt_text.5293: They saw that a brave and skilful general was going to lead the king's forces, and to take the field against them, a man whom they could overmatch neither by stratagem nor by strength.
tgt_text.5294: With these considerations they collected a great fleet, and set sail under the leadership of Pisander.
tgt_text.5295: Conon, attacking them near Cnidus, routed them in a great battle, took several of their ships, and sunk several more, a victory by which not only Athens, but also all Greece, which had been under the power of the Lacedæmonians, was set free.
tgt_text.5296: Conon proceeded with part of his fleet to his native city, and caused the walls of the Piræeus and of Athens, both of which had been pulled down, to be rebuilt, and presented to his country­ men fifty talents in money, which he had received from Pharnabazus.
tgt_text.5298: What happens to other men happened to him, that he was more inconsiderate in good than in bad fortune;
tgt_text.5299: for when he had defeated the fleet of the Peloponnesians, and thought that he had avenged the injuries done to his country, he aimed at more objects than he was in a condition to accom plish.
tgt_text.5300: Not that these aims, however, were not patriotic and deserving of praise, since he preferred that the power of his country should be increased, rather than that of the king;
tgt_text.5301: for, after he had secured himself great influence by the battle which he fought at Cnidus, not only among foreigners but in all the states of Greece, he began to endeavour secretly * to restore Ionia and Æolia to the Athenians.
tgt_text.5302: But as this pro­ iect was not concealed with sufficient care, Tiribazus, who was governor of Sardis, sent for Conon, on pretence that he wished to send him in great haste to the king ;
tgt_text.5303: when he had gone, in compliance with this message, he was placed in confinement, in which he was kept for some time.
tgt_text.5304: Some have left on record that he was conveyed to the king, and there died.
tgt_text.5305: On the other hand Dinont the historian, whom we chiefly credit concerning Persian affairs, has related that he made his escape, but is in doubt whether 't was effected with or without the knowledge of Tiribazus.
