tgt_text.5312: -Gets possession of Syracuse, and forces Dionysius to make terms with him, V.—Alienates the people by putting Heraclides to death, VI.
tgt_text.5314: —Is deceived by a stratagem of Callicrates, VIII.
tgt_text.5315: —Is assassinated in his own house on a feast­ day, IX.
tgt_text.5316: -Change of feeling towards him after his death, X.I. DION, the son of Hipparinus, a native of Syracuse, was of a noble family, and allied to both the Dionysii, the tyrants.
tgt_text.5318: for the elder married Aristomache, Dion's sister, by whom he had two sons, Hipparinus and Nysæus, and also two daughters named Sophrosyne and Arete, the elder of whom he gave in marriage to his son Dionysius,t to whom he also left his dominions, and the other, Arete, to Dion.
tgt_text.5319: ‡But Dion, besides this noble connexion, and the honourable character of his ancestors, inherited many other advantages from nature;
tgt_text.5320: among them, a disposition docile, courteous, and adapted for acquiring the most important branches of know­ ledge, and extreme grace of person, which is no small recommendation ;
tgt_text.5321: § he had also great wealth bequeathed him by his father, which he himself had augmented by the presents he received from the tyrant.
tgt_text.5322: He was familiar with the elder Dionysius, not less on account of his character than his relationship;
tgt_text.5323: for though the cruelty of Dionysius offended him, yet he was desirous that he should be secure because of his family connexion with himself, and still more for the sake of his own relatives*
tgt_text.5324: He aided him in important matters, and the tyrant was greatly influenced by his advice, unless, in any case, some violent humour of his own interposed.
tgt_text.5325: But embassies,† such at least as were of a more distinguished kind, were all conducted by Dion;
tgt_text.5326: and by discharging them assiduously, and managing faithfully, he palliated the most cruel name of tyrant with his own benevolence.
tgt_text.5327: The Cartha­ ginians so much respected him, when he was sent thither by Dionysius, that they never regarded any man that spoke the Greek tongue with more admiration.
tgt_text.5329: Nor did these circumstances escape the notice of Dionysius, for he was sensible how great an honour he was to him ;
tgt_text.5330: hence it happened that he showed him more favour than any other person, ‡ and loved him not less than a son.
tgt_text.5331: When a report reached Sicily, too, that Plato was come to Tarentum, Dionysius could not refuse the young man leave to send for him, as Dion was inflamed with a desire of hearing him.
tgt_text.5332: He accordingly granted him that permission, and brought Plato with great pomp§ to Syracuse ;
tgt_text.5333: whom Dion so greatly admired and loved, that he devoted himself wholly to his society ;
tgt_text.5334: nor was Plato less delighted with Dion.
tgt_text.5335: Although, therefore, Plato was cruelly insulted by Dionysius (for he ordered him to be sold |), yet he paid a second visit to the city, induced again by the entreaties of Dion.
tgt_text.5336: In the meantime Dionysius fell ill of some disease, and when he was labouring under the severity of it, Dion inquired of the physicians how he was," and begged them, at the same time, " if he should happen to be in extreme danger, to acquaint him of it;
tgt_text.5337: for he wished to speak to him about a division of the realm, as he thought that the sons of his mister by him ought to have a share in the dominions."
tgt_text.5338: This request the physicians did not keep secret, but reported the words to Dionysius the younger, who, taking alarm at it, compelled thE physicians to give his father a sleeping potion, that Dion might have no opportunity of addressing him.
tgt_text.5339: The sick man, having taken the draught, ended his life like one buried in deep sleep.
tgt_text.5341: Such was the commencement of the dissension between Dion and Dionysius;
tgt_text.5342: and it was increased by many circum­ stances ;
tgt_text.5343: yet in the beginning of his reign there subsisted for a time an assumed friendship between them;
tgt_text.5344: and as Dion persisted in soliciting Dionysius to send for Plato from Athens, and follow his counsels, he, who was willing to imitate his father in something, complied with his wishes.
tgt_text.5345: At the same time, also, he brought back Philistus the historian to Syracuse, a man not more friendly to the tyrant than to tyranny itself.
tgt_text.5346: But of this author more has been said in the work of mine which is written " On Historians."
tgt_text.5347: Plato, however, had so much influence over Dionysius by his authority, and produced suen an effect on him by his eloquence, that he persuaded him to put an end to his tyranny, and to restore liberty to the Syracusans ;
tgt_text.5348: but being dissuaded from his intention by the representations of Philistus, he began to grow somewhat more cruel.
tgt_text.5350: Being conscious that he was surpassed by Dion in ability, influence, and in the affection of the people, and fear­ ing that, if he kept Dion with him, he might give him some opportunity of overthrowing him, he gave him a trireme to sail to Corinth, declaring that he did so for both their sakes, lest, as they were afraid of each other, one of them might take the other by surprise.
tgt_text.5351: As many people were indignant at this proceeding, and as it was the cause of great hatred to the tyrant, Dionysius put on board some vessels all the pro­ perty of Dion that could be removed, and sent it after him ;
tgt_text.5352: for he wished it to be thought that he had adopted that course, not from hatred of the man, but for the sake of his own safety.
tgt_text.5353: But when he heard that Dion was levying troops in the Pelo.
tgt_text.5354: ponnesus, and endeavouring to raise a war against him, he gave Arete, Dion's wife, in marriage to another man, and caused his son to be brought up in such a manner, that he might, through indulgence, be imbued with the most disgraceful propensities;
tgt_text.5355: for mistresses were brought him when but a boy, before he was full grown;
tgt_text.5356: he was overwhelmed with wine and luxuries, nor was any time allowed him to be sober.
tgt_text.5357: He was so little able to bear such a change in his way of life, which was altered after his father returned to his country (for keepers were set over him to draw him from his former mode of living), that he threw himself from the top of a house and so perished.
tgt_text.5358: But I return to the point from whence I digressed.
tgt_text.5360: When Dion had arrived at Corinth, and Heraclides, who had been commander of the cavalry, had also come thither (having been likewise banished by Dionysius), they began to prepare for war in every possible way;
tgt_text.5361: but they made but little progress;
tgt_text.5362: for a tyranny of many years' standing was thought to be of great strength, and for that reason few were induced to join in so perilous an undertaking.
tgt_text.5363: But Dion, who trusted not so much to his troops as to the general hatred towards the tyrant, setting out, with the greatest courage, in two transport vessels, to attack a power of fifty years' growth, defended by five hundred ships of war, ten thousand cavalry, and a hundred thousand infantry, so easily made an impression upon it (what seemed wonderful to all people), that he entered Syracuse the third day after he touched the coast of Sicily.
tgt_text.5364: Hence it may be understood that no government is safe, unless guarded by the love of its sub­ jects.
tgt_text.5365: Dionysius at that time was absent, and waiting for his fleet in Italy, supposing that none of his enemies would come against him without a great force;
tgt_text.5366: a supposition which de­ ceived him;
tgt_text.5367: for Dion curbed the tyrant's pride with those very men that had been under the rule of his adversary, and gained possession of all that part of Sicily which had been under the government of Dionysius;
tgt_text.5368: and with like success he secured the city of Syracuse, except the citadel and the island adjoining the town, and brought matters to such a state, that the tyrant consented to make peace on such terms as these:
tgt_text.5369: that Dion should have Sicily, Dionysius Italy,- and Apollocrates, in whom alone Dionysius t had great confidence, Syracuse.
tgt_text.5371: A sudden change followed close upon such eminent and unexpected success, for fortune, through her fickleness, endeavoured to sink him whom she had just before exalted.
tgt_text.5372: In the first place she exercised her power over his son, of whom I have previously made mention ;
tgt_text.5373: for after he had taken back his wife, who had been given to another, and wished to recal his son, from his abandoned course of sen­ suality, to habits of virtue, he received, as a father, a most severe affliction in the death of that son.
tgt_text.5374: A disagreement next arose between him and Heraclides, who, refusing to yield the supremacy to Dion, organized a party against him;
tgt_text.5375: nor had he indeed less influence than Dion among the aristocracy, with whose sanction he commanded the fleet, while Dion had the direction of the land forces.
tgt_text.5376: Dion could not endure this opposition patiently, but retorted with that verse of Homer in the second book of the Iliad,- in which is this sentiment, " That a state cannot be managed well by the government of many."
tgt_text.5377: Much ill feeling, on the part of the people, followed this remark;
tgt_text.5378: for he appeared to have let it escape him that he wished everything to be under his own authority.
tgt_text.5379: This feeling he did not try to soften by conciliation, but to over­ come by severity, and caused Heraclides, when he came to Syracuse, to be put to death.
tgt_text.5381: This act struck extreme terror into every one;
tgt_text.5382: for nobody, after Heraclides was killed, considered himself safe.
tgt_text.5383: Dion, when his adversary was removed, distributed among his soldiers, with greater freedom, the property of those whom he knew to have been unfavourable to him.
tgt_text.5384: But after this division had taken place, money, as his daily expenses grew very great, began to fail him;
tgt_text.5385: nor was there anything on which he could lay his hands but the property of his friends;
tgt_text.5386: a circumstance which was attended with this effect, that while he gained the soldiery, he lost the aristocracy.
tgt_text.5387: At this state of things he was overcome with anxiety, and, being unac­ customed to be ill spoken of, he could not patiently endure that a bad opinion of him should be entertained by those by whose praises he had just before been extolled to the skies,
tgt_text.5388: The common people, however, when the feelings of the soldiers were rendered unfavourable towards him,* spoke with less restraint, and said that " he was a tyrant not to be endured."
tgt_text.5390: While he knew not, as he contemplated this state of things, how he should put a stop to it, and was apprehensive as to what it might end in, a certain Callicrates, a citizen of Athens, who had accompanied him from the Peloponnesus to Sicily, a man of address, subtle enough for any artifice, and without any regard for religion or honour, went to him, and told him that " he was in great danger on account of the dis­ affection of the people and the hostile feelings of the soldiers;
tgt_text.5391: which danger he could by no means escape, unless he com­ missioned some one of his friends to pretend that he was an enemy to him;
tgt_text.5392: and that, if he found him fit for the under­ taking, he would learn the feelings of every one, and cut off his enemies, as his opponents would readily disclose their thoughts to any one disaffected towards him."
tgt_text.5393: This sug­ gestion being approved, Callicrates himself undertook this part, and armed himself through the unsuspiciousness of Dion;
tgt_text.5394: he sought for accomplices to join in killing him;
tgt_text.5395: he held meetings with his enemies, and formed an actual con­ spiracy against him.
tgt_text.5396: But these proceedings, as many were privy to what was going on, became known, and were com­ municated to Aristomache, Dion's sister, and his wife Arete;
tgt_text.5397: who, being struck with alarm, sought an interview with him for whose danger they were concerned.
tgt_text.5398: Dion assured them that no plot was concerted against him by Callicrates, but that what was done, was done by his own directions.
tgt_text.5399: The women, notwithstanding, took Callicrates into the temple of Proser­ pine, and obliged him to swear that " there should be no danger to Dion from him."
tgt_text.5400: But Callicrates, by this oath, was not only not deterred from his design, but was stimulated to hasten the execution of it, fearing that his plot might be laid open before he had effected his purpose.
tgt_text.5402: With this resolution, on the next festival day, while Dion was keeping himself at home, secluded from the assembly of the people, and was reposing in an upper room,* he com­ mitted to his accomplices the stronger parts of the city, sur­ rounded Dion's house with guards, and stationed trusty persons at the door, who were not to leave it;
tgt_text.5403: he also manned a trireme with an armed force, entrusted it to his brother Philocrates, and gave directions that it should be rowed about in the harbour, as if he wished to exercise the rowers, with a view, if fortune should baffle his attempts, to have a vessel in which he might flee to a place of safety.
tgt_text.5404: He then chose from among his followers some young men of Zacynthus, of great courage and extraordinary strength, whom he ordered to go to Dion's house unarmed, so that they might seem to have come for the sake of speaking with him.
tgt_text.5405: These youths, as being well known, were admitted, but as soon as they had crossed the threshold, they bolted the door, seized him as he lay on his couch, and bound him.
tgt_text.5406: A great noise ensued, so that it was distinctly heard out of doors.
tgt_text.5407: And here it was easy to be understood, as has often been said before, how unpopular absolute power is, and how unhappy the life of those who had rather be feared than loved;
tgt_text.5409: if they had been favourably inclined towards him, might have saved him by breaking open the door, as the Zacynthians, who were unarmed, were holding him still alive, calling to those without for a weapon.
tgt_text.5410: Nobody coming to his rescue, one Lyco, a Syracusan, gave them a sword through the window, with which Dion was slain.X.
tgt_text.5411: When the murder was consummated, and the people came in to view the scene, some were killed as guilty by those who were ignorant of the real actors ;
tgt_text.5412: for a report being soon spread abroad that violence had been offered to Dion, many, to whom such a deed was detestable, ran together to the spot;
tgt_text.5413: and these persons, prompted by a false suspicion, killed the innocent as if they had been the delinquents.
tgt_text.5414: But as soon as his death became publicly known, the feeling of the popu­ lace was wonderfully altered, for those who had called him a tyrant while he was alive, called him now the deliverer of his country and the expeller of a tyrant.
tgt_text.5415: So suddenly had pity succeeded to hatred, that they wished to redeem him from Acheron, if they could, with their own blood.
tgt_text.5416: He was there­ fore honoured with a sepulchral monument in the city, in the most frequented part of it, after having been interred at the public expense.
tgt_text.5417: He died at the age of about fifty-five years, four years after he had returned from the Peloponnesus into Sicily.
tgt_text.5418: Iphicrates eminent for skill in military discipline, I.-His acts in Thrace, at Corinth, against the Lacedæmonians, in Egypt, and against Epaminondas, II.
tgt_text.5420: IPHICRATES of Athens has become renowned, not so much for the greatness of his exploits, as for his knowledge of mill.
tgt_text.5422: for he was such a leader, that he was not only comparable to the first commanders of his own time, but no one even of the older generals could be set above him.
tgt_text.5423: He was much engaged in the field ;
tgt_text.5424: he often had the command of armies;
tgt_text.5425: he never miscarried in an undertaking by his own fault;
tgt_text.5426: he was always eminent for invention, and such was his excellence in it, that he not only introduced much that was new into the military art, but made many improvements in what existed before.
tgt_text.5427: He altered the arms of the infantry ;
tgt_text.5428: for whereas, before he became a commander, they used very large shields, short spears, and small swords, he, on the con­ trary, introduced the pelta instead of the parma* (from which the infantry were afterwards called peltastæ), that they might be more active in movements and encounters;
tgt_text.5429: he doubled the length of the spear, and made the swords also longer.
tgt_text.5430: He likewise changed the character of their cuirasses, and gave them linen ones instead of those of chain-mail and brass ;
tgt_text.5431: a change by which he rendered the soldiers more active;
tgt_text.5432: for, dininishing the weight, he provided what would equally pro tect the body, and be light.
tgt_text.5434: He made war upon the Thracians, and restored Seuthes, the ally of the Athenians, to his throne.
tgt_text.5435: At Corinth* he commanded the army with so much strictness, that no troops in Greece were ever better disciplined, or more obedient to the orders of their leader;
tgt_text.5436: and he brought them to such a habit, that when the signal for battle was given them by their general, they would stand so regularly drawn up, without any trouble on the part of the commander, that they seemed to have been severally posted by the most skilful captain.
tgt_text.5437: With this army he cut off a mora t of the Lacedæmonians;
tgt_text.5438: an exploit which was highly celebrated through all Greece.
tgt_text.5439: In this war, too, he defeated all their forces a second time, by which success he obtained great glory.
tgt_text.5440: Artaxerxes, when he had resolved to make war upon the king of Egypt,‡ asked the Athenians to allow Iphicrates to be his general, that he might place him at the head of his army of mercenaries, the number of whom was twelve thousand.
tgt_text.5441: This force he so instructed in all military discipline, that as certain Roman soldiers were formerly called Fabians,§ so the Iphicrateans were in the- highest repute among the Greeks.
tgt_text.5442: Going afterwards to the relief of the Lacedæmonians, he checked the efforts of Epaminondas;
tgt_text.5443: for, had not he been draw­ ing near,.
tgt_text.5444: the Thebans would not have retreated from Sparta until they had taken and destroyed it by fire.
tgt_text.5446: He was a man of large mind and large body, and of an appearance indicating the commander so that by his very look he inspired every one with admiration of him.
tgt_text.5447: But in action he was too remiss, and too impatient of continued exer­ tion, as Theopompus has recorded.
tgt_text.5448: Yet he was a good citizen, and a person of very honourable feelings, as he showed, not only in other transactions, but also in protecting the children of Amyntas t the Macedonian ;
tgt_text.5449: for Eurydice, the mother of Perdiccas and Philip, fled with these two boys, after the death of Amyntas, to Iphicrates, and was secure under his power.
tgt_text.5450: He lived to a good old age, with the feelings of his countrymen well affected towards him.
tgt_text.5451: He was once brought to trial for his life, at the time of the Social war,‡ together with Timotheus, and was acquitted.
tgt_text.5452: He left a son named Menestheus, whom he had by a Thra­ clan woman, the daughter of King Cotys.
tgt_text.5453: When this son was asked whether he had more regard for his father or his mother, he replied, " For his mother."
tgt_text.5454: As this answer appeared strange to all who heard it, he added, " I do so with justice;
tgt_text.5455: for my father, as far as was in his power, made me a Thracian, but my mother, as far as she could, made me an Athenian.
tgt_text.5456: "Chabriasbecomes celebrated for a new mode of fighting, I.—His acta in Egypt and Cyprus;
tgt_text.5457: his command of the Egyptian fleet, II.—
tgt_text.5459: he lived but little at home in consequence of the envious feelings of his countrymen, III.
tgt_text.5460: —He is killed in the Social war, IV.I. CHABRIAS the Athenian was also numbered among the most eminent generals, and performed many acts worthy 01 record.
tgt_text.5461: But of these the most famous is his manoeuvre in the battle which he fought near Thebes, when he had gone to the relief of the Bœotians;
tgt_text.5462: for in that engagement, when the great general Agesilaus felt sure of victory, and the mercenary troops had been put to flight by him, Cbabrias forbade the rest of his phalanx* to quit their ground, and instructed them to receive the attack of the enemy with the knee placed firmly against the shield, and the spear stretched out.
tgt_text.5463: Agesilaus, observing this new plan, did not dare to advance, and called off his men, as they were rushing forward, with sound of trumpet.
tgt_text.5464: This device was so extolled by fame throughout Greece, that Chabrias chose to have the statue, which was erected to him at the public charge by the Athenians in the forum, made in that posture.
tgt_text.5465: Hence it happened that wrestlers, and other candidates for public applause,!
tgt_text.5466: adopted, in the erection of their statues, those postures in which they had gained a victory.
tgt_text.5468: Chabrias also, when he was general of the Athenians, carried on many wars in Europe ;
tgt_text.5469: and he engaged in one in Egypt of his own accord ;
tgt_text.5470: for setting out to assist Nectanabis,‡ he secured him the throne.
tgt_text.5471: He performed a similar exploit in Cyprus, but he was then publicly sent to support Evagoras ;
tgt_text.5472: notdid he return from thence till he had conquered the whole island;
tgt_text.5473: from which achievement the Athenians obtained great glory.
tgt_text.5474: In the meantime a war broke out between the Egyptians and Persians, when the Athenians formed an alliance with Artaxerxes, and the Lacedæmonians with the Egyptians, from whom their king Agesilaus received a large share of spoil.*
tgt_text.5475: Chabrias, seeing Agesilaus's good fortune, and thinking himself in no respect inferior to him, set out to assist them of his own accord, and took the command of the Egyptian fleet, while Agesilaus held that of the land forces.
tgt_text.5477: In consequence, the officers of the king of Persia sent deputies to Athens, to complain that Chabrias was warring against their king on the side of the Egyptians.
tgt_text.5478: The Athenians then prescribed a certain day to Chabrias, before which if he did not return home, they declared that they would condemn him to die.
tgt_text.5479: On receiving this communication he returned to Athens;
tgt_text.5480: but did not stay there longer than was necessary;
tgt_text.5481: for he did not willingly continue under the eyes of his countrymen, as he was accustomed to live spIeD.
tgt_text.5482: didly, and to indulge himself too freely to be able to escape the envy of the populace.
tgt_text.5483: For this is a common fault in great and free states, that envy is the attendant on glory, and that the people willingly detract from those whom they see raised above others;
tgt_text.5484: nor do the poor contemplate with patience the lot of others who are grown rich.
tgt_text.5485: Chabrias, therefore, when he could, was generally away from home.
tgt_text.5486: Nor was he the only one that willingly absented himself from Athens, but almost all their great men did the same, for they thought that they should be as far removed from envy as they were distant from their native country.
tgt_text.5487: Conon, in conse­ quence, lived very much in Cyprus, Iphicrates in Thrace, Timotheus in Lesbos, Chares at Sigeum.
tgt_text.5488: Chares, indeed, differed from the others in conduct and character, but was nevertheless both distinguished and powerful at Athens.
tgt_text.5490: Chabrias lost his life in the Social war,* in the following manner.
tgt_text.5492: Chabrias was on board the fleet as a private man, but had more influence than all who were in command;
tgt_text.5493: and the soldiers looked up to him more than to those who were over them.
tgt_text.5494: This cir­ cumstance hastened his death;
tgt_text.5495: for while he was anxious to be the first to enter the harbour, and ordered the captain to steer the vessel towards it, he was the occasion of his own death, since, after he had made his way into it, the other ships did not follow.
tgt_text.5496: Upon which, being surrounded by a body of the enemy, his ship, while he was fighting with the utmost bravery, was struck with the beak of one of the enemy's vessels, and began to sink.
tgt_text.5497: Though he might have escaped from the danger, if he had cast himself into the sea, for the fleet of the Athenians was at hand to take him up as he swam, he chose rather to die, than to throw away his arms and abandon the vessel in which he had sailed.
tgt_text.5498: The others would not act in a similar manner, but gained a place of safety by swimming.
tgt_text.5499: He, on the other hand, thinking an honourable death preferable to a dishonourable life, was killed with the weapons of the enemy, while he was fighting hand to hand with them.
tgt_text.5500: The merits and acts of Timotheus, I.—A statue erected to him on his victory over the Lacedæmonians, II.
tgt_text.5501: —Is appointed, at an advanced age, as an adviser to Menestheus;
tgt_text.5502: is accused by Chares, and con­ demned, III.
tgt_text.5503: —His son Conon obliged to repair the walls of Athens:
tgt_text.5504: attachment of Jason to Timotheus, IT.I.
tgt_text.5505: TIMOTHEUS, the son of Conon, a native of Athens, in­ creased the glory which he inherited from his father by many excellent qualities of his own;
tgt_text.5506: for he was eloquent, active, persevering, skilled in military affairs, and not less so in managing those of the state.
tgt_text.5507: Many honourable actions of his are recorded, the following are the most famous.
tgt_text.5508: He subdued the Olynthians and Byzantians by force of arms;
tgt_text.5509: he took Samos, on the siege of which, in a previous war, the Athenians had spent twelve hundred talents.
tgt_text.5510: This sum he restored * tc the people without any expense to them ;
tgt_text.5511: for he carried on a war against Cotys, †and thence brought twelve hundred talents' worth of spoil into the public treasury.
tgt_text.5512: He relieved Cyzicus ‡ from a siege, he went with Agesilaus to the assistance of Ariobarzanes;
tgt_text.5513: § but while the Lacedæmonians received ready money from him in requital, he chose rather to have his countrymen enriched with lands and towns, than to take that of which he himself might carry a share to his own home;
tgt_text.5514: and he accordingly received from him Crithote || and Sestos.
tgt_text.5516: Being made commander of the fleet, and sailing round the Peloponnesus, he laid waste Laconia, and defeated its naval force.
tgt_text.5517: He also reduced Corcyra under the power of the Athenians, and attached to them, as allies, the Epirots the Athamanians, the Chaonians, and all those nations which lie on the sea.¶
tgt_text.5518: After this occurrence, the Lacedæmonians desisted from the protracted struggle, and yielded, of their own accord, the sovereignty at sea to the Athenians, making peace upon these terms, " that the Athenians should be commanders by sea."
tgt_text.5519: This victory gave so much delight to the Athenians, that altars were then first publicly erected to Peace, and a pulvinar.
tgt_text.5521: And that the remembrance of this glorious action might be preserved, they raised a statue to Timotheus in the forum at the public expense.
tgt_text.5522: Such an honour, that, after the people had erected a statue to the father, they should also present one to the son happened, down to that period, to him alone.
tgt_text.5523: Thus the new statue of the son, placed close by the other, revived old recollections of the father.
tgt_text.5525: When he was at an advanced age, and had ceased to hold any office, the Athenians began to be pressed with war on every side.
tgt_text.5528: Philip of Macedon, then very powerful, was making many efforts;
tgt_text.5529: and in Chares,t who had been opposed to him, there was not thought to be sufficient defence Menestheus, the son of Iphicrates, and son-in-law of Timotheus, was in consequence made commander, and a decree was passed that he should proceed to take the management of the war.
tgt_text.5530: These two persons, his father and father-in-law, men eminent in experience and wisdom, were appointed to give him advice,‡ for there was such force of character in them, that great hopes were entertained that what had been lost might be recovered by their means.
tgt_text.5531: When they had set out for Samos ;
tgt_text.5532: and Chares, having heard of their approach, was also proceeding thither with his force, lest anything should appear to be done in his absence, it happened that, as they drew near the island, a great storm arose, which the two veteran commanders, thinking it expedient to avoid, checked the progress of their fleet.§
tgt_text.5533: But Chares, taking a rash course, would not submit to the advice of his elders, but, as if success depended on his own vessel, pushed his way for the point to which he had been steering, and sent orders to Timotheus and Iphicrates to follow him thither.
tgt_text.5534: But having subsequently mis-managed the affair, and lost several ships, he returned to the same place || from which he had come, and despatched a letter to the government at Athens, saying that it would have been easy for him to take Samos, if he had not been lett unsupported by Timotheus and Iphicrates.
tgt_text.5535: On this charge they were impeached.
tgt_text.5536: The people, violent, auspicious, fickle, and unfavourable to them, recalled them home ;
tgt_text.5537: and they were brought to trial for treason.
tgt_text.5538: On this charge Timotheus was found guilty, and his fine was fixed at a hundred talents;
tgt_text.5539: when, compelled by the hatred of an ungrateful people, he sought a refuge at Chalets.
tgt_text.5541: After his death, when the people had repented of the sentence passed upon him, they took off nine-tenths of the fine, and ordered that his son Conon should give ten talents to repair a certain portion of the wall.
tgt_text.5542: In this occurrence was seen the changeableness of fortune;
tgt_text.5543: for the grandson was obliged, to the great scandal of his family, to repair, out of his own estate, the same walls which his grandfather Conon had rebuilt with the spoil taken from the enemy.
tgt_text.5544: Of the temperate and judicious life of Timotheus, though we could produce a great many proofs, we will be content with one, from which it may be easily conjectured how dear he was to his friends.
tgt_text.5545: When he was brought to trial, while quite a young man, at Athens, not only his friends, and others connected with him by ties of private hospitality, came to give him their support, but among them also the tyrant Jason,* who at that time was the most powerful of all men.
tgt_text.5546: Jason, though he did not think himself safe in his own country without guards, came to Athens unattended, having such value for his guest-friend, that he chose to hazard his life rather than not stand by Timotheus when he was contending for his honour.t
tgt_text.5547: Yet Timotheus, under an order from the people, carried on a war against him afterwards, for he considered the rights of his country more sacred than those of hospitality.
tgt_text.5548: This was the last age of Athenian commanders;
tgt_text.5549: the age of Iphicrates, Chabrias, and Timotheus;
tgt_text.5550: nor, after their death, was there any leader ‡ worthy of remembrance in that city.
tgt_text.5552: his war with the Cardusii, I.—He takes prisoner Thyus of Paphlagouia, II.
tgt_text.5554: Thyus to the king of Persia ;
tgt_text.5555: is appointed to command in Egypt, III.—
tgt_text.5556: Is directed to attack Aspis of Cappadocia, IV.
tgt_text.5557: —Finds that the courtiers are plotting against him, and takes possession of Cappa­ docia and Paphlagonia, V.—Loses his son in a war with the Pisidians;
tgt_text.5559: —Is betrayed by his eldest son, VII.
tgt_text.5560: —Defeats the general of the Persians who is sent against him, VIII.
tgt_text.5561: —Escapes a plot formed against him by the king, IX.
tgt_text.5562: —Is deceived by Mithridates, X.—Is killed by him, XI.I. I NOW come to the bravest and wisest man of all the barbarians, except the two Carthaginians, Hamilcar and Hannibal.
tgt_text.5563: I shall say the more concerning this general, because most of his acts are but little known, and because the undertakings that were attended with success to him, were accomplished, not by vastness of force, but by sagacity, in which he sur­ passed all of that age;
tgt_text.5564: and unless the manner of his proceedings be set forth, his merits cannot be fully understood.
tgt_text.5565: Datames, son of a father named Camissares, a Carian by nation, and of a mother a native of Scythia, served first of all among the soldiers who were guards of the palace to Artax­ erxes.
tgt_text.5566: His father Camissares, having been found undaunted in fight, active in command, and faithful on many occasions to the king, was granted as a province that portion of Cilicia which borders on Cappadocia, and which the Leucosyrians inhabit.
tgt_text.5567: Datames first showed what sort of man he was, when engaged in military service, in the war which the king carried on against the Cardusii;
tgt_text.5568: for in this enterprise, after several thousands of the king's troops were killed, his exertions proved of great value.
tgt_text.5569: Hence it happened that, as Camissares lost his life in the war, his father's province was conferred upon him.
tgt_text.5571: He distinguished himself by equal valour when Auto­ phradates, by the king's order, made war upon those who had revolted;
tgt_text.5572: for the enemy, even after they had entered the camp, were put to flight by his effortsand the rest of the king's army was saved.
tgt_text.5573: In consequence of this success, he began to be appointed over more important affairs.
tgt_text.5574: At that time Thyus was prince of Paphlagonia, a man of ancient family, descended from that Pylæmenes whom Homer states to have been killed by Patroclus* in the Trojan war.
tgt_text.5575: This prince paid no respect to the king's commands.
tgt_text.5576: The king, in consequence, determined to make war upon him, and gave the command of the enterprise to Defames, who was a near relative of the Paphlagonian, for they were sons of a brother and a sister.
tgt_text.5577: Datames, on this account, was desirous, in the first place, to try every means to bring back his kinsman to his duty without having recourse to arms.
tgt_text.5578: But going to confer with him without a guard, as he apprehended no treachery from a friend, he almost lost his life, for Thyus had resolved to assassinate him secretly.
tgt_text.5579: Datames was however accompanied by his mother, the aunt of the Paphlagonian, who discovered what was going on, and gave her son warning of it.
tgt_text.5580: Datames escaped the danger by flight, and declared open war against
tgt_text.5581: Thyus, in which, though he was deserted by Ario­ barzanes, the satrap of Lydia, Ionia, and all Phrygia, he nevertheless vigorously persevered, and succeeded in takina Thyus alive with his wife and children.
tgt_text.5583: He then used his utmost efforts that the news of his success might not reach the king before him, and thus, while all were still ignorant of it, he arrived at the place where the king was encamped, and the day after arrayed Thyus, a man of huge stature, and frightful aspect, being of a black com­ plexion, and having long hair and a long beard, in a splendid robe such as the king's satraps used to wear.
tgt_text.5584: He adorned him also with a chain and bracelets of gold, and other royal ornaments, while he himself was dressed in a coarse thick cloak,† and rough coat, having a hunter's cap upon his head, a club in his right hand, and in his left a chain, with which he drove
tgt_text.5585: Thyus secured before him, as if he were bringing along a wild beast that he had taken.
tgt_text.5586: While the people were all gazing at him, on account of the strangeness of his attire, and his person being unknown to them, and a great crowd was in consequence gathered round him, it happened that there was somebody in it who knew Thyus, and went off to tell the king, The king at first did not believe the account, and therefore sent Pharnabazus to make inquiry.
tgt_text.5587: Learning from him what had been done, he ordered Datames to be instantly admitted, being extremely delighted both with his success and the dress of his captive, rejoicing especially that that eminent prince had fallen into his hands when he scarcely expected it.
tgt_text.5588: He therefore sent Datames, after bestowing magnificent presents upon him, to the army which was then assembling, under the command of Pharnabazus and Tithraus tes, to make war upon Egypt, and directed that he should have equal authority with them.
tgt_text.5589: But as the king afterwards recalled Pharnabazus, the chief direction of the war was com­ mitted to Datames.
tgt_text.5591: As he was raising an army with the utmost diligence, and preparing to set out for Egypt, a letter was unexpectedly sent him by the king, desiring him to attack Aspis, who then held Cataonia, a country which lies above Cilicia, and borders on Cappadocia.
tgt_text.5592: Aspis, occupying a woody country, defended with fortresses, not only refused to obey the king's orders, but ravaged the neighbouring provinces, and intercepted what­ ever was being conveyed to the king.
tgt_text.5593: Datames, though he was far distant from those parts, and was drawn off from a greater matter, yet thought it necessary to yield to the king's wish.
tgt_text.5594: He therefore went on board a ship with a few brave followers, thinking (what really happened) that he would more easily overcome him, when unaware of his approach and unprepared, than when ready to meet him, though with ever so great an army.
tgt_text.5595: Sailing in this vessel to the coast of Cilicia, landing there, and marching day and night, he passed Mount Taurus, and arrived at the part to which he had directed his course.
tgt_text.5596: He inquired where Aspis was, and learned that he was not far off, and was gone to hunt.
tgt_text.5597: While he was watching for his return, the cause of his coming became known, and Aspis prepared the Pisidians, and the attendants that he had with him, to offer resistance.
tgt_text.5598: When Datames heard this, he took up his arms, and ordered his men to follow him ;
tgt_text.5599: he himself, setting spurs to his horse, rode on to meet the enemy.
tgt_text.5600: Aspis, seeing him, from a distance, advancing upon him, was struck with fear, and, being deterred from his resolution to resist, delivered himself up.
tgt_text.5601: Datames consigned him in chains to Mithridates, to be con­ ducted to the king.
tgt_text.5603: While these occurrences were passing, Artaxerxes, re­ flecting from how important a war, and to how inconsiderable an enterprize, he had sent the best of his generals, blamed himself for what he had done, and sent a messenger to the troops at Ace (not supposing that Datames had yet set out), to tell him not to quit the army.
tgt_text.5604: But before this messenger arrived at the place to which he was sent, he met upon the road the party that were leading Aspis.
tgt_text.5605: Though Datames, by this celerity, gained great favour from the king, he incurred no less dislike on the part of the courtiers, because they saw that he alone was more valued than all of them;
tgt_text.5606: and on this account they all conspired to ruin him.
tgt_text.5607: Pandates, the keeper of the king's treasury, a friend to Datames, sent him an account of this state of things in writing, in which he told him that “he would be in great peril if any ill-success should fall out while he commanded in Egypt, for such was the practice of kings, that they attributed adverse occurrences to other men, but prosperous ones to their own good fortune;
tgt_text.5608: and hence it happened that they were easily inclined to the ruin of those under whose conduct affairs were said to have'been ill-managed;
tgt_text.5609: and that he would be in so much the greater danger as he had those for his bitterest enemies to whom the king chiefly gave ear."
tgt_text.5610: Datames, having read this letter, after he had arrived at the army at Ace, resolved, as he was aware that what was written was true, to leave the king's service.
tgt_text.5611: He did nothing, however, that was unworthy of his honour;
tgt_text.5612: for he appointed Mandrocles of Magnesia to command the army, while he himself went off with his adherents into Cappadocia, and took possession of Paphlagonia, that bordered upon it, concealing what his feelings were towards the king.
tgt_text.5613: He then privately made a league with Ariobarzanes, raised a force, and assigned the fortified towns to be defended by his own troops.
tgt_text.5615: But these proceedings, from its being winter, went on with but little success.
tgt_text.5616: He heard that the Pisidians were raising some forces to oppose him, and sent his son Aridæus with a detachment against them.
tgt_text.5617: The young man fell in battle, and the father marched away to the scene of his death with but a small number of followers, concealing how great a loss he had sustained, for he wished to reach the enemy before the report of his ill-success should become known to his men, lest the spirits of the soldiers should be depressed by hearing of the death of his son.
tgt_text.5618: He arrived at the spot to which he had directed his course, and pitched his camp in such a position that he could neither be surrounded by the superior number of the enemy, nor be hindered from keeping his forces always ready to engage.
tgt_text.5619: There was with him Mithrobarzanes, his father-in-law, commander of the cavalry, who, despairing of the state of his son-in-law's affairs, went over to the enemy.
tgt_text.5620: When Datames heard this, he was sensible that if it should go abroad among the multitude that he was deserted by a man so intimately connected with him, it would happen that others would follow his example.
tgt_text.5621: He therefore spread a report throughout the camp that “Mithrobarzanes had gone off as a deserter by his direction, in order that, being received as such, he might the more easily spread destruction among the enemy.
tgt_text.5622: It was not right therefore," he added, " that he should be left unsupported, but that they ought all to follow without delay, and, if they did so with spirit, the consequence would be that their foes would be unable to resist, as they would be cut to pieces within their ramparts and without."
tgt_text.5623: This exhortation being well received, he led forth his troops, pursued Mithro­ barzanes, and, almost at the moment that the latter was joining the enemy,.
tgt_text.5625: The Pisidians, sur­ prised by this new movement, were led to believe that the deserters were acting with bad faith, and by arrangement with Datames, in order that, when received into the camp, they might do them the greater mischief;
tgt_text.5627: The deserters, as they knew not what was in agitation, or why it took place, were compelled to fight with those to whom they had deserted, and to act on the side of those whom they had quitted ;
tgt_text.5628: and, as neither party spared them, they were quickly cut to pieces.
tgt_text.5629: Datames then set upon the rest of the Pisidians who offered resistance, repelled them at the first onset, pursued them as they fled, killed a great number of them, and captured their camp.
tgt_text.5630: By this stratagem he at once both cut off the traitors, and overthrew the enemy, and turned to his preservation what had been contrived for his destruction.
tgt_text.5631: We have nowhere read, on the part of any commander, any device more ingeniously conceived than this, or more promptly executed.
tgt_text.5633: Yet from such a man as this his eldest son Scismas deserted, and went over to the king, carrying intelligence of his fathers defection.
tgt_text.5634: Artaxerxes, being startled at this news (for he was aware that he should have to do with a brave and active man, who, when he had conceived a project, had courage to execute it, and was accustomed to think before he attempted to act), despatched Autophradates into Cappadocia.
tgt_text.5635: To pre. vent this general from entering the country, Datames endea­ voured to be the first to secure a forest, in which the Gate of Cilicia* is situate.
tgt_text.5636: But he was unable to collect his troops with sufficient expedition, and being obliged to desist from his attempt, he took up, with the force which he had got together, a position of such a nature, that he could neither be sur­ rounded by the enemy, nor could the enemy pass beyond him without being incommoded by difficulties on both sides;
tgt_text.5637: while, if he wished to engage with them, the numbers of his oppo­ nents could not greatly damage his own smaller force.
tgt_text.5639: Autophradates, though he was aware of these circum stances, yet thought it better to fight than to retreat with sc large an army, or to continue inactive so long in one place.
tgt_text.5640: He had twenty thousand barbarian cavalry, a hundred thou­ sand infantry, whom they call Cardaces,t and three thousand slingers of the same class.
tgt_text.5641: He had besides eight thousand Cappadocians, ten thousand Armenians, five thousand Paphla­ gonians, ten thousand Phrygians, five thousand Lydians, about three thousand Aspendians and Pisidians, two thousand Cilicians, as many Captianians, ‡ three thousand hired men from Greece, and a very large number of light-armed troops.
tgt_text.5642: Against this force all Datames's hopes rested on himself and the nature of his ground, for he had not the twentieth part of his enemy's numbers.
tgt_text.5643: Trusting to himself and his position,­ therefore, he brought on a battle, and cut off many thousands of the enemy, while there fell of his own army not more than a thousand men;
tgt_text.5644: on which account he erected a trophy the next day on the spot where they had fought the day before.
tgt_text.5645: When he had moved his camp from thence, and always, though inferior in forces, came off victorious in every battle (for he never engaged but when he had confined his adver.
tgt_text.5646: saries in some defile, an advantage which often happened to one acquainted with the ground and taking his measures with skill), Autophradates, seeing that the war was protracted with more loss to the king than to the enemy, exhorted Datames to peace and friendship,† so that he might again be received into favour with the king.
tgt_text.5647: Datames, though he saw that peace would not be faithfully kept, nevertheless accepted the offer of it, and said that “he would send deputies to Artaxerxes."
tgt_text.5648: Thus the war, which the king had undertaken against Data­ mes, was ended;
tgt_text.5651: But the king, as he had conceived an implacable hatred to Datames, endeavoured, when he found that he could not be overcome in the field, to cut him off by underhand artifices ;
tgt_text.5652: but most of these he eluded.
tgt_text.5653: For instance, when it was told him that some, who were reckoned in the number of his friends, were laying a plot for him (concerning whom, a? their enemies were the informers, he thought that the inti mation was neither entirely to be believed nor utterly disre­ garded), he resolved to make trial whether what had been told him was true or false.
tgt_text.5654: He accordingly went forward on the road on which they had stated that an ambush would be laid for him ;
tgt_text.5655: but he selected a man closely resembling himself in person and stature, gave him his own attire, and ordered him to ride on in that part of the line where he himself had been accustomed to go, while Datames himself, in the equip­ ments and dress of a common soldier, prepared to march among his own body-guard.
tgt_text.5656: The men in ambuscade, as soon as the party reached the spot where they were stationed, being deceived by the place and dress, made an assault upon him who had been substituted for Datames.
tgt_text.5657: But Datames had previously directed those among whom he was marching, to be ready to do what they should see him do.
tgt_text.5658: He, as soon as he saw the conspirators collecting in a body, hurled his darts among them, and, as all the rest did the same, they fell down dead before they could reach him whom they meant to attack.
tgt_text.5660: Yet this man, crafty as he was, was at last ensnared by a device of Mithridates, the son of Ariobarzanes ;
tgt_text.5661: for Mithri­ dates promised the king that he would kill Datames, if the king would allow him to do with impunity whatever he wished, and would give him a pledge to that effect with his right hand after the manner of the Persians.
tgt_text.5662: When he received this pledge sent him by the king,.
tgt_text.5663: he prepared a force, and though at a distance, made a league with Datames, ravaged the king's provinces, stormed his fortresses, and carried off a great quan­ tity of spoil, part of which he divided among his men, and part he sent to Datames, putting into his hands, in like manner, many strong-holds.
tgt_text.5664: By pursuing this course for a long time, he made Datames believe that he had undertaken an everlast­ ing war against the king, while notwithstanding (lest he should raise in him any suspicion of treachery), he neither sought a conference with him, nor showed any desire to come into his sight.
tgt_text.5665: Thus, though keeping at a distance, he maintained friendship with him;
tgt_text.5666: but so that they seemed to be bound to one another, not by mutual kindnesses, but by the common hatred which they had conceived towards the king.
tgt_text.5668: When he thought that he had sufficiently established this notion, he gave intimation to Datames that it was time for greater armies to be raised, and an attack to be made on the king himself;
tgt_text.5669: and that, with reference to this sub­ ject, he might, if he pleased, come to a conference with him in any place that he might choose.
tgt_text.5670: The proposal being accepted, a time was fixed for the conference, and a place in which they were to meet.
tgt_text.5671: To this spot Mithridates came some days previously, in company with a person in whom he had the greatest confidence, and buried swords in several different places, carefully marking each spot.
tgt_text.5672: On the day of the con­ ference, each of them brought people to examine the place, and to search Datames and Mithridates themselves.
tgt_text.5673: They then met, and after they had spent some time in conference, and parted in different directions, and Datames was some distance off, Mithridate , before he went back to his attendants (lest he should excite any suspicion), returned to the same place, and sat down, as if he wished to rest from weariness, on one of the spots in which a sword had been concealed, and, at the same time, called back Datames, pretending that he had forgotten something at their conference.
tgt_text.5674: In the mean time he drew out the sword that was hid, and concealed it, un­ sheathed, under his garment, and observed to Datames, as he was returning, that he had noticed, when going off, that a certain place, which was in sight, was suitable for pitching a camp.
tgt_text.5675: While he was pointing this out with his finger, and the other was looking towards it, he ran him through, as his back was turned, with the sword, and put an end to his life before any one could come to his assistance.
tgt_text.5676: Thus a man who had gained the mastery over many by prudence, over none by treachery, was ensnared by pretended friendship.

tgt_text.5679: —An in­ stance of his freedom from covetousness, IV.
tgt_text.5680: —His ability in speaking, V.—An instance of his power of persuasion;

tgt_text.5689: the glory of Thebes, X.I.EPAMINONDAS was the son of Polymnis, ;
tgt_text.5691: Before we proceed to write of him, the following caution seems necessary to be given to our readers;
tgt_text.5692: that ej should not confound the customs of other nations with thai!
tgt_text.5693: own, or think that those things which appear unimportant to themselves must be equally so to others.
tgt_text.5694: We know that skill in music, according to our habits, is foreign to the character of any eminent personage ;
tgt_text.5695: and that to dance is accounted dispa­ raging to the character;
tgt_text.5696: * while all such accomplishments among the Greeks, are regarded both as pleasing and as worthy of admiration.
tgt_text.5697: But as we wish to draw a correct picture of the habits and life of Epaminondas, we seem called upon to omit nothing that may tend to illustrate it.
tgt_text.5698: We shall therefore speak in the first place of his birth;
tgt_text.5699: we shall then show in what accom­ plishments, and by whom, he was instructed;
tgt_text.5700: next we shall touch upon his manners and intellectual endowments, and whatever other points in his character may deserve notice ;
tgt_text.5701: and lastly on his great actions, which are more regarded by many than all the best qualities of the mind.
tgt_text.5703: He was the son, then, of the father whom we named, and was of an honourable family, though left poor by his an­ cestors ;
tgt_text.5704: but he was so well educated that no Theban was more so;
tgt_text.5705: for he was taught to play upon the harp, and to sing to the sound of its strings, by Dionysius, who was held in no less honour among musicians than Damon or Lamprus,‡whose names are well known ;
tgt_text.5706: to play on the flutes § by Olympiodo­ rus;
tgt_text.5708: For his instructor in philosophy he had Lysis ||of Tarentum, a Pythagorean, to whom he was so devoted that, young as he was, be preferred thesociety of a grave and austere old man * before that of all these of his own age ;
tgt_text.5709: nor did he part with him until he so far excelled his fellow students in learning, that it might easily be perceived he would in like manner excel them all in other pursuits.
tgt_text.5710: These acquirements, according to our habits, are trifling, and rather to be despised ;
tgt_text.5711: t but in Greece, at least in former times, they were a great subject for praise.
tgt_text.5712: After he grew up, and began to apply himself to gymnastic exercises, he studied not so much to increase the strength, as the agility, of his body;
tgt_text.5713: for he thought that strength suited the purposes of wrestlers, but that agility con­ duced to excellence in war.
tgt_text.5714: He used to exercise himself very much, therefore, in running and wrestling, as long as ‡ lie could grapple, and contend standing, with his adversary.
tgt_text.5715: But he spent most of his labour on martial exercises.
tgt_text.5717: To the strength of body thus acquired were added many good qualities of the mind ;
tgt_text.5718: for he was modest, prudent, grave, wisely availing himself of opportunities, skilled in war, brave in action, and possessed of remarkable courage ;
tgt_text.5719: he was so great a lover of truth, that he would not tell a falsehood even in jest;
tgt_text.5720: he was also master of his passions, gentle in disposition, and patient to a wonderful degree, submitting to wrong, not only from the people, but from his own friends ;
tgt_text.5721: he was a remarkable keeper of secrets, a quality which is some­ times not less serviceable than to speak eloquently;
tgt_text.5722: and he was an attentive listener to others, because he thought that by this means knowledge was most easily acquired.
tgt_text.5723: Whenever he came into a company, therefore, in which a discussion was going on concerning government, or a conversation was being held on any point of philosophy, he never went away till the discourse was brought to its conclusion.
tgt_text.5724: He bore poverty so easily, that he received nothing from the state but glory.
tgt_text.5725: He did not avail himself of the means of his friends to maintain himself;
tgt_text.5726: but he often used his credit to relieve others, to such a degree that it might be thought all things were in common between him and his friends ;
tgt_text.5727: for when any one of his countrymen had been taken by the enemy, or when the marriageable daughter of a friend could not be married for want of fortune, he used to call a council of his friends, and to prescribe how much each should give according to his means ;
tgt_text.5728: and when he had made up the sum required, he brought the man who wanted it to those who contributed, and made them pay it to the person himself, in order that he, into whose hands the sum passed, might know to whom he was indebted, and how much to each.
tgt_text.5730: His indifference to money was put to the proof by Diomedon of Cyzicus;
tgt_text.5731: for he, at the request of Artaxerxes, had undertaken to bribe Epaminondas.
tgt_text.5732: He accordingly came to Thebes with a large sum in gold, and, by a present of five talents, brought over Micythus, a young man for whom Epaminondas had then a great affection, to further his views.
tgt_text.5733: Micythus went to Epaminondas, and told him the cause of Diomedon's coming.
tgt_text.5734: But Epaminondas, in the presence of Diomedon, said to him, " There is no need of money in the matter;
tgt_text.5735: for if what the king desires is for the good of the Thebans, I am ready to do it for nothing;
tgt_text.5736: but if otherwise, he has not gold and silver enough to move me, for I would not accept the riches of the whole world in exchange for my love for my country.
tgt_text.5737: At you, who have made trial of me without knowing my character, and have thought me like yourself, I do not wonder ;
tgt_text.5739: but quit the city at once, lest you should corrupt others though you have been unable to corrupt me.
tgt_text.5740: You, Mycithus, give Diomedon his money back;
tgt_text.5741: or, unless you do so immediately, I shall give you up to the magistrates."
tgt_text.5742: Diomedon entreating that he might be allowed to depart in safety, and carry away with him what he had brought, " That," he replied, “I will grant you, and not for your sake, but for my own, lest any one, if your money should be taken from you, should say that what I would not receive when offered me, had come into my possession after being taken out of yours."

tgt_text.5771: Nor did he act in this manner once only, but often;
tgt_text.5772: ‡ but the most remarkable instance was, when he had led an army into the Peloponnesus against the Lacedæmonians, and had two joined in command with him, of whom one was Pelopidas, a man of valour and activity ;
tgt_text.5773: — on this occasion, when, through the accusations of their enemies, they had all fallen under the displeasure of their countrymen, and their commission was in consequence taken from them, and other commanders came to take their place, Epaminondas did not obey the order of the people, and persuaded his colleagues to follow his example, continuing to prosecute the war which he had undertaken, for he saw that, unless he did so, the whole army would be lost through the incautiousness and ignorance of its leaders.
tgt_text.5774: But there was a law at Thebes, which punished any one with death who retained his command longer than was legally appointed.
tgt_text.5775: Epaminondas, however, as he saw that this law had been made for the purpose of preserving the state, was unwilling to make it contribute to its ruin, and continued to exercise his command four months longer than the people had prescribed.
tgt_text.5777: When they returned home, his colleagues* were impeached for this offence, and he gave them leave to lay all the blame upon him, and to maintain that it was through his means that they did not obey the law.
tgt_text.5778: They being freed from danger by this defence, nobody thought that Epaminondas would make any reply, because, as was supposed, he would have nothing to say.
tgt_text.5779: But he stood forward on the trial, denied nothing of what his adversaries laid to his charge, and admitted the truth of all that his colleagues had stated;
tgt_text.5780: nor did he refuse to submit to the penalty of the law;
tgt_text.5781: but he re­ quested of his countrymen one favour, namely, that they would inscribe in their judicial record of the sentence passed upon him, † " Epaminondas was punished by the Thebans with death, because he obliged them to overthrow the Lacedaemonians at Leuctra, whom, before he was general, none of the Bœotians durst look upon in the field, and because he not only, by one battle, rescued Thebes from destruction, but also secured liberty for all Greece, and brought the power of both people to such a condition, that the Thebans attacked Sparta, and the Lacedæ­ monians were content if they could save their lives ;

tgt_text.5812: Phœbidas, the Lacedæmonian, when he was leading an army to Olynthus, ‡ and marching through the territory of Thebes,§ possessed himself (at the instigation of a few of the Thebans, who. the better to withstand the opposite faction, favoured the interest of the Lacedæmonians,) of the citadel of Thebes, which is called the Cadmea,* and this he did of his own private determination, not from any public resolution of his countrymen.
tgt_text.5813: For this act the Lacedæmonians removed him from his command of the army, and fined him a sum of money, but did not show the more inclination, on that account, to restore the citadel to the Thebans, because, as enmity had arisen between them, they thought it better that they should be under a check than left at liberty;
tgt_text.5814: for, after the Peloponnesian war was ended, and Athens subdued, they supposed that the contest must be between them and the Thebans, and that they were the only people who would venture to make head against them.
tgt_text.5815: With this belief they committed the chief posts to their own friends, while they partly put to death, and partly banished, the leading men of the opposite party;
tgt_text.5816: and amongst them Pelopidas, of whom we have begun to write, was expelled from his country.
tgt_text.5818: Almost all these exiles had betaken themselves to Athens, not that they might live in idleness, but that, whatever opportunity chance should first offer, they might avail them­ selves of it to regain their country.t
tgt_text.5819: As soon, therefore, as it seemed time for action, they, in concert with those who held similar views at Thebes, fixed on a day for cutting off their enemies and delivering their country, and made choice of that very day on which the chief magistrates were accustomed to meet at a banquet together.
tgt_text.5820: Great exploits have been often achieved with no very numerous forces, but assuredly never before was so great a power overthrown from so small a beginning.

tgt_text.5822: and by this small number the power of the Lacedæmonians was overcome;
tgt_text.5823: for these youths made war on that occasion, not more upon the faction of their adversaries than upon the Spartans, who were lords of Greece, and whose imperious domination, shaken by this commencement, was humbled not long after in the battle of Leuctra.
tgt_text.5824: These twelve, then, whose leader was Pelopidas, quitting Athens in the day-time, with a view to reach Thebes when the sky was obscured by evening, set out with hunting dogs, carrying nets in their hands, and in the dress of countrymen, in order that they might accomplish their journey with less suspicion.
tgt_text.5825: Having arrived at the very time that they had desired, they proceeded to the house of Charon, by whom the hour and day* had been fixed.

tgt_text.5869: In his early days he had a dispute with Leotychides, his brother's son, about the throne;
tgt_text.5870: for it was a custom handed down among the Lacedæmonians from their ancestors, that they should always have two kings, in name rather than power, of the two families of Procles and Eurysthenes, who were the first kings of Sparta, of the progeny of Hercules.
tgt_text.5871: It was not lawful for a king to be made out of one of these families instead of the other;
tgt_text.5872: each of the two, therefore, maintained its order of succession.
tgt_text.5873: Regard was had, in the first place, to the eldest of the sons of him who died while on the throne;
tgt_text.5874: but if he had left no male issue, the choice then fell on him who was next of kin.
tgt_text.5875: King Agis, the brother of Agesilaus, had recently died, and had left a son named Leotychides, whom, during his life, he had not acknowledged, but, at his death, had declared to be his.
tgt_text.5876: Leotychides contended for the royal dignity with his uncle Agesilaus, but did not obtain what he sought, for Agesilaus was preferred through the interest of Lysander, a man, as we have already stated, of a factious character, and at that time of great influence.
tgt_text.5878: Agesilaus, as soon as he got possession of the throne, solicited the Lacedæmonians to send an army into Asia, and make war upon the king of Persia, assuring them that it was better to fight in Asia than in Europe;
tgt_text.5879: for a rumour had gone abroad that Artaxerxes was equipping a fleet, and raising land forces, to send into Greece.
tgt_text.5880: Permission being granted him, he exerted so much expedition, that he arrived in Asia with his troops before the king's satraps knew that he had set out;
tgt_text.5881: hence it happened that he surprised them all unprepared, and expecting nothing of the kind.
tgt_text.5882: But as soon as Tissaphernes, who had the chief authority among the royal satraps, heard of his arrival, he begged a truce of the Spartan, on pretence that he would try to effect an agreement between the Lacedæ­ monians and the king, but in reality to gain time for collecting troops ;
tgt_text.5883: and he obtained a truce for three months.
tgt_text.5884: Each of them, however, took an oath to observe the truce without fraud;
tgt_text.5885: to which engagement Agesilaus adhered with the greatest honour;
tgt_text.5886: but Tissaphernes, on the other hand, did nothing but make preparations for war.
tgt_text.5887: Though Agesilaus became aware of his proceedings, he still kept his oath, and said that " he was a great gainer by doing so, for Tissaphernes, by his perjury, both alienated men from his interest, and made the gods angry with him;
tgt_text.5888: while he, by being faithful to his obligation, produced confidence among his troops, as they felt that the power of the gods was on their side, and that men were rendered greater friends to them, because they were accustomed to favour those whom they saw keeping faith."
tgt_text.5890: When the period of the truce was expired, the bar­ barian, not doubting that as he had many residences in Caria, and as that province was then thought by far the richest in Asia, the enemy would direct their attacks on that quarter especially, assembled his whole force on that side.
tgt_text.5891: But Agesilaus turned into Phrygia, and laid waste the country before Tissaphernes could make a movement in any direction.
tgt_text.5892: After enriching his men with abundance of plunder, he led back his army to Ephesus to winter, and erecting forges for arms there, made preparations for war with great industry.
tgt_text.5893: That his soldiers might be armed with greater care, too, and equipped with more display, he proposed rewards, with which those were to be presented whose efforts to that end should be remarkably distinguished

tgt_text.5895: By this means he succeeded in getting an army most admirably accoutred and trained.
tgt_text.5896: When he thought it time to draw his troops out of winter quarters, he saw that if he openly declared in what direction he was going to march, the enemy would not give credit to his statement, but would occupy other parts with their forces, not doubting that be would do something quite different from what he said.
tgt_text.5897: Agesilaus, accordingly, giving out that be would march for Sardis, Tissaphemes felt convinced that Caria must again be defended.
tgt_text.5898: When his expectation deceived him in the matter, and he found himself outwitted by his adversary's shrewdness, he hastened to protect his dependants, but too late, for, when he arrived, Agesilaus had taken many places, and secured abundance of spoil.
tgt_text.5899: The Lacedæmonian king, seeing that the enemy were superior to him in cavalry, never gave them an opportunity of attacking him in the plains, but engaged them in those parts in which infantry would be of greater service.
tgt_text.5900: As often as he came to a battle, therefore, he routed forces of the enemy far more numerous than his own;
tgt_text.5901: and he so conducted himself in Asia that he was in the judgment of every one accounted superior to his opponent.
tgt_text.5903: While he was thinking of marching into Persia, and attacking the king himself, a messenger came to him from home, by order of the Ephori, to acquaint him that the Athenians and Bœotians had declared war against the Lace­ dæmonians, and that he should therefore not delay to return.
tgt_text.5904: In this juncture, is dutifulness to his country is not less to be admired than his merit in war, for though he was at the head of a victorious army, and felt assured, to the utmost, of becoming master of the kingdom of Persia, he obeyed the orders of the absent magistrates with as much respect as if he had been a private person in the comitium.
tgt_text.5906: Would that our generals had followed his example !
tgt_text.5907: But let us proceed with our subject.
tgt_text.5908: Agesilaus preferred an honour­ able name to the most powerful empire, and thought it much more glorious to obey the laws of his country than to subdue Asia in war.
tgt_text.5909: With these feelings, therefore, he led his forces over the Hellespont, and employed such expedition, that he accomplished in thirty days a journey which Xerxes had taken a year to perform.!
tgt_text.5910: When he was not very far from the Peloponnesus, the Athenians and Bœotians, and ethers in alliance with them, endeavoured to make a stand against him at Coronea, all of whom he defeated in a great battle.
tgt_text.5911: It was an eminent merit in his victory, that when a numerous body of the enemy had taken refuge in a temple of Minerva after the defeat, and the question was put to him, " what he would wish to be done with them," he, though he had received some wounds in the battle, and seemed angry with all who had borne arms against him, preferred, nevertheless, respect for religion to the gratification of his resentment, and gave orders that they should suffer no injury.
tgt_text.5912: Nor did he act thus in Greece only,-so as to save the temples of the gods from profanation,-but even among the barbarians also, he preserved every image and altar with the utmost scrupulosity.

tgt_text.5920: for if we should proceed," he added, " to extirpate those who have supported us against the barbarians, we should weaken ourselves while the barbarians remain at their ease ;

tgt_text.5925: But when Epaminondas attacked Sparta, and the city was without walls, he proved himself such a commander, that it was apparent to all on that occasion, that if it had not been for him, Sparta would have ceased to exist.t
tgt_text.5926: In this time 01 danger, indeed, the celerity of his proceedings was the pre­ servation of the whole people;
tgt_text.5927: for when a number of the young men, alarmed at the approach of the enemy, had determined on going over to the Thebans, and had taken a position on an eminence without the city, Agesilaus, who saw that it would have a most pernicious effect, if it were noticed that any were trying to desert to the enemy, went thither with some of his men, and, as if they had been acting with a good intention, commended their procedure in having taken posses­ sion of that spot, and said that he himself had also observed that this ought to be done.
tgt_text.5928: Thus, by his pretended com­ mendation, he prevented the young men from deserting, and, after joining some of his followers with them, left the place quite safe ;
tgt_text.5929: for when the number of those was increased who were unacquainted with the project, ‡ the conspirators were afraid to mo ve, and retained their ground the more willingly as they thought that what they had meditated was still unknown.
tgt_text.5931: After the battle of Leuctra, it is certain, the Lacedæ­ monians never recovered themselves, or regained their former power, though, at that period, Agesilaus did not cease to assist his country by whatever means he could use.
tgt_text.5932: When the Lacedæmonians were greatly in want of money, he gave his support to all those * who had revolted from the king, and being presented by them with a large sum, he relieved his country with it.
tgt_text.5933: In his character, indeed, this point was par­ ticularly worthy of admiration, that, though great presents were given him by kings, princes, and states, he never took any portion of them into his own house, and never departed in the least from the usual diet and dress of the Spartans;
tgt_text.5934: he remained content with the same house which Eurysthenes, the progenitor of his family, had inhabited;
tgt_text.5935: and whoever entered it could see no indication of luxury or extravagance, but, on the contrary, many proofs of temperance and frugality, for it was furnished in such a manner that it differed in no respect from that of any poor or private person.
tgt_text.5937: As this great man had found nature favourable in giving him excellent qualities of mind, so he found her unpro­ pitious with regard to the formation of his body;
tgt_text.5938: for he was of low stature, small in person, and lame of one foot.
tgt_text.5939: These circumstances rendered his appearance the reverse of attractive, and strangers, when they looked at his person, felt only contempt for him, while those who knew his merits could not sufficiently admire him.
tgt_text.5940: Such fortune attended him, when, at the age of eighty, he went into Egypt to the aid of Tachos, and lay down with his men on the shore without any shelter, having merely such a couch that the ground was but covered with straw, and nothing more than a skin thrown upon it,t while all his attendants lay in the same manner, in plain and well-worn attire, so that their equipments not only did not indicate that there was a king among them, but even raised a suspicion that he must be a man not very rich.
tgt_text.5941: The news of his arrival having reached the king's officers, presents of every kind were soon brought him;
tgt_text.5942: but when the officers inquired for Agesilaus, they could scarcely be made to believe that he was one of those who were sitting before them.
tgt_text.5943: When they presented him what they had brought, with a message from the king, he accepted nothing but some veal, and such sorts of meat as his present circumstances required;
tgt_text.5944: the oint­ ments, chaplets, and sweetmeats he distributed among the slaves, and the other things he directed to be carried back.
tgt_text.5945: Upon this, the barbarians looked upon him still more con­ temptuously, thinking that he had made choice of what he had taken from ignorance of what was valuable.
tgt_text.5946: As he was returning from Egypt, after having been pre­ sented by King Nectanabis * with two hundred and twenty talents, in order that he might bestow them upon his country­ men, and had arrived at what is called the harbour of Mene­ laus,t lying between Cyrenae‡ and Egypt, he fell in and died.
tgt_text.5947: His friends, in order the more conveniently to convey him to Sparta, enveloped his body, as they had no honey, in wax, and so carried it home.
