tgt_text.6123: and hence he was sur­ named The Good.
tgt_text.6124: He was always poor, though he might have been extremely rich, by reason of the numerous offices conferred upon him.
tgt_text.6125: and the high commissions given him by the people.
tgt_text.6126: When he refused the present of a large sum of money from King Philip, and Philip's ambassadors urged him to receive it, and at the same time reminded him, that if he himself could easily do without it, he should nevertheless have some regard for his children, for whom it would be difficult, in the depth of poverty, to act up to the high character of their father, he gave them this answer:
tgt_text.6127: "If my children be like me, this same little farm, which has enabled me to reach my present eminence, will maintain them;
tgt_text.6128: but if they prove unlike me, I should not wish their luxury to be supported and increased at my expense."
tgt_text.6130: After fortune had continued favourable to him almost to his eightieth year, he fell, towards the close of his life, into great unpopularity with his countrymen.
tgt_text.6131: In the first place, he had acted in concert with Demades in delivering up the city to Antipater;
tgt_text.6132: and, by his suggestions, Demostbenes and others, who were thought to deserve well of their country, had been sent into banishment by a decree of the people.
tgt_text.6133: Nor had he given offence only in this respect, that he had ill consulted the interest of his country, but also in not having observed the obligations of friendship;
tgt_text.6134: for though he had risen to the eminence which he then held through being supported and aided by Demosthenes, when he furnished him with means of defence against Chares,* and though he had several times come off with acquittal on trials, when he had to plead for his life, through having been defended by Demos­ thenes, he not only did not take the part of Demosthenes when he was in peril, but even betrayed him.
tgt_text.6135: But his fate was decided chiefly on one charge, that, when the supreme government of the state was in his hands, and he was warned by Dercyllus that Nicanor, the prefect of Cassander, was forming designs upon the Piraeus, and Dercyllus begged him, at the same time, to take care that the city should not want provisions, Phocion told him in the hearing of the people, that there was no danger, and engaged to be security for the truth of his statement;
tgt_text.6136: whereas Nicanor, not long after, became master of the Piræeus;
tgt_text.6137: and when the people assembled under arms to defend that harbour, without which Athens could not at all subsist, Phocion not only did not call any body to arms, but would not even take the command of those who were armed.
tgt_text.6139: There were at that period in Athens two parties, one of which espoused the cause of the people, and the other that of the aristocracy;
tgt_text.6140: to the latter Phocion and Demetrius Phalereus were attached.
tgt_text.6141: Each of them relied on the sup­ port of the Macedonians;
tgt_text.6142: for the popular party favoured Polysperchon, and the aristocracy took the side of Cassander.
tgt_text.6143: After a time Cassander was driven from Macedonia by Poly­ sperchon ;
tgt_text.6144: and the people, in consequence, getting the superiority, immediately expelled from their country the leaders of the opposite faction, after they had been capitally convicted;
tgt_text.6146: and among them Phocion and Demetrius Pha lereus;
tgt_text.6147: and they then sent a deputation on the subject to Polysperchon, to request him to confirm their decrees.
tgt_text.6148: Pho­ cion went to him at the same time, and as soon as he arrived he was summoned to plead his cause, nominally before King Philip,t but in reality before Polysperchon;
tgt_text.6149: for he at that time held the direction of the king's affairs.
tgt_text.6150: Being accused by Agnonides‡ of having betrayed the Piræeus to Nicanor, and being thrown, by order of the council, into confinement, he was then conveyed to Athens, that a trial might there be held upon him according to law.
tgt_text.6152: On his arrival, as he was weak in his feet through age, and was brought to the city in a carriage, great crowds of people gathered about him, of whom some, calling to mind his former reputation, expressed commiseration for his declining years but the greater number were violently exasperated against him, from the suspicion that he had betrayed the Piræeus, but especially because he had opposed the interest of the people in his old age.
tgt_text.6153: Hence not even the liberty of make ing a speech, and of pleading his cause, was granted him, but being forthwith sentenced to death, after some formalities of law had been despatched, he was delivered over to the eleven,­ to whom public criminals, by the custom of the Athenians, are wont to be consigned.
tgt_text.6154: As he was being led to execution, Emphyletus, a man with whom he had been very intimate, met him, and having exclaimed, with tears, "0 what unworthy treatment you suffer, Phocion! " Phocion rejoined, " But not unexpected, for most of the famous men of Athens have come . to this end."
tgt_text.6155: So violent was the hatred of the multitude towards him, that no free person dared to bury him;
tgt_text.6156: and he was accordingly interred by slaves.
tgt_text.6157: Timoleon delivers Corinth from the tyranny of his brother, and causes him to be put to death, I.—He expels Dionysius the younger from Sicily;
tgt_text.6160: —After settling affairs in Sicily, he lays down the government, III.
tgt_text.6161: —He loses his sight from old age, but still attends to the interests of his country;
tgt_text.6162: builds a temple to Fortune, IV.
tgt_text.6164: his death, V.I. TIMOLEON of Corinth was doubtless a great man in the opinion of everybody, since it happened to him alone (for I know not that it happened to any one else),t to deliver his country, in which he was born, from the oppression of a tyrant, to banish a long established slavery from Syracuse (to the assistance of which he had been sent), and, on his arrival.
tgt_text.6165: to restore Sicily, which had been disturbed by war for many years, and harassed by barbarians,* to its former condition.
tgt_text.6166: But in these undertakings he struggled not with one kind of fortune only, and, what is thought the more difficult, he bore good much more discreetly than evil fortune;
tgt_text.6167: for when his brother Timophanes, on being chosen general by the Corinthians, had made himself absolute by the aid of his mercenary troops, and Timoleon himself might have shared the sovereignty with him, he was so far from taking part in his guilt, that he preferred the liberty of his countrymen to the life of his brother, and thought it better to obey the laws of his country than to rule over his country.
tgt_text.6168: With this feeling, he contrived to have his brother the tyrant put to death by a certain augur, a man connected with them both, as their sister by the same parents† was married to him.
tgt_text.6169: He himself not only did not put his hand to the work, but would not even look upon his brother's blood;
tgt_text.6170: for, until the deed was done, he kept himself at a distance on the watch, lest any of his brother's guards should come to his aid.
tgt_text.6171: This most noble act of his was not equally approved by all;
tgt_text.6172: for some thought that natural affection had been violated by him, and endeavoured, from envy, to lessen the praise of his virtue.
tgt_text.6173: His mother, indeed, after this proceeding, would neither admit her son into her house, nor look upon him, but, uttering imprecations against him, called him a fratricide, and destitute of natural feeling.
tgt_text.6174: With this treatment he was so much affected, that he was sometimes inclined to put an end to his life, and withdraw himself by death from the sight of his ungrateful fellow­ creatures.
tgt_text.6176: In the meantime, after Dion was assassinated at Syracuse, Dionysius again became master of that city, and his enemies solicited assistance from the Corinthians, desiring a general whose services they might employ in war.
tgt_text.6178: being in consequence despatched thither, expelled Dionysius.
tgt_text.6179: with wonderful success, quite out of Sicily.
tgt_text.6180: Though he might have put him to death, he refused to do so, and secured him a safe passage to Corinth, because the Corinthians had often been supported by the aid of both the Dionysii, and he wished the memory of that kindness to.
tgt_text.6181: be preserved, esteeming that victory noble in which there was more clemency than cruelty;
tgt_text.6182: and, finally, he wished it not only to be heard, but seen, what a personage he bad reduced from such a height of power to so low a condition.
tgt_text.6183: After the departure of Dionysius, he had to go to war with Icetas, who had been the opponent of Dionysius ;
tgt_text.6184: but that he did not disagree with him from hatred of tyranny, but from a desire for it, this was a sufficient proof, that after the expulsion of Dionysius he was unwilling to lay down his command.
tgt_text.6185: Timoleon, after defeating Hicetas, put to flight a vast army of the Carthaginians on the river Crimessus, and obliged those who had now for several years maintained their ground in Sicily, to be satisfied if they were allowed to retain Africa.
tgt_text.6186: He took prisoner also Mamercus, an Italian general, a man of great valour and influence, who had come into Italy to support the tyrants.
tgt_text.6188: Having achieved these objects, and seeing not only the lands, but also the cities, deserted through the long continuance of the war, he assembled, in the first place, as many Sicilians as he could, and then sent for settlers also from Corinth, because it was by the Corinthians that Syracuse had been originally founded.
tgt_text.6189: He gave back to the old inhabitants their own lands, and divided such estates as had lost their owners in the war, among the new colonists;
tgt_text.6190: he repaired the dilapidated walls of the cities, and the neglected temples;
tgt_text.6191: * he restored their laws and liberties to the several communities, and, after a most destructive war, established such tranquillity through the whole island, that he, and not those who had brought colonists thither at first, might have been thought the founder of those cities.
tgt_text.6192: The citadel of Syracuse, which Dionysius had built to overawe the city, he demolished to its foundations;
tgt_text.6193: other bulwarks of tyranny he removed, and exerted his efforts that as few traces as possible of servitude might be left.
tgt_text.6194: Though he was possessed of so much influence that be might have ruled the Syracusans even against their will, and though he had so strongly gained the affection of all the Sicilians that he might have assumed supreme power without opposition from any one, he chose rather to be loved than to be feared.
tgt_text.6195: He therefore laid down his authority as soon as he could, and lived as a private person at Syracuse during the remainder of his life.
tgt_text.6196: Nor did he act in this respect in­ judiciously;
tgt_text.6197: for, what other rulers could scarcely effect by absolute power, he attained by the good will of the people.
tgt_text.6198: No honour was withheld from him;
tgt_text.6199: nor, when any public business was afterwards transacted at Syracuse, was a decision made upon it before Timoleon's opinion was ascertained.
tgt_text.6200: Not only was no man's advice ever preferred to his, but no man's was even compared to it;
tgt_text.6201: nor was this occasioned more by the good will of others towards him, than by his own prudence.
tgt_text.6203: When he was advanced in age he lost the sight of his eyes, without any apparent disease in them;
tgt_text.6204: a misfortune which he bore with so much patience, that neither did any one ever hear him complain, nor did he take a less part in private and public business.
tgt_text.6205: He used to come to the theatre,* when any assembly of the people was held there, riding in a carriage by reason of his infirmity, and used to state from the vehicle what he thought proper.
tgt_text.6206: Nor did any one impute this to pride ;
tgt_text.6207: for nothing arrogant or boastful ever came out of his mouth.
tgt_text.6208: Indeed when he heard his praises repeated, he never made any other observation than that “ be paid and felt the utmost gratitude to the immortal gods for this favour, that when they had resolved on regenerating Sicily, they had appointed him, above all others, to be the leader to execute their will."
tgt_text.6209: For he thought that nothing in human affairs was done without the directing power of the gods;
tgt_text.6210: and he therefore erected a temple to Fortunet in his own house, and used to worship at it most religiously.
tgt_text.6212: To this eminent virtue in his character were added certain wonderful incidents in his life;
tgt_text.6213: for he fought all his most remarkable battles on his birth-day;
tgt_text.6214: and hence it happened that all Sicily kept his birth-day as a festival When one Lamestius, an impudent and ungrateful fellow, wanted to compel him to give bail for his appearance, as he said that he was merely dealing with him according to law, and several persons, flocking about him, would have curbed the insolence of the man by laying hands upon him, Timoleon entreated them all " not to do so, for that he had encountered extreme labours and dangers in order that Lamestius and others might enjoy such privileges;
tgt_text.6215: since this was the true form of liberty, if it were permitted to every one to try at Jaw what he pleased."
tgt_text.6216: When a person, too, something like Lamestius, by name Demænetus, had proceeded to detract from his actions before an assembly of the people, and uttered some invectives against Timoleon himself, he observed, that “ he now enjoyed the fulfilment of his prayers,* for that he had always made this his request to the immortal gods, that they would re-establish that degree of liberty among the Syracusans.
tgt_text.6217: in which it would be lawful for every mail to say what he wished of any one with impunity."
tgt_text.6218: When he died, he was buried at the public expense by the Syracusans, in the Gymnasium, which is called the Timoleontean Gymnasium,!
tgt_text.6220: The Spartan kings, kings only in name;
tgt_text.6221: the most eminent kings of Persia, I.—The greatest kings of Macedonia;
tgt_text.6222: the only great sovereign of Sicily, It.
tgt_text.6223: -The kings that arose after the death of Alexander the Great, III.I.
tgt_text.6224: THESE were almost all the generals of Greece ‡ that seemed worthy of record, except kings, for we would not treat of them, because the actions of them all are narrated separately ;
tgt_text.6225: § nor are they indeed very numerous.
tgt_text.6226: As for Agesilaus the Lacedæmonian, he was a king in name, not in power, just like the other Spartan kings.
tgt_text.6227: But of those who were sovereigns with absolute authority, the most eminent were, as we think, Cyrus, king of the Persians, and Darius, the son of Hystaspes, both of whom, originally in a private station, obtained thrones by merit.
tgt_text.6228: The first of these was killed in battle among the Massagetæ;
tgt_text.6229: Darius died a natural death at an advanced age.
tgt_text.6230: There are also three others of the same nation;
tgt_text.6231: Xerxes and the two Artaxerxes, Macrochir and Mnemon.*
tgt_text.6232: The most remarkable set of Xerxes was, that he made war upon Greece, by land and sea, with the greatest armies in the memory of man.
tgt_text.6233: Macrochir is greatly celebrated for a most noble and handsome person, which he rendered still more remarkable by extraordinary bravery in the field;
tgt_text.6234: for no one of the Persians was more valorous in action than he.
tgt_text.6235: Mnemon was renowned for his justice;
tgt_text.6236: for, when he lost his wife through the wickedness of his mother, he indulged his resentment so far only, that filial duty overcame it.t
tgt_text.6237: Of these, the two of the same name died a natural death;
tgt_text.6238: the third was killed with the sword by Artabanus, one of his satraps.
tgt_text.6240: Of the nation of the Macedonians, two kings far excelled the rest in renown for their achievements;
tgt_text.6241: Philip, the son of Amyntas, and Alexander the Great.
tgt_text.6242: One of these was cut off by a disease at Babylon;
tgt_text.6243: Philip was killed by Pausanias, near the theatre at Ӕgæ, when he was going to see the games.
tgt_text.6244: Of Epirus, the only great king was Pyrrhus, who made war upon the people of Rome;
tgt_text.6245: he was killed by a blow from a stone, when he was besieging the city of Argos in the Peloponnesus.
tgt_text.6246: There was also one great sovereign of Sicily, Dionysius the elder;
tgt_text.6247: for he was both brave in action and skilful in military operations, and, what is not commonly found in a tyrant, was far from being sensual, or luxurious, or avaricious, and was covetous indeed of nothing but absolute and firmly-established sovereignty;
tgt_text.6248: and to attain that object he was cruel;
tgt_text.6249: for in his eagerness to secure it he spared the life of no one that he thought to be plotting against it.
tgt_text.6250: After having gained absolute power for himself by his abilities, he preserved it with remarkable good fortune, and died at the age of more than sixty, with his dominions in a flourishing condition.
tgt_text.6251: Nor in the course of so many years did he see the funeral of any one of his offspring, though he had children by three wives, and several grand-children had been born to him.
tgt_text.6253: There arose also some great kings from among the followers of Alexander the Great, who assumed regal authority after his death.
tgt_text.6254: Among these were Antigonus, and his son Demetrius, Lysimachus, Seleucus, and Ptolemy;
tgt_text.6255: of whom Antigonus was killed in battle, when he was fighting against Seleucus and Lysimachus;
tgt_text.6256: and Lysimachus was cut off in a similar way by Seleucus, for the alliance between the two being broken, they went to war with one another.
tgt_text.6257: Demetrius, after he had given his daughter to Seleucus in marriage, and yet the alliance between them could not be maintained the more faithfully on that account, was taken prisoner in battle, and died of some disease, the father-in-law in the custody of his son- in-law.
tgt_text.6258: Not long after, Seleucus was treacherously killed by Ptolemy Ceraunus, whom he had entertained, when he was expelled by his father from Alexandria, and stood in need of assistance from others.
tgt_text.6259: As for Ptolemy himself, he is said, after having resigned his throne to his son during his life, to have been deprived of life by that same son.
tgt_text.6260: But, as we think that sufficient has been said concerning these, it seems proper not to omit Hamilcar and Hannibal, who, as is agreed, surpassed all the natives of Africa in power and subtilty of intellectHamilcar’s success in Sicily;
tgt_text.6261: his defence of Eryx, and honourable capitulation, I.—His suppression of the rebellion raised by the Carthaginian mercenaries, II.
tgt_text.6262: —He takes his son Hannibal with him into Spain, and his son-in-law Hasdrubal, III.
tgt_text.6263: —Is killed in battle in Spain, IV.I. HAMILCAR the Carthaginian, the son of Hannibal, and surnamed Barcas, began in the first Punic war, but towards the end of it, to hold the command of the army in Sicily;
tgt_text.6264: and though, before his coming, the efforts of the Carthaginians were unsuccessful both by sea aDd land, he, after he arrived, never gave way to the enemy,- or afforded them any oppor­ tunity of doing him harm, but, on the contrary, often attacked the foe when occasion presented itself, and always came off with the advantage.
tgt_text.6265: Afterwards, though the Carthaginians had lost almost every place in Sicily, he so ably defended Eryx,† that there seemed to be no war going on there.
tgt_text.6266: In the meantime, the Carthaginians, having been defeated at sea, near the islands called Ægates,‡ by Caius Lutatius, the Roman consul, resolved on putting an end to the war, and left the settlement of the matter to the judgment of Hamilcar, who, though he ardently desired to continue in arms, thought it, nevertheless, necessary to submit to make peace, because he saw that his country, exhausted by the expenses of the war, was no longer in a condition to bear the pressure of it;
tgt_text.6267: but such was his feeling on the occasion, that he soon meditated, if the affairs of his country should be but in a small degree improved, to resume the war, and to pursue the Romans with hostilities, until they should indisputably obtain the mastery, or, being conquered, should make submission.
tgt_text.6268: With this resolution he concluded a peace, but showed such a spirit in the transaction, that when Catulus refused to desist from hos­ tilities unless Hamilcar, with such of his men as were in possession of Eryx, should lay down their arms and quit Sicily, Hamilcar replied, that, though his country submitted, he himself would rather perish on the spot than return home under such disgrace, for that it was not consistent with his spirit to resign to his enemies arms which he had received from his country as a defence against enemies.
tgt_text.6271: But Hamilcar, when he arrived at Carthage, found the republic in a far different condition than he had expected;
tgt_text.6272: for, through the long con­ tinuance of foreign troubles, so violent a rebellion had broken out at home, that Carthage was never in such danger, except when it was actually destroyed.
tgt_text.6273: In the first place, the mer­ cenary troops, who had served against the Romans, and the number of whom amounted to twenty thousand, revolted;
tgt_text.6274: and these drew the whole of Africa over to their side, and laid siege to Carthage itself.
tgt_text.6275: With these disasters the Cartha­ ginians were so much alarmed, that they requested aid even from the Romans, and obtained it.
tgt_text.6276: But at last, when they were almost sunk into despair, they made Hamilcar general, who not only repulsed the enemy from the walls of Carthage, though they amounted to a hundred thousand men in arms, but reduced them to such a condition, that being shut up in a confined space, they perished in greater numbers by famine than by the sword.
tgt_text.6277: All the towns that had revolted, and among them Utica and Hippo, the strongest cities of all Africa, he brought back to their allegiance to his country.
tgt_text.6278: Nor was he satisfied with these successes, but extended even the bounds of the Carthaginian empire, and re-established such tranquillity through all Africa, that there seemed to have been no war in it for many years.
tgt_text.6280: These objects being executed according to his desire, he then, by dint of a spirit confident and incensed against the Romans, contrived, in order more easily to find a pretext for going to war with them, to be sent as commander-in-chief with an army into Spain, and took with him thither his son Hanni­ bal, then nine years old.
tgt_text.6281: There also accompanied him a young man named Hasdrubal, a person of high birth and great beauty, who, as some said, was beloved by Hamilcar with less regard to his character than was becoming;
tgt_text.6282: for so great a man could not fail to have slanderers.
tgt_text.6283: Hence it happened that Hasdrubal was forbidden by the censor of public morals to associate with him;
tgt_text.6284: but Hamilcar then gave him his daughter in marriage, because, according to their usages, a son-in-law could not be interdicted the society of his father-in- law.
tgt_text.6285: We have inserted this notice of Hasdrubal, because, after Hamilcar was killed, he took the command of the army, and achieved great exploits;
tgt_text.6286: and he was also the first that corrupted the ancient manners of the Carthaginians by bribery.
tgt_text.6287: After his death Hannibal received the command from the army.
tgt_text.6289: Hamilcar, however, after he had crossed the sea, and arrived in Spain, executed some great undertakings with excel­ lent success;
tgt_text.6290: he subdued some very powerful and warlike nations, and supplied all Africa with horses, arms, men, and money.
tgt_text.6291: But as he was meditating to carry the war into Italy, in the ninth year after his arrival in Spain, he was killed in a battle with the Vettones.
tgt_text.6292: His constant hatred to the Romans seems to have been the chief cause of producing the second Punic war;
tgt_text.6293: for Hannibal, his son, was so wrought upon by the continual instigations of his father, that he would have chosen to die rather than not make trial of the Romans.
tgt_text.6294: Hannibal, the greatest of generals, suffers from the envy of his countrymen, I.—Was the deadly enemy of the Romans, II.
tgt_text.6299: -His further proceedings in that country, V.—Is recalled to the defence of his country, and defeated by Scipio, VI.
tgt_text.6300: —Quits his country, and seeks refuge with Antiochus, VII.
tgt_text.6301: —Endeavours in vain to excite his countrymen to war;
tgt_text.6303: —Eludes the avarice of the Cretans, IX.
tgt_text.6304: —Stirs up Prusias against the Romans, X.—His stra­ tagem in contending with Eumenes, XI.
tgt_text.6305: - Commits suicide to escape being delivered to the Romans.
tgt_text.6308: HANNIBAL was the son of Hamilcar, and a native of Carthage.
tgt_text.6309: If it be true, as no one doubts, that the Roman people excelled all other nations in warlike merit, it is not to be disputed that Hannibal surpassed other commanders in ability as much as the Romans surpassed all other people in valour;
tgt_text.6310: for as often as he engaged with the Romans in Italy, he always came off with the advantage;
tgt_text.6311: and, had not his efforts been paralyzed by the envy of his countrymen at home, he would appear to have been capable of getting the mastery over the Romans.
tgt_text.6312: But the jealous opposition of many prevailed against the ability of one.
tgt_text.6313: He, however, so cherished in his mind the hatred which his father had borne the Romans, and which was left him, as it were, by bequest, that he laid down his life before he would abate it;
tgt_text.6314: for even when he was exiled from his country, and stood in need of support from others, he never ceased in thought to make war with the Romans.
tgt_text.6317: whom he rendered an enemy to the Romans, though at a distance from him, Antiochus was the most powerful of all kings at that period;
tgt_text.6318: and him he so inflamed with a desire for war, that he endeavoured to bring troops against Italy even from the Red Sea.t
tgt_text.6319: As some ambassadors from Rome were sent to that prince, in or ler tc gain information respecting his intentions, and to endeavour.
tgt_text.6320: by underhand contrivances, to render Hannibal an object of suspicion to the king (as if, being bribed by them, he entertained other sentiments than before) ;
tgt_text.6321: and as they were not unsuccessful in their attempts, and Hannibal became aware of that fact, and found himself excluded from the privy council, he went at a time appointed to the king himself, and, after having said much concerning his attachment to him and his hatred to the Romans, he added the following statement:
tgt_text.6322: ‘My father Hamilcar," said he, “ when I was a very little boy, being not more than nine years old, offered sacrifices at Car thage, when he was going as commander into Spain, to Jupiter, the best and greatest of the gods;
tgt_text.6323: and while this religious ceremony was being performed, he asked me whether I should like to go with him to the camp.
tgt_text.6324: As I willingly expressed my consent, and proceeded to beg him not to hesitate to take me, he replied, ‘ I will do so, if you will give me the promise which I ask of you’
tgt_text.6325: At the same time he led me to the altar at which he had begun to sacrifice, and, sending the rest of the company away, required me, taking hold of the altar, to swear that I would never be in friendship with the Romans.
tgt_text.6326: This oath, thus taken before my father, I have so strictly kept ever:
tgt_text.6327: to this day, that no man ought to doubt but that I shall be of the same mind for the rest of my life.
tgt_text.6328: If, therefore, you entertain any friendly thoughts towards the Romans, you will not act imprudently if you conceal them from me ;
tgt_text.6329: but when­ ever you prepare war, you will disappoint yourself unless you constitute me leader in it."
tgt_text.6331: At this age, accordingly, he accompanied his father into Spain.
tgt_text.6332: After his fathers death, when Hasdrubal was made general-in-chief, he bad the command of all the cavalry.
tgt_text.6333: When Hasdrubal also was killed, the army conferred upon him the supreme command, and this act, when reported at Carthage, received public approbation.
tgt_text.6334: Hannibal being thus made commander-in-chief, at the age of five-and-twenty, subdued in war, during the next three years, all the nations of Spain, took Saguntum, a city in alliance with the Romans, by storm, and collected three vast armies, of which he sent one into Africa, left another with his brother Hasdrubal in Spain, and took the third with him into Italy.
tgt_text.6335: He made his way through the forests of the Pyrenees,* he engaged, wherever he directed his course, with all the inhabit­ ants of the country, and let none go unconquered.
tgt_text.6336: On arriving at the Alps, which separate Italy from Gaul, and which no one had ever crossed with an army before him, (except Hercules the Greek, from which achievement the forest there is now called the Grecian forest), he cut to pieces the people of the Alps who endeavoured to prevent his passage, laid open those parts, made roads, and put things in such a state, that an elephant fully equipped could walk where pre­ viously one unarmed man could scarcely crawl.
tgt_text.6337: Along this tract he led his army, and arrived in Italy.IV.
tgt_text.6338: On the banks of the Rhone he engaged with the consul Publius Cornelius Scipio, and put him to flight.
tgt_text.6339: At the Po he fought with the same consul for the possession of Clastidium,t and expelled him from that place wounded and defeated
tgt_text.6340: The same Scipio, with his colleague Tiberius Longus, came against him a third time at the Trebia;
tgt_text.6341: he came to battle with them, and put both of them to flight.
tgt_text.6342: He then passed through the country of the Ligurians over the chain of the Apennnines, directing his course towards Etruria.
tgt_text.6343: During this march he was afflicted with so violent a distemper in his eyes, that he never had the use of his right eye so well afterwards.
tgt_text.6344: But even when he was troubled with this malady, and carried in a litter, he cut off Caius Flaminius the consul at the lake Trasimenus, being caught with his army in an ambush ;
tgt_text.6345: and not long after he killed the prætor Caius Centenius, who was occupying the forest with a choice body of troops.
tgt_text.6346: He then proceeded into Apulia, where the two consuls, Caius Terentius Varro, and Paulus Ӕmilius, met him, both of whose armies he routed in one battle;
tgt_text.6347: the consul Paulus he killed, with several others of consular dignity, and among them Cnæus Servilius Geminus, who had been consul the year before.
tgt_text.6349: After fighting this battle, he marched towards Rome, nobody opposing him, and halted on the hills near the city.
tgt_text.6350: When he had lain encamped there some days, and was turning back towards Capua, Quintus Fabius Maximus, the Roman dictator, threw himself in his way in the Falemian territory.
tgt_text.6351: Here, though enclosed in a confined space, he extricated himself without any loss to his army.
tgt_text.6352: He deceived Fabius, a most skilful commander;
tgt_text.6353: for, when night had come on, he set fire to some bundles of twigs, tied upon the horns of oxen, and drove forward a vast number of those cattle, scattering themselves hither and thither.
tgt_text.6354: By presenting this object suddenly to their view,.
tgt_text.6355: he struck such terror into the army of the Romans, that nobody ventured to stir beyond the rampart.
tgt_text.6356: Not many days after this success, he put to flight Marcus Minucius Rufus, master of the horse, who was equal in power with the dictator, and who had been drawn into an engagement by a stratagem.
tgt_text.6357: While he was at a distance, too, he cut off*
tgt_text.6358: Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus, consul for the second time, in the country of the Lucanians, after he had been inveigled into an ambush.
tgt_text.6359: In like manner he caused the death of Marcus Claudius Marcellus, consul for the fifth time, at Venusia.
tgt_text.6360: To enumerate his battles would occupy too much time;
tgt_text.6361: and this one observation, accordingly, (from which it will be understood how great a general he was), will be sufficient, that, as long as he continued in Italy, none made a stand against him in a regular engagement, none, after the battle of Cannæ, pitched a camp against him in the field.
tgt_text.6363: Being recalled, without having suffered any defeat, to defend his country, he maintained a war with the son of that Publius Scipio whom he had routed first on the Rhone, again on the Po, and a third time on the Trebia.
tgt_text.6364: As the resources of his country were now exhausted, he wished, by a treaty with him, to put a stop to the war for a time, in order that he might engage in it afterwards with greater vigour.
tgt_text.6365: He came to a conference with him, but the conditions were not agreed upon.
tgt_text.6366: A few days after this meeting, he came to battle with Scipio at Zama;
tgt_text.6367: and being defeated (incredible to relate !) he made his way to Adrumetum, which is about three hundred miles t from Zama, in two days and two nights.
tgt_text.6368: In the course of his retreat, some Numidians, who had left the field in his company, formed a conspiracy against him;
tgt_text.6369: however he not only escaped them, but deprived them of life.
tgt_text.6370: At Adrumetum he assembled those who had survived the defeat, and, with the aid of new levies, drew together, in a few days, a numerous force.
tgt_text.6372: While he was most vigorously engaged in preparing for action, the Carthaginians made an end of the war by a treaty with the Romans.
tgt_text.6373: He had nevertheless afterwards the command of the army, and continued to act, as well as his brother Mago, in Africa, until the time when Publius Sulpicius and Caius Aurelius became consuls;
tgt_text.6374: for, during their term of office, ambassadors from Carthage went to Rome, to thank the Roman senate and people for having made peace with them, and to present them, on that account, with a crown of gold, requesting, at the same time, that their hostages might reside at Fregellæ,* and that their prisoners might be re­ stored.
tgt_text.6375: An answer was made them, by a resolution of the senate, that “ their present was acceptable and welcome, and that their hostages should live in, the place which they desired, but that they would not restore the prisoners, because the Carthaginians retained Hannibal, by whose acts the war had been occasioned, and who was the bitterest of enemies to the name of Rome, in command of the army, as also his brother Mago."
tgt_text.6376: The Carthaginians, on hearing this answer, recalled Hannibal and Mago home.
tgt_text.6377: When he returned, he was made prætor,† in the two-and-twentieth year after he had been appointed king;
tgt_text.6378: ‡ for, as consuls are elected at Rome, so, at Carthage, two kings are annually chosen, retaining their office for a year.
tgt_text.6379: In that post Hannibal conducted himself with the same activity as he had exhibited in war;
tgt_text.6380: for he took care, not only that there should be money raised from new taxes, to be paid to the Romans according to the treaty, but that there should be a surplus to be deposited in the treasury.
tgt_text.6381: In the year after his prætorship, when Marcus Claudius and Lucius Furius were consuls, ambassadors from Rome came again to Carthage;
tgt_text.6382: and Hannibal, supposing that they were sent to demand that he should be delivered to the Romans, went secretly, before an audience of the senate was given them, on board a vessel, and fled into Syria to Antiochus.
tgt_text.6383: His departure being made public, the Carthaginians sent two ships to seize him, if they could overtake him.
tgt_text.6385: his house they razed to its foundations;
tgt_text.6386: and himself they declared an outlaw.
tgt_text.6388: In the third year, however, after he had fled from home, and in the consulship of Lucius Cornelius and Quintus Minu­ cius, Hannibal landed with five ships in Africa, on the coast of the Cyrenæans, to try if he could move the Carthaginians to war, by giving them hope and confidence in Antiochus, whom he had now persuaded to proceed with his forces to Italy.
tgt_text.6389: Thither he summoned his brother Mago ;
tgt_text.6390: and, when the Carthaginians knew of the circumstance, they inflicted on Mago the same penalties as they had laid on his absent brother.
tgt_text.6391: When they had let loose their vessels, and sailed off, in despair of success, Hannibal went to join Antiochus.
tgt_text.6392: Of Mago's end two accounts have been given ;
tgt_text.6393: for some have left on record that he perished by shipwreck, others that he was killed by his own slaves.
tgt_text.6394: Antiochus, if he had been as ready to obey Hannibal's advice in conducting the war as he had resolved to be when he undertook it, might have fought for the empire of the world nearer the Tiber than Thermopylæ.*
tgt_text.6395: Hannibal, however, though he saw him attempt many things imprudently, left him in nothing unsupported.
tgt_text.6396: He took the command of a few ships, which he had been directed to bring from Syria into Asia, and with these he engaged the fleet of the Rhodians in the Pamphylian sea,t and though his men were overpowered in the struggle by the number of the enemy, he had the advan tage himself in the wing in which he acted.
tgt_text.6398: After Antiochus was put to flight,t Hannibal, fearing that he should be delivered to the Romans (an event which would doubtless have come to pass, if he had given the king an opportunity of securing him), went off to the people of Gortyn, in Crete, that he might there consider in what place he should settle himself.
tgt_text.6399: But, as he was the most perspica­ cious of all men, he saw that unless he took some precautions, he should be in great danger from the covetousness of the Cretans ;
tgt_text.6400: for he carried with him a large sum of money, of which he knew that a report had gone abroad.
tgt_text.6401: He therefore adopted the following contrivance ;
tgt_text.6402: he filled several pots with lead, covering the upper part with gold and silver, and de­ posited them, in the presence of the leading men§, in the temple of Diana, pretending that he trusted his fortune to their honesty
tgt_text.6403: Having thus deceived them, he filled the whole of some brazen statues, which he carried with him, with his money, and threw them down in an open place at his own residence.
tgt_text.6404: The Gortynians, meanwhile, guarded the temple with extreme care, not so much against others as against Hannibal himself, lest he should remove any thing without their knowledge, and carry it off with him.X.
tgt_text.6405: The Carthaginian, having thus saved his property, and deceived all the Cretans, went into Pontus to Prusias, with whom he showed himself of the same mind as to Italy;
tgt_text.6406: for he did nothing but excite the king to arms, and animate him against the Romans, and seeing that he was not at all strong in domestic resources, he induced other princes to join him, and united warlike nations on his side.
tgt_text.6407: Eumenes, king of Pergamus, wrs at variance with Prusias, and war was main­ tained between them by sea and land, for which reason Hannibal was the more desirous that he should be crushed.
tgt_text.6408: Eumenes had the superiority on both elements, and Hannibal thought that, if he could but cut him off, his other projects would be easier of execution.
tgt_text.6409: To put an end to his life, therefore, he adopted the following stratagem.
tgt_text.6410: They were to engage by sea in a few days;
tgt_text.6411: Hannibal was inferior in number of vessels, and had to use art in the contest, as he was no match for his enemy in force.
tgt_text.6412: He accordingly ordered as many poisonous serpents as possible to be brought together alive, and to be put into earthen vessels, of which when he had collected a large number, he called the officers of his ships together, on the day on which he was going to fight at sea, and directed them all to make an attack upon the single ship of King Eumenes, and to be content with simply defending themselves against others, as they might easily do with the aid of the vast number of serpents;
tgt_text.6413: adding that he would take care they should know in what ship Eumenes sailed, and promising that, if they took or killed him, it should be of great advantage to them.
tgt_text.6415: After this exhortation was given to the soldiers, the fleets were brought out for action by both parties.
tgt_text.6416: When the line of each was formed, and before the signal was given for battle, Hannibal, in order to show his men where Eumenes was, despatched to him a letter-carrier in a boat with a herald's staff;
tgt_text.6417: who, when he reached the enemy's line of vessels, held out a letter, and signified that he was looking for the king;
tgt_text.6418: he was therefore immediately taken to Eumenes.
tgt_text.6419: because nobody doubted that there was something written in the letter relating to peace.
tgt_text.6420: The messenger, having thus made the king's ship known to his party, returned to the same place from which he had come.
tgt_text.6421: Eumenes, on opening the letter, found nothing in it but what was meant to ridicule him;
tgt_text.6422: and though he wondered as to the motive of it, and none could be discovered, yet he did not hesitate to come at nee to battle.
tgt_text.6423: In the conflict, the Bithyniaus, according to the direction of Hannibal, fell all at once upon the ship of Eumenes.
tgt_text.6424: That prince, as he was unable to withstand then onset, sought safety in flight, but would not have found it, nad he not taken refuge behind his guards, which had been posted on the neighbouring shore.
tgt_text.6425: As the rest of the Per­ gamenian ships bore hard upon the enemy, the earthen pots, of which we have previously spoken, began suddenly to be hurled into them.
tgt_text.6426: These, when thrown, at first excited laughter among the combatants, nor could it be conceived why such a thing was done;
tgt_text.6427: but when they saw their ships filled with serpents, and, startled at the strangeness of the oc­ currence, knew not what to avoid first, they put about their ships, and retreated to their camp upon the coast.
tgt_text.6428: Thus Hannibal, by his stratagem, prevailed over the force of the Pergamenians.
tgt_text.6429: Nor was this the only occasion;
tgt_text.6430: but often, at other times, he defeated the enemy with his troops on land, and with equally skilful management.
tgt_text.6432: While these transactions were taking place in Asia, it happened accidentally at Rome that certain ambassadors from Prusias took supper at the house of Lucius Quintius Flamininus, one of the consuls;
tgt_text.6433: and there, as mention was made of Hannibal, one of them observed that he was in the dominions of Prusias.
tgt_text.6434: This information Flamininus commu­ nicated the next day to the senate.
tgt_text.6435: The conscript fathers, who thought that they would never be free from plots as long as Hannibal was alive, sent ambassadors to Bithynia, and among them Flamininus, to request the king not to keep their bitterest enemy with him, but to deliver him up to them.
tgt_text.6436: To this embassy Prusias did not dare to give a refusal;
tgt_text.6437: he made some opposition, however, to one point, begging them not tc require of him* what was contrary to the rights of hospitality, saying that they themselves might make Hannibal prisoner, if they could, as they would easily find out the place where he was.
tgt_text.6438: Hannibal indeed confined himself to one place, living in a fortress which had been given him by the king;
tgt_text.6439: and this he had so constructed that it had outlets on every side of the building, always fearing lest that should happen which eventually came to pass.
tgt_text.6440: When the Roman ambassadors had gone thither, and had surrounded his house with a number of men, a slave, looking out at a gate, told Hannibal that several armed men were to be seen, contrary to what was usual.
tgt_text.6441: Hannibal desired him to go round to all the gates of the castle, and bring him word immediately whether it was beset in the same way on all sides.
tgt_text.6442: The slave having soon reported how it was, and informed him, that all the passages were secured, he felt certain that it was no accidental occur­ rence, but that his person was menaced, and that his life was no longer to be preserved.
tgt_text.6443: That he might not part with it, however, at the pleasure of another, and dwelling on the remembrance of his past honours, he took poison, which he had been accustomed always to carry with him.
tgt_text.6445: Thus this bravest of men, after having gone through many and various labours, found repose in the seventieth year of his age.
tgt_text.6446: Under what consuls he died, is not agreed;
tgt_text.6447: for Atticus has left it recorded in his chronicle that he ended his life in the consulship of Marcus Claudius Marcellus and Quintus Fabius Labeo ;
tgt_text.6448: but Polybius says in that of Lucius .
tgt_text.6449: Emilius Paullus and Cnæus Bæbius Tamphilus;
tgt_text.6451: cius in that of Publius Cornelius Cethegus and Marcus Bæbius Tamphilus.
tgt_text.6452: This great man, though occupied in such vast military operations, devoted some portion of his time to literature;
tgt_text.6453: for there are some books of his written in the Greek language, and amongst them one addressed to the Rhodians on the acts of Cnæus Manlius Vulso in Asia.
tgt_text.6454: Of the wars which he conducted many have given the history ;
tgt_text.6455: and two of them were persons that were with him in the camp, and lived with him as long as fortune allowed, 8ilenus and Sosilus the Lacedæmonian;
tgt_text.6456: and this Sosilus Hannibal had as his instructor in the Greek language.
tgt_text.6457: But it is now time to make an end of this book, and to give an account of commanders among the Romans, that, when the actions of both are compared, it may be the better determined which generals deserve the preference.
tgt_text.6458: Cato's birth, youth, and the offices that he held, I.—His consulship in Hither Spain;
tgt_text.6459: his severity as censor, IL —His eulogy;
tgt_text.6462: born in the municipal town of Tusculum,t resided, when a very young man, and before he turned his attention to the attainment of office, in the territory of the Sabines, because he had an estate there which had been left him by his father.
tgt_text.6463: It was at the persuasion of Lucius Valerius Flaccus, whom he had for a colleague in his consulate and censorship, that he removed, as Marcus Perpema Censorius was accustomed to relate, to Rome, and proceeded to employ himself in the forum.
tgt_text.6464: He served his first campaign at the age of seventeen, in the consulship of Quintus Fabius Maximus and Marcus Claudius Marcellus.
tgt_text.6465: He was military tribune in Sicily.
tgt_text.6466: When he returned from thence, he attached himself to the staff of Caius Claudius Nero, and his service was thought of great value in the battle near Sena, in which Hasdrubal, the brother of Hannibal, fell.
tgt_text.6467: As quæstor, he happened to be under the consul, Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus, with whom he did not live according to the intimate connexion of his office;
tgt_text.6468: for he was at variance with him during his whole life.
tgt_text.6469: He was made ædile of the commons ‡ with Caius Helvius.
tgt_text.6470: As prætor he had the province of Sardinia, from which, when he was returning from Africa some time before in the character of quæstor, he had brought Quintus Ennius, the poet, an act which we value not less than the noblest triumph that Sardinia could have afforded.
tgt_text.6472: He held the consulship with Lucius Valerius Flaccus, and had by lot Hither Spain for his province, from which he gained a triumph.
tgt_text.6473: As he stayed there a long time, Publius Scipio Africanus, when consul for the second time, wanted to remove him from his province, and to succeed him himself, but was unable, through the senate, to effect that object, even though he then possessed the greatest authority in the state;
tgt_text.6474: for the government was then conducted, not with regard for personal influence, but according to justice.
tgt_text.6475: Being displeased with the senate on this account, Scipio, after his consulship was ended, remained in the city as a private person.
tgt_text.6476: *Cato, being made censor with the Flaccus above mentioned, exercised that office with severity;
tgt_text.6477: for he inflicted penalties on many noblemen, and introduced many new regulations into his edict,!
tgt_text.6478: by means of which luxury, which was even then beginning to germinate, might be repressed.
tgt_text.6479: For about eighty years.‡ from his youth to the end of his life, he never ceased to incur enmity in behalf of the commonwealth.
tgt_text.6480: Though attacked by many,§ he not only suffered no loss of character, but increased in reputation for virtue as long as he lived.
tgt_text.6482: In all his pursuits he gave proofs of singular in­ telligence and industry;
tgt_text.6483: for he was a skilful agriculturist, well-informed in political affairs, experienced in the law, an eminent commander, a respectable orator.
tgt_text.6484: He was also much devoted to literature, and though he had entered on the study of it at an advanced age, yet he made such progress in it, that you could not easily discover anything, either in Grecian or Italian history, that was unknown to him.
tgt_text.6485: From his youth he composed speeches.
tgt_text.6486: In his old age he began to write his Histories, of which there are ten books.
tgt_text.6487: The first contains the acts of the kings of Rome;
tgt_text.6488: the second and third show from whence each Italian state had its rise, for which reason he seems to have called the whole body of them Origines:
tgt_text.6489: in the fourth is related the first Carthaginian war;
tgt_text.6491: and all these subjects are treated in a summary way.
tgt_text.6492: Other wars he has narrated in a similar manner, down to the prætorship of Lucius Galba, who spoiled the Lusitanians.
tgt_text.6493: The leaders in these wars, however, he has not named, but has stated the facts without the names.
tgt_text.6494: In the same books he has given an account of whatever seemed remarkable in Italy and Spain ;
tgt_text.6495: and there are shown in them much labour and industry, and much learning.
tgt_text.6496: Of his life and manners we have spoken more at large in the book which we wrote expressly concerning him at the request of Titus Pomponius Atticus;
tgt_text.6497: and we therefore refer those who would know Cato to that volume.
tgt_text.6498: Birth, talents, and education of Atticus, I.—He goes to Athens;
tgt_text.6505: his friendship with Cicero and Hortensius, V.—He abstains from seeking offices or honours, but maintains his dignity of character, VI.
tgt_text.6506: —In the civil war he offends neither Pompey nor Cæsar, VII.
tgt_text.6507: —After Cæsar is killed, he supplies Brutus with money, VIII.
tgt_text.6508: —Is not even an enemy to Antony, whose wife and children he relieves, IX. — Antony's regard for the services of Atticus, X.—He aids many of the pro­ scribed, XI.
tgt_text.6509: —He uses his interest only to avert dangers and troubles from his friends, XII—Of his private life;
tgt_text.6510: is a good father and citizen, XIII - His meals ;
tgt_text.6511: his prudence in pecuniary matters, XIV.
tgt_text.6512: —His love of truth and diligence, XV.—Agreeable to the old in his youth, and to the young in his old age, XVI.—
tgt_text.6513: His dutifulness to his mother, XVII.
tgt_text.6514: —His love of antiquity, and literature in general, XVIIL—His connexion with Cæsar Octavianus, XIX.
tgt_text.6515: —His friendship with Cæsar and Antony, XX.—
tgt_text.6519: TITUS POMPONIUS ATTICUS, descended from a most ancient Roman family,.
tgt_text.6520: held the equestrian rank received in uninterrupted succession from his ancestors.
tgt_text.6521: He had a father who was active, indulgent, and, as times then were, wealthy, as well as eminently devoted to literature;
tgt_text.6522: and, as he loved learning himself, he instructed his son in all branches of knowledge with which youth ought to be made acquainted.
tgt_text.6523: In the boy, too, besides docility of disposition, there was great sweetness of voice, so that he not only imbibed rapidly what was taught him, but repeated it extremely well.
tgt_text.6524: He was in consequence distinguished among his companions in his boy­ hood, and shone forth with more lustre than his noble fellow-students could patiently bear;
tgt_text.6525: hence he stirred them all to new exertions by his application.
tgt_text.6526: In the number of them were Lucius Torquatus, Caius Marius the younger, and Marcus Cicero, whom he so attached to himself by his inter­ course with them, that no one was ever more dear to them.
tgt_text.6528: His father died at an early age.
tgt_text.6529: He himself, in his youth, on account of his connexion with Publius Sulpicius, who was killed when tribune of the people, was not unapprehensive of sharing in his danger;
tgt_text.6530: for Anicia, Pomponius's cousin, was married to Marcus Servius, the brother of Sulpicius.
tgt_text.6531: When he saw that the state, therefore, after the death of Sulpicius, was thrown into confusion by the disturbances of Cinna, and that no facility was allowed him of living suitably to his dignity without offending one side or the other (the feelings of the citizens being divided, as some favoured the party of Sylla and others that of Cinna) he thought it a proper time for devoting himself to his studies, and betook himself to Athens.
tgt_text.6532: He nevertheless, however, assisted young Marius, when declared an enemy, by such means as he could, and relieved him in his exile with money.
tgt_text.6533: And, lest his sojourn in a foreign country should cause any detriment to his estate, he transported thither a great portion of his fortune.
tgt_text.6534: Here he lived in such a manner, that he was deservedly much beloved by all the Athenians;
tgt_text.6535: for, in addition to his interest, which was great for so young a man, he relieved their public exigencies from his own property;
tgt_text.6536: since, when the government was obliged to borrow money,- and had no fair offer of it, he always came to their aid, and in such a way, that he never received any interest of them, and never allowed them to be indebted to him longer than had been agreed upon;
tgt_text.6537: both which modes of acting were for their advantage, for he neither suffered their debt to grow old upon them, nor to be increased by an accumulation of interest.
tgt_text.6538: He enhanced this kindness also by other instances of liberality;
tgt_text.6539: for he presented the whole of the people with such a supply of corn, that seven modii t of wheat (a kind of measure which is called a medimnus at Athens) were allotted to each person.
tgt_text.6541: He also conducted himself in such a way, that he appeared familiar with the lowest, though on a level with the highest.
tgt_text.6542: Hence it happened that they publicly bestowed upon him all the honours that they could, and offered to make him a citizen of Athens;
tgt_text.6543: an offer which he would not accept, because some are of opinion that the citizenship of Rome is forfeited by taking that of another city.
tgt_text.6544: As long as he was among them, he prevented any statue from being erected to him;
tgt_text.6545: but when absent, he could not hinder it;
tgt_text.6546: and they accordingly raised several statues both to him and Phidias,* in the most sacred places, for, in their whole management of the state, they took him for their agent and adviser.
tgt_text.6547: It was the gift of fortune, then, in the first place, that he was born in that city, above all others, in which was the seat of the empire of the world, and had it not only for his native place but for his home;
tgt_text.6548: and, in the next, it was a proof of his wisdom, that when he betook himself to a city which excelled all others in antiquity, polite­ ness, and learning, he became individually dear to it beyond other men.
tgt_text.6550: When Sylla arrived at Athens in his journey from Asia, he kept Pomponius in his company as long as he remained there, being charmed with the young man's politeness and knowledge;
tgt_text.6551: for he spoke Greek so well that he might have been thought to have been born at Athens;
tgt_text.6552: while there was such agreeableness in his Latin style, as to make it evident that the graces of it were natural, not acquired.
tgt_text.6553: He also recited verses, both in Greek and Latin, in so pleasing a manner that nothing could have been added to its attractions.
tgt_text.6554: It was in consequence of these accomplishments that Sylla would never suffer him to be out of his company, and wanted to take him away with him to Rome.
tgt_text.6555: But when he endeavoured to persuade him to go, " Do not desire, I entreat you," replied Pomponius, “ to lead me with you against those, with whom, that I might not bear arms against you, I quitted Italy."
tgt_text.6556: Sylla, commending the good feeling of the young man, directed, at his departure, that all the presents which he had received at Athens should be carried to his house.
tgt_text.6557: Though he resided at Athens many years, paying such attention to his property as a not unthrifty father of a family ought to pay, and devoting all the rest of his time either to.
tgt_text.6558: literature or to the public affairs of the Athenians, he never­ theless afforded his services to his friends at Rome;
tgt_text.6559: for he used to come to their elections, and whatever important busi­ ness of theirs was brought forward, he was never found wanting on the occasion.
tgt_text.6560: Thus he showed a singular fidelity to Cicero in all his perils;
tgt_text.6561: and presented him, when he was banished from his country, with the sum of two hundred and fifty sestertia.*
tgt_text.6562: And when the affairs of the Romans became tranquil, he returned to Rome, in the consulship, as I believe, of Lucius Cotta and Lucius Torquatus;
tgt_text.6563: and the whole city of Athens observed the day of his departure in such a manner, that they testified by their tears the regret which they would afterwards feel for him.
tgt_text.6565: He had an uncle, Quintus Cæcilius, a Roman knight, an intimate friend of Lucius Lucullus, a rich man, but of a very morose temper, whose peevishness he bore so meekly, that he retained without interruption, to the extremity of old age, the good will of a person whom no one else could endure.
tgt_text.6566: In consequence, he reaped the fruit of his respectful conduct;

tgt_text.6764: adding concisely, also, such matters as were remarkable in the lives of the emperors ;
tgt_text.6765: that your Serenity's divine mind may rejoice to learn that it has followed the actions of illustrious men in governing the empire, before it became acquainted with them by reading.

tgt_text.6779: -Destruction of Rome by the Gauls, XX.I. THE Roman empire, than which the memory of man can recal scarcely any one smaller in its commencement, or greater in its progress throughout the world, had its origin from Romulus;
tgt_text.6780: who, being the son of a vestal virgin, and, as was supposed, of Mars, was brought forth at one birth with his brother Remus.
tgt_text.6781: While leading a predatory life among the shepherds, he founded, when he was eighteen years of age, a small city on the Palatine Hill, on the 21st day of April, in the third year of the sixth Olympiad, and the three hundred and ninety-fourth after the destruction of Troy..
tgt_text.6783: After founding the city, which he called Rome, from his own name, he proceeded principally as follows.
tgt_text.6784: He took a great number of the neighbouring inhabitants into the city;
tgt_text.6785: he chose a hundred of the older men, by whose advice he might manage all his affairs, and whom, from their age, he named senators.
tgt_text.6786: Next, as both himself and his people were in want of wives, he invited the tribes contiguous to the city to an exhibition of games, and seized upon their young women.
tgt_text.6787: Wars having arisen in consequence of this outrage in cap turing the females, he conquered the Cæninenses, the Antem nates, the Crustumini, the Sabines, the Fidenates, and the Vejentes;
tgt_text.6788: all whose towns lay around the city.
tgt_text.6789: And since, after a tempest that suddenly arose, in the thirty-seventh year of his reign, he was no longer to be seen, he was believed to have been translated to the gods, and was accordingly deified.
tgt_text.6790: The senators then ruled at Rome by periods of five days;
tgt_text.6791: and under their government a year was passedIII.
tgt_text.6792: Afterwards Numa Pompilius was elected king, who engaged indeed in no wars, but was of no less service to the state than Romulus;
tgt_text.6793: for he established both laws and customs among the Romans, who, by the frequency of their wars, were now regarded as robbers and semi-barbarians.
tgt_text.6794: He divided the year, before unregulated by any computation, into ten months, and founded numerous sacred rites and temples at Rome.
tgt_text.6795: He died a natural death in the forty-third year of his reign.
tgt_text.6797: To him succeeded Tullus Hostilius, who re-commenced war.
tgt_text.6798: He conquered the Albans, who lay twelve miles distant from Rome.
tgt_text.6799: He overcame also in battle the Vejentes and Fidenates, the one six, the other eighteen miles from Rome;
tgt_text.6800: and increased the dimensions of the city by the addition of the Ccelian hill.
tgt_text.6801: After reigning thirty-two years, he was struck by lightning, and consumed together with his house.
tgt_text.6802: V. After him, Ancus Martius, the grandson of Numa by a daughter, succeeded to the government.
tgt_text.6803: He fought against the Latins, added the Aventine and Janiculan hills to the city, and founded Ostia, a city on the sea-coast, sixteen miles from Rome.
tgt_text.6804: He died a natural death in the twenty-fourth year of his reign.
tgt_text.6805: VI. Priscus Tarquinius was next invested with the govern­ ment.
tgt_text.6806: He doubled the number of the senators, built a Circus at Rome, and instituted the Roman games which continUa even to our time.
tgt_text.6807: He also conquered the Sabines, and alded a considerable extent of territory, which he took from that people, to the lands of Rome;
tgt_text.6808: he was also the first that entered the city in triumph.
tgt_text.6809: He built the walls and sewers, and commenced the Capitol.
tgt_text.6810: He was killed in the thirty-eighth year of his reign, by the sons of Ancus, the king whom he had succeeded.
tgt_text.6812: After him Servius Tullius was placed on the throne, the son of a woman of noble origin, but who was, neverthe­ less, a captive and a slave.
tgt_text.6814: annexed three hills, the Quirinal, Viminal, and Esquiline, to the city ;
tgt_text.6815: and formed trenches round the city walls.
tgt_text.6816: He was the first to institute the census, which till that time was unknown throughout the world.
tgt_text.6817: The people being all subjected to a census during his reign, Rome was found to contain eighty-four thousand citizens, including those in the country.
tgt_text.6818: He was cut off in the forty-fifth year of his reign, by the criminal machinations of his son-in-law Tarquin the Proud, the son of the king to whom he had succeeded, and of his own daughter, whom Tarquin had married.
tgt_text.6820: Lucius Tarquinius Superbus, the seventh and last of the kings, overcame the Volsci, a nation not far from Rome, on the road to Campania;
tgt_text.6821: reduced the towns of Gabii and Suessa Pometia;
tgt_text.6823: and built a temple to Jupiter in the Capitol.
tgt_text.6824: Afterwards, while he was besieging Ardea, a town that lay about eighteen miles from the city, he was deprived of his throne;
tgt_text.6825: for, as his younger son, who was also named Tarquin, offered violence to Lucretia, the wife of Collatinus, a most noble and chaste woman;
tgt_text.6826: and as she, after complaining to her husband, her father, and her friends, of the injury that she had suffered, slew herself in the sight of them all;
tgt_text.6827: Brutus, in consequence, who was a kinsman of Tarquinius, excited an insurrection among the people, and deprived Tarquin of his regal authority.
tgt_text.6828: The army, also, which was engaged with the king in besieging Ardea, soon after deserted him;
tgt_text.6829: and the king himself, on going to the city, found the gates closed against him;
tgt_text.6830: and, after having reigned five-and-twenty years, was forced to take flight with his wife and children.
tgt_text.6831: Thus a regal form of government continued at Rome, under seven kings, for the space of two hundred and forty-three years, while as yet the dominion of the city, where its extent was greatest, hardly reached fifteen miles.
tgt_text.6833: Henceforth, instead of one king, two consuls were chosen, with this view, that, if one should be disposed to act unjustly, the other, having equal authority, might exercise a control over him.
tgt_text.6834: It was determined also that they should not hold their office longer than a year;
tgt_text.6835: in order that they might not, by continued possession of power, grow too over­ bearing;
tgt_text.6836: but, knowing that in a year they would return to the level of private persons, might constantly conduct them­ selves with moderation.
tgt_text.6837: In the first year, then, after the expulsion of the king and his family, the consuls were Lucius Junius Brutus, who had been the chief agent in the banishment of Tarquin, and Tar­ quinius Collatinus, the husband of Lucretia.
tgt_text.6838: But that dignity was soon taken from Tarquinius Collatinus;
tgt_text.6839: for it was enacted that no one who bore the name of Tarquin should remain in the city.
tgt_text.6840: Having collected, therefore, all his private property, he removed from the city, and Valerius Publicola was made consul in his stead.
tgt_text.6841: King Tarquin, however, after his expul­ sion, stirred up war against Rome, and, having collected a large force from all quarters, in order that he might be rein­ stated on the throne, took the field.
tgt_text.6843: In the first encounter, Brutus and Aruns, Tarquin's son, killed each other;
tgt_text.6844: but the Romans left the field conquerors.
tgt_text.6845: The Roman matrons mourned for Brutus, the guardian of their honour, as if he had been their common father, for the space of a year.
tgt_text.6846: Valerius Publicola fixed upon Spurius Lucretius Tricipitinus.
tgt_text.6847: the father of Lucretia, for his colleague;
tgt_text.6848: and he dying of some disease, he next chose Horatius Pulvillus for his fellow consul.
tgt_text.6849: Thus the first year had five consuls;
tgt_text.6850: Tarquinius Collatinus having left the city on account of his name, Brutus having fallen in battle, and Spurius Lucretius having died a natural death.
tgt_text.6852: In the second year also, Tarquin, with a view to being re-established on the throne, again made war on the Romans, and, as Porsena, king of Tuscany, afforded him aid, almost took Rome.
tgt_text.6853: But he was also defeated on that occasion.
tgt_text.6854: In the third year after the expulsion of the royal family, Tarquin, as he could not get himself re-admitted into the king dom, and as Porsena, who had made peace with the Romans, gave him no support, retired to Tusculum, a town which is not far from Rome;
tgt_text.6855: where he and his wife lived for fourteen years in a private station, and reached an advanced age.
tgt_text.6856: In the fourth year after the abolition of the kingly power, the Sabines, having made war on the Romans, were conquered;
tgt_text.6857: and a triumph was celebrated over them.
tgt_text.6858: In the fifth year, Lucius Valerius, the colleague of Brutus, and consul for the fourth time, died a natural death, and in such extreme poverty, that the expenses of his funeral were defrayed by a public subscription.*
tgt_text.6859: The matrons mourned for him, as for Brutus, during a year.
tgt_text.6861: In the ninth year after the overthrow of the kingly power, the son-in-law of Tarquin, having assembled a vast army, in order to avenge the wrongs of his father-in-law, a new office was introduced at Rome, which was called the dictator­ ship, and which was more absolute than the consulate.
tgt_text.6862: In the same year also a master of the horse was appointed to be an officer under the dictator.
tgt_text.6863: Nor can anything be named more like to the imperial authority, which your Serenity t now enjoys, than the ancient dictatorship, especially since Cæsar Octavianus, also, of whom we shall speak hereafter, and Caius Cæsar before him, ruled with the title and rank of dictator.
tgt_text.6864: The first dictator at Rome was Lartius;
tgt_text.6865: the first master of the horse, Spurius Cassius.
tgt_text.6867: In the sixteenth year after the termination of the regal power, the people at Rome, thinking themselves oppressed by the senate and consuls, broke out into a sedition.
tgt_text.6868: On this occasion they created for themselves tribunes of the people, as their own peculiar judges and defenders, by whom they might be protected against the senate aud the consuls.
tgt_text.6870: In the following year the Volsci recommenced hos­ tilities against the Romans ;
tgt_text.6871: and being overcome in the field, lost also Corioli, the best city that they had.
tgt_text.6873: In the eighteenth year after the banishment of the royal family, Quintius Marcius, the Roman general who had taken Corioli, the city of the Volsci, being compelled to flee from Rome, directed his course, in resentment, to the Volsci themselves, and received from them support against the Romans.
tgt_text.6874: He obtained several victories over the Romans :
tgt_text.6875: he made his way even to the fifth mile-stone from the city;
tgt_text.6876: and, refusing to hear a deputation that came to sue for peace, would have laid siege even to the place of his birth, had not his mother Veturia and his wife Volumnia gone out from the city to meet him, by whose tears and supplications he was pre­ vailed on to withdraw his army.
tgt_text.6877: He was the next after Tarquin that acted as general against his country.
tgt_text.6879: In the consulate of Cæso Fabius and Titus Vir­ ginius, three hundred noblemen, members of the Fabian family, undertook alone a war against the Vejentes, assuring the senate and the people that the whole contest should be brought to an end by themselves.

tgt_text.6882: After these events a census was held in the city, in which the number of the citizens was found to be a hundred and nine­ teen thousand three hundred and nineteen.
tgt_text.6884: In the following year, in consequence of the blockade of a Roman army on Mount Algidus, about twelve miles from the city, Lucius Quintius Cincinnatus was appointed dictator;

tgt_text.6890: In the three hundred and second * year from the founding of the city, the consular government ceased;
tgt_text.6891: and, instead of two consuls, ten magistrates were appointed to hold the supreme authority, under the title of decemviri.
tgt_text.6892: These during the first year conducted themselves with honour;
tgt_text.6893: but in the second, one of them, Appius Claudius, proceeded to offer violence to the maiden daughter of a certain Virginius, who was at that time filling an honourable post on military service against the Latins on Mount Algidus;
tgt_text.6894: but the father slew her with his own hand, that she might not suffer violation from the decemvir, and, returning to the army, raised an insurrection among the soldiers.
tgt_text.6895: Their power was in conse­ quence taken from the decemviri, and they themselves received sentences of condemnation.
tgt_text.6897: In the three hundred and fifteenth year from the founding of the city, the Fidenates rebelled against the Romans.
tgt_text.6898: The Vejentes and their king Tolumnius gave them assistance.
tgt_text.6899: These two states are so near to Rome, that Fidenæ is only seven, Veii only eighteen miles distant.
tgt_text.6901: but they were defeated by Marcus Æmilius the dictator, and Lucius Quintius Cincinnatus the master of the horse, and lost also their king.
tgt_text.6902: Fidenæ was taken, and utterly destroyed.
tgt_text.6904: Twenty years afterwards, the people of Veil resumed hostilities.
tgt_text.6905: Furius Camillus was sent as dictator against them, who first defeated them in battle, and then, after a long siege, took their city, the oldest and richest in Italy.
tgt_text.6906: He next took Falisci, a city of no less note.
tgt_text.6907: But popular odium was excited against him, on the ground that he had made an unfair division of the booty, and he was condemned on that charge and banished.
tgt_text.6908: Soon after the Galli Senones marched towards Rome;
tgt_text.6909: and, pursuing the Romans, whom they defeated at the river Allia, eleven miles from the city, possessed themselves of the city itself, no part of which could be defended against them, except the Capitol.
tgt_text.6910: After they had besieged it a long time, and the Romans were suffering from famine, Camillus, who was in exile in a neighbouring city, attacked the Gauls unexpectedly, and gave them a severe defeat.
tgt_text.6912: on receiving a sum in gold, to desist from the siege of the Capitol, they retreated;
tgt_text.6913: Camillus, however, pursued them, and routed them with such a slaughter, that he recovered both the gold which had been given to them, and all the military standards which they had taken.
tgt_text.6914: Thus he entered the city for the third time in triumph, and received the appellation of a second Romulus, as if he also had been a founder of the city.
