tgt_text.6927: IN the three hundred and sixty-fifth year after the foun­ dation of the city, and the first after its capture by the Gauls, the form of government was changed;
tgt_text.6928: and, instead of two consuls, military tribunes, invested with consular power, were created.
tgt_text.6929: From this time the power of Rome began to increase;
tgt_text.6930: for that very year Camillus reduced the state of the Volsci, which had persisted to make war for seventy years;
tgt_text.6931: also the cities of the Æqui and Sutrini;
tgt_text.6932: and, overthrowing their armies, took possession of them all;
tgt_text.6933: and thus enjoyed three triumphs at the same time.
tgt_text.6935: Titus Quintius Cincinnatus, also, having pursued the Prænestini, who had advanced in a hostile manner to the very gates of Rome, defeated them on the river Allia, annexing eight cities that were under their dominion to the Roman empire;
tgt_text.6936: and, attacking Præneste itself, forced it to surrender;
tgt_text.6937: all which acts were accomplished by him in the space of twenty days ;
tgt_text.6938: and a triumph was decreed him.
tgt_text.6940: But the office of military tribunes did not last long;
tgt_text.6941: for, after a short time, it was enacted that no more should be created;
tgt_text.6942: and four years passed in the state in such a manner.
tgt_text.6943: that none of the superior magistrates were appointed.
tgt_text.6944: The military tribunes, however, were re-instated in their office with consular authority, and continued for three years, when consuls were again elected.
tgt_text.6946: In the consulship of Lucius Genucius and Quintus Servilius, Camillus died, and honour next to that of Romulus was paid him.
tgt_text.6948: Titus Quintius was sent out as dictator against the Gauls, who had marched into Italy;
tgt_text.6949: and had encamped about four miles from the city, on the other side of the river Anio.
tgt_text.6950: Titus Manlius, one of the noblest of the senators, encountering a Gaul who had challenged him to single combat, slew him ;
tgt_text.6951: and, having taken from his neck a chain of gold, and put it on his own, secured the appellation of Torquatus to himself and his posterity for ever.
tgt_text.6952: The Gauls were repulsed, and soon afterwards entirely defeated by Caius Sulpicius the dictator.
tgt_text.6953: Shortly after, the Tuscans were defeated by Caius Marcius, and eight thousand of them were taken prisoners and led in triumph.
tgt_text.6956: and as the Latins, who had been subdued by the Romans, refused to furnish troops, recruits were levied from among the Romans only, and ten legions were raised, making sixty thousand fighting men, or upwards;
tgt_text.6957: so great was the power of the Romans in war, while their territory was as yet but small.
tgt_text.6958: These troops having marched out against the Gauls, under the conduct of Lucius Furius Camillus, one of the Gauls challenged the most valiant among the Romans to single combat;
tgt_text.6959: when Marcus Valerius, a tribune of the soldiers, came forward to accept the challenge;
tgt_text.6960: and, as he advanced in full armour, a crow settled upon his right shoulder.
tgt_text.6961: Afterwards, too, when he commenced the encounter with the Gaul, the same crow, with his wings and talons, furiously assailed the Gaul's eyes, so that he was not able to see before him, and thus, being slain by the tribune Valerius, he gave him not only a victory, but a name;
tgt_text.6962: for he was afterwards called Corvus.
tgt_text.6963: For the same service also, at the age of three and twenty, he was made consul.
tgt_text.6965: The Latins, who had refused to furnish troops, proceeded also to demand of the Romans, that one of the consuls should be elected from their own people, the other from the Romans;
tgt_text.6966: this demand having been rejected, war was commenced against them, and they were overcome
tgt_text.6968: and a triumph was celebrated on account of their defeat.
tgt_text.6969: Statues were erected to the consuls in the Rostra, for their service in gaining this victory.
tgt_text.6971: The Romans had now begun to be powerful;
tgt_text.6972: for a war was carried on by them against the Samnites, who hold a middle situation between Picenum, Campania, and Apulia, at the distance of nearly a hundred and thirty miles from the city.
tgt_text.6973: Lucius Papirius Cursor went to conduct that war with the rank of dictator, and, on returning to Rome, gave orders to Quintus Fabius Maximus, his master of the horse, whom he left in charge of the army, not to fight during his absence.
tgt_text.6974: He, however, seeing a favourable opportunity, commenced an engagement with great success, and utterly defeated the Sam­ nites ;
tgt_text.6975: he was accordingly condemned to death by the dictator, for fighting contrary to his orders, but was saved by the power­ ful interposition of the soldiers and people, so great a tumult having been excited against Papirius, that he was almost slain.
tgt_text.6977: The Samnites subsequently, in the consulate of Titus Veturius and Spurius Posthumius, defeated the Romans with signal ignominy, and compelled them to pass under the yoke.
tgt_text.6978: The peace, however, which had been concluded with them through mere necessity, was broken by the senate and people.
tgt_text.6979: After this the Samnites were defeated by Lucius Papirius the consul, and seven thousand of them made to pass under the yoke.
tgt_text.6980: Papirius was granted a triumph over the Samnites.
tgt_text.6981: About the same time Appius Claudius the censor brought the Claudian water into the city, and made the Appian way.
tgt_text.6982: The Samnites, renewing the war, defeated Quintus Fabius Maximus, with the slaughter of three thousand of his troops;
tgt_text.6983: but afterwards, his father, Fabius Maximus, being appointed his lieutenant, he both defeated the Samnites, and took several of their towns.
tgt_text.6984: Subsequently, Publius Cornelius Rufinus and Manius Curius Dentatus, the two consuls, being sent against the Samnites, reduced their strength in some considerable battles.
tgt_text.6985: Thus they brought the war with the Samnites to an end;
tgt_text.6986: a war which had lasted for forty-nine years, Nor was there any enemy in Italy that put the valour of the Romans more to the test.X.
tgt_text.6987: After an interval of a few years, the forces of the Gauls united with the Tuscans and Samnites against the Romans;
tgt_text.6988: but, as they were marching to Rome, were cut off by the consul Cnæus Cornelius Dolabella.
tgt_text.6990: War was at the same time proclaimed against the Tarentines (who are still a people at the extremity of Italy), because they had offered violence to some Roman ambassadors.
tgt_text.6991: These people asked aid against the Romans of Pyrrhus, king of Epirus, who derived his origin from the family of Achilles.
tgt_text.6992: He soon after passed over into Italy, and it was then that the Romans fought for the first time with an enemy from beyond sea.
tgt_text.6993: The consul Publius Valerius Lævinus was sent against him;
tgt_text.6994: who, having seized some spies of Pyrrhus, ordered them to be led through the camp, and the whole army to be exhibited to them, and then to be dismissed, that they might tell Pyrrhus whatever was going on among the Romans.
tgt_text.6995: An engagement taking place soon after, Pyrrhus, when on the point of fleeing, got the victory by means of his elephants, at the sight of which the Romans, to whom they were strange, were greatly terrified;
tgt_text.6996: but night put an end to the battle.
tgt_text.6997: Lævinus however fled during the night.
tgt_text.6998: Pyrrhus took a thousand eight hundred Romans prisoners, and treated them with the greatest honour;
tgt_text.7000: On observing those lying dead, with their wounds in front, and with stern coun­ tenances, he is said to have lifted up his hands to heaven, exclaiming that “ he might himself have been master of the whole world, if such soldiers had fallen to his lot.
tgt_text.7002: Pyrrhus afterwards, having united to him the Sam­ nites, the Lucanians, and the Bruttii, proceeded towards Rome.
tgt_text.7003: He laid all waste with fire and sword, depopulated Campania, and advanced to Preeneste, eighteen miles from Rome.
tgt_text.7004: Soon after, through fear of an army which was pursuing him with a consul at its head, he fell back upon Campania.
tgt_text.7005: Ambassadors, who were sent to treat with Pyrrhus respecting the ransom of the captives, were honourably entertained by him;
tgt_text.7006: and he sent the captives back to Rome without payment.
tgt_text.7007: Fabricius, one of the Roman ambassadors, he admired so much, that, finding he was poor, he endeavoured to draw him over to his side with the promise of a fourth part of his kingdom, but he was repulsed with disdain by Fabricius.
tgt_text.7008: Pyrrhus, therefore, being struck with admiration at the character of the Romans, seut an eminent man.
tgt_text.7009: Cineas by name, as ambassador, to ask for peace on reasonable terms, provided that he might retain possession of that part of Italy, of which he had already become master in the war.
tgt_text.7011: Such terms of peace were not satisfactory, and an answer was returned by the senate to Pyrrhus, that " he could have no peace with the Romans, unless he retired from Italy."
tgt_text.7012: The Romans then ordered that all the prisoners whom Pyrrhus had sent back should be considered infamous,* because they had suffered themselves to be taken with arms in their bands;
tgt_text.7013: and not to be restored to their former rank, until they had each produced the spoils of two slain enemies.
tgt_text.7014: Thus the ambassador of Pyrrhus returned;
tgt_text.7015: and, when Pyrrhus asked him " what kind of a place he had found Rome to be," Cineas replied, that " he had seen a country of kings, for that all there were such, as Pyrrhus alone was thought to be in Epirus and the rest of Greece.
tgt_text.7016: "The consuls Publius Sulpicius and Decius Mus were sent out as generals against Pyrrhus.
tgt_text.7017: A battle being commenced, Phrrhus was wounded, his elephants killed, twenty thousand of the enemy slain, and of the Romans only five thousand.
tgt_text.7018: Pyrrhus was forced to retire to Tarentum.XIV.
tgt_text.7019: After the lapse of a year, Fabricius was sent out against Pyrrhus, the same who, when he was before among the ambassadors, could not be won with a promise of the fourth part of his kingdom.
tgt_text.7020: As Fabricius and the king had their camps near to each other, the physician of Pyrrhus came to Fabricius by night, offering to despatch Pyrrhus by poison, if he would promise him some remuneration;

tgt_text.7269: A conference being held, peace was offered on the same terms as before, only a hundred thou­ sand pounds of silver were added to the former five hundred thousand, on account of their late perfidy..
tgt_text.7270: The terms were unsatisfactory to the Carthaginians, and they ordered Han­ nibal to continue the war.
tgt_text.7271: The war was carried by Scipio, and Masinissa, another king of the Numidians, who had made an alliance with Scipio, to the very walls of Carthage.
tgt_text.7272: Hannibal sent three spies into Scipio’s camp, who were captured, and Scipio ordered them to be led round the camp, the whole army to be shown them, and themselves to be entertained and dismissed, that they might report to Hannibal all that they had seen among the Romans.
tgt_text.7274: In the meantime preparations were made by both generals for a battle, such as scarce ever occurred in any age, since they were the ablest commanders that ever led forces into the field.
tgt_text.7275: Scipio came off victorious, having almost captured Hannibal himself, who escaped at first with several horse, then with twenty, and at last with only four.
tgt_text.7276: There were found in Hannibal's camp twenty thousand pounds of silver, and eight hundred of gold, with plenty of stores.
tgt_text.7277: After this battle, peace was concluded with the Carthaginians.
tgt_text.7278: Scipio returned to Rome, and triumphed with the greatest glory, receiving from that period the appellation of Africanus.
tgt_text.7279: Thus the second Punic war was brought to an end in the nineteenth year after it began.
tgt_text.7280: War with Philip, king of Macedonia, L II.
tgt_text.7281: —War with Antiochus, king of Syria, III.
tgt_text.7282: IV.—Triumph of Fulvius over the Ætolians;
tgt_text.7283: death of Hannibal, V.—War with Perseus, king of Macedonia, and with Gentius, king of Illyria, VI.—VIII.
tgt_text.7285: —Third Punic war, and destruction of Carthage, X. —XII.
tgt_text.7287: —The Achæan war, and destruction of Corinth, XIV.
tgt_text.7288: —War in Mace­ donia with Pseudo Perseus, XV.
tgt_text.7291: Attalus bequeaths his kingdom to the Roman people, XVIII.
tgt_text.7292: —Triumphs of Junius Brutus and Scipio, XIX.
tgt_text.7294: Carthage becomes a Roman colony, XXI.
tgt_text.7295: —War with the Transal­ pine Gauls, and Bituitus, king of the Arverni, XXII.
tgt_text.7298: —Unsuc­ cessful war with the Scordisci, XXIV.
tgt_text.7302: AFTER the Punic was terminated, the Macedonian war, against King Philip, succeeded.
tgt_text.7304: In the five hundred and fifty-first year from the build­ ing of the city, Titus Quintius Flamininus was sent against King Philip.
tgt_text.7305: He was successful in his undertaking;
tgt_text.7306: and peace was granted to Philip on these conditions, that "he should not make war on those states of Greece which the Romans had defended against him;
tgt_text.7307: that he should restore the prisoners and deserters ;
tgt_text.7308: that he should retain only fifty vessels, and deliver up the rest to the Romans;
tgt_text.7309: that he should pay, for ten years, a tribute of four thousand pounds weight of silver;
tgt_text.7310: and give his own son Demetrius as a hostage."
tgt_text.7311: Titus Quintius made war also on the Lacedæmonians;
tgt_text.7312: de­ feated their general Nabis, and admitted them into alliance on such terms as he thought proper.
tgt_text.7313: He led with great pride before his chariot hostages of most noble rank, Demetrius the son of Philip, and Armenes the son of Nabis.
tgt_text.7315: The Macedonian war being thus terminated, the Syrian war, against King Antiochus, succeeded, in the consul­ ship of Publius Cornelius Scipio and Manius Acilius Glabrio.
tgt_text.7316: To this Antiochus Hannibal had joined himself, abandoning his native country, Carthage, to escape being delivered up to the Romans.
tgt_text.7317: Manius Acilius Glabrio fought successfully in Achaia.
tgt_text.7318: The camp of King Antiochus was taken by an attack in the night, and he himself obliged to flee To Philip his son Demetrius was restored, for having assisted the Romans in their contest with Antiochus.
tgt_text.7320: In the consulate of Lucius Cornelius Scipio and Caius Lælius, Scipio Africanus went out as lieutenant to his brother Lucius Cornelius Scipio, the consul, against Antiochus.
tgt_text.7321: Hannibal, who was with Antiochus, was defeated in a battle by sea.
tgt_text.7322: Antiochus himself was afterwards routed by Cornelius Scipio, the consul, in a great battle at Magnesia, a city of Asia, near mount Sipylus.
tgt_text.7323: Eumenes, who founded the city of Eumenia in Phrygia, the brother of king AttaIns, assisted the Romans in that engagement.
tgt_text.7324: Fifty thousand foot, and three thousand horse were killed in that battle on the side of the king.
tgt_text.7325: In consequence, King Antiochus sued for peace, which was granted to him, though vanquished, by the senate, on the same conditions as it had been offered before :
tgt_text.7326: “ that he should withdraw from Europe and Asia, and confine himself within mount Taurus;
tgt_text.7327: that he should pay ten thousand talents, and give twenty hostages, and surrender Hannibal, the author of the war."
tgt_text.7328: All the cities of Asia, which Antio­ chus had lost in this war, were given to Eumenes;
tgt_text.7329: many cities also were granted to the Rhodians, who had assisted the Romans against Antiochus.
tgt_text.7330: Scipio returned to Rome, and celebrated his triumph with great pomp;
tgt_text.7331: and he also, after the example of his brother, received the name of Asiaticus, from his conquest of Asia;
tgt_text.7332: as his brother, from the subjugation of Africa, had been surnamed Africanus.V.
tgt_text.7333: Under the consuls Spurius Posthumius Albinus and Quintus Marcius Philippus, Marcus Fulvius triumphed for conquering the Ætolians.
tgt_text.7334: Hannibal, who, on the defeat of Antiochus, had fled to Prusias, king of Bithynia, that he might not be surrendered to the Romans, was demanded also at his hands by Titus Quintius Flamininus;
tgt_text.7335: and, as he seemed likely to be surrendered, he drank poison, and was buried at Libyssa, in the territory of the Nicomedians.
tgt_text.7337: On the death of Philip, king of Macedonia, who had both waged war with the Romans, and afterwards given aid to the Romans against Antiochus, his son Perseus took up arms again in Macedonia, having levied great forces for the war, and having as allies Cotys, king of Thrace, and the king of Illyricum, whose name was Gentius.
tgt_text.7338: On the side of the Romans were Eumenes, king of Asia, Ariarathes of Cappa. docia, Antiochus of Syria, Ptolemy of Egypt, Masinissa of Numidia.
tgt_text.7339: Prusias, the king of Bithynia, although he had married the sister of Perseus, remained neutral.
tgt_text.7340: The general of the Romans, the consul Publius Licinius, was defeated by Perseus in a severe engagement;
tgt_text.7341: yet the Romans, although vanquished, refused peace to the king when he solicited it, except on condition that he should surrender himself and his people to the senate and the people of Rome.
tgt_text.7342: The consul Lucius Æmilius Paulus was afterwards sent against him.
tgt_text.7343: and the prætor Caius Anicius into Illyricum against Gen­ tius:
tgt_text.7344: but Gentius, being defeated with ease in a single battle, soon surrendered ;
tgt_text.7345: and his mother, his wife, his two sons, and his brother, fell at the same time into the power of the Romans.
tgt_text.7346: Thus the war was terminated within thirty days, and the news of Gentius's defeat arrived before it was an­ nounced that the war had been begun.
tgt_text.7348: The consul Æmilius Paulus came to a battle with Perseus on the 3rd of September, and defeated him, killing twenty thousand of his infantry ;
tgt_text.7349: the cavalry which remained with the king was unbroken;
tgt_text.7350: on the side of the Romans only a hundred men were missing.
tgt_text.7351: All the cities of Macedonia, that Perseus had under his sway, submitted to the Romans.
tgt_text.7352: The king himself, deserted by his friends, fell into the hands of Paulus ;
tgt_text.7353: but Paulus treated him with respect, and not as a vanquished enemy, for, when he desired to prostrate himself at his feet, he would not permit him, but placed him in a seat by his side.
tgt_text.7354: The terms granted to the Macedonians and Illyrians were these, " that they might remain free, on paying half the tribute which they had been accustomed to pay to their kings;
tgt_text.7355: " that it might be seen that the Roman people contended with a view to equity and not to covetousness:
tgt_text.7356: and these terms Paulus proclaimed in an assembly of a vast concourse of people, entertaining the ambassadors of several states, who had come to pay their respects to him, with a most sumptuous feast;
tgt_text.7357: saying that "it ought to be possible for the same individual to be victorious in war and elegant in his entertainments."
tgt_text.7359: Shortly after he took seventy cities of Epirus, which had resumed hostilities;
tgt_text.7360: the booty he distributed among his soldiers.
tgt_text.7361: He then returned to Rome with great display, in a vessel belonging to Perseus, which is recorded to have been of such extraordinary magnitude, that it contained sixteen banks of oars.
tgt_text.7362: He celebrated his triumph most magnificently in a golden car, with his two sons standing on each side of him;
tgt_text.7363: the two sons of Perseus, and Perseus himself, then forty-five years of age, were led in procession before the car.
tgt_text.7364: After Æmilius, Caius Anicius also celebrated a triumph on account of the Illyrians;
tgt_text.7365: in which Gentius, with his brother and sons, were led before his car.
tgt_text.7366: To witness this spectacle the kings of several nations came to Rome;
tgt_text.7367: among others, even Attains and Eumenes, kings of Asia, and Prusias, king of Bithynia;
tgt_text.7368: who were entertained with great consideration, and, by per­ mission of the senate, deposited the presents which they had brought in the Capitol.
tgt_text.7369: Prusias also entrusted his son Nico­ medes to the senate.
tgt_text.7371: In the year following Lucius Memmius was successful in the war in Spain.
tgt_text.7372: Marcellus the consul afterwards met with success in the same country.X.
tgt_text.7373: A third war was then undertaken against Carthage, in the six hundred and second* year from the building of the city, in the consulship of Lucius Manlius Censorinus and Marcus Manilius, and in the fifty-first year after the termina­ tion of the second Punic war.
tgt_text.7374: The consuls in consequence proceeded to attack Carthage.
tgt_text.7375: Hasdrubal, the Carthaginian general, engaged them;
tgt_text.7376: Phamea, another general, had the command of the Carthaginian cavalry.
tgt_text.7377: At that time, Scipio, the grandson of Scipio Africanus, served in the army in the capacity of tribune, for whom great fear and respect was felt by all;
tgt_text.7378: for he was regarded as eminently brave and skilful in the field.
tgt_text.7379: Many enterprises were accordingly conducted with success by his agency;
tgt_text.7380: nor did Hasdrubal or Phamea shrink from anything more than engaging with that part of the army in which Scipio commanded.
tgt_text.7382: About the same time, Masinissa, king of Numidia, who had been an ally of the Roman people for nearly sixty years, died in the ninety-seventh year of his age, leaving behind him forty-four sons.
tgt_text.7383: He appointed Scipio to divide his kingdom amongst his sonsXII.
tgt_text.7384: As the name of Scipio had already become famous, he was created consul, although but a young man, and sent against Carthage.
tgt_text.7385: He took it and demolished it:
tgt_text.7386: the spoils found there, which had been amassed by Carthage from the ruins of various cities, and the ornaments of towns, he restored to such cities of Sicily, Italy, and Africa, as recognized their own.
tgt_text.7387: Thus Carthage, in the seven hundredth year after its foundation, was destroyed.
tgt_text.7388: Scipio earned the same title which his grandfather had gained, being, on account of his valour, called Africanus Junior.
tgt_text.7389: XIII, In the meantime a certain Pseudo-Philip took up arms in Macedonia, and defeated Publius Juvencius, a Roman praetor, who had been sent out against him, with a terrible slaughter.
tgt_text.7390: After him Quintus Cæcilius Metellus was sent by the Romans as general against this pretended Philip, and, having slain twenty-five thousand of his soldiers, recovered Macedonia, and took the impostor himself prisoner.
tgt_text.7392: War was also declared against Corinth, the noblest city of Greece, on account of an affront offered to a Roman embassy.
tgt_text.7393: That city Mummius the consul took and demolished.
tgt_text.7394: Three most remarkable triumphs therefore were celebrated at Rome at the same time, that of Scipio for Africa, before whose chariot Hasdrubal was led ;
tgt_text.7396: before whose chariot walked Andriscus, also called Pseudo- Philip ;
tgt_text.7397: and that of Mummius for Corinth, before whom brazen statues, pictures, and other ornaments of that celebrated city, were carried.
tgt_text.7399: In Macedonia, meanwhile, a Pseudo-Perseus, who called himself the son of Perseus, collecting the slaves, took up arms, and, when he was at the head of a force of seven­ teen thousand fighting men, was defeated by Tremellius the quæstor.
tgt_text.7400: FAt this time a hermaphrodite was discovered at Rome, and drowned in the sea by order of the soothsayers.
tgt_text.7403: About the same time Metellus had singular success against the Spaniards in Celtiberia.
tgt_text.7405: Not long after Quintus Cæpio was also sent to the same war, which a leader named Viriathus was still keep­ ing up against the Romans in Lusitania;
tgt_text.7406: through fear of whom Viriathus was killed by his own men, after he had kept Spain in a state of excitement against the Romans for fourteen years.
tgt_text.7407: He was at first a shepherd, then captain of a band of robbers, and at last he stirred up so many powerful nations to war, that he was considered as the protector of Spain against the Romans.
tgt_text.7408: When his assassins asked a reward of the consul Cæpio, they received for answer, that “ it was never pleasing to the Romans, that It. general should be killed by his own soldiers.
tgt_text.7410: The consul Quintus Pompeius being afterwards de­ feated by the Numantines, the most powerful nation of Spain, made an ignominious peace with them.
tgt_text.7411: After him, the consul Caius Hostilius Mancinus again concluded a dishonourable peace with the Numantines, which the people and senate ordered to be annulled, and Mancinus himself to be given up to the enemy, that they might avenge themselves for the dissolution of the treaty on him with whom they had made it..
tgt_text.7412: After such signal disgrace, therefore, with which the Roman armies had been twice defeated by the Numantines, Publius Scipio Africanus was made consul a second time, and sent to Numantia.
tgt_text.7413: He reformed, in the first place, the dissolute and idle soldiery, rather by inuring them to labour than by punish­ ment, and without any great severity.
tgt_text.7414: He then took several cities of Spain, some by force, and allowing others to surren­ der.
tgt_text.7415: At last he reduced Numantia itself by famine after it had been long besieged, and razed it to the ground, and received the rest of the province into alliance.
tgt_text.7417: About this time Attalus, king of Asia, the brother of Eumenes, died, and left the Roman people his heir.
tgt_text.7418: Thus Asia was added to the Roman empire by will.
tgt_text.7420: Shortly after, also, Decimus Junius Brutus triumphed with great glory over the Gallæcians aud Lusitanians;
tgt_text.7421: and Publius Scipio Africanus had a second triumph over the Nu­ mantines, in the fourteenth year after his first triumph for his exploits in Africa.
tgt_text.7423: A war in the meantime was kindled in Asia by Aris­ tonicus, the son of Eumenes by a concubine :
tgt_text.7424: this Eumenes was the brother of Attalus.
tgt_text.7425: Against him was sent out Publius Licinius Crassus, who had ample assistance from several kings, for not only Nicomedes, the king of Bithynia, supported the Romans, but also Mithridates king of Pontus, with whom they had afterwards a very great war, as well as Ariarathes, king of Cappadocia, and Pylæmenes of Paphlagonia.
tgt_text.7426: Crassus not­ withstanding was defeated, and killed in battle;
tgt_text.7427: his head was carried to Aristonicus, and his body buried at Smyrna.
tgt_text.7428: Soon after Perperna, the Roman consul, who was appointed suc­ cessor to Crassus, hearing of the event of the war, hastened to Asia;
tgt_text.7429: and defeating Aristonicus in battle, near the city Strato­ nice to which he had fled, reduced him by famine to surrender.
tgt_text.7430: Aristonicus, by command of the senate, was strangled in prison at Rome ;
tgt_text.7431: for a triumph could not be celebrated on his account, because Perperna had died at Pergamus on his return.
tgt_text.7433: In the consulate of Lucius Cæcilius Metellus and Titus Quintius Flamininus, Carthage in Africa, which still exists, was rebuilt by order of the senate, two and twenty years after it had been destroyed by Scipio.
tgt_text.7434: A colony of Roman citizens was sent out thither.
tgt_text.7436: In the six hundred and twenty-seventh year from the founding of the city, Caius Cassius Longinus and Sextus Domitius Calvinus, the consuls, made war upon the Trans alpine Gauls, and the city of the Arverni, at that time very distinguished, and their king, Bituitus;
tgt_text.7437: and slew a vast number of men near the river Rhone.
tgt_text.7438: A great booty, consist­ ing of the golden collars of the Gauls, was brought to Rome.
tgt_text.7439: Bituitus surrendered himself to Domitius, and was conveyed by him to Rome;
tgt_text.7440: and both consuls triumphed with great glory.
tgt_text.7442: In the consulship of Marcus Porcius Cato and Quintus Marcius Rex, in the six hundred and thirty-third year from the building of the city, a colony was led out to Narbonne in Gaul.
tgt_text.7443: Afterwards a triumph was obtained over Dalmatia by the consuls Lucius Metellus and Quintus Mucius Scævola.
tgt_text.7445: In the six hundred and thirty-fifth year from the building of the city, the consul Caius Cato made war upon the Sc ordisci, and fought with them to his dishonour.
tgt_text.7447: When emus Cæcilius Metellus and Cnæus Carbn were consuls, the Metelli, two brothers, had triumphs on the same day, one for Sardinia, the other for Thrace;
tgt_text.7448: and news was brought to Rome, that the Cimbri had crossed from Gaul into Italy.
tgt_text.7450: In the consulship of Publius Scipio Nasica and Lucius Calpurnius Bestia, war was made upon Jugurtha, king of Numidia, because he had murdered Adherbal and Riempsal, the sons of Micipsa, his cousins, princes, and allies of the Roman people.
tgt_text.7451: The consul Calpurnius Bestia being sent against him, was corrupted by the king's money, and con­ cluded a most ignominious treaty of peace with him, which was afterwards repudiated by the senate.
tgt_text.7452: Spurius Albinus Postumius proceeded against him in the following year:
tgt_text.7453: he also, through the agency of his brother, fought against the Numidians to his disgrace.
tgt_text.7455: In the third place, the consul Quintus Cæcilius Metellas being sent out against him, brought back the army, which he reformed with great severity and judgment, without exercising cruelty on any one, to the ancient Roman discipline.
tgt_text.7456: He defeated Jugurtha in various battles, killed or captured his elephants, and obliged many of his towns to surrender ;
tgt_text.7457: and, when on the point of putting an end to the war, was succeeded by Caius Marius.
tgt_text.7458: Marius overthrew both Jugurtha and Boc­ chus, the king of Mauritania, who had undertaken to afford assistance to Jugurtha;
tgt_text.7459: he also took several towns in Numidia, and put an end to the war, having, through the instrumentality of his quæstor Cornelius Sylla, a distinguished man, taken Jugurtha prisoner, whom Bocchus, who had before fought for him, betrayed.
tgt_text.7460: In Gaul, the Cimbri were defeated by Marcus Junius Silanus, the colleague of Quintus Metellus, the Scordisci and Triballi in Macedonia by Minutius Rufus, and the Lusitani in Spain by Servilius Cæpio;
tgt_text.7461: and two triumphs were celebrated on account of Jugurtha, the first by Metellus, the second by Marius.
tgt_text.7462: It was before the chariot of Marius, however, that Jugurtha, with his two sons, was led in chains;
tgt_text.7463: and he was soon after, by order of the consul, strangled in prison.
tgt_text.7464: The war with the Cimbri, Teutones, and their allies, L II.
tgt_text.7466: —The Civil war between Marius and Sylla, IV.
tgt_text.7469: continuation and conclusion of the Civil war, V.—IX.I. WHILE the war was going on in Numidia against Jugurtha, the Roman consuls, Marcus Manlius and Quintus Cæpio, were defeated by the Cimbri, Teutones, Tigurini, and Ambroues, nations of Germany and Gaul, near the river Rhone;
tgt_text.7470: and, being reduced by a terrible slaughter, lost their very camp, as well as the greater part of their army.
tgt_text.7471: Great was the con­ sternation at Rome, such as was scarcely experienced during the Punic wars in the time of Hannibal, from dread that the Gauls might again march to the city.
tgt_text.7472: Marius, in consequence, after his victory over Jugurtha, was created consul the second time, and the war against the Cimbri and Teutones was com­ mitted to his management.
tgt_text.7473: The consulship was also conferred on him a third and fourth time, in consequence of the war with the Cimori being protracted;
tgt_text.7474: but in his fourth consul­ ship he had for his colleague Quintus Lutatius Catulus.
tgt_text.7475: He came to battle, accordingly,* with the Cimbri, and in two engagements killed two hundred thousand of the enemy, and took eighty thousand prisoners, with their general Teutobo­ dus ;
tgt_text.7476: for which service he was elected consul a fifth time during his absence.
tgt_text.7478: In the meantime the Cimbri and Teutones, whose force was still innumerable, passed over into Italy.
tgt_text.7479: Another battle was fought with them, by Caius Marius and Quintus Catulus, though with greater success on the part of Catulus, for in that battle, in which they both commanded, a hundred and forty thousand were either slain in the field or in the pur­ suit, and sixty thousand taken prisoners.
tgt_text.7480: Of the Roman soldiers in the two armies three hundred fell.
tgt_text.7481: Thirty-three standards were taken from the Cimbri;
tgt_text.7482: of which the army of Marius captured two, that of Catulus thirty-one.
tgt_text.7483: This was the end of the war:
tgt_text.7484: a triumph was decreed to both the consuls.
tgt_text.7486: In the consulship of Sextus Julius Cæsar and Lucius Marcius Pbilippus, in the six hundred and fifty-ninth year from the building of the city, when almost all other wars were at an end, the Piceni, Marsi, and Peligni, excited a most dangerous war in Italy;
tgt_text.7487: for after they had lived for many years in subjection to the Roman people, they now began to assert their claim to equal privileges.
tgt_text.7488: This was a very de­ structive war.
tgt_text.7489: Publius Rutilius, one of the consuls, Cæpio, a nobleman in the flower of his age, and Porcius Cato, another consul, were killed in it.
tgt_text.7490: The generals against the Romans on the part of the Piceni and Marsi were Titus Vettius, Hierius Asinius, Titus Herennius, and Aulus Cluentius.
tgt_text.7491: The Romans fought against them successfully under the con­ duct of Caius Marius, who had now been made consul for the sixth time, also under Cnaeus Pompey, but particularly under Lucius Cornelius Sylla, who, among other signal exploits.
tgt_text.7492: so completely routed Cluentius, one of the enemy's generals, with his numerous forces, that he lost only one man of his own army.
tgt_text.7493: The war, however, was protracted for four years, with great havoc;
tgt_text.7494: at length, in the fifth, it was terminated by Lucius Cornelius Sylla when consul, who had greatly dis­ tinguished himself on many occasions when prætor in the same war.
tgt_text.7496: In the six hundred and sixty second year from the foundation of the city, the first civil war began at Rome ;
tgt_text.7497: and in the same year also the Mithridatic war.
tgt_text.7498: Marius, when in his sixth consulship, gave rise to the Civil war;
tgt_text.7499: for when Sylla, the consul, was sent to conduct the war against Mithri­ dates, who had possessed himself of Asia and Achaia, and delayed his army for a short time in Campania, in order that the remains of the Social war, of which we have just spoken, and which had been carried on within the limits of Italy, might be extinguished, Marius showed himself ambitious to be appointed to the Mithridatic war.
tgt_text.7500: Sylla, being incensed at this conduct, marched to Rome with his army.
tgt_text.7501: There he fought with Marius and Sulpicius;
tgt_text.7502: he was the first to enter the city in arms;
tgt_text.7505: and then, having appointed Cnæus Octavius and Lucius Cor­ nelius Cinna the consuls for the year ensuing, set out for Asia.V. For Mithridates, who was king of Pontus, and possessed Armenia Minor and the entire circuit of the Pontic sea with the Bosphorus, first attempted to expel Nicomedes, an ally of the Romans, from Bithynia;
tgt_text.7506: sending word to the senate, that he was going to make war upon him on account of the injuries which he had received.
tgt_text.7507: Answer was returned by the senate to Mithridates, that if he did so he himself should feel the weight of a war from the Romans.
tgt_text.7508: Incensed at this reply, he immediately invaded Cappadocia, and expelled from thence Ariobarzanes the king, an ally of the Roman people.
tgt_text.7509: He next marched into Bithynia and Paphlagonia, driving out the kings, Pylæmenes and Nicomedes, who were also in alliance with the Romans.
tgt_text.7510: He then hastened to Ephesus, and sent letters into all parts of Asia, with directions that wherever any Roman citizens should be found, they should all be put to death the same day.
tgt_text.7512: In the meantime Athens also, a city of Achaia, was delivered up to Mithridates by Aristion an Athenian.
tgt_text.7513: For Mithridates had previously sent Archelaus, his general, into Achaia, with a hundred and twenty thousand horse and foot, by whom the rest of Greece was also occupied.
tgt_text.7514: Sylla besieged Archelaus at the Piræeus near Athens, and took the city itself.
tgt_text.7515: Engaging afterwards in battle with Archelaus, he gave him such a defeat, that out of a hundred and twenty thousand of the army of Archelaus scarce ten remained;
tgt_text.7516: while of that of Sylla only fourteen were killed.
tgt_text.7517: Mithridates, on receiving intelligence of this battle, sent seventy thousand chosen troops out of Asia to Archelaus, with whom Sylla came again to an engagement.
tgt_text.7518: In the first battle twenty thousand of the enemy were slain, and Diogenes, the son of Archelaus ;
tgt_text.7519: in the second the entire forces of Mithridates were cut off.

tgt_text.7534: But on a change of consuls at Rome, and the election of Marius, the son of Marius, and Papirius Carbo to the con­ sulate, Sylla again came to battle with Marius the younger, and killed fifteen thousand men, with the loss of only four hundred.

tgt_text.7590: In the six hundred and seventy-sixth year from the building of the city, in the consulate of Lucius Licinius Lucullus and Marcus Aurelius Cotta, Nicomedes, king of Bithynia, died, appointing by his will the Roman people his heir.
tgt_text.7591: Mithridates, breaking the peace, again proceeded to invade Bithynia and Asia.
tgt_text.7592: Both the consuls being sent out against him, met with various success.
tgt_text.7593: Cotta, being defeated by him in a battle near Chalcedon, was even forced into the town, and ieged there.
tgt_text.7594: But Mithridates, having marched from thence to Cyzicus, that, after capturing that city, he might overrun all Asia, Lucullus, the other consul, met him ;
tgt_text.7595: and, whilst Mithri­ dates was detained at the siege of Cyzicus, besieged him in the real, exhausted him with famine, defeated him in several battles, and at last pursued him to Byzantium, now called Constantinople.
tgt_text.7596: Lucullus also vanquished his commanders in a sea-fight.
tgt_text.7597: Thus, in a single winter and summer, almost a hundred thousand men on the king's side were cut off by Lucullus.
tgt_text.7599: In the six hundred and seventy-eighth year of Rome, Marcus Licinius Lucullus, the cousin of that Lucullus who had carried on the war against Mithridates, obtained the province of Macedonia.
tgt_text.7600: A new war, too, suddenly sprung up in Italy;
tgt_text.7601: for eighty-four gladiators, led by Spartacus.

tgt_text.7603: and, wandering over Italy, kindled a war in it, not much less serious than that which Hannibal had raised;
tgt_text.7604: for, after defeating several generals and two consuls of the Romans, they collected an army of nearly sixty thousand men.
tgt_text.7605: They were, however, defeated in Apulia by the proconsul Marcus Licinius Crassus;
tgt_text.7606: and, after much calamity to Italy, the war was terminated in its third year.
tgt_text.7608: In the six hundred and eighty-first year from the founding of the city, in the consulate of Publius Cornelius Lentulus and Cnæus Aufidius Orestes, there were but two wars of any importance throughout the Roman empire, the Mithridatic and the Macedonian.
tgt_text.7609: Of these the two Luculli, Lucius and Marcus, had the direction.
tgt_text.7610: Lucius Lucullus, after the battle at Cyzicus, in which he had conquered Mithridates, and the sea-fight, in which he had overcome his generals, pursued him;
tgt_text.7611: and, recovering Paphlagonia and Bithynia, invaded his very kingdom.
tgt_text.7612: He took Sinope and Amisus, two most eminent cities of Pontus.
tgt_text.7613: In a second battle, near the city Cabira, where Mithridates had assembled a vast army from all parts of his kingdom, thirty thousand of the king's chosen troops were cut in pieces by five thousand of the Romans, and Mithridates was put to flight and his camp plundered.
tgt_text.7614: Armenia Minor, also, of which he had taken possession, was wrested from him.
tgt_text.7615: Mithridates was, however, received after his flight by Tigranes, the king of Armenia, who at that time reigned in great glory;
tgt_text.7616: for he had frequently defeated the Persians, and had made himself master of Meso­ potamia, Syria, and part of Phoenicia.
tgt_text.7617: IX Lucullus, therefore, still pursuing his routed enemy, entered even the kingdom of Tigranes, who ruled over both the Armenias.
tgt_text.7618: Tigranocerta, the most noble city of Armenia, he succeeded in taking;
tgt_text.7619: the king himself, who advanced against him with six hundred thousand cuirassiers, and a hun­ dred thousand archers and other troops, he so completely defeated with a force of only eighteen thousand, that he anni­ hilated a great part of the Armenians.
tgt_text.7620: Marching from thence to Nisibis, he took that city also, and made the king's brother prisoner.
tgt_text.7621: But as those whom Lucullus had left in Pontus with part of the army in order to defend the conquered countries belonging to the Romans, grew negligent and avaricious in their conduct, they gave Mithridates an oppor­ tunity of again making an irruption into Pontus, and thus the war was renewed.
tgt_text.7622: While Lucullus, after the reduction of Nisibis, was preparing for an expedition against the Persians, a successor was sent out to take his place.X.
tgt_text.7623: The other Lucullus, who had the management of affairs in Macedonia, was the first of the Romans that made war upon the Bessi, defeating them in a great battle on Mount Hæmus;
tgt_text.7624: he reduced the town of Uscudama, which the Bessi inhabited, on the same day in which he attacked it;
tgt_text.7625: he also took Cabyle, and penetrated as far as the river Danube.
tgt_text.7626: He then besieged several cities lying above Pontus, where he destroyed Apol­ lonia, Calatis, Parthenopolis, Tomi, Bistros, and Burziaone,* and, putting an end to the war, returned to Rome.
tgt_text.7627: Both the Luculli however triumphed, but the Lucullus, who had fought against Mithridates, with the greater glory, because he had returned victorious over such powerful nations.
tgt_text.7629: After the Macedonian war was ended, but while that with Mithridates still continued (which, on the departure of Lucullus, that king had renewed, collecting all his forces for the purpose),.
tgt_text.7630: the Cretan war arose, and Cæcilius Metellus being sent to conduct it, secured the whole province, by a suc­ cession of great battles, within three years, and received the appellation of Creticus, and a triumph on account of the island.
tgt_text.7631: About this time Libya also, by the will of Apion, the king of the country, was added to the Roman empire;
tgt_text.7632: in it were the celebrated cities, Berenice, Ptolemais, and Cyreno.XII.
tgt_text.7633: During these transactions, pirates infested all the seas, so that navigation, and that alone, was unsafe to the Romans, who were now victorious throughout the world.
tgt_text.7634: The war against these pirates, therefore, was committed to Cnæus Pompey, who, with surprising success and celerity, finished it in the course of a few months.
tgt_text.7635: Soon after, the war against Mithridates and Tigranes was entrusted to him;
tgt_text.7636: in the con­ duct of which, he overcame Mithridates in Armenia Minor in a battle by night, and plundered his camp, killing at the same time forty thousand of his troops, while he lost only twenty of his own men, and two centurions.
tgt_text.7637: Mithridates fled with his wife and two attendants;
tgt_text.7638: and not long after, in consequence of his cruelty to his own family, he was reduced, through a sedition excited among his soldiers by his son Pharnaces, to the necessity of putting an end to his existence, and swallowed poison.
tgt_text.7639: Such was the end of Mithridates, a man of singular energy and ability;
tgt_text.7640: his death happened near the Bosporus.
tgt_text.7641: He reigned sixty years, lived seventy-two, and maintained a war against the Romans for forty.
tgt_text.7643: Pompey next made war upon Tigranes, who sur­ rendered himself, coming to Pompey's camp at sixteen miles distance from Artaxata;
tgt_text.7644: and, throwing himself at his feet, placed in his hands his diadem, which Pompey returned to him, and treated him with great respect, but obliged him to give up part of his dominions and to pay a large sum of money:
tgt_text.7645: Syria, Phœnicia, and Sophene, were taken from him, and six thousand talents of silver, which he had to pay to the Roman people because he had raised a war against them without cause.
tgt_text.7647: Pompey soon after made war also upon the Albani;
tgt_text.7648: * and defeated their king Orodes three times;

tgt_text.7660: After these achievements, he returned into Asia, and put an end to this most tedious war.
tgt_text.7662: In the consulate of Marcus Tullius Cicero, the orator, and Caius Antonius, in the six hundred and eighty-ninth year from the foundation of the city, Lucius Sergius Catiline, a man of very noble family, but of a most corrupt disposition, conspired to destroy his country, in conjunction with some other eminent but desperate characters.
tgt_text.7663: He was expelled from the city by Cicero;

tgt_text.7665: and he himself was defeated and killed in battle by Antonius, the other consul.

tgt_text.7673: In the six hundred and ninety-third year from the founding of the city, Caius Julius Cæsar, who was afterwards emperor, was made consul with Lucius Bibulus;
tgt_text.7674: and Gaul and Illyricum, with ten legions, were decreed to him.
tgt_text.7675: He first subdued the Helvetii, who are now called Sequani ;
tgt_text.7676: * and afterwards, by conquering in most formidable wars, pro ceeded as far as the British ocean.
tgt_text.7677: In about nine years he subdued all that part of Gaul which lies between the Alps, the river Rhone, the Rhine, and the Ocean, and extends in circumference nearly three thousand two hundred miles.
tgt_text.7678: He next made war upon the Britons, to whom not even the name of the Romans was known before his time;
tgt_text.7679: and having subdued them, and received hostages, sentenced them to pay a tribute.
tgt_text.7680: On Gaul, under the name of tribute, he imposed the yearly sum of forty thousand sestertia;
tgt_text.7681: * and invading the Germans on the other side of the Rhine, defeated them in several most sanguinary engagements.
tgt_text.7682: Among so many successes, he met with three defeats, once in person among the Arverni, and twice in Germany during his absence;
tgt_text.7683: for two of his lieu­ tenant generals, Titurius and Aurunculeius, were cut off by ambuscades.
tgt_text.7685: About the same time, in the six hundred and ninety-seventh year from the foundation of the city, Marcus Licinius Crassus, the colleague of Cnaeus Pompey the Great in his second consulship, was sent against the Parthians;
tgt_text.7686: and having engaged the enemy near Carræ, contrary to the omens and auspices, was defeated by Surena, the general of king Orodes, and at last killed, together with his son, a most noble and excellent young man.
tgt_text.7687: The remains of the army were saved by Caius Cassius the quæstor, who, with singular courage, so ably retrieved the ruined fortune of the Romans, that, in his retreat over the Euphrates, he defeated the Persians in several battles.
tgt_text.7689: Soon after followed the Civil war, a war truly exe­ crable and deplorable, in which, besides the havoc that occurred in the several battles, the fortune of the Roman people was changed.!
tgt_text.7690: For Cæsar, on returning victorious from Gaul, pro­ ceeded to demand another consulship, and in such a manner, that it was granted him without hesitation;
tgt_text.7691: yet opposition was made to it by Marcellus the consul, Bibulus, Pompey, and Cato, and he was in consequence ordered to disband his army and return to Rome;
tgt_text.7692: in revenge for which insult, he marched with his army from Ariminum, where he kept his forces assembled, against his country.
tgt_text.7693: The consuls, together with Pompey, the whole senate, and all the nobility, fled from the city, and crossed over into Greece;
tgt_text.7694: and in Epirus, Macedonia, and Achaia, the senate, under Pompey as their general, pre­ pared war against Cæsar.XX.
tgt_text.7695: Cæsar, having marched into the deserted city, made himself dictator.
tgt_text.7696: Soon after he set out for Spain, where he defeated the armies of Pompey, which were very powerful and brave, with their three generals, Lucius Afranius, Marcus Petreius, and Marcus Varro.
tgt_text.7697: Returning from thence, he went over into Greece.
tgt_text.7698: He took the field against Pompey, but in the first battle was defeated and put to flight;
tgt_text.7699: he escaped, however, because Pompey declined to pursue him, as the night was coming on;
tgt_text.7700: when Cæsar remarked, that Pompey knew not how to conquer, and that that was the only day on which he himself might have been vanquished.
tgt_text.7701: They next fought at Palaeopharsalus,* in Thessaly, leading great forces into the field on both sides.
tgt_text.7702: The army of Pompey consisted of forty thousand foot, six hundred horse on the left wing, and five hundred on the right, besides auxiliary troops from the whole east, and all the nobility, senators without number, men of praetorian and consular rank, and some who had already been conquerors of powerful nations.
tgt_text.7703: Cæsar had not quite thirty thousand infantry in his army, and but one thousand horse.
tgt_text.7705: Never before had a greater number of Roman forces assembled in one place, or under better generals, forces which would easily have subdued the whole world, had they been led against barbarians.
tgt_text.7706: They fought with great eagerness, but Pompey was at last overcome, and his camp plundered.
tgt_text.7707: Pompey himself, when put to flight, sought refuge at Alex­ andria, with the hope of receiving aid from the king of Egypt, to whom, on account of his youth, he had been appointed guardian by the senate;
tgt_text.7708: he, however, regarding fortune rather than friendship, caused Pompey to be killed, and sent his head and ring to Cæsar;
tgt_text.7709: at sight of which even Cæsar is said to have shed tears, as he viewed the head of so great a mail, once his own son-in law.
tgt_text.7711: Cæsar soon after went to Alexandria.
tgt_text.7712: Ptolemy attempted to form a plot against his life also;
tgt_text.7713: for which reason war was made upon him, and, being defeated, he perished in the Nile, and his body was found covered with a golden coat of mail.
tgt_text.7714: Cæsar, having made himself master of Alexandria, conferred the kingdom on Cleopatra, the sister of Ptolemy, with whom he himself had an illicit connexion.
tgt_text.7715: On his return from thence, Cæsar defeated in battle Pharnaces, the son of Mithridates the Great, who had assisted Pompey in Thessaly, taken up arms in Pontus, and seized upon several provinces of the Roman people;
tgt_text.7716: and at last drove him to self-destruc­ tion.
tgt_text.7718: Returning from thence to Rome, he created him­ self a third time consul with Marcus Æmilius Lepidus, who had been his master of the horse when dictator the year before.
tgt_text.7719: Next he went into Africa, where a great number of the nobility, in conjunction with Juba, king of Mauritania, had resumed hostilities.
tgt_text.7720: The Roman leaders were Publius Cornelius Scipio, of the most ancient family of Scipio Africanus (who had also been the father-in-law of the great Pompey) Marcus Petreius, Quintus Varus, Marcus Porcius Cato, and Lucius Cornelius Faustus, the son of Sylla the dictator.
tgt_text.7721: In a pitched battle fought against them, Cæsar, after many struggles, was victorious.
tgt_text.7722: Cato, Scipio, Petreius, Juba, killed themselves ;
tgt_text.7723: Faustus, Pom­ pey's son-in-law, was slain by Cæsar.
tgt_text.7725: On his return to Rome the year after, Cæsar made himself a fourth time consul, and immediately proceeded to Spain, where the sons of Pompey, Cnæus, and Sextus, had again raised a formidable war.
tgt_text.7726: Many engagements took place, the last near the city of Munda, in which Cæsar was so nearly defeated, that, upon his forces giving way, he felt inclined to kill himself, lest, after such great glory in war, he should fall, at the age of fifty-six, into the hands of young men.
tgt_text.7727: At length, having rallied his troops, he gained the victory;
tgt_text.7728: the elder son of Pompey was slain, the younger fled.
tgt_text.7730: The civil wars throughout the world being now terminated, Cæsar returned to Rome, and began to conduct himself with too great arrogance, contrary to the usages of Roman liberty.
tgt_text.7731: As he disposed, therefore, at his own pleasure, of those honours, which were before conferred by the people, and did not even rise up when the senate approached him, and exercised regal or almost tyrannical power, in other respects, a conspiracy was formed against him by sixty or more Roman senators and knights.
tgt_text.7732: The chief among the conspirators were the two Bruti, (of the family of that Brutus who had been made first consul of Rome, and who had expelled the kings) Caius Cassius, and Servilius Casca.

tgt_text.7751: AFTER the assassination of Cæsar, in about the seven hundred and ninth year of the city, the civil wars were re­ newed ;
tgt_text.7752: for the senate favoured the assassins of Caesar ;

tgt_text.7797: Having thus brought wars to an end throughout the world, OCTAVIANUS AUGUSTUS returned to Rome in the twelfth year after he had been elected consul.

tgt_text.7802: During the forty-four years that he held the government alone, he conducted himself with the greatest courtesy, being most liberal to all, and most faithful to his friends, whom he raised to such honours, that he placed them almost on a level with his own dignity.
