tgt_text.8256: He also suppressed, in several battles, some persons that attempted to seize the throne, as Saturninus in the east, and Proculus and Bonosus at Agrippina.
tgt_text.8257: He allowed the Gauls and Cannonians to have vineyards.
tgt_text.8258: By obliging his soldiers to work, too, he planted vineyards on Mount Alma in Sirmium, and on Mount Aureus in Upper Mcesia, and left them to the people of the provinces to cultivate.
tgt_text.8259: After he had gone through a great number of wars, and had at last obtained peace, he observed, that " in a short time soldiers would not be wanted."
tgt_text.8260: He was a man of spirit, activity, and justice, equalling Aurelian in military glory, and surpassing him in affability of manners.
tgt_text.8261: He was killed, however, at Sirmium, in an iron turret, during an insurrection of the soldiery.
tgt_text.8262: He reigned six years and four months.
tgt_text.8264: After the death of Probus, CARUS was created emperor, a native of Narbo in Gaul, who immediately made his sons, Carinus and Numerianus, Cæsars, and reigned, in conjunction with them, two years.
tgt_text.8265: News being brought, while he was engaged in a war with the Sarmatians, of an insurrec­ tion among the Persians, he set out for the east, and achieved some noble exploits against that people ;
tgt_text.8266: he routed them in the field, and took Seleucia and Ctesiphon, their noblest cities, but, while he was encamped on the Tigris, he was killed by lightning.
tgt_text.8267: His son NUMERIANUS, too, whom he had taken with him to Persia, a young man of very great ability, while, from being affected with a disease in his eyes, he was carried in a litter, was cut off by a plot of which Aper, his father-in-law, was the promoter;
tgt_text.8268: and his death, though attempted craftily to be concealed until Aper coald seize the throne, was made known by the oduur of his dead body;
tgt_text.8269: for the soldiers, who attended liim, being struck by the smell, and opening the curtains of his litter, discovered his death some days after it had taken place.
tgt_text.8271: In the meantime CARINUS, whom Cams, when he set out to the war with Parthia, had left, with the authority of Cæsar, to command in Illyricum, Gaul, and Italy, disgraced himself by all manner of crimes;
tgt_text.8272: he put to death many inno­ cent persons on false accusations, formed illicit connexions with the wives of noblemen, and wrought the ruin of several of his school-fellows, who happened to have offended him at school by some slight provocation.
tgt_text.8273: Incurring the hatred of all men by such proceedings, he not long after met with deserved punishment.
tgt_text.8274: The victorious army, on returning from Persia, as they had lost their emperor Carus by lightning, and the Cæsar Numeri­ anus by a plot, conferred the imperial dignity on DIOCLETIAN, a native of Dalmatia, of such extremely obscure birth, that he is said by most writers to have been the son of a clerk, but by some to have been a freed man of a senator named Anulinus.
tgt_text.8275: XX, Diocletian, in the first assembly of the army that was held, took an oath that Numerian was not killed by any treachery on his part;
tgt_text.8276: and while Aper, who had laid the plot for Nume­ rian's life, was standing by, he was killed, in the sight of the army, with a sword by the hand of Diocletian.
tgt_text.8277: He soon after overthrew Carinus, who was living under the utmost hatred and detestation, in a great battle at Margum,* Carinus being betrayed by his own troops, for though he had a greater num­ ber of men than the enemy, he was altogether abandoned by them between Viminacium and mount Aureus.
tgt_text.8278: He thus became master of the Roman empire;
tgt_text.8279: and when the peasants in Gaul made an insurrection, giving their faction the name of Bagaudæ,† and having for leaders Amandus and Ælianus, he despatched Maximian Herculius, with the authority of Caesar, to suppress them.
tgt_text.8280: Maximian, in a few battles of little importance, subdued the rustic multitude, and restored peace to Gaul.
tgt_text.8281: XXI, During this period, Carausius, who, though of very mean birth, had gained extraordinary reputation by a course of active service in war, having received a commission in his post at Bononia, to clear the sea, which the Franks and Saxons infested, along the coast of Belgica and Armorica, and having captured numbers of the barbarians on several occasions, but having never given back the entire booty to the people of the province or sent it to the emperors, and there being a suspi­ cion, in consequence, that the barbarians were intentionally allowed by him to congregate there, that he might seize them and their booty as they passed, and by that means enrich him­ self, assumed, on being sentenced by Maximian to be put to death, the imperial purple, and took on him the government of Britain.
tgt_text.8283: While disorder thus prevailed throughout the world, while Carausius was taking arms in Britain and Achilleus in Egypt, while the Quinquegentiani * were harassing Africa, and Narseust was making war upon the east, Diocletian pro­ moted MAXIMIAN HERCULIUS from the dignity of Cæsar to that of emperor, and created Constantius and Maximian Galerius Cæsars, of whom Constantius is said to have been the grand-nephew of Claudius ‡ by a daughter, and Maximian Galerius to have been born in Dacia not far from Sardica.§
tgt_text.8284: That he might also unite them by affinity, Constantius married Theodora the step-daughter of Herculius, by whom he had afterwards six children, brothers to Constantine ;
tgt_text.8285: while Gale­ rius married Valeria, the daughter of Diocletian;
tgt_text.8286: both being obliged to divorce the wives that they had before.
tgt_text.8287: With Carausius, however, as hostilities were found vain against a man eminently skilled in war, a peace was at last arranged.
tgt_text.8288: At the end of seven years, Allectus, one of his supporters, put him to death, and held Britain himself for three years subse­ quently, but was cut off by the efforts of Asclepiodotus, præfect of the praetorian guard.
tgt_text.8290: At the same period a battle was fought by Con­ stantius Caesar in Gaul, at Lingonæ,* where he experienced both good and bad fortune in one day;
tgt_text.8291: for though he was driven into the city by a sudden onset of the barbarians, with such baste and precipitation that after the gates were shut he was drawn up the wall by ropes, yet, when his army came up, after the lapse of scarcely six hours, he cut to pieces about sixty thousand of the Alemanni.
tgt_text.8292: Maximian the emperor, too, brought the war to an end in Africa, by subduing the Quinquegentiani, and compelling them to make peace.
tgt_text.8293: Diocletian, meanwhile, besieging Achilleus in Alexandria, obliged him to surrender about eight months after, and put him to death.
tgt_text.8294: He used his victory, indeed, cruelly, and distressed all Egypt with severe proscriptions and massacres.
tgt_text.8295: Yet at the same time he made many judicious arrangements and regulations, which continue to our own days.
tgt_text.8297: Galerius Maximian, in acting against Narseus, fought, on the first occasion, a battle far from successful, meeting him between Callinicus and Carræ, and engaging in the combat rather with rashness than want of courage;
tgt_text.8298: for he contended with a small army against a very numerous enemy.
tgt_text.8299: Being in consequence defeated, and going to join Diocletian, be was received by him, when he met him on the road, with such extreme haughtiness, that he is said to have run by his chariot for several miles in his scarlet robes.
tgt_text.8301: But having soon after collected forces in Illyricum and Mœsia, he fought a second time with Narseus (the grand­ father of Hormisdas and Sapor), in Greater Armenia, with extraordinary success, and with no less caution and spirit, for he undertook, with one or two of the cavalry, the office of a speculator.†
tgt_text.8302: After putting Narseus to flight, he captured his wives, sisters, and children, with a vast number of the Persian nobility besides, and a great quantity of treasure;
tgt_text.8303: the king himself he forced to take refuge in the remotest deserts in his dominions.
tgt_text.8304: Returning therefore in triumph to Diocletian, who was then encamped with some troops in Mesopotamia, he was welcomed by him with great honour.
tgt_text.8305: Subsequently, they conducted several wars both in conjunction and separately, subduing the Carpi and Bastarnæ, and defeating the Sarmatians, from which nations he settled a great number of captives in the Roman territories.
tgt_text.8307: Diocletian was of a crafty disposition, with much sagacity, and keen penetration.
tgt_text.8308: He was willing to gratify his own disposition to cruelty in such a way as to throw the odium upon others;
tgt_text.8309: he was however a very active and able prince.
tgt_text.8310: He was the first that introduced into the Roman empire a ceremony suited rather to royal usages than to Roman liberty, giving orders that he should be adored,* whereas all emperors before him were only saluted.
tgt_text.8311: He put ornaments of precious stones on his dress and shoes, when the imperial distinction had previously been only in the purple robe, the rest of the habit being the same as that of other men.
tgt_text.8313: But Herculius was undisguisedly cruel, and of a violent temper, and showed his severity of disposition in the sternness of his looks.
tgt_text.8314: Gratifying his own inclination, he joined with Diocletian in even the most cruel of his proceed­ ings.
tgt_text.8315: But when Diocletian, as age bore heavily upon him, felt himself unable to sustain the government of the empire, he suggested to Herculius that they should both retire into private life, and commit the duty of upholding the state to more vigorous and youthful hands.
tgt_text.8316: With this suggestion his colleague reluctantly complied.
tgt_text.8317: Both of them, in the same day, exchanged the robe of empire for an ordinary dress, Diocletian at Nicomedia, Herculius at Milan, soon after a magnificent triumph which they celebrated at Rome over several nations, with a noble succession of pictures,!
tgt_text.8318: and in which the wives, sisters, and children of Narseus were led before their chariots.
tgt_text.8319: The one then retired to Salonæ, and the other into Lucania.
tgt_text.8321: Diocletian lived to an old age in a private station, at a villa which is not far from Salonæ, in honourable retirement, exercising extraordinary philosophy, inasmuch as he alone of all men, since the foundation of the Roman empire, voluntarily returned from so high a dignity to the condition of private life, and to an equality with the other citizens.
tgt_text.8322: That happened to him, therefore, which had happened to no one since men were created, that, though he died in a private condition, he was enrolled among the gods.
tgt_text.8323: Division of the empire between Constantius and Galerius, Maximin and Severus being Caesars, I.—Constantine made emperor in Britain, and Maxentius, son of Maximian, at Rome;
tgt_text.8324: Maximian attempts to regain the throne;
tgt_text.8325: failure of Severus against Max­ entius, II.
tgt_text.8328: —Four emperors at once, Constantine, Maxentius, Licinius, and Maximin;
tgt_text.8331: —Licinius defeated by Constantine, who becomes sole emperor, and makes three Cæsars, V. VI.—Character and death of Constantine, VII.
tgt_text.8333: —He is succeeded by three sons and a nephew, Constantine, Constantius, Constans, and Dal­ matius;
tgt_text.8334: Constantius survives them all, and becomes sole emperor, suppressing Veteranio and Nepotian, IX.-XI.
tgt_text.8338: —Julian sent to Gaul by Constantius with the authority of Cæsar ;
tgt_text.8341: death and character of Constantius, XV.—Julian's expedition to the east;
tgt_text.8345: he cedes a portion of the Roman territory to Sapor;
tgt_text.8346: his death, and the supposed causes of it, XVII.
tgt_text.8347: XVIII.I. THESE emperors, then, having retired from the govern­ ment of the state, CONSTANTIUS and GALERIUS were made emperors;
tgt_text.8348: and the Roman world was divided between them in such a manner, that Constantius had Gaul, Italy, and Africa;
tgt_text.8349: Galerius Illyricum, Asia, and the East;
tgt_text.8350: two Cæsars being joined with them.
tgt_text.8351: Constantius, however, content with the dignity of emperor, declined the care of governing Africa.
tgt_text.8352: He was an excellent man, of extreme benevolence, who studied to increase the resources, of the provinces and of private persons, cared tut little for the improvement of the public treasury, and used to say that " it was better for the national wealth to be in the hands of individuals than to be laid up in one place of confinement."
tgt_text.8353: So moderate was the furniture of his house, too, that if, on holidays, he had to entertain a greater number of friends than ordinary, his dining-rooms were set out with the plate of private persons, borrowed from their several houses.
tgt_text.8354: By the Gauls* he was not only beloved but venerated, especially because, under his government, they had escaped the suspicious prudence of Diocletian, and the sanguinary rashness of Maximian.
tgt_text.8355: He died in Britain, at York, in the thirteenth year of his reign, and was enrolled among the gods.
tgt_text.8357: Galerius, a man of excellent moral character, and skil.
tgt_text.8358: ful in military affairs, finding that Italy, by Constantius's permission, was put under his government, created two Cæsars, MAXIMIN, whom he appointed over the east, and SEVERUS, to whom he committed Italy.
tgt_text.8359: He himself resided in Illyricum But after the death of Constantius, CONSTAN TINE, his son by a wife of obscure birth, was made emperor in Britain, and succeeded his father as a most desirable ruler.
tgt_text.8360: In the meantime the prætorian guards at Rome, having risen in insurrection, declared MAXENTIUS, the son of Maximian Herculius, who lived in the Villa Publica† not far from the city, emperor.
tgt_text.8361: At the news of this proceeding, Maximian, filled with hopes of regaining the imperial dignity, which he had not willingly resigned, hurried to Rome from Lucania, (which, on retiring into private life, he had chosen for his place of residence, spending his old age in a most delightful country), and stimulated Diocletian by letters to resume the authority that he had laid down, letters which Diocletian utterly disregarded.
tgt_text.8362: Severus Cæsar, being despatched to Rome by Galerius to suppress the rising of the guards and Maxentius, arrived there with his army, but, as he was laying siege to the city, was deserted through the treachery of his so diers.
tgt_text.8364: The power of Maxentius was thus increased, and his government established.
tgt_text.8365: Severus, taking to flight, was killed at Ravenna.
tgt_text.8366: Maximian Herculius, attempting afterwards, in an assembly of the army, to divest his son Maxentius of his power, met with nothing but mutiny and reproaches from the soldiery.
tgt_text.8367: He then set out for Gaul, on a planned stratagem, as if he had been driven away by his son, that he might join his son-in-law Constantine,* designing, however, if he could find an opportunity, to cut off Constàntine, who was ruling in Gaul with great approbation both of the soldiers and the people of the province, having overthrown the Franks and Alemanni with great slaughter, and captured their kings, whom, on exhibiting a magnificent show of games, he exposed to wild beasts.
tgt_text.8368: But the plot being made known by Maxi­ mian's daughter Fausta, who communicated the design to her husband, Maximian was cut off at Marseilles, whence he was preparing to sail to join his son, and died a well-deserved death ;
tgt_text.8369: for he was a man inclined to every kind of cruelty and severity, faithless, perverse, and utterly void of consideration . for others.
tgt_text.8371: At this time LICINIUS, a native of Dacia, was made emperor by Galerius, to whom he was known by old compa­ nionship, and recommended by his vigorous efforts and services in the war which he had conducted against Narseus.
tgt_text.8372: The death of Galerius followed immediately afterwards.
tgt_text.8373: The empire was then held by the four new emperors, Constantine and Maxen­ tius, sons of emperors, Licinius and Maximian, sons of undistin.
tgt_text.8375: Constantine, however, in the fifth year of his reign, commenced a civil war with Maxentius, routed his forces in several battles, and at last overthrew Maxentius himself (when he was spreading death among the nobility by every possible kind of cruelty,t) at the Milvian bridge, and made himself master of Italy.
tgt_text.8376: Not long after, too, Maximin, after commencing hostilities against Licinius in the east, anti­ cipated the destruction that was falling upon him by an accidental death at Tarsus.
tgt_text.8377: V. CONSTANTINE, being a man of great energy, bent upon effecting whatever he had settled in his mind, and aspiring to the sovereignty of the whole world, proceeded to make war on Licinius, although he had formed a connexion with him by marriage,* for his sister Constantia was married to Licinius.
tgt_text.8378: And first of all be overthrew him, by a sudden attack, at Cibalæ in Pannonia, where he was making vast preparations for war;
tgt_text.8379: and after becoming master of Dardania, Mæsia, and Macedonia, took possession also of several other provinces.
tgt_text.8381: There were then various contests between them, and peace made and broken.
tgt_text.8382: At last Licinius, defeated in a battle at Nicomedia by sear and land, surrendered himself, and, in violation of an oath taken by Constantine, was put to death, after being divested of the purple, at Thessalonica.
tgt_text.8383: At this time the Roman empire fell under the sway of one emperor and three Cæsars, a state of things which had never existed before;
tgt_text.8384: the sons of Constantine ruling over Gaul, the east, and Italy.
tgt_text.8385: But the pride of prosperity caused Constantine greatly to depart from his former agreeable mildness of temper.
tgt_text.8386: calling first upon his own relatives, he put to death his son, an excellent man;
tgt_text.8387: his sister's son, a youth of amiable disposi­ tion ;
tgt_text.8388: soon afterwards his wife, and subsequently many of his friends.
tgt_text.8390: He was a man, who, in the beginning of his reign, might have been compared to the best princes;
tgt_text.8391: in the latter part of it, only to those of a middling character.
tgt_text.8392: Innumerable good qualities of mind and body were apparent in him;
tgt_text.8393: he was exceedingly ambitious of military glory, and had great success in his wars;
tgt_text.8394: a success, however, not more than pro­ portioned to his exertions.
tgt_text.8395: After he had terminated the Civil war, he also overthrew the Goths on various occasions, granting them at last peace, and leaving on the minds of the barbarians a strong remembrance of his kindness.
tgt_text.8396: He was attached to the arts of peace and to liberal studies, and was ambitious of honourable popularity, which he, indeed, sought by every kind of liberality and obligingness.
tgt_text.8397: Though he was slow, from suspicion, to serve some of his friends,† yet he was exceedingly generous towards others, neglecting no opportunity to add to their riches and honours.
tgt_text.8399: He enacted many laws, some good and equitable, but most of them superfluous, and some severe.
tgt_text.8400: He was the first that endeavoured to raise the city named after him * to such a height as to make it a rival to Rome.
tgt_text.8401: As he was pre­ paring for war against the Parthians, who were then disturbing Mesopotamia, he died in the Villa Publica, † at Nicomedia, in the thirty-first year of his reign, and the sixty-sixth of his age.
tgt_text.8402: His death was foretold by a star with a tail, which shone for a long time, of extraordinary size, and which the Greeks call a ϰομήτης.
tgt_text.8403: He was deservedly enrolled among the gods.
tgt_text.8405: He left for his successors three sons and one nephew, the son of his brother.
tgt_text.8406: But DALMATIUS CÆSAR, a man of happy genius, and not unlike his brother, was soon after cut off by a mutiny among the soldiers, Constantius, his cousin, sanctioning the act, rather than commanding it.
tgt_text.8407: The officers of Constans also put to death CONSTANTINE, when he was making war upon his brother, and had rashly commenced an engagement at Aquileia.
tgt_text.8408: Thus the government was left in the hands of two emperors.
tgt_text.8409: The rule of CONSTANS was for some time energetic and just, but afterwards, falling into ill­ health, and being swayed by ill-designing friends, he indulged in great vices;
tgt_text.8410: and, becoming intolerable to the people of the provinces, and unpopular with the soldiery, was killed by a party headed by Magnentius.
tgt_text.8411: He died not far from the borders of Spain, in a fortress named Helena, in the seventeenth year of his reign, and the thirtieth of his age;
tgt_text.8412: yet not till he had performed many gallant actions in the field, and had made himself feared by the army through the whole course of his life, though without exercising any extraordinary severity.
tgt_text.8414: The fortune of CONSTANTIUS was different;
tgt_text.8415: for he suf­ fered many grievous calamities at the hands of the Persians, his towns being often taken, his walled cities besieged, and his troops cut off.
tgt_text.8416: Nor had he a single successful engagement with Sapor, except that, at Singara, when victory might certainly have been his, he lost it, through the irrepressible eagerness of his men, who, contrary to the practice of war, mutinously and foolishly called for battle when the day was declining.
tgt_text.8417: After the death of Constans, when MAGNENTIUS held the government of Italy, Africa, and Gaul, Illyricum also felt some new commotions, VETRANIO being elected to the throne by a combination of the soldiery, whom they made emperor when he was very old and universally popular from the length and success of his service in the field;
tgt_text.8418: an upright man, of morality severe as that of the ancients, and of an agree­ able unassumingness of manner, but so ignorant of all polite learning, that he did not even acquire the first rudiments of literature until he was old and had become emperor.
tgt_text.8420: But the imperial authority was snatched from Vetranio by Constantius, who stirred up a civil war to avenge his brother's death;
tgt_text.8421: Vetranio being compelled, with the consent of the soldiers, and, by a new and extraordinary proceeding, to divest himself of the purple.
tgt_text.8422: There was at the same time an insurrection at Rome.
tgt_text.8423: Nepotianus, a son of Constantine's sister, endeavouring to secure the throne with the aid of a body of gladiators;
tgt_text.8424: but he met with an end such as his savage attempts merited, for he was cut off on the twenty-eighth day of his usurpation by the officers of Magnentius, and paid the penalty of his rashness.
tgt_text.8425: His head was carried through the city on a lance;
tgt_text.8426: and dreadful proscriptions and massacres of the nobility ensued.
tgt_text.8428: Not long afterwards Magnentius was overthrown in a battle at Mursa,* and nearly taken prisoner.
tgt_text.8429: Vast forces of the Roman empire were cut off in that struggle, sufficient for any foreign wars, and for procuring many triumphs, and a lasting peace.
tgt_text.8430: Soon after, GALLUS, his uncle's son, was appointed by Constantius, as Cæsar, over the east;
tgt_text.8431: and Magnentius, being defeated in several battles, put an end to his life at Lyons, in the third year and seventh month of his reign, as did also his brother at Sens, † whom he had sent as Caesar to defend Gaul.
tgt_text.8433: About this time the Caesar Gallus, after committing inany tyrannical acts, was put to death by Constantius.
tgt_text.8434: Gallus was a man naturally cruel, and too much inclined to tyranny, if he could but have reigned in his own right Silvanus also, who attempted an insurrection in Gaul, was cut off before the end of thirty days;
tgt_text.8435: and Constantius then remained sole ruler and emperor over the Roman dominions.
tgt_text.8437: He then sent into Gaul, with the authority of Cæsar, his cousin Julian, the brother of Gallus, giving him his sister in marriage, at a time when the barbarians had stormed many towns and were besieging others, when there was every where direful devastation, and when the Roman empire was tottering in evident distress.
tgt_text.8438: But by Julian, with but a moderate force, vast numbers of the Alemanni were cut off at Strasburg, a city of Gaul;
tgt_text.8439: their distinguished king was taken prisoner, and Gaul recovered.
tgt_text.8440: Many other honourable achievements, too, were afterwards performed by Julian against the barbarians, the Germans being driven beyond the Rhine, and the Roman empire extended to its former limits.
tgt_text.8442: Not long after, when the German armies were with­ drawing from the defence of Gaul, JULIAN was made emperor by the unanimous consent of the army, and, after the lapse of a year, went to take the government of Illyricum, while Con­ stantius was engaged in the war with Parthia.
tgt_text.8443: Constantius, hearing what had occurred, and returning to the civil strife, died on his march between Cilicia and Cappadocia, in the thirty-eighth year of his reign, and the forty-fifth of his age, and was deservedly enrolled among the gods.
tgt_text.8444: He was a man of a remarkably tranquil disposition, good-natured, trusting too much to his friends and courtiers, and at last too much in the power of his wives.
tgt_text.8445: He conducted himself with great mode­ ration in the commencement of his reign;
tgt_text.8446: he enriched his friends, and suffered none, whose active services he had experienced, to go unrewarded.
tgt_text.8447: He was however somewhat inclined to severity, whenever any suspicion of an attempt on the government was excited in him ;
tgt_text.8449: His fortune is more to be praised in civil than in foreign wars.
tgt_text.8451: Julian then became sole emperor, and made war, with a vast force, upon the Parthians;
tgt_text.8452: in which expedition I was also present.
tgt_text.8453: Several towns and fortresses of the Persians he induced to surrender, or took them by storm ;
tgt_text.8454: and, having laid waste Assyria, fixed his camp for some time at Ctesiphon.
tgt_text.8455: As he was returning victorious, and mingling rashly in the thick of a battle, he was killed by the hand of an enemy, on the 26th of June, in the seventh year of his reign, and the thirty-second of his age, and was enrolled among the gods.
tgt_text.8456: He was a remarkable man, and one that would have governed the empire with honour, if he had but been permitted by the fates.
tgt_text.8457: He was eminently accomplished in liberal branches of knowledge, but better read in the literature of the Greeks, so much so indeed that his Latin was by no means comparable to his Greek learning.
tgt_text.8458: He was possessed of great and ready eloquence, and of a most tenacious memory.
tgt_text.8459: In some respects he was more like a philosopher than a prince.
tgt_text.8460: Towards his friends he was liberal, yet less discriminating as to the objects of his generosity than became so great an emperor;
tgt_text.8462: there were some of them that cast a stain on his glory.
tgt_text.8463: To the people of the provinces he was most just, and remitted the taxes on them as far as was possible.
tgt_text.8464: He was indulgent towards all men ;
tgt_text.8465: he felt no great anxiety about the public treasury;
tgt_text.8466: but of glory he was a great lover, and manifested even an intemperate desire for the attainment of it.
tgt_text.8467: He was a persecutor of the Christian religion, yet so that he abstained from shedding blood.
tgt_text.8468: He was not unlike Marcus Antoninus, whom he even studied to rival.
tgt_text.8470: After him JOVIAN, who attended him in the expe­ dition as one of his body-guard, was chosen by the suffrages of the soldiers to fill the throne ;
tgt_text.8471: a man better known to the army by the fame of his father than by his own.
tgt_text.8472: As affairs were now in confusion, and the army distressed for want of provisions, Jovian, after being defeated in one or two battles by the Persians, made peace with Sapor, a peace which was necessary indeed, but ignominious, for he was obliged to contract his boundaries, a portion of the Roman dominions being ceded to the enemy;
tgt_text.8473: a disgrace which had never occurred, before his time, since the Roman empire had been founded, during a space of one thousand one hundred and eighteen years.
